webTitle: Ranieri sets sights on ageing Jonk

fields.headline: Ranieri sets sights on ageing Jonk
fields.trailText: In a move that is bound to arouse debate, Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri has attempted to sign Sheffield Wednesday's Dutch midfielder Wim Jonk.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri's efforts to strengthen his Chelsea squad took him to the basement of the First Division last night with a surprise move for Sheffield Wednesday's Dutch midfielder Wim Jonk.

The new Chelsea manager has contacted his Wednesday counterpart Paul Jewell with a view to signing Jonk on loan until the end of the season.

Ranieri is looking for a midfielder to fill the void left by Roberto di Matteo suffering a broken leg in last week's Uefa Cup defeat against the Swiss side St Gallen but his choice is bound to arouse much debate.

Jonk will be 34 next week and has been hugely disappointing during his two years at Hillsborough after signing for £2.5m from PSV Eindhoven. From having a reputation as one of Europe's finest playmakers, with 48 caps for Holland, his form has deteriorated to the point where he is no longer guaranteed a starting place at a club propping up the First Division.

Jonk has played only twice this season because of a back injury and in 70 games for Wednesday he has scored five goals. He has asked for time to consider the move but it would seem unlikely that he would turn down the chance of playing in the Premiership again.

Wednesday, meanwhile, are holding out for a fee for Gilles de Bilde after refusing to let the striker return to Belgium on a free transfer to Genk.

 Paul Bracewell yesterday took over as manager of the league's bottom club, Halifax.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Work Unlimited
fields.body:
Sara James, 42 chief executive

When I got my current job, I made contact with as many people in my organisation as I could rather than sit at my desk and wait for people to come to me. I used to pore over files because I always thought that was the best way to impress a boss, but communication is the key to success. When you're new you have the advantage of not knowing all the answers, so you can ask as many questions as you want. Colleagues and clients can forgive you if you have no solutions, so they're happy to give you answers. Also, it's flattering to people if you come to them for advice rather than tell them exactly what you are going to do. That way you can build up better working relationships.

John Hilton, 45 PR manager

I think you can be over-eager when you join a new company. Of course it's important to be keen, but it's much more important to listen and watch colleagues rather than offer opinions. I once got on the wrong side of a boss at work by harassing him with all these wonderful half-baked ideas for new projects, and I got in the way rather than helped. A new person with lots of bright ideas can be terribly wearing. My advice? Ask people what they want doing and do it. Gradually they'll respect you and listen to your suggestions.

Tim Williams, 42 company director

I think the key to starting a job well is to do your research. Find out exactly who does what and who your clients are if you're going to work for a large organisation. And make sure you know who everyone is - not just the people in your chain of command, but everyone in the company who you're working with. There is nothing less impressive than having to constantly remind a new recruit who's who in the marketing team. Also, memorise the clients' business, think about their needs and how you can add to the service your company provides. Of course, you have to do some of this at the interview stage, but bosses are always impressed when new recruits do more homework.

Katie Barnes, 23 marketing executive

I think a lot of career success comes from having a face that fits. In my last job I bluffed my way through the interview and didn't really have a clue what I was doing. But I acted as though I did, watched what my colleagues did or charmed them into helping me. I think if you are amenable and enthusiastic you can get away with most things, but you have to learn quickly. And if you're dealing with clients, charming them in the early days is more important than impressing them with your expertise. After all, they want to enjoy working with you as well as get the service they're paying for.

Julie Evans, 31 IT manager

I think the best way to hit the ground running at work is to get on the right side of the people who matter. By watching your colleagues you can suss out who's going up and who's going down. Align yourself with the movers and shakers and you can make your life easier at work. I once got on the wrong side of a colleague very early on in a new job. He went on to be my immediate boss and my manager, and was a constant thorn in my side. Be careful who you choose as friends and who you don't.

webTitle: Surge in house prices fuels interest rate fears

fields.headline: Surge in house prices fuels interest rate fears
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: British house prices last month recorded their biggest increase this year according to the Halifax, prompting fears the Bank of England may raise interest rates in response.
fields.body:
British house prices last month recorded their biggest increase this year according to the Halifax, prompting fears the Bank of England may raise interest rates in response.

The 1.6% rise during September undercut the assumption that the price boom of recent years had reached a plateau.

The Bank of England, which starts its monthly review of interest rates today, has been concerned that higher house prices encourages people to save less and spend more, fuelling a consumer boom that can quickly run out of control.

These fears were cited among others for its decision to raise rates four times between September 1999 and February this year.

But with the Nationwide Building Society releasing conflicting figures, citing a 0.4% gain last month, most analysts believe the Bank of England will overcome its concern and follow its American counterpart in keeping policy steady.

The Halifax - Britain's biggest mortgage lender - said that house prices rose by 1.6% in September to stand 9.2% higher on the year. That compares with growth of 0.5% in August, and an annual rate of 7.4%. Nationwide Building Society figures for last month show a smaller 0.4% gain in house prices.

Economists explain the discrepancy by pointing out that the Nationwide is more biased to the south of England, where prices have been under greater pressure following heady rises seen in recent years. However, the Nationwide's annual rate of house inflation at 10.2% is higher than the Halifax's estimate. In the Halifax series, the annual rate has now returned to the level seen in June, though it remains well below the 16.0% peak reached in January. September marked the third monthly rise in a row following four falls during the five months between February and June. "Overall, the latest monthly figures suggest that the housing market has stabilised following the sharp slowdown earlier in the year," the Halifax report said.

The bank said the fall in prices between February and June appeared to have been a temporary correction following a period of rapidly rising prices.

While it felt that housing demand was likely to be underpinned by a sound economic background, "the rise in September is unlikely to mark a return to rapid house price inflation".

The Halifax said the average price of a home is now a seasonally-adjusted £86,304.

fields.headline: On The Town
fields.standfirst:
On The Town
Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.trailText:
On The Town

Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.body:
On The Town was Leonard Bernstein's first Broadway show, which opened in December 1944. He called it a musical comedy; the story of three sailors on 24-hour shore leave experiencing New York for the first time and looking for love and adventure.

It was developed out of the ballet Fancy Free, which he had written earlier the same year for Jerome Robbins. Adolph Green and Betty Comden were recruited to provide the lyrics, and the show was a huge success.

Now, though, it is best known through the film version with Gene Kelly, made five years after the premiere.

But that has a very different score from the original, and for the three Festival Hall performances, with the BBC Concert Orchestra and Paul Daniel conducting, On the Town was being heard as Bernstein originally intended, complete with the strange little intermission song and the ballet sequences (which the composer later turned into a self-standing concert work) as well as the enduring numbers like New York, New York, and Lonely Town. There was no dancing at the Festival Hall. This was a semi-staging, and a very effective one, devised by Annilese Miskimmon, with lighting effects, costumes, and all the necessary exits and entrances, and Daniel made it fizz along.

The cast was an excellent one too. The three sailors, Gabey, Chip, and Ozzie, were sung and acted by Brent Barrett, Graham Bickley and Karl Dymond with exactly the right kind of boyish, gauche enthusiasm, and Barrett especially treated his two solo numbers, the most beautiful in the score, with all the refinement they deserve.

The remarkable Kim Criswell was Hildy Esterhazy, the extrovert cabbie desperate for male company. Her panache seemed effortless. But Sally Burgess as Claire de Loone, the nymphomaniac anthropologist, and Daniel Washington as her long-suffering fiancé Pitkin W Bridgework, took their numbers with equal zest, while Lilian Watson sparkled as Ivy Smith, the target of Gabey's affections.

It was just a pity that her part is small and we didn't get to see more of her. Julia Mckenzie turned in a fabulous cameo as the grotesque singing teacher Madame Maude P Dilly and shared the narration with Ned Sherrin. London Voices supplied the chorus. Great stuff; only the fierceness of the amplification sometimes seemed overbearing.

fields.headline: Lewis Taylor
fields.standfirst:
Lewis Taylor
Hanover Grand, London **
fields.trailText:
Lewis Taylor

Hanover Grand, London **
fields.body:
Lewis Taylor takes the stage after a three year absence and confronts not a mere audience but a Nuremberg rally. The place is packed with starry- eyed fans. Everyone wants to eat his trousers. Everyone knows the words.

"I've been away a long time," he says. "It's not my fucking fault. We all know whose fucking fault it is though." I think he means the record company, though who knows, it could be the West Side Boys.

No matter, he's back in business which is languid mid-tempo funk, like a Jamiroquai on tranquillizers with loads of George Clinton records and a book of 10,000 guitar chords. Taylor doesn't really do verses and choruses, but epic jams which take quirky structural detours until we hit a recognizeable groove.

Like on You Make Me Wanna from the new album, which swells and calms for half an age before the riotous drums and keyboards finale. On Party the shuddering juggernaut gets going again. Taylor's wispy, falsetto vocals work like a mild anaesthetic before he deploys a solo to the blissed out hordes like a cattle prod.

According to some, he sounds like Marvin Gaye. No more than Carol Vorderman convinced us she was really Cher in Celebrity Stars In Their Eyes. And some say it is "good" that he plays all the instruments himself. So did Roy Castle.

I have to say I admired his "musicianship" in the way I admire people who bake their own bread. Er, well done but it's hardly new or deep or inspiring. Nothing against him, but nothing for him either.

fields.headline: Dodgy logic on endowments
fields.standfirst:
Regulator's case does not add up

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Regulator's case does not add up
fields.body:
Item one: 6m people are told by their insurers their endowment is in shortfall, some by tens of thousands of pounds. Item two: the regulator says endowments have "delivered value" to homeowners and there is no case for a full-scale review and compensation.

How dreadful does an endowment have to be before it punctures the FSA's value system? The 6m people with shortfall letters will certainly regard the FSA's logic as incomprehensible. Many will also assume that their trusty watchdog has jumped into bed with the insurance industry. The FSA insists endowment holders are no worse off than people who took out repayment loans. But backing up this claim are some puzzling numbers.

The FSA has decided to put a figure on endowments which assumes these famously high-charging products have their charges spread evenly across the life of the contract. In reality, endowments fund the large commissions they earn by giving the holder next to nothing back if they are cashed in early. If these real surrender values are used endowments would almost certainly look worse than repayment mortgages.

But even if the FSA's methodology is accepted, endowment holders still have a right to complain.

If you are sold a dodgy car, it doesn't let the salesman off the hook just because the local train service is even worse. What matters is that the product you were sold does not come up to scratch and has not delivered what it promised. Endowments promised lots - not just to repay the mortgage, but also an extra tax-free lump sum - and they are failing to deliver.

Judging by yesterday's report, redress will not, except in a few cases, be forthcoming courtesy of the FSA. Instead homeowners will have little option but to enforce the contract by going to court.

There is a precedent. Policyholders at Equitable Life used the legal process to force the company to stand by guarantees made in its contracts during the 1970s and 1980s. They won, and forced the company to its knees.

Although "guarantees" in endowment contracts are less clear-cut, it seems likely courts will treat the small print with disdain, as they did with Equitable Life. Lawyers will be the ultimate winners, and confidence in the regulatory system the ultimate loser.

False friends

With friends like European commission president Romano Prodi and Italian treasury minister Vincenzo Visco, the euro has little need of enemies.

Yesterday Mr Visco declared, apparently in all seriousness, that the euro had regained its stability. Oh, really. If it has finally hit the floor against the dollar the landing has certainly been a bone judderingly hard one. At best the euro has been granted an expensive breathing space - courtesy of G7 intervention. And as every currency dealer knows, when finance ministers are heard rather than seen in the forex market it is usually time to sell.

Mr Prodi's call for the European commission to become economic policy mouthpiece for the European Union is another opinion that would have been best left unsaid. If management of economic policy looks indecisive and muddled now, how would it be with the commission sticking its oar in as well? The only policy decisions the EU might take are already taken by others - be they national finance ministers or the European Central Bank - who are unlikely to cede power to Brussels.

The most likely outcome of Mr Prodi's comments is that they will help to undermine whatever credibility EU economic policy structures possess. Now, that will really help to stabilise the euro.

No time to lose

Urgent action is needed from Marks & Spencer to arrest its decline. The troubled retailer's shares hit their lowest level in a decade yesterday. For one painful moment, with the price below 200p, its market capitalisation slid below £5.5bn. At this rate the chance of some upstart like Philip Green, the Monaco-based financier, being able to finance a bid will soon become credible.

Luc Vandevelde, the chairman, is also chief executive. He has to act fast. He needs to rid M&S of its overseas operations to concentrate on Britain. Painful decision as it might be, he also needs to cut the presence on British high streets.

The retailer still has work to do stocking its stores with items consumers want. Making the stores more attractive gets shoppers through its door, but they do need to buy things.

M&S also needs to agree an arrival date with Roger Holmes, the Kingfisher man billed as potential saviour. He faces the prospect of arriving after confirmation of another slump in profits and another cut in the dividend. He might even decide not to join, having decided that M&S has become a textbook example of how impossible it is for a lost reputation to be restored.

He has to act fast. He needs to rid M&S of its overseas operations to concentrate on Britain. Painful decision as it might be, he also needs to cut the presence on British high streets. The retailer still has work to do stocking its stores with items consumers want. Making the stores more attractive gets shoppers through its door, but they do need to buy things. M&S also needs to agree an arrival date with Roger Holmes, the Kingfisher man billed as potential saviour. He faces the prospect of arriving after confirmation of another slump in profits and another cut in the dividend. He might even decide not to join, having decided that M&S has become a textbook example of how impossible it is for a lost reputation to be restored.

fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst:
An employment tribunal lawyer writes

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.body:
Seeing lots of other people's medical notes makes one doctor-shy. You know that if you ever sue over a whiplash injury or similar, some lawyer is going to be flipping idly through your notes, musing about your verrucas, your urinary tract infections, that thing on your nose you just thought you'd ask your GP about; all your physical failings and fits of hypochondria laid out bleakly in black and white.

I'm not sure what Julie, my client this week, thought her GP was writing in her notes. We had the first instalment of Julie's case about six months ago. Julie was a junior solicitor who said she had been bullied by her boss to the point where she had a nervous breakdown and had to leave work. When I first saw Julie she seemed to present graphic physical evidence of whatever she had been through - her eyelids were red, her neck covered in silver and pink scales that she scrubbed at with shaking hands. She talked very fast, but she made sense.

Her solicitor and I suggested to Julie that we get a medical report to explain her condition to the tribunal. She agreed. So here we are: Julie, her solicitor, the psychiatrist and I, sat round a table a week before her case resumes, looking in silence at fat photocopied bundles of Julie's medical records.

I don't want to know all of the things I now know about Julie. Julie is 30. There are entries going back more than 14 years about her eating disorders, her abortions, her suicide attempts. But the most disturbing notes, from the point of view of Julie's case, go back about three years. They say things like: "Still abusing cocaine and amphetamines. Not sleeping. Paranoia++."

Julie shakes her head: "I didn't know he was writing all this stuff down. I thought it was confidential." Me: "It is. It was. But we told your ex-employer we were going to rely on evidence of your medical condition. You agreed they should see this material." Julie's nails are raising a storm of scales from her neck: "Does it matter that much? Why does it matter?"

Julie's solicitor doesn't want to spell it out. The psychiatrist is busying himself with a biscuit. I try to look at Julie's eyes and not her ravaged neck: "Because they will cross-examine you on your medical notes and say you had a drug problem that made you paranoid, that there was no bullying."

Julie's face tells me that she knew this, that she just needed to hear it, that she doesn't want to sit in a tribunal and be exposed in this way, that she won't continue with her case. But as she leaves the room, she says to me quietly: "You know, just because you're screwed up doesn't mean people haven't done things to hurt you."

fields.headline: Andrew Motion's top 10 poetry books
fields.trailText: Andrew Motion is currently poet laureate
fields.body:
Andrew Motion is currently poet laureate.
Read some of Andrew Motion's recent poems (including Picture this: For the 100th birthday of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother) in the poetry archive.

1. Lyrical Ballads by Anon (1798)
In fact by Wordsworth and Coleridge (who had only four poems in the volume); a defining moment in the Romantic revolution, and the evolution of our distinctly modern age.

2. Lamia, Isabella, The Eve of St Agnes and Other Poems by John Keats (1820)
The title speaks for itself, especially when we remember those 'other poems' include the great odes.

3. Poems, Chiefly Lyrical by Alfred (not yet Lord) Tennyson (1830)
Why did Auden call Tennyson the stupidest English poet? This collection is crammed with evidence of a wonderfully intelligent heart.

4. Leaves of Grass by Walt Whitman (1855)
This blows apart what 'lyrical' might mean, instigating its own extraordinary traditions as it adapts existing ones.

5. North of Boston by Robert Frost (1914)
An example of how the most intense kind of personal poetry and the most general kind of narrative can be brought together to create stories at once beautiful and true.

6. Poems by Edward Thomas (1917)
The volume that contains (among other things) As the Team's Head-Brass, the sort of quiet-speaking masterpiece that made Thomas one of the most influential and best-loved 20th century poets.

7. Poems by WH Auden (1930)
The eruption of a completely new-sounding voice, yet resonant with the echoes of older voices.

8. The Less Deceived by Philip Larkin (1955)
His first 'mature' volume; the distinctive sad music of post-war British life.

9. North by Seamus Heaney (1975)
The authentic Heaney voice, at once earthy and ethereal.

10. Complete Poems by Elizabeth Bishop (1983)
A lifetime's immaculate adventuring.

fields.headline: Romeo and Juliet
fields.standfirst:
Sadler's Wells, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: When Angelin Preljocaj agreed to create a new Romeo and Juliet for Lyon Opera Ballet, it was only on condition that he wouldn't use a pure, unedited version of Prokofiev's score. Not only would some of that music sit badly with his vision of Verona as a modern totalitarian state (Romeo as a homeless outcast and Juliet the daughter of a Ceausescu-style dictator). But the length of the score and its literal soundpainting would also contradict his desire to reduce the story to its emotional and political essences.
fields.body:
When Angelin Preljocaj agreed to create a new Romeo and Juliet for Lyon Opera Ballet, it was only on condition that he wouldn't use a pure, unedited version of Prokofiev's score. Not only would some of that music sit badly with his vision of Verona as a modern totalitarian state (Romeo as a homeless outcast and Juliet the daughter of a Ceausescu-style dictator). But the length of the score and its literal soundpainting would also contradict his desire to reduce the story to its emotional and political essences.

So when the curtain opens on a futuristic set - a kind of decaying space station surrounded by a grim wall - the familiar rhythms of Prokofiev's overture are overlaid by the sinister whirr of helicopters patrolling out of sight. Later, when Juliet is trying to escape reprisals for her transgressive passion for Romeo, we hear amplified footsteps running down a Kafkaesque maze of corridors.

In between the chunks of Prokofiev that Preljocaj does use, there are passages of silence which let us hear the grunting of coupling, fighting bodies, sirens, clanking metal and marching.

This jagged aural jigsaw is mirrored on stage by a similar clashing of elements. Some sections are a modern refraction of the familiar ballet libretto, for example the battles between the militiamen and the street rats led by Mercutio; or themad scientist who stands in for Friar Laurence. But others come out of Preljocaj's own imagination - such as the compression of Capulet and Tybalt into one sadistic dictator, and the climactic bedroom pas de deux in which five couples mirror the two lovers dancing, in an attempt to convey the immensity of Romeo and Juliet's desire.

Sometimes the two narratives collide to produce remarkable poetry. Though this ballet, made in 1989, was Preljocaj's first attempt at a large-scale narrative, its 90 minutes are sustained by some startling, and intensely musical dance invention. The robotic classical moves of the militiamen and the two nurses possess a sophistication and glamour far more scary than plain drilling; and the vocabulary for the two lovers - while lacking lyric flight - fuses a poignant human terror with animal need.

In the final death scene each of the lovers nuzzles the other like a grief stricken dog. The choreography is fabulously danced throughout by Preljocaj's own company, especially Sylvain Groud's Romeo, who dances as if he were throwing his life away.

But there are many instances where the production falls between the cracks of the two narratives and where Preljocaj's inexperience (at the time its creation) shows. Not only are there intractable dramatic oddities (this version can give no reason for Juliet's assumed death) but the fragmented storytelling fails to give us a really intimate knowledge of the two lovers. Anyone hoping for an old-fashioned romantic tragedy will be disappointed, yet in this flawed, ambitious, compelling work Preljocaj certainly gives us poetry of another sort.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

fields.headline: Delgados on top post-Mercury form
fields.standfirst:
Delgados
Newcastle University ****
fields.trailText:
Delgados

Newcastle University ****
fields.body:
It's barely a fortnight since Glasgow's Delgados were being wined and dined at the Mercury music prize. Backs were slapped as the mainstream industry poured praise on their nominated The Great Eastern album, released on their own longstanding Chemikal Underground indie label. The album didn't win, of course, but two weeks later the band are back in their preferred habitat, proving that there is life after the Mercury.

The Delgados specialise in deceptively fragile anthems fired by harrowing social realism. They are often thought of as an archetypal indie band but an hour in their company proves they are anything but. Painstakingly simple but effective in construction, their songs may have grown up in modern Glasgow but were tutored in the 1960s.

Listen closely and you'll hear the teachings of the Band and Van Morrison; the Delgados are also one of the few to have learned from the inexplicably overlooked gentle side of the Velvet Underground.

For this tour, the basic four-piece are augmented by a nine-piece strings and wind section, which further conjure up the ghosts of Astral Weeks. However, any band that begins a set with a song (Knowing When To Run) about the death of children is one with a firm grasp of their own identity.

The Great Eastern is named, incidentally, after a Glaswegian hostel for the homeless and alcoholic. Since the demise of Happy Mondays, the Delgados are virtually unique in even acknowledging the subject of the underclass, one that now seems to be sectioned off from rock songwriting like a dilapidated building tourists aren't supposed to see.

Lyrics about hopelessness and unplanned pregnancies can be uncomfortable, but the Delgados challenge us to not just care, but to actually understand. It helps that they contrast their downbeat, traumatic verses with hugely uplifting choruses, which would fill stadiums if they contained even an ounce of bombast.

The vocal interplay between pure-voiced tomboy Emma Pollock and introspective pretty boy Alun Woodward is especially stunning, and they play the entire Great Eastern, building up to an orchestral collision which hasn't been heard since the Beatles' A Day In The Life. Just another day in the life of the Delgados, but we feel privileged to be there.

 Delgados play the Fiddlers, Bristol (0117-987 3403), then tour.

fields.headline: A brave but frail Orpheus
fields.standfirst:
Orphée et Eurydice
Cardiff New Theatre ***
fields.trailText:
Orphée et Eurydice
Cardiff New Theatre ***
fields.body:
Can Gluck's operas work on the modern stage? A performance of Orphée et Eurydice - in any of its various versions - can be an instructive experience. Gluck was a uniquely imaginative and innovative operatic composer. His dramatic flair, understanding of voices, feeling for orchestral colour and atmosphere were unparalleled in his time. No wonder he was such a potent influence on Mozart and Berlioz.

And yet it so rarely seems to come to life - to "draw blood'', as Gluck himself put it. Too often, the effect of Orphée is to make one realise how different audience sensibilities must have been in the second half of the 18th century. Were they really moved to pity and fear by this?

It's possible that one day Orphée et Eurydice will be vindicated afresh for today's audiences. But it will need a stronger performance, and a much stronger production than the one currently on offer from Welsh National Opera.

A line-up that includes Katerina Karnéus in the title role, with the lively and intelligent baroque specialist Paul McCreesh as conductor, promises well. McCreesh's arguments for reviving the 1859 Berlioz version of the opera made a lot of sense, and he directed it with conviction. Unfortunately the WNO's playing sparked sporadically - it wasn't all perfectly polished either.

Karnéus, agile as ever, managed a decent show of feeling as Orphée, but there was a lack of power in the lower reaches of the voice where details were often smothered by the orchestra. Natalie Christie was a firmer, sweet-toned if somewhat characterless Eurydice.

Only Jeni Bern as the god L'Amour hit the mark exactly: musically, expressively, dramatically. Her costume - a delicious orange and gold baroque extravagance - is one of the few visual treats of the evening.

Perhaps Karnéus and Christie might have achieved more if they'd been given interesting things to do. The action was, on the whole, limp and ineffectual. All poor Orphée had to do in the opening tomb scene was to change position from number to number: beginning in a stiff standing posture, ending prone on the ground - a variant of the lifeless old operatic stand-and-deliver technique.

The dance numbers weren't much better. The Spectres and Furies of Hades, decked out like mutant new age travellers, run around in groups and gesture decorously enough, but it's all very camp and frothy, with an occasional stale whiff of Pan's People. Worst of all, the production - the joint creation of Patrice Caurrier and Moshe Leiser - has no coherent artistic personality or vision. Gluck needs plenty of both if he's to draw blood today.

 Orphée et Eurydice is at Cardiff New Theatre on October 9 and 11 (0292-087 8889), then on tour in Oxford, Southampton, Liverpool, Birmingham, Belfast and Bristol.

webTitle: Making the worst of a good job

fields.headline: Making the worst of a good job
fields.standfirst:
As a survey shows that employees in the UK are among the most miserable in the world, Merope Mills asks: is Britain really such a bad place to work?

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As a survey shows that employees in the UK are among the most miserable in the world, Merope Mills asks: is Britain really such a bad place to work?
fields.body:
Barely have our Olympic team stepped off the plane and already someone is taking a pin to the bubble of national pride we have from the Sydney games. According to a report out this week, British workers should be given a medal of their own - for being among the most miserable in the world.

In a survey of more than 200 international businesspeople, just 25% of Britons said they were happy at work, compared with 54% of Americans. Furthermore, while more than 80% of the Australian and French respondents - and 100% of the Americans - cited their home among the top countries in the world in which to work, only 38% of Britons did so. And in the overall vote on the most miserable country in which to work, Britain took bronze, coming third after China and Japan.

The list of statistics goes on, with British workers consistently rating our western working counterparts as having more blessed working lives than us. It is a damning indictment of our own job market, but one which is hardly surprising when you scour the lengthy list of complaints that arise out of the way we work. We may be used to working the longest and most insecure days in Europe, but the message of this research is clear: we don't have to like it.

Carolyn Asome, who used to teach in France, can relate to the research. Recalling her days there with fondness, she says: "Over there the working conditions are so much better. The hours are shorter, the job security is stronger and there are really good state benefits - if you don't earn over a certain amount you get a great rebate for your rent," she says. "All the time I was there, unions were fighting for better conditions. They were really successful, but the irony is the conditions are far worse over here."

Likewise, Clare Macfarlane, an advertising account executive, enjoyed the relaxing year she spent working in Australia. "There was a definite mass exodus from the office at five o'clock every day, and it's certainly not like that over here," she says. Even the managing director took a relaxed approach to the company commitments: "He was definitely more interested in what he was doing at the weekend. But that could be to do with the quality of life in Australia. They definitely get their priorities right."

Ben Williams, an Edinburgh-based chartered corporate psychologist, preaches a similar relaxed attitude. "We have to try to have more fun at work," he says. "I spend most of my professional career optimising the performance of people at work, and one of the things that does that best is a willingness to play, share and enjoy. It is something workers in this country really have yet to master."

Part of the problem with Britain is that our priorities are all over the place. As work dominates our lives, we become more and more subservient by the day. The confrontations between unions and managements are long gone, and in their place sits a drained, clock-watching workforce which does nothing but moan. As Williams puts it: "We're much less positive about things. We have a less can-do attitude than some of the other parts of the world where they make things happen."

In France, where unions have fought for high levels of job security, generous state pensions and high levels of company-funded insurance, workers can, of course, afford to be happier.

Yet, as in our resignation to the death of union strength and workers' rights, there is a very British defeatism in denouncing ourselves as one of the western world's worst places to work. Given the chance in the survey, other nationalities rated us highly as a good place to earn a crust. It may well be an outsider's misconception, but Professor Cary Cooper, the occupational psychologist who analysed the research, believes the foreigner takes the correct standpoint. He puts Britain's poor performance in the league table of happy workers down as more of a reflection of the British psyche than of poor working culture.

'We have a very negative view of ourselves," says Cooper. "British people always seem to put themselves down a lot more than other countries. In the same way the Americans show their arrogance by unanimously saying they hail from one of the world's top three places to work, so we British show our self-effacing and demure side by constantly labelling ourselves a national failure."

It is a conclusion that Williams is equally quick to draw from the findings. "You can't change the results of 150 years of British social and economic history, and that history has taught us that it pays to keep your place and be humble," he says. "We have a natural reserve about us and a kind of enforced inferiority complex which keeps us down and in our place. That is the reason we find the Americans and Australians and all the Brits who went overseas to form the New World as being very cocky, arrogant and pushy."

So, work-wise, we conform to our national stereotypes - the arrogant Americans meet the diffident Brits. Yet the stigma is acceptable only because we manufactured it. It is a national habit to malign our own assets and habits but, of course, completely unacceptable to hear anyone else make a similar slur. The British workforce should rest assured: the moment another country labels us a nation of miseryguts there will be a scramble to defend ourselves.

Work in Britain: the foreign view

The recruitment agency worker:
For the past nine months Sarah Kinney, from Canada, has worked for S&G Recruitment in London. She believes employment is very different here. "There seems to be a lot more paper shuffling and shifting here, and more middle management, more invented jobs. The whole attitude to work is different - people work hard all week and play hard at the weekend. In Vancouver, everyone's very laid-back." Originally Sarah wanted to work with children, but she found it didn't pay enough.

The brand marketing manager:
Originally from Italy, Christina Fedi has also worked in Paris. She is now employed by Channel 4, and prefers having a job in the UK: "There are more media jobs available, and it is easier to change jobs or be a freelancer," she says. One difficulty she has encountered is excessive politeness: "People are not very confrontational at work. If you want to express an opinion you have to package it in a nice way, listen to what they say and then say 'I understand what you're saying, but...' It becomes a very lengthy process."

The academic:
American-born Steve Greenwold, the deputy head of Birmingham University's school of social sciences, cannot imagine ever working anywhere but the UK. "Maybe people here are less well paid compared to the rich Germans and Americans, but they're funny, amusing and cooperative," he says. "And the work ethic is strong; it's very strong in America, but it's equally strong here, and I don't think that's a source of grumpiness. My experience is that people who are in jobs that are fulfilling seem content with their lot."

The trainee lawyer:
Zohar Zik, from Israel, works for a firm of solicitors in London. After completing a degree at Cardiff law school he started his legal training last October. He too prefers working in London: "I feel much more comfortable in London - plus there are better job prospects for me here as an Israeli graduate from a British university. There are better working conditions here in terms of hours and pay; I still have to work a long day, but I am paid more than I was in Israel. The hours are incredibly long there and the pay is very low. This is not the only reason I chose to stay here, but it is a significant factor."

Ilan leshem, from Germany, has worked in London for two-and-a-half years. He says: "Germany has nicer, more modern offices, but that's not so important to me. Furthermore, while more than 80% of the Australian and French respondents - and 100% of the Americans - cited their home among the top countries in the world in which to work, only 38% of Britons did so. And in the overall vote on the most miserable country in which to work, Britain took bronze, coming third after China and Japan. The list of statistics goes on, with British workers consistently rating our western working counterparts as having more blessed working lives than us. It is a damning indictment of our own job market, but one which is hardly surprising when you scour the lengthy list of complaints that arise out of the way we work. We may be used to working the longest and most insecure days in Europe, but the message of this research is clear: we don't have to like it. Given the chance in the survey, other nationalities rated us highly as a good place to earn a crust. webTitle: Online banks fight for their share

fields.headline: Online banks fight for their share
fields.standfirst: The stakes, and the rates, rise as internet banks battle for customers
fields.trailText: The stakes, and the rates, rise as internet banks battle for customers.
fields.body:
The battle of the internet banks is gathering pace with Cahoot making headline grabbing offers just days after Intelligent Finance went live.

The Abbey National offshoot has increased its current account interest rate to a maximum of 7.1% on non-chequebook accounts with balances over £5,001. Chequebook accounts will get 5% on balances up to £5,000, rising to 6.4% on balances of £25,001 or more. And on October 16 the bank will start offering 5% cashback on credit card balance transfers.

Intelligent Finance, a subsidiary of the Halifax, offers a 5% rate to its current account customers, but said it will not be increasing its interest rate and is confident that its offers of 0% on credit cards and mortgages will give it the edge over its rivals.

Smile, the internet bank which, arguably, started the current account rate competition when it launched with a 4% rate last October, said it will not increase rates as much as Cahoot's. Its rate has increased to 4.85% over the past year, in line with base Bank of England base rates, but Smile said further increases would eat into the product's profits. "We have a policy of passing base rate increases on to our customers, but, unlike Cahoot, will never go above base rates," a spokesperson for the company said. "Its 7.1% offering seems like a license to lose money to us." Egg, the only internet bank still to launch its current account, may follow Cahoot's suit. A spokesperson for the company said its current account will be launched in a very competitive position but declined to comment further.

Meanwhile, consumer watchdogs have dismissed the banks' wrangling. Stuart Cliffe at the National Association of Bank and Insurance Customers said: "I think it's great the banks are offering attractively priced products, I just wonder how many people will be able to take advantage of them. These banks cherry pick their customers with a vengeance and people who, in the past, would have been good credit risks find they are being turned down for accounts."

"Its also important to point out that these sorts of rates are not that amazing when you consider the enormous savings the banks make by operating on the internet. They offer these rates by cutting down on things like face-to-face customer support, but I don't think that's what people want. They like and need good customer service."

fields.headline: Theatrical Dettol in The Blue Room
fields.standfirst:
The Blue Room
Theatre Royal, Haymarket, London **
fields.trailText:
The Blue Room
Theatre Royal, Haymarket, London **
fields.body:
Stripped of the star-names that made it the hottest ticket in town at the Donmar, David Hare's free adaptation of Schnitzler's La Ronde looks a frail, shivering creature.

Even Loveday Ingram's perfectly decent production, conceived for the studio theatre at Chichester, has a faintly goose-pimpled quality when transplanted to the Haymarket, pending the arrival of the bare-backed Jeffrey Archer.

Hare justifies his updating of Schnitztler's 1900 sexual daisy-chain on the grounds that the author himself dubbed the original scenes "completely unprintable." But he omits the rest of the quote in which Schnitzler says that the scenes "if disinterred after a couple of hundred years may illuminate in a unique way aspects of our culture."

Schnitzler was, in fact, writing a social satire about a stratified society in which class divisions were eroded by the sexual act. But he was also creating a specifically Viennese Totentanz in which love and death were locked in Freudian conflict.

My argument against this version is that it is neither one thing nor the other - neither true Schnitzler nor vintage Hare.

In fact, Hare keeps the original structure and even tries to find contemporary equivalents for the characters but the mind boggles when an aristocrat visits an actress in her dressing-room as if we still lived in the world of stage-door johnnies and Gaiety Girls.

Hare also undercuts Schnitzler's lambent pathos. One of the original's points was that sweet suburban girls were shamelessly exploited but here Schnitzler's "das susse Madel" becomes a pill-popping model who is as much predator as victim.

Echoing the past, the play exists in the present without fully inhabiting either. Indeed you learn more about contemporary sex from Hare's My Zinc Bed than you do from this half-hearted act of obeisance.

Ingram's production whisks us efficiently through the sundry couplings but the use, as at the Donmar, of a sign denoting the precise duration of each sexual act shows precisely what is wrong: smart knowingness has replaced Schnitzler's rueful pessimism.

Camilla Power, a leggy lady with appealing elfin features, captures the variety of the female quintet and is particularly good as a teasingly pious actress.

And Michael Higgs moves with equal versatility from emotionally inarticulate cabbie to sententious politician for whom women are either wives or whores.

But the evening still strikes me as second-hand Schnitzler. And the show's ersatz quality is confirmed by the way the actors, while busily simulating sex, rarely take the elementary step of removing their briefs. The result is pure theatrical Dettol.

 Until November 25. Box office: 020-7930 8800.

fields.headline: Endowments escape FSA
fields.standfirst:
Millions face mortgage shortfall, but only a few insurers will be 'named and shamed'

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A small group of insurers will be "named and shamed" and forced to pay compensation on endowment mortgages, the financial services authority said yesterday. But it stepped back from ordering a full review of the policies held by 11m homebuyers.
fields.body:
A small group of insurers will be "named and shamed" and forced to pay compensation on endowment mortgages, the financial services authority said yesterday. But it stepped back from ordering a full review of the policies held by 11m homebuyers.

Though 6.4m policies might not generate enough cash to repay mortgages, with a serious shortfall on 1.3m, the FSA said most buyers were no worse off than if they had taken out repayment mortgages instead. Endowments had enjoyed good returns and benefited proportionately more from falling interest rates.

Amid widespread dismay that tougher action will not be taken, Christine Farnish, the FSA's director of consumer relations, said: "There has been quite a lot of poor practice, which is deeply regrettable, and a number of people have been badly advised. But it does not mean they have necessarily suffered a loss for which they can claim compensation."

An industry-wide review would cost billions of pounds and probably fail to identify a significant number of cases requiring compensation, she added.

The FSA is to issue a further report before Chistmas naming a small number of companies where "mystery shopping" and enforcement visits identified poor advice and serious breaches of rules. They are thought to number about 10 insurers, rather than building societies, and include some household names.

The FSA says guilty companies are likely to be forced to restore homeowners to the financial position equivalent to having taken out a repayment mortgage, including repaying of the shortfall. They are also likely to be reprimanded, fined and possibly restricted from selling certain types of policy.

The FSA yesterday issued a new factsheet, outlining how policyholders can take cases for compensation firstly to insurers and then to the financial services ombudsman - but not the FSA. Yesterday the ombudsman's office said it had received more than 5,000 complaints and expected more.

The Consumers' Association said the FSA figures proved the scale of the problem was "staggering".

The association's director, Sheila McKechnie, said: "This is a 'no progress' report from the FSA. It is time for the FSA to get tough on behalf of millions of consumers and not let guilty firms get away with bad practice."

The association criticised the methodology used by the FSA to suggest that endowment holders were no worse off. It said: "The FSA calculations are biased in favour of endowments. For example, they have given the value of endowments assuming the charges are spread over 25 years, when everybody knows the charges are stacked up at the front. To say you are no worse off is unrealistic."

Insurance companies - which have paid out £13bn to people missold personal pensions - were relieved to have avoided another review.

The Association of British Insurers criticised scaremongering by the press and said: "Having looked thoroughly at this matter, the FSA has found no evidence to change its view, with which we agree, that on average people have done well with endowment mortgages."

The decision not to force a review may prompt court action against insurers. One legal firm, Joseph Aaron & Co, plans a group action on behalf of 200 policyholders with shortfalls.

Mr Aaron said: "People were sold endowment policies with the specific aim of repaying a mortgage and giving them a lump sum at the end. That was the contract, and that is what they are bound by."

webTitle: United shy away from big-money signings

fields.headline: United shy away from big-money signings
fields.standfirst: High salaries and cup failure hits Man Utd profits
fields.trailText: Manchester United yesterday ruled out making any big-money signings until the European Commission's challenge to football transfer fees has been resolved.
fields.body:
Manchester United yesterday ruled out making any big-money signings until the European Commission's challenge to football transfer fees has been resolved.

The United plc chief executive Peter Kenyon said the club would not risk spending millions on new players if there was a chance they could then walk away for nothing.

"We're happy with our squad the way that it is at the moment," he insisted. "The calibre of players we might have looked to have brought in would more than likely be cup-tied anyway."

Further investment in the club's new state-of-the-art £14m training complex at Carrington will also be put on hold until the transfer issue has been clarified. Shares in United have fallen sharply over the past few months amid the uncertainty generated by the commission's challenge.

However, Kenyon remains optimistic that a compromise solution can be found by the end of the year.

"This is an important review for Manchester United and an even bigger review for football in general," Kenyon said. "However, the discussions that we have had with the commission as a board member of the G14 leaves us optimistic that they will not abolish the system and a transfer system of sorts will be left in place.

"The commission understands the specific nature of football and everyone in the game has made it clear they want to retain the transfer system. The noises of late from the commission have been encouraging but we would not wish to be presumptive about what the outcome will be."

The freeze on spending could leave Sir Alex Ferguson short of cover in the event of an injury crisis and could also delay any efforts to resurrect Ruud van Nistelrooy's £18.5m move from PSV Eindhoven.

Kenyon was speaking after United revealed a 25% slump in profits for the year to July 31, due largely to the club's failure to retain either the European Cup or the FA Cup, which they withdrew from in favour of the inaugural World Club Championship, and rising player wages.

United's total wage bill jumped 21% to £44.7m in a year when captain Roy Keane tested the club's salary structure to the limit by negotiating a £52,000 per week pay packet.

Kenyon hopes that growth in the club's off-field interests - particularly broadcasting and merchandising - will act as a counter to spiralling wages. Turnover is at a record high of £116m and sales of the new Vodafone replica kit range are approaching the record levels of 1995-6. Each league match at Old Trafford now generates £1.75m, more than double the sum of five years ago.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Continental football: Coaches living on borrowed time

fields.headline: Top coaches living on borrowed time
fields.trailText: Barcelona coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer has vowed to reverse the club's disastrous run of results, while Marcello Lippi appears to be on borrowed time at Internazionale. But luck has already run out for Atletico Madrid's Fernando Zambrano.
fields.body:
The embattled Barcelona coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer has vowed to "correct" problems at the club after a disastrous run of results which have seen his side slip out of contention at home and abroad in recent weeks.

Sunday's 2-0 defeat at Deportivo Coruna left them four points behind the Spanish champions after only four league games and follows successive European defeats to Besiktas and Milan which mean the Catalan club face an early exit from the Champions League.

"It's normal that there will be rumours over the coming days, that people will talk about the coach's future," said Serra Ferrer. "I accept that but what we have to do is continue working. There are things that we need to correct."

He has two weeks' respite before he faces a make-or-break three games in eight days which will decide his future. A daunting Champions League trip to Milan's San Siro stadium comes in between two crucial league games against Real Sociedad and Barca's arch rivals Real Madrid. And later Barca will face Leeds at Elland Road.

Atletico Madrid's coach Fernando Zambrano has been sacked after only five games of the season, the president Jesus Gil showing that his ruthless streak has survived the drop down to the Spanish second division.

webTitle: FA chief executive outlines plans for future England success

fields.headline: Crozier sets six-year target for winning World Cup
fields.standfirst:
Saturday's clash with Germany begins long road, says Jim White
England sweat on Dyer's knee
fields.trailText: Jim White talks to FA chief executive Adam Crozier about his plans for future England success as Kevin Keegan's men begin the long road to 2002.
fields.body:
One of the many reasons suggested for the huge success enjoyed by the British team in the Sydney Olympics was the reaction to failure the previous time round. Atlanta hosted the "and there's the British girl coming in a valiant seventh" games. And in the post-mortem to humiliation back in 1996, many of the participating sports bodies made the kind of major changes to the way they were run that was needed to achieve results.

On Saturday, the England football team begins the long march from its own Atlanta: Euro 2000. It was a shambolic performance in which, had there been medals for taking part, England's players would probably have dropped theirs at the presentation ceremony.

Add to that the administrative disappointment of failing to land the 2006 World Cup, and the stock of English football internationally has rarely been lower. Oddly, Adam Crozier, the FA chief executive who has been in charge of the English game for nine months now, believes this is no bad place to start.

"In the long run what happened at Euro 2000 might be a good thing," he says. "In the past what has tended to happen is we've had glorious failure, and the glory hides the failure. Euro 2000 hurt. What it really did was focus everyone's minds on the kind of longer-term thinking we need to take if we're going to achieve success. These are decisions France took 10-12 years ago and they've reaped the benefit since."

And there is no question Crozier has set out to give the FA the kind of direction and sense of purpose that used to be entirely lacking in the moribund, arthritic organisation. He has streamlined operations, removed tiers of bureaucracy, introduced internal audits and performance targets. There is even soon to be a move from the creaking old headquarters in Lancaster Gate to state-of-the-art Soho offices, complete with a swanky atrium to host FA Cup draws. And to sharpen minds he has set the organisation a target: winning the 2006 World Cup. Which, given the current state of the game in this country, makes William Hague's assertion that he will snatch the next election look a racing certainty by comparison. At the moment English players barely make up a quorum in our leading clubs, and here is the chief executive of the FA proposing that in a mere six years' time there will be enough native talent around to see off the collective endeavours of France, Italy, Spain, Brazil and Argentina.

In his softly persuasive Scots burr Crozier says: "2006 isn't plucked out of nowhere. It's a timetable tied in with the players coming through the academy system ready to meet the Owens and Coles absolutely at their peak. One of the most important ways of preparing players for the future is to qualify for every tournament. That's why these two games coming up [against Germany and Finland] are so crucial. But to achieve the goal will require patience."

Ah, patience. Not a virtue much in evidence in English football, as exemplified by the FA committee member Ken Bates or, indeed, representatives of the press. If things go as wrong on Saturday as they did in Euro 2000 there will be plenty advising that patience should be tempered with realism. Defeat against Germany, and even more so against Finland the following Wednesday, will have many suggesting that the long-term future of the England team would be better off in a different pair of hands.

"I've said this I don't know how many times," says Crozier. "We believe in Kevin [Keegan], we're 100% behind him. Don't forget the position he took over. Things were a bit of a mess. There was a lot of unhappiness in the squad, players weren't playing for the manager, and he pulled that round and qualified for Euro 2000. Yes, it didn't go as well as we hoped, but look at it in club terms and he's not yet a quarter of the way into one season. I'm absolutely convinced he is the right person to take us forward."

Forward is a favourite Crozier word. He uses it constantly as he talks about the investment the FA is making in grassroots football (£125m a year from next year, compared with only £3m in 1998). He uses it to describe the youth academy system now in place, and to talk about the essential need for quality coaching of junior players. He is also looking forward to a mooted new national football centre, along the lines of Clairefontaine, a place which, he says "is at the root of every French success these past five years".

But it is in the nature of English football that, however keen we are to look to the future, the past has a habit of intruding. This Saturday will be no exception: the last game at Wembley against the old enemy. The two teams will be led out by Franz Beckenbauer and Bobby Charlton, a reminder not just of past clashes on the pitch but more recent battles over 2006.

"It's very difficult going into a match like this," says Crozier. "Like everyone, I love Wembley, I get nostalgic. But I'm very aware I get the best seat in the house. All you need to do to put that nostalgia in perspective is go and sit behind the goal, take a walk round and look at the facilities and you instantly recognise that that is not the place where people should be watching football. So I think we're doing the right thing by rebuilding the place. And if you were going to choose a way to close Wembley, what a way to do it: a World Cup game against Germany. It'll be a great occasion, but more importantly it will be a great game and that's the thing to focus on."

And what about the suggestion from Kate Hoey, the minister for sport, last week that the new Wembley might yet get a running track and become the centre of a bid for the 2012 Olympics?

"I'm ignoring that," he smiles. "Wembley will be a football stadium and we want it to be the finest in the world. In the future, nothing else will do."

And on Saturday, we will get the first opportunity to see how far into their chief executive's future the England football team have really travelled.

webTitle: Dyer's knee a worry ahead of Germany clash

fields.headline: England sweat on Dyer's knee
fields.standfirst: Crozier sets six-year target for winning World Cup
fields.trailText: Paul Scholes and David Beckham are expected to be fit for England's match against Germany on Saturday's after sustaining minor injuries last weekend, but Kieron Dyer's twisted knee is causing concern for Kevin Keegan.
fields.body:
England's players gathered at their Burnham HQ last night reporting a variety of knocks before Saturday's crucial World Cup group nine qualifier against Germany, with the most concern surrounding Kieron Dyer.

Paul Scholes has a foot injury and may have to miss a couple of days' training, and his Manchester United team-mate David Beckham suffered a knock to his knee in United's defeat at Arsenal. But both are expected to recover before Saturday's farewell to Wembley.

Martin Keown also limped away from the game but Highbury officials described it as a "mild ankle sprain". With England's new captain Tony Adams fit again, that is good news for Kevin Keegan, who is already without Sol Campbell through injury; in their five appearances together under Keegan, Keown and Adams have conceded only one goal.

The Arsenal centre-backs earned praise from Sir Alex Ferguson after United's defeat on Saturday: "More than anyone else in the Arsenal team they earned the points for them."

Paul Ince has had two stitches to a knee injury but is confident of being ready. The main worry for Keegan is Dyer, who twisted a knee on Saturday.

Germany's caretaker coach Rudi Völler also has injury problems. The defender Jorg Heinrich and the striker Alexander Zickler are both doubtful for Saturday. If they fail to recover, Völler will be forced to change his side for the first time in his short reign of two games, the wins against Greece and Spain.

He will not risk anyone who is not fully fit. "We need to prepare ourselves for a full 90 minutes of power football on Saturday," he said. "That will require players who can stand up to the challenge and keep up with what I expect to be the high tempo of the game."

 The Finland coach Antti Muurinen has named the Stockport midfielder Jarkko Wiss in his squad for the World Cup qualifying matches against Greece in Athens on Saturday and England in Helsinki next Wednesday.

Midfielders: Litmanen (Barcelona), Nurmela (Heerenveen), Riihilahti (Valerenga), Valakari (Derby), Wiss (Stockport), Kolkka (PSV Eindhoven). Strikers: Kuqi (Jokerit), Kottila (Brann Bergen), Johansson (Charlton), Forssell (Crystal Palace).

webTitle: Collymore's misery goes on with FA charge

fields.headline: Collymore's misery goes on with FA charge
fields.standfirst: The life and times of Stan
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore's troubles continued when he was charged with violent misconduct by the FA on the day that Leicester agreed to his transfer request.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore's fragile confidence was dealt a further blow yesterday as he was charged with violent misconduct by the Football Association on the day that Leicester agreed to his transfer request.

The charge comes eight days after the controversial striker clashed with Everton's Paul Gascoigne during a televised game at Filbert Street. It looks likely to have been Collymore's last game for Leicester as two days later his manager, Peter Taylor, denounced the player's attitude, saying: "You never say never, but I would be surprised if I ever played him again."

The incident was missed by the referee, Alan Wiley, but not by the FA's video panel, who recommended that Collymore be charged. The player now has 14 days to reply to the charge and request a personal hearing.

The FA has also charged Norwich and Blackpool with misconduct following an incident during their Worthington Cup tie on September 19, again on the recommendation of the video panel. On a busy day for football's disciplinarians the FA started an investigation into a half-time argument between Leicester's Gerry Taggart and Sunderland's Niall Quinn on Sunday.

Denis Smith has resigned as manager of Oxford, but will remain in an advisory role. The club are bottom of the Second Division having lost eight of their first 10 games.

Dennis Bergkamp, the Arsenal striker, yesterday began negotiations with the London club with a view to extending his contract, which expires at the end of the season..

Scotland seem likely to lose Dominic Matteo, Paul Lambert and Barry Ferguson through injury for Saturday's World Cup qualifier against San Marino. Also withdrawing from international squads yesterday were Leeds' Lucas Radebe, who has concussion, and Gary Kelly, who has a groin injury, and Manchester United's Mark Bosnich, who "has personal issues to resolve," according to the Australia manager Frank Farina.

Everton's Alessandro Pistone may be ruled out until next summer. The Italian defender faces exploratory knee surgery on cruciate ligament damage suffered during a warm-up for the Worthington Cup tie against Bristol Rovers two weeks ago. Since arriving from Newcastle in a £3m deal in July, Pistone has managed less than two hours of senior football for Everton.

Brazil yesterday appointed Candinho as their caretaker manager following the sacking of Wanderley Luxemburgo. He will take charge of the World Cup qualifier against Venezuela on Sunday after Luiz Felipe Scolari, who had been the favourite to take over, turned the job down. Carlos Alberto Parreira, who coached Brazil to victory at the 1994 World Cup, is considered the likely beneficiary.

webTitle: The life and times of Stan

fields.headline: The life and times of Stan
fields.trailText: 1971: Born Stone, Staffordshire, January 22.
fields.body:
1971: Born Stone, Staffordshire, January 22.

1989: Kicked off career with Walsall, who later cancelled his YTS contract. Wolves completed his trainee term and he scored 18 goals in 20 games for their youth side but failed to make first team. Joined Conference club Stafford Rangers, scoring eight goals in first season.

1990: Moved to Crystal Palace for £100,000. Made six league appearances as substitute in first season.

1992: Left Palace (four League starts, 16 sub appearances, one goal) after being deployed as a winger. Joined Southend (November) for £80,000 and scored 18 goals in 33 games (15 in 30 League).

1993: Nottingham Forest manager Brian Clough refused to pay Southend's £2.2million asking price. Forest relegated, Clough left club and Collymore signed for his successor Frank Clark for original fee, rising to £2.75million on goal and international achievements.

1994: Hit 24 goals (19 in 28 League games) as Forest won immediate return to Premiership. Clark says £10million offer might tempt a sale.

1995: Manchester United fail in New Year signing bid, settling instead for £7million Andy Cole. In February Collymore acquitted of assault charge for alleged fight outside nightclub. Scores season's total of 25 goals (22 League), including 10 in last two months, as Forest finish third in Premiership and qualify for UEFA Cup. First England cap against Japan on June 3 and second as a substitute against Brazil. Joins Liverpool for British record £8.5million.

1996: Makes 44 appearances in his first season at Anfield and scores 19 goals as Liverpool finish third in the Premiership. Scores the winner in a memorable 4-3 victory over Newcastle meaning the Magpies finish as runners-up to Manchester United. As new season kicks off, Collymore still commutes from his West Midlands home to Merseyside, and finds competition for his first team place from Czech Republic striker Patrik Berger. Aston Villa reported to have failed in a £6million bid for Collymore. Fined £20,000 for not attending training but Liverpool boss Roy Evans says Collymore will be staying even though he fails to play a reserve team fixture.

1997: Better form sees Collymore called up to the England squad to play Mexico in a Wembley friendly. Finishes season having made 37 appearances and scored 16 goals. May 13: Joins Villa in a £7million deal.

October: Sent off and given a three-match ban after exchanging blows with Bolton defender Andy Todd. Undergoes nose operation to cure a breathing problem.

1998: Accuses Liverpool's Steve Harkness of racist abuse during and after Villa's 2-1 home victory in March. PFA forced to step in as neither player backs down. Both shake hands as they agree to disagree.

Involved in an altercation in June with girlfriend and television presenter Ulrika Jonsson in a bar in Paris. Via a statement from his agent, Collymore "deeply regrets everything that occurred" and "is beside himself with remorse" before publicly apologising.

Collymore scores a hat-trick in Villa's UEFA Cup win over Stromsgodset in September.

1999: January: Collymore announces that he is seeking counselling for troubles in his private life, and spends two weeks in a clinic to undergo treatment for depression.

February: Returns to Villa side against Leeds. After 3-0 home defeat by Chelsea, Villa boss John Gregory admits he will not pick Collymore again this season as he needs full-time treatment for his depression.

June: Collymore has talks with Greek club Panathinaikos but a proposed deal falls through.

August: Starts the season with a three-month loan at Fulham, with a view to a £1million permanent deal. But Collymore and Fulham fail to agree terms and he returns to Villa.

December: Collymore talks over a move to French club Montpellier but the deal is off when Collymore refuses to play in a practice match.

2000: Bradford end their interest in Collymore in February because they refuse to pay a £3million transfer fee.

Leicester sign Collymore on an incentive-based pay-as-you-play deal.

February 16: Leicester are thrown out of their La Manga training base after Collymore is accused of letting off a fire extinguisher in a bar. The Spanish resort's bosses ordered the team to leave after the incident.

February 17: Fined two weeks' wages for letting off the fire extinguisher and warned about future conduct. Collymore is also required to undertake additional community duties for deserving causes in Leicestershire at the direction of manager Martin O'Neill. The former England international and all the Leicester the players are told to pay all costs of the trip, and additional air fares will be paid for by the players. A hotel bill of £700 for damage to the bar area will also be paid by the players.

March: Collymore scores a hat-trick on his home debut for Leicester in the 5-2 victory over Sunderland.

April: Breaks left leg in the 17th minute of the 3-0 defeat at Derby.

August: Scores first goal after his horrific injury in a 3-0 friendly win at Wycombe.

Targets an England recall, citing Paul Gascoigne as an example of a player who is still on the fringe of international recognition in his 30s.

September: The FA confirm that their video advisory panel will meet to review Collymore's tangle with Gascoigne in the Premiership clash with Everton, when the Leicester striker appeared to stamp on - and later elbow - Gascoigne.

October 2: Leicester officially accept Collymore's transfer request on the same day that the player is charged with violent conduct by the FA following the clash with Gascoigne.

Wolves completed his trainee term and he scored 18 goals in 20 games for their youth side but failed to make first team. Joined Conference club Stafford Rangers, scoring eight goals in first season. 1990: Moved to Crystal Palace for £100,000. Made six league appearances as substitute in first season. 1992: Left Palace (four League starts, 16 sub appearances, one goal) after being deployed as a winger. Joined Southend (November) for £80,000 and scored 18 goals in 33 games (15 in 30 League). 1993: Nottingham Forest manager Brian Clough refused to pay Southend's £2.2million asking price. Forest relegated, Clough left club and Collymore signed for his successor Frank Clark for original fee, rising to £2.75million on goal and international achievements. 1994: Hit 24 goals (19 in 28 League games) as Forest won immediate return to Premiership. Clark says £10million offer might tempt a sale. 1995: Manchester United fail in New Year signing bid, settling instead for £7million Andy Cole. In February Collymore acquitted of assault charge for alleged fight outside nightclub. Scores season's total of 25 goals (22 League), including 10 in last two months, as Forest finish third in Premiership and qualify for UEFA Cup. First England cap against Japan on June 3 and second as a substitute against Brazil. Joins Liverpool for British record £8.5million. 1996: Makes 44 appearances in his first season at Anfield and scores 19 goals as Liverpool finish third in the Premiership. Scores the winner in a memorable 4-3 victory over Newcastle meaning the Magpies finish as runners-up to Manchester United. As new season kicks off, Collymore still commutes from his West Midlands home to Merseyside, and finds competition for his first team place from Czech Republic striker Patrik Berger. Aston Villa reported to have failed in a £6million bid for Collymore. Fined £20,000 for not attending training but Liverpool boss Roy Evans says Collymore will be staying even though he fails to play a reserve team fixture. 1997: Better form sees Collymore called up to the England squad to play Mexico in a Wembley friendly. Finishes season having made 37 appearances and scored 16 goals. May 13: Joins Villa in a £7million deal. October: Sent off and given a three-match ban after exchanging blows with Bolton defender Andy Todd. Undergoes nose operation to cure a breathing problem. 1998: Accuses Liverpool's Steve Harkness of racist abuse during and after Villa's 2-1 home victory in March. PFA forced to step in as neither player backs down. Both shake hands as they agree to disagree. Involved in an altercation in June with girlfriend and television presenter Ulrika Jonsson in a bar in Paris. Via a statement from his agent, Collymore "deeply regrets everything that occurred" and "is beside himself with remorse" before publicly apologising. Collymore scores a hat-trick in Villa's UEFA Cup win over Stromsgodset in September. 1999: January: Collymore announces that he is seeking counselling for troubles in his private life, and spends two weeks in a clinic to undergo treatment for depression. February: Returns to Villa side against Leeds. After 3-0 home defeat by Chelsea, Villa boss John Gregory admits he will not pick Collymore again this season as he needs full-time treatment for his depression. June: Collymore has talks with Greek club Panathinaikos but a proposed deal falls through. August: Starts the season with a three-month loan at Fulham, with a view to a £1million permanent deal. But Collymore and Fulham fail to agree terms and he returns to Villa. December: Collymore talks over a move to French club Montpellier but the deal is off when Collymore refuses to play in a practice match. 2000: Bradford end their interest in Collymore in February because they refuse to pay a £3million transfer fee. Leicester sign Collymore on an incentive-based pay-as-you-play deal. February 16: Leicester are thrown out of their La Manga training base after Collymore is accused of letting off a fire extinguisher in a bar. The Spanish resort's bosses ordered the team to leave after the incident. February 17: Fined two weeks' wages for letting off the fire extinguisher and warned about future conduct. Collymore is also required to undertake additional community duties for deserving causes in Leicestershire at the direction of manager Martin O'Neill. The former England international and all the Leicester the players are told to pay all costs of the trip, and additional air fares will be paid for by the players. A hotel bill of £700 for damage to the bar area will also be paid by the players. March: Collymore scores a hat-trick on his home debut for Leicester in the 5-2 victory over Sunderland. April: Breaks left leg in the 17th minute of the 3-0 defeat at Derby. August: Scores first goal after his horrific injury in a 3-0 friendly win at Wycombe. Targets an England recall, citing Paul Gascoigne as an example of a player who is still on the fringe of international recognition in his 30s. September: The FA confirm that their video advisory panel will meet to review Collymore's tangle with Gascoigne in the Premiership clash with Everton, when the Leicester striker appeared to stamp on - and later elbow - Gascoigne. October 2: Leicester officially accept Collymore's transfer request on the same day that the player is charged with violent conduct by the FA following the clash with Gascoigne.

fields.headline: News round-up
fields.trailText: Surrey sign Zimbabwe Test batsman Murray Goodwin as their overseas player while teams competing in the ICC Trophy in Kenya are issued with Aids health advisories.
fields.body:
Sussex have signed the former Zimbabwe Test batsman Murray Goodwin as their overseas player for next season as a replacement for the Australia all-rounder Michael Bevan. The 28-year-old, who was recommended by Bevan, scored three centuries in eight matches during Zimbabwe's tour of England this summer before announcing his international retirement.

 Health advisories warning of the very high incidence of Aids in Kenya are being issued to teams competing in the ICC Trophy. "All teams should advise members of the risk of HIV infection," says the advisory. "Should anyone be beguiled by the charms of local ladies, they should definitely use a condom." England play a 14-a-side warm-up match against Australia today.
