As Robbins notes: "It is hospitals trying to do the right thing, but it seems a bit ridiculous that, when you've been lying where there's only a curtain between you and the rest of the ward and every stranger in the room can hear, your family is then denied necessary information for your care." The row in April over DNR orders being assigned to elderly patients without their knowledge highlighted new concerns over patient and relative consultation. When the health secretary, Alan Milburn, later stepped into the controversy to insist that hospital trusts produce a document stating their policy, he put an end to the illicit practice but not to the qualms that some doctors obviously feel when discussing such matters. Clare Rayner, president of the Patient Association, says: "Very often doctors don't tell patients news because it's too unpleasant or because they think it might upset them too much and delay their recovery. It is a culture of silence left over from the 50s, when it was considered good, honourable practice not to tell a patient they had cancer." Fifty years on, diagnosis concealment is near extinct in the UK. However, what exists in its place is an equally problematic culture of blame that encourages the masking of medical mistakes by health practitioners. Knowing that hospitals are likely to punish and families are keen for recompense, doctors are less likely to admit their errors outside the surgery walls, she argues. Rayner believes that access to more information from the health service will only be given once we accept medicine is not a 100% accurate science. "Every screening, every operation and every diagnosis is a gamble," she says, "and we must learn to accept that medical help involves an element of risk if we are to get rid of this face of clinical judgement where individual doctors decide what patients can and can't be told." The campaign to assert some control over individual medical notes continues to grow. One system that is commonly advocated is a "living will" policy, similar to that which exists in America. In order to assure some kind of control over medical notes, this involves patients detailing who they would and would not like to know about their condition, before seeking medical treatment. "That's something we are telling people to do," says Robbins. "It's a little piece of authorisation that people just don't think of. Chief executive Arnold Simanowitz says the organisation supports a complete change of system in the UK, whereby conscious patients keep their medical records with them. "There have been a number of experiments in that area and they have all turned out to be very successful," he says. "There is a lot of anxiety on the part of the profession about patients knowing what's going on, but whenever patients have been informed it has always been a good thing. It would also mean that if that patient dies, their information should go to the next of kin." Like other patients' campaigning groups, Simanowitz argues that problems nearly always stem from a culture of secrecy. Realising that openness and confidentiality should both be adhered to he suggests health practitioners should start with the premise "that you've got to be open and have access to your information" and only diverge from that when it conflicts with issues of confidentiality. "It would mean a complete system overhaul," says Simanowitz, "but if you start being open and honest from the start, then the patient, the families and the doctors are much more likely to get a fairer ride."

fields.headline: Portillo pledges less state interference
fields.standfirst: Full text of speech
fields.trailText: In his first speech to the Conservative party conference as shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo this afternoon told delegates he aimed to cut taxes and "intrude less in people's lives".
fields.body:
In his first speech to the Conservative party conference as shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo this afternoon told delegates he aimed to cut taxes and "intrude less in people's lives".

The shadow chancellor emphasised the Tories' opposition to the euro and welcomed the recent Danish vote against membership of the single currency. He also attacked the government for producing "the most expensive petrol in Europe" and reiterated his party's promise to cut fuel duty.

While paying tribute to the work of public services - and particularly the national health service - Mr Portillo came out in favour of increased private-sector involvement in health care.

He blamed Labour's "pure dogma" for building a "Berlin Wall" between the public and private sectors.

In contrast, he stressed his own commitment to state education, contrasting the public school educated Tony Blair with William Hague's comprehensive education.

But the speech ventured onto less traditional territory. "My job is not just about dry economics," Mr Portillo said. "We have seen Britain changed and we are a party that has changed with Britain," he claimed, calling for Britain to "be proud of its rich diversity".

"We are not just a party of tolerance," he said. "We are willing to extend respect " to "sexual orientation". The line was brave, given the controversy last year over Mr Portillo's homosexual experiences while at university.

fields.headline: Michael Portillo's speech
fields.standfirst: Full text
fields.trailText: Full text
fields.body:
Four years ago Tony Blair promised us a new Britain.
He promised taxes wouldn't rise. But they have.
He promised shorter waiting lists. But they're longer.
He promised smaller classes. But they're larger.
He promised more police. But there are fewer.
He promised his government would be purer than pure. What a joke.

I feel so sorry for the many people who put their hopes in that man. They are so bitterly disappointed.

They were sold a dream and it's just not there. And there hasn't been a single word of apology.

Well, he did say the Dome hadn't been a runaway success.

Not a runaway success? As I recall, that's what people said to me after my defeat in Enfield Southgate.

It's four years since I could address a party conference from the platform. A lot of water has flowed under the bridge. We've travelled a long distance since then: I have, you have, the party has.

I was devastated by my defeat at the time. It certainly didn't feel like it at the time, but the British electorate did me a favour. My period out of parliament was a chance to connect with the Britain of today.

Now, as Shadow Chancellor, I cannot forget those experiences. My job is not just about dry economics. The quality of British life cannot be measured in material terms alone.

We are the party that understands how much the world has changed.

Our country would be stronger and its people more willing to take responsibility if we had fewer politicians passing fewer laws, raising fewer taxes and intruding less in our lives.

Young people reject the Labour Party's bossiness, meddling, banning and regulating.

Britain has changed and the Conservatives have changed with it. For new generations of British people, old prejudices have been swept away.

The Conservative Party is a party for our times.

We are a party for people, not against people. We are for all Britons: black Britons, British Asians, white Britons. Britain is a country of rich diversity. That Britain was on display in Sydney. Athletes of every background united by a pride in Britain, and Britain united by its pride in them. Conservatives don't look for uniformity, but for the qualities that mark people out as individual and exceptional.

We are for people whatever their sexual orientation. The Conservative Party isn't merely a party of tolerance: it's a party willing to accord every one of our citizens respect. Why should people respect us if we withhold respect from them?

We value people for what's inside them.

We heard last week Labour's smears against our policy on asylum seekers. That policy will re-establish public confidence in our controls. That frees us to give a warm welcome to those who come to Britain in fear of their lives.

That's how my father came. Britain's willingness to take in refugees defines us as a generous and responsible people. It's a tradition that will be upheld by the Conservative Party.

We want people to aspire, to reach the heights to which their qualities can lift them.

While I was out of parliament I took a television camera into some housing estates. I saw a lot of poverty. But in a way what shocked me was not so much the absolute poverty for many people had videos and their children wore Reebok trainers. What distressed me most was the poverty of expectation and ambition, the lack of hope for anything better in life to come.

But in a Saturday school organised by the black community in Sandwell, I found that aspiration: parents determined that their children should have a chance to fulfil their dreams. And education would be the ladder by which they'd climb.

Many Labour politicians climbed that ladder. But now they want to kick it away from others. For reasons of pure dogma, they destroy good schools: grant-maintained schools and grammar schools.

But they send their own children to exclusive schools. That's Labour's real policy on education. One rule for themselves, another rule for those they govern.

William Hague went to a state school. So did Theresa May. So did I. I had excellent teachers. We weren't intimidated by public schools like Mr Blair's. We thought we could do just as well as they did.

No state school should ever feel second class.

Every parent knows that a school is only as good as its head teacher. The Conservative way is to trust the head teachers and give them the money to spend as they choose. We will give them the opportunity to create great schools, to lift the sights of their pupils, and to transform their young lives.

This is our message to parents and teachers: we will set the schools free.

The next generation will want to be more independent in their retirement than pensioners are today. We will give them the chance to put their money into a properly-funded pension. We'll enable future generations to accrue prosperity and share fully in the growth of our economy.

We won't fudge welfare reform.

Gordon Brown promised pensioners change. They got it. Loose change. 75 pence. And when pensioners sent it back in disgust, Gordon cashed the cheques.

While I was enjoying my sabbatical, I worked for a few shifts as a hospital porter. I remember once wheeling a patient to the operating theatre on a trolley. He was motionless and I was awfully afraid he might be dead. But without warning, almost like Frankenstein's monster he sat bolt upright and said, "What on earth are you doing here Mr Portillo?"

I was experiencing the sharp end of the NHS.

Everything was in short supply. There weren't enough wheel chairs. So porters had to horde them. It reminded me of stories of the war, when there was rationing, but everyone mucked in and tried to be cheerful.

It was impressive. The doctors, nurses and porters are heroes. But things shouldn't have to be like that.

Britain spends too little on health.

There's a consensus amongst the parties that we should spend much more money on the NHS. But not on how to spend it, nor on how that money can be supplemented.

Labour impose politically motivated targets on our doctors and nurses. No wonder they're demoralised. We would give doctors responsibility, and trust them to spend the money wisely, treating the sickest patients first.

Where Labour's horizons end, ours begin.

Our neighbours in Europe know that you cannot rely on taxes alone to finance health. They would think it silly that families in Britain are encouraged to spend money on their home, on their continued education and on their retirement, but are discouraged through dogma from spending their own money on their health. So other countries have schemes, for instance organised by trade unions and employers. We'll want to encourage that in Britain too.

Well spend much more money on the Health Service. And attract extra money too.

Labour are stuck in ancient ideology. As Ann Widdecombe once said, Labour have built a Berlin Wall between the public and private sectors.

We will tear down that wall.

Liberal Democrats have a policy for health and education too. It's is to make doctors and teachers pay more tax. It's not much of a gift for the NHS. But it's a great gift for every Conservative candidate fighting a Liberal Democrat. Let's hear a round of applause for my old pal Charles Kennedy, the Tory candidate's friend.

While I was out of Parliament, I became a small business. The Inland Revenue and Customs and Excise sent me a pile of forms and books and tables that thick. I found it daunting and time-wasting. What a pity Gordon Brown doesn't live in the real world where business people live.

We never forget that governments don't create prosperity. Businesses do.

Tomorrow David Heathcoat Amory will tell you about our plans to cut red tape. We will make VAT simpler and fairer. Let's stop punishing the people who create the jobs.

All Labour Chancellors regulate more. All Labour Chancellors tax more. But Gordon Brown is no socialist hero. He hasn't taxed the rich to give to the poor. He's cynically chosen soft targets for his stealth taxes: hard-working families, people he thought who would never protest.

Labour think high taxes give them the moral high ground. They talk of social justice. They believe that money that government spends is always more worthwhile than money that people spend for themselves on their families.

But I don't.

I believe in allowing hardworking families to keep more of the money they have earned. I believe in allowing them to keep more of their dignity and responsibility.

Recently, a man wrote to me, a member of the seamen's union. The union's told him Gordon Brown's taxed the pension fund and he must pay out another £200 a year if he's not to be worse off in his retirement.

Is that social justice?

Another man told me he's just retiring. Gordon Brown's abolished the married couple's allowance and age allowance. The man will have to pay £500 a year more in tax than his brother who retired last year.

Is that social justice?

In Suffolk last week a mother of four children, a beautician, told me she's been driven out of business by Gordon Brown. She can't afford to fill her tank with the most expensive petrol in Europe.

Call that social justice, Mr Brown?

There is no social justice in high taxation.

The Prime Minister devoted a large part of his Brighton speech to smearing the Conservatives. People long ago stopped believing Mr Blair when he spins his own policies let alone when he falsifies ours. People found his speech not only unbelievable but also disillusioning. Wasn't he meant to bring a new honesty to politics? Why can't he behave like a Prime Minister?

Before the election Labour claimed it was no longer addicted to high public spending, that the amount we spend is less important than how well we spend it. They committed themselves to stick to Conservative spending plans, because they knew that our prudence was a foundation of economic stability.

But as the events of the last few weeks have shown, this is not a Chancellor whose word is his bond.

Our economy has been growing since 1992. That gives us an opportunity to increase public spending. I plan to spend more on public services in every year than Labour has spent in any year. But I don't intend to spend money the country hasn't earned. I will leave room for tax cuts.

Labour taxes more and delivers less, and plans higher taxes year after year. Conservatives will tax less, spend better and deliver more. That will be the choice at the next election.

We will cut taxes on business, so that they can compete and create prosperity and jobs.

We will reform Labour's taxes on entrepreneurs and on inward investment.

We will encourage savings, to give people security and self-esteem.

We will help pensioners and hard-working families.

We will restore a married couple's allowance.

We will cut the duty on fuel.

That gives you a flavour of my budgets!

We will keep an independent Bank of England. We will make it more independent of government and more accountable to Parliament.

We will establish a National Accounts Commission to show the world that under the Conservatives there will be no fiddled figures.

And we will have an independent committee of economists to give public advice to me on the proper level of surplus or deficit.

These measures will ensure honesty, transparency and prudence.

They will ensure stable economic policies. They will protect the value of the pound in your pocket.

And when I say the pound I mean the pound. For our economic policy will be based on Britain having its own currency and setting its own interest rates.

Gordon Brown wants to be the next Chancellor of the Exchequer and he can't tell you whether he wants to control his own currency or not.

Labour like to call us little Englanders. Is it likely a little Englander would be called Portillo? I am half Spanish, and proud of it. I am a true European, someone with a love of Europe's different cultures.

As the Spanish proverb goes: Antes de que te cases, mira lo que haces. Before you get yourself hitched, watch what you're doing. Look before you leap.

The euro plan fails to respect Europe's differences. It shoe horns all the economies of Europe, with their different qualities and cycles and stages of development, into just one currency, and just one interest rate.

It threatens to take Europe back to boom and bust. The Irish now have high inflation. But there's nothing they can do about it. When Ireland joined the euro it gave up the right to set its own interest rates.

In Germany the economy seems to be faltering. For Germany the single European interest rate is too high.

Not surprisingly, one interest rate for all of Europe is wrong for most places most of the time.

And here's the rub. Supposing the people of Ireland want to vote against the policies that are driving up their prices? They can't do it. Their elected government doesn't make the policy. The critical political decisions about growth and jobs in Ireland are being taken by the European Central Bank.

And who votes for the European Central Bank? No one. It's wholly unaccountable.

The most precious thing in Europe is democracy. Mr Blair hoped to bamboozle Britain into joining the euro. He hoped to scare us like children with tales of how frightening it would be to be left out. Denmark has shown that people cannot be fooled or bullied by arrogant politicians.

Mr Blair please take note.

At the election we will oppose the euro. British public opinion is suspicious of the euro as an unproven piece of political dogma. That is our view. That is the view of the moderate majority. We want to keep the pound.

And remember this. The euro is a bright idea recommended by the people who brought us the Dome!

Labour is leading Britain in the wrong direction. Compared with the United States we are under-performing. Labour is weighing us down with regulations and taxes. It's making us uncompetitive. It'll throw away our national goal of full employment.

Last week Tony Blair talked about Britain in his usual cool Britannia terms. In reality Labour lack confidence in Britain and seem ashamed of it. They are defeatist, thinking there's no future for us unless we are more and more absorbed into Europe, less and less able to make choices for ourselves.

It's amazing that the government of the world's fourth largest economy should have given up the game.

Conservatives recognise the need for Britain to be globally competitive and produce global companies. If we commit ourselves to maintain control of our own currency and taxes, to be agile and open to change, to cut regulation and make our taxes competitive with the world, we can make Britain the outstanding enterprise centre in Europe.

We have a vision that fits our times.

William Hague has led this party out of dark days. I have never seen anyone face difficulty with such composure. He has real courage. The courage Britain needs in its next Prime Minister.

The quality of British life cannot be measured in material terms alone. I will not forget the experiences I had while out of parliament.

We will be the party of tax cuts, and welfare reform. Of social justice and full employment.

We will use the months ahead to be ready for government, to win the trust of the people that Labour has betrayed.

We are a party that believes in Britain, a party for all our people, a party that offers them aspiration and hope.

If we commit ourselves to maintain control of our own currency and taxes, to be agile and open to change, to cut regulation and make our taxes competitive with the world, we can make Britain the outstanding enterprise centre in Europe. We have a vision that fits our times. William Hague has led this party out of dark days. I have never seen anyone face difficulty with such composure. He has real courage. The courage Britain needs in its next Prime Minister. The quality of British life cannot be measured in material terms alone. I will not forget the experiences I had while out of parliament. We will be the party of tax cuts, and welfare reform. Of social justice and full employment. We will use the months ahead to be ready for government, to win the trust of the people that Labour has betrayed. We are a party that believes in Britain, a party for all our people, a party that offers them aspiration and hope.

fields.headline: Administrators called into Powernet Telecom
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Administrators have been called into Powernet Telecom, Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
Administrators have been called into Powernet Telecom, the Manchester-based internet company which owns ISP TotalServe and internet incubator fund PowerTen.

Arthur Andersen partners Simon Allport and Richard Fleming have been appointed to administer the group. Staff and a business partners have been told that they won't be paid and, according to a report in the Sunday Times this weekend, the group's 85 employees were evicted from their offices by police on Friday afternoon.

Chief executive Ian Carey, a former advertising executive at Saatchi & Saatchi, founded Powernet in 1993. His previous company Callfree Directories went into voluntary liquidation, and Mr Carey received a court ruling banning him from being a company director for five years. He managed to overturn the ruling on appeal and was given permission to continue running Powernet subject to strict conditions.

Arthur Andersen said it was uncertain at this stage of the level of group debt because of Powernet's high cash burn rate. Some £8m was spent this year on an above-the-line ad campaign for TotalServe through McCann-Erickson's Manchester office.

Less than three months ago Powernet said it planned to create 500 new jobs over the next year to cope with a planned increase in TotalServe subscribers. At the time the company was planning an IPO which some analysts speculated could value it at £1bn.

Powernet blamed the collapse on failed efforts to raise finance after it abandoned a £600m IPO. It was reported to have raised £84m in July this year to fund its expansion plans. It is not clear what happened to this money, although a number of high-profile deals, such as a £13m deal with Cisco Systems and a planned £150m spend on infrastructure, could have contributed to the cash burn.

fields.headline: Dyson wins vacuum cleaner battle
fields.trailText: The battle of the vacuum cleaners was won by Dyson Appliances today when a high court judge held that Hoover had infringed the patent on bagless dust-collection.
fields.body:
The battle of the vacuum cleaners was won by Dyson Appliances today when a high court judge held that Hoover had infringed the patent on bagless dust-collection.

The judge, Mr Justice Fysh, said that in the light of his technical findings after comparison of the two products, Dyson's claim of patent breach succeeded.

He added that a Hoover counter-claim that the Dyson cleaner lacked novelty should be dismissed.

The parties are to return to court on October 13, when the question of injunctions banning further sales of Hoover products which infringe the Dyson patent will be considered.

Inventor James Dyson, who was at court today, said he was also seeking damages which could run into millions of pounds.

"I am very pleased I spent 20 years developing this technology, and I am very pleased to see Hoover - who made a lot of false claims about their product - have been found guilty of patent infrigement."

Mr Dyson had accused Hoover of infringing a Dyson patent with its Hoover Triple Vortex - a new Hoover machine that works with a cyclone instead of the traditional vacuum cleaner bag.

Dyson's patent for a "vacuum cleaning appliance" was originally granted in December 1995. The company said Hoover had infringed one of the patents of its "dual cyclone" technology.

webTitle: BBC signs video on demand deal

fields.headline: BBC signs video-on-demand deal
fields.trailText: 9.30am: BBC Worldwide has signed a deal with video-on-demand provider Video Networks, Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide has signed a deal with video-on-demand provider Video Networks that will allow BBC programming to be seen on demand.

The details of programmes included in the deal, inked at this week's Mipcom 2000, have yet to be finalised. But the package is likely to see classic British programmes made available to subscribers to the Video Networks service Home Choice, which launched its London facillity last week.

Video Networks has already struck deals giving it access to content from Warner Brothers, Channel 4 International and Disney, as well as some BBC Sport programmes.

fields.headline: Conference diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative conference 2000
fields.trailText: The organisers expect an instant return to government. Conference standing orders state: "The expression 'winding-up' speech shall mean the speech made at the end of a debate by a minister or other person invited by the chairman."
fields.byline: Peter Bottomley, Tory MP for Worthing West
fields.body:
The organisers expect an instant return to government. Conference standing orders state: "The expression 'winding-up' speech shall mean the speech made at the end of a debate by a minister or other person invited by the chairman."

In Channel 4's pre-conference documentary Just William... and Ffion it was intriguing to see a selection of star Guardian writers asking William Hague to gain their votes. Did the editing leave out congratulations for becoming Conservative leader against the initial odds? Why didn't they comment on the fact that few estimable political journalists anticipated Tory success in European, local or London assembly elections?

It is true that everyone misses parts of the conference and its fringes. Reporters may have been on the train when Judith Edwards, tax barrister and prospective candidate for Liverpool Riverside, spoke in the effective discussion on women's choices - for a future generation, in the workplace and for families. She is the Conservative equivalent to Labour's Patricia Scotland and Helena Kennedy. Perhaps a 16-year-old young white star from Yorkshire attracts more attention than a grown-up black woman from Lancashire.

At the successful meeting on "blue and black in Britain" some journalists came for Steven Norris's major contribution. I wish more had heard and reported what home affairs spokesman John Bercow contributed, as well as the fair, well-received critique by the Guardian's Gary Younge.

Peter Bottomley is a Conservative MP and former minister

fields.headline: Archer faces perjury charges
fields.trailText:
Millionaire author Lord Archer appeared at Bow Street Magistrates Court, central 
London, today  to face five charges of perverting the course of justice and 
perjury.
fields.body:
Millionaire author Lord Archer appeared at Bow Street Magistrates Court, central London, today to face five charges of perverting the course of justice and perjury.

The allegations centre on claims that he asked a friend to lie for him during his 1987 libel trial with the Daily Star.

The peer arrived at Bow Street Magistrates Court, central London, at 10.23am in a chauffeur-driven dark green BMW. Wearing a navy blue suit, blue shirt and red striped tie he was greeted at the court with a blaze of flashlights from waiting photographers.

The charges were read out and the hearing lasted approximately ten minutes. Lord Archer was later remanded on bail until 14 November.

Earlier his former friend Ted Francis arrived to face a single charge of perverting the course of justice.

The allegations centre on claims that the author asked a friend to lie for him during his 1987 libel trial with the Daily Star.

Archer faces two counts of perverting the course of justice, two of perjury and one of making a false instrument.

Tonight the best-selling novelist is due to star again in his courtroom drama The Accused at the Theatre Royal in Windsor.

At the end of each performance the audience is invited to decide on the guilt or innocence of Archer's character - a doctor accused of murdering his wife.

fields.headline: Panorama journalists angry at new Sunday slot
fields.standfirst:
Panorama moves to Sunday
BBC sets date for news move
Bland defends news move
Reaction
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Panorama journalists are "indignant" at the BBC's decision to move its news bulletin and current affairs flagship programme, according to an insider at the programme. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Panorama journalists are "indignant" at the BBC's decision to move its news bulletin and current affairs flagship programme, according to an insider at the programme.

He told MediaGuardian the mood among Panorama reporters was "pretty bad". Another source said that while journalists had known for a long time that the corporation was threatening to move the bulletin, they were shocked by the speed at which it happened.

Speculation has surrounded the future of the current affairs show since May when the programme's run was cut by eight episodes. Suggestions have included splitting the series between BBC1 and BBC2 and cutting the programme's run to 40 minutes.

However, a BBC news spokesman said the move could prove beneficial, adding that "it's still a very big programme". But insiders said they would have preferred Panorama to have taken a 40-minute midweek slot.

The programme is still seeking an editor after the promotion of Peter Horrocks earlier this year to head of BBC current affairs. Favourites are thought to include Newsnight editor Sian Kevill and the incumbent acting editor, Karen O'Connor.

Ms O'Connor was not available for comment.

fields.headline: Goodkind makes PR comeback with Frank
fields.trailText: 8am: Graham Goodkind, co-founder of Another.com and former managing director of Lynne Franks PR, has launched himself back into PR with a new agency called Frank PR. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Graham Goodkind, co-founder of Another.com and former managing director of Lynne Franks PR, has taken a step back from the dot.com start-up world and launched himself back into PR with a new agency called Frank PR.

Mr Goodkind has teamed up with two associate directors of Ketchum Life, the company formed after Lynne Franks PR was merged with Ketchum in 1998, to set up the business. He becomes chairman of the company, with Andrew Bloch and Nadia Gabbie named joint managing directors.

Marketing consultancy Branded has taken a strategic investment in Frank PR, which is already working on PR strategy for Telegram Teddies - an online teddy bear shop - Shopfittingsdirect.com and Amstrad. Mr Goodkind said he expected to launch a new media division dedicated to these clients once the agency had found its feet.

He added: "We're called Frank PR as our approach to public relations is frank, honest, open, down-to-earth and no bullshit - a bit of a departure from the norm in this industry. Given our backgrounds, we also aim to take the 'best bits' from the Lynne Franks PR days into the 'noughties'."

Mr Goodkind is now focusing full time on Frank PR, although he remains a director of web email firm Another.com, and says he is "in and out of there every week, but not in any executive capacity".

Explaining his reasons for the move, he added: "PR is my first love. I'd always wanted to go back into it and, as I'm naturally quite an all-or-nothing person, I can only throw myself in to it 100% to make it a success.

"My passion is creating, getting things up and running and giving them energy. Having taken funmail to Another.com, getting 1m-plus registered users and raising $10m (£m) last year, I reckon I'd done my bit."

Another.com is now being run on a day-to-day basis by Troels Henriksen and Steve Bowbrick.

fields.trailText: ZIMBABWE v NEW ZEALAND
fields.body:
ZIMBABWE v NEW ZEALAND

1st Test, Bulawayo
September 12-16 New Zealand won by 7 wickets
Debuts Richardson (NZ), Mutendera (Zim)
*Zimbabwe 350 in 175.2 overs (Campbell 88, Streak 51, Wiseman 5-90) and 119 in 67.5 overs (Cairns 5-31)
New Zealand 338 in 153.5 overs (Horne 110, McMillan 58, Paul Strang 8-109) and 132 for 3 in 45.4 overs

NZ won their 1st Test in Zim for 8 years. 1st inns Campbell scored his 1st Test 50 for two-and-a-half years. Wiseman (MoM, BB) claimed his 2nd Test 5-for. When he dismissed Andy Flower, Cairns moved 2nd in NZ's all-time wicket-list on 161, ahead of Danny Morrison, but 270 behind Sir Richard Hadlee. 2nd inns Horne scored his 4th Test hundred, passing 50 for 1st time since his last century (100 v Eng at Lord's, 1999), 19 innings ago. Strang took 10-158, his 1st ten-wicket haul and only the 2nd by a Zim (Adam Huckle, 11-255 v NZ at Bulawayo, 1997-98). Strang's 8-109 were the best for Zim, beating Streak's 6-87 v Eng at Lord's, 1999. Parore and Vettori put on 78 for the 9th wicket, a record for NZ v Zim. 3rd inns Cairns took his 10th 5-for. When Parore caught Mutendera, he reached 150 dismissals in Tests. 4th inns On the final day, Grant Flower was no-balled three times for throwing in one over by square-leg Umpire Darrell Hair. John Rennie bowled the final three deliveries of the over.

2nd Test, Harare
September 19-23 New Zealand won by 8 wickets
Debuts None
*New Zealand 465 in 160.3 overs (Richardson 99, Astle 86, Cairns 124, Nash 62) and 74 for 2 in 15.2 overs
Zimbabwe 166 in 92 overs and 370 in 178.3 overs (Andy Flower 65, Whittall 188*, Streak 54, O'Connor 4-73)

New Zealand won with 16 balls to spare to take series 2-0 and become the 1st side to win both Tests of a two-match series in Zim. Fleming became NZ's most successful captain with 12 wins in 29 Tests (prev Geoff Howarth 11 in 30) 1st inns Richardson the 6th NZ to be dismissed for 99. Olonga the 5th Zim to move to 50 Test wickets (Parore). Cairns 4th Test 100, 2nd v Zim. His stand of 144 with Nash was NZ's best for 8th wkt against all countries (prev Nash and Vettori, 137 v India at Wellington, 1998-99). NZ's total of 465 their best v Zim (prev 460 at Auckland, 1997-98) 3rd inns Whittall's 3rd Test 100: 472 minutes, 429 balls, 27x4, 2x6.

fields.headline: Open takes Big Brother idea up the aisle
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Open TV plans to capitalise on the popularity of reality TV with a wedding game show scheduled to start next month, Claire Cozens writes.
fields.body:
Open TV has become the latest broadcaster to capitalise on the popularity of reality TV with a wedding game show scheduled to start next month.

Thousands of couples will compete for the chance to have a dream wedding paid for and broadcast by Open TV in a tie-up with OK! Magazine, which will also cover the wedding. The catch? Everything from the dress to the best man will be decided by the viewers via a Big Brother-style viewers' poll.

Barnaby Dawe, head of brand marketing for Open, said: "It's all about handing the decision-making over to Open viewers. It will be a fly-on-the-wall documentary with a difference in that it will also be interactive."

The search for the couple will begin next month with a series of regional heats. The winning pair will be announced on December 30. They will then be followed by the cameras until the wedding on June 2 next year, with viewers voting every week.

Reassuringly, viewers will be allowed to choose between three things in each category (dress, honeymoon destination, venue etc), and will not be given complete control. "The couple won't end up on a honeymoon in Skegness; all the choices will be attractive," said Mr Dawe.

Mr Dawe said the idea for the show arose from the popularity of Open's weekly polls, in which viewers vote on the major issues of the week. OK! Magazine was an obvious partner because it already has a site on the Open platform.

webTitle: Wallace appointed Mirror head of news

fields.headline: Wallace appointed Mirror head of news
fields.trailText: 12.30pm update: The Mirror's showbusiness editor, Richard Wallace, is to be made head of news in editor Piers Morgan's first major shake-up of the newsdesk.
fields.body:
Mirror editor Piers Morgan has instigated the first major shake-up of the paper's newsdesk since he took over as editor four years ago.

The Mirror's showbusiness editor, Richard Wallace is to be promoted to head of news, according to senior sources at the newspaper. Eugene Duffy, currently head of news, will move to the back bench as associate editor (news) taking on what is described by senior sources as a "troubleshooter" role.

Conor Hanna, currently number three on the day newsdesk, will become news editor while David Leigh, number one on the newsdesk, is said to be considering various options within the paper.

Anthony Harwood is likely to remain deputy news editor while Wallace's job running the showbiz team is likely to be taken by his long-standing number two, Kevin O'Sullivan.

Sources close to Morgan say that the editor felt the news operation had become stagnant with too few exclusive stories. He has told friends: "Politics is showbiz for ugly people so this is a natural transition for Richard Wallace."

Trade magazine Press Gazette recently ran a leaked memo from Mr Morgan, critising the news operation. It began: "It's 9.45am and the newsroom resembles the offices of a Norwegian bank that has recently been put into receivership. There's hardly anyone here, we have no stories for tomorrow's paper at all and apparently no idea how this situation is going to change through the course of the day."

The managing director of Express Newspapers, Andy Jonesco, has been elected chairman of the Newspaper Publishers' Association. He replaces Roger Eastoe, who resigned as Trinity Mirror managing director last month.

Mr Jonesco, who was deputy managing director and advertising director of Express Newspapers, was promoted to managing director earlier this year. Before joining Express Newspapers he was sales director at the Telegraph.

Kevin Beatty, the chief operating officer of Associated New Media, becomes NPA chairman.

webTitle: After the ceasefire, whither the peace?

fields.headline: After the ceasefire, whither the peace?
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown on where the Middle East peace process can go now
fields.trailText: Derek Brown on where the Middle East peace process can go now.
fields.body:
Long after the 50-plus victims of the last spasm of Middle East violence are cold in their graves, arguments will rage over what provoked the bloodshed. Israelis are reluctant to share the widespread Arab view that the spark which ignited the fire was last week's visit to Jerusalem's most holy mosque complex, the Haram as-Sharif, by the vitriolically rightwing Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon.

To Israelis, the Haram as-Sharif is the Temple Mount, the very heart of Judaism. Many believe that Sharon had an absolute right to be there, even though the mosque is off-limits to Jews. Today's Jerusalem Post carries an opinion poll suggesting that only 29% of Israelis believe that Sharon sparked the violence.

Most, apparently, prefer to believe the official Israeli explanation for the eruption of violence, that it was largely directed by Palestinian leaders in the West Bank and Gaza strip. There is little if any evidence to support that claim, and in any case it does not explain the ominous spillover of violence into Israel itself.

There have been riots and gunbattles inside Israel itself, in Galilee and other districts that are home to a large and highly discontented Arab minority, which accounts for 15% of Israel's 6.2m population. Though prime minister Erhud Barak's government is committed to raising living standards and removing discrimination, the Arab community - nearly a million strong - is visibly Israel's poor relation.

The most plausible explanation for the resumption of street fighting is that Sharon's astonishingly provocative act was simply the detonator that set off an already ticking bomb of Arab frustration, both in Israel and the Palestinian territories.

It is more than seven years since Yasser Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin shook hands on the White House lawn. It is more than three years since their historic deal was supposed to produce a comprehensive peace settlement. Yet still the region is mired in hatred and recrimination, uncertainty and fear.

The 1993 accord, negotiated secretly in Norway, was made possible only because both parties agreed to put the most contentious issues on the back burner. The idea was to establish trust, and then make incremental progress towards lancing the boils on the Middle East body politic.

That was not a mistake. Indeed, there is every reason to suppose that if they had attempted a full-scale instant agreement, the enterprise would have foundered at the outset.

Nor is it true to say that that the deal remains bogged down in its tentative Oslo form. There has been, by any standard, remarkable progress towards the Holy Grail of a permanent settlement.

At their Camp David summit in July, Arafat and Barak came agonisingly close to wrapping up a final package. Three of the four outstanding issues, each of them explosive enough to blow the entire process apart, were effectively settled.

Barak was prepared to hand over 90% of the West Bank to the control of Arafat's Palestinian National Authority, and was even reportedly offering to cede pockets of Arab-inhabited territory inside Israel.

The knotty issue of Jewish settlements was also tidied up, with Israel retaining sovereignty and security control of small patches of West Bank territory adjoining its own borders.

There was even agreement on the huge and festering issue of the Palestinian diaspora: the 6m refugees scattered around the region and beyond, most of them living in squalor. Israel was prepared to allow tens of thousands to return to their ancestral homes, with the rest to be aided by an international fund.

That left the biggest, thorniest, and most emotional issue: the future status of Jerusalem, which the Arabs call Al-Quds.

For decades, Arafat and the PLO have insisted that their objective is a sovereign Palestinian state, with Jerusalem as its capital. Since 1967, when Israeli troops captured the Old City and the West Bank from Jordan, Israel has been equally adamant that the city will remain forever united, as the capital of the Jewish state.

Yet even this apparently unbridgeable chasm has begun to narrow. Arafat's people have started to talk of Islamic, rather than Palestinian, control of the Haram as-Sharif. Ehud Barak, even this week as the fighting raged, was talking to the Jerusalem Post about two capitals, Jerusalem and Al Quds, existing side by side.

In the international clamour for both sides to call a halt to the fighting and get back to the negotiating table, both Barak and Arafat are under heavy diplomatic pressure to take the last lunge towards a permanent settlement. It is much more likely, however, that they will do what has become second nature over the past seven angry, bloodsoaked years: stitch together a new interim agreement, and pledge themselves that one day, very soon, they really will get down to resolving the future of Jerusalem.

webTitle: O&M wins pitch to get UK online

fields.headline: O&M wins three-way pitch to land online task
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Ogilvy & Mather has been chosen by the government to get the UK online after the agency beat D'Arcy & Grey in a three-way pitch.
fields.body:
Ogilvy & Mather has been chosen by the government to get the UK online after the agency beat D'Arcy & Grey in a three-way pitch.

O&M will create a fully integrated campaign, due to break this year across different media, to promote a network of learning centres and a government portal. It will be a long-running campaign, the aim of which will be get the whole country onto the internet.

The budget for the campaign has not been disclosed, but the size and duration of the drive would suggest that the government is expected to invest a substantial sum in marketing the initiative.

Free learning centres will be set up across the country and private-public partnerships will be extablished, so that users can get online for the cost of a cut-price phone call.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, recently promised to deliver 452 public services electronically by 2005, a date that was brought forward in April from 2008. More than one third - 152 - of those services are already online, including the National Statistics site, Companies House and Ordnance Survey.

fields.headline: 'Who told you, Mr. Barak, that Jerusalem belongs to the Zionists?'
fields.standfirst: What the Arab and Israeli papers say
fields.trailText: What the Arab and Israeli papers say.
fields.body:
Any impartial observer will concur that Palestinians have already gone the extra mile and made enough concessions in return for which they received nothing. Israel's non-compliance with a string of international peace accords is a case in point. Israeli leaders, whether from Likud or Labour, have developed the crippling habit of haggling about agreements even before the ink dries.

Egyptian Gazette.

The events presently unfolding in Jerusalem should sound an alarm to those who have been tempted by their own power to stray, tampering with peoples' destinies, making light of the reaction of the Palestinian and Arab people on the street, and going one step too far by violating the sanctity of sacred places.

Fahmi Howeidi in Al Ahram.

Who told you, Mr. Barak, that Jerusalem belongs to the Zionists? Who said we were ready to accept a partition? We will have the entire city back without ceding an inch of its sacred land. At our moment of weakness, you have thought we could be made to forget the facts of history and of geography? You have believed our nation to be dead, and our Jerusalem to be fair game? But you believe wrongly. For Jerusalem is our life; it is the future for which we have been waiting for long decades, the soul without which a body would decay. Have you known anyone to surrender his soul?

Mustafa Al Bakri from the Egyptian weekly, Al Osbo'u.

It is not at all clear, as much as Palestinian Authority Chairman Yasser Arafat might want to be "credited" with inciting Israeli Arabs, that he has the ability to do so. Israeli Arabs may at times call themselves Palestinians, and even identify fervently with the Palestinian cause. At the same time, it is a fair guess that few Israeli Arabs would consider moving to a Palestinian state, or would envy their brethren who are already living under Arafat's rule.

Jerusalem Post editorial

Most Israeli Jews view Arabs as their fellow citizens, while respecting their heritage, their religion and their culture. A large Jewish public wants to involve Israeli Arabs in the fateful decisions that must be made in the course of negotiations with the Palestinian Authority. Loss of faith in the Arab community and its representatives is liable to strengthen the separatist strain among the Jewish public - a development that will affect both the nature of Israel's government and the entire region.

Ha'aretz

fields.headline: Mark Chapman
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about John Lennon's killer, whose first parole bid has been rejected
fields.trailText: All you need to know about John Lennon's killer, whose first parole bid has been rejected.
fields.body:
1. Mark Chapman's first application for parole at Attica State Prison has been rejected. He was sentenced 20 years ago to life in prison for murdering John Lennon, with no parole until 2000.

2. He shot the ex-Beatle from point-blank range outside the Dakota building in New York City on December 8 1980. Had Lennon survived, he would have been 60 on October 9.

3. Lennon's millions of distraught fans aren't too happy and want to see Chapman remain in the choky where he belongs.

4. But was Lennon's murder what it seems? It didn't exactly come as a surprise in February this year when it was revealed that the FBI had been bugging the peace-loving musician for years, even going as far as logging "subversive" remarks made by a parrot at an activists' meeting.

5. Naturally, the Feds' murky involvement in Lennon's life has fuelled all manner of conspiracy theories about his death.

6. Such speculation, one of the USA's top export industries, falls along rather familiar lines. One is that Chapman may not have been working alone.

7. Going one better, some people have even suggested that Chapman was an MC, or Manchurian Candidate, programmed by sinister government forces to waste the musician.

8. Spooky, huh? Those at the less rabid end of the conspiracy-theory market prosaically comb over the details of Chapman's life for clues about why he felt compelled to kill his idol.

9. Chapman's identification with Holden Caulfield, the irked hero of JD Salinger's cult novel Catcher in the Rye, has raised much interest. He was carrying the book with him on the day of the murder.

10. Whatever the reason, it's likely that Chapman was just one of the more decisive in the great lineage of disturbed celebrity stalkers. But if you feel it was something more sinister - and fear that the same may happen to you, then take this test.

fields.headline: Book trade news
fields.standfirst: More woe for Waterstone's | Cherry shortage at HarperCollins | Booker rumours abound | Dynamic pricing comes of age
fields.trailText: More woe for Waterstone's | Cherry shortage at HarperCollins | Booker rumours abound | Dynamic pricing comes of age
fields.body:
More woe for Waterstone's

Whither Waterstone's? Britain's largest bookseller picked the week of the first anniversary of its flagship Piccadilly store to reveal that sales are still falling within the chain.

Waterstone's recorded a 3.8% decline in like-for-like sales in its shops during the three months to the end of July, the first quarter of its financial year. By contrast, its sister company HMV managed a 3.9% rise in turnover. It is not the first time that Waterstone's has witnessed a contraction of its business. This latest fall was in fact an increase on the 3.7% decline in like-for-like sales seen in its last financial year. The accelerating decline is a signal that managing director David Kneale's 'three-point strategy', designed to reverse the decline in Waterstone's fortunes, has yet to show any signs of working.

Alan Giles, chief executive of parent company HMV Media and former managing director of Waterstone's, attributed the fall to everything from the impact of the internet to lower spending from schools. But publishers, who have borne witness for more than a year to falling morale within the chain after the incoming managing director imposed a recruitment freeze and curtailed individual booksellers' powers to buy books, will have treated the excuses with some scepticism. For those publishers who have recently suffered from Waterstone's destocking policies the response might more properly have been described as schadenfreude were their businesses not so dependent on Waterstone's own performance.

Waterstone's problems have been mounting almost from the moment Mr Giles and Tim Waterstone, the original founder of the chain, led a management buyout of the business (alongside the smaller book chain Dillons and the music chain HMV) from their respective parents WH Smith and EMI, saddling themselves with more than £500m of debt and a nagging requirement to float on the stock exchange. Things might have progressed more smoothly had the American bookseller Borders not chosen to enter the UK market at roughly the same time, signalling the start of a race for space which Waterstone's could ill-afford and which Mr Giles now appears to regret. The fact that Jeff Bezos's improbable proposition of an internet-based bookshop called Amazon proved anything but improbable only served to compound their troubles.

That Waterstone's Piccadilly store has not turned into a bookselling Millennium Dome is due, in no small measure, to a public relations machine which shrouds the performance of the shop in secrecy. Some in the trade believe the shop is haemorrhaging money, others that it was a necessary fillip for the group in the face of the Borders expansion. But few regard it as a success. Waterstone's says the shop is trading ahead of expectations, a neat way of avoiding the real issue. The news that Mr Waterstone, now non-executive vice chairman of the group he helped to instigate, wants to buy back the bookshop chain, and seems to have secured backing for a £250m bid, merely clouds the issue still further.

It is doubtful that Mr Giles, regarded as the real architect behind the success of the chain after Mr Waterstone sold it to WH Smith, will want to offload it to his non-executive chairman. But with powerful groups such as Bertelsmann and US bookseller Barnes & Noble waiting in the wings and Mr Kneale's vision clearly not working it can only be a matter of time before Waterstone's is detached from the rest of the group.

Waterstone's poor performance was put into harsher perspective when rival bookselling chain Ottakar's released sales figures which showed that the market was perhaps a little more buoyant than Mr Giles would have the outside world believe.

Ottakar's, which is about a quarter of the size of Waterstone's, recorded comparable store sales growth of 7.4% during the 26-week period to July 29. For those who need more objective evidence of Ottakar's success and Waterstone's failings, BookTrack, which records books sales on the high street and in supermarkets, has reported that the market was up by almost 10% in the first half of the year.

Cherry shortage at HarperCollins

Unhappy meetings over at HarperCollins, too, where Victoria Barnsley's efforts to reel in her first acquisition since taking over as chief executive are reported to have proved more problematic than the plucky publisher would have liked.

HarperCollins announced earlier this month that it had agreed to purchase "selected assets" of the failed mind, body and spirit publisher Element from the receiver. But now Bridgewater Books, the company that created many of the books for Element, has stated that it holds the rights to the publisher's entire illustrated backlist, including works by mind, body and spirit overlords Lillian Too and Yuri Geller. Ms Barnsley, not widely experienced in asset stripping companies, could well find herself with a shortage of cherries left to pick.

Booker rumours abound

Ms Barnsley should at least find succour from the announcement of the Booker shortlist on October 5, with HarperCollins widely expected to have at least one book among the five nominated. Super-Cannes, JG Ballard's follow-up to Cocaine Nights, is thought to be a strong contender, while Amitav Ghosh's The Glass Palace is proving popular among London's literati.

Other titles thought to be in the general vicinity of the shortlist include Michael Ondaatje's Anil's Ghost and Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin. Zadie Smith's White Teeth remains the strong favourite, despite some recent negative criticism, although it is questionable whether it will be the choice among booksellers, who generally prefer titles which have not already sold 24,000 copies in hardback to gain the prize and the subsequent sales boost.

Dynamic pricing comes of age

Meanwhile, bookselling in the virtual realm continues apace with Amazon.com becoming the first online retailer to experiment with what has been termed 'dynamic pricing'. The concept, which helps to explain why companies have invested so much money over the years gathering information about their clientele, involves charging customers what the retailer thinks they should be able to afford rather than a blanket price. Amazon, which reportedly offered DVDs at different prices to different customers, has denied that it was testing a system of pricing based on customer demographics.

However, not everyone is convinced by the e-tailer's denials. Internet consultant Vernon Keenan told the Washington Post: "Dynamic pricing is the new reality, and it's going to be used by more and more retailers. In the future, what you pay will be determined by where you live and who you are. It's unfair, but that doesn't mean it's not going to happen."

It is hard to believe that booksellers in the UK would ever have the chutzpah (or the sophistication) to try and push up prices in wealthier areas but Waterstone's head office, which likes to think it has an upmarket clientele, must be following events closely.

Amazon, which reportedly offered DVDs at different prices to different customers, has denied that it was testing a system of pricing based on customer demographics. However, not everyone is convinced by the e-tailer's denials. Internet consultant Vernon Keenan told the Washington Post: "Dynamic pricing is the new reality, and it's going to be used by more and more retailers. In the future, what you pay will be determined by where you live and who you are. It's unfair, but that doesn't mean it's not going to happen." It is hard to believe that booksellers in the UK would ever have the chutzpah (or the sophistication) to try and push up prices in wealthier areas but Waterstone's head office, which likes to think it has an upmarket clientele, must be following events closely.

fields.headline: Middle East fighting restarts
fields.standfirst:
• Ceasefire breaks down
• Israeli and Palestinian officials agree to meet in Egypt and Paris
• 51 dead so far

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
• Ceasefire breaks down
• Israeli and Palestinian officials agree to meet in Egypt and Paris
• 51 dead so far

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.body:
Palestinian gunmen and Israeli troops have exchanged fire today in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, ending a tentative ceasefire that lasted barely half a day and threatening hopes of reviving Mideast peace.

Hospital officials in Gaza said one man was killed and 10 were seriously wounded in the firefight at an Israeli army outpost near the isolated settlement of Netzarim. In the West Bank town of Nablus, gunmen returning from a funeral fired on a tiny Israeli enclave, drawing return fire.

There were also reports of shots fired in the West Bank town of Ramallah.

Israeli and Palestinian security officials today reached a new agreement to try to end fierce fighting as the US intensified diplomatic efforts.

President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today said that the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, have agreed to come to Egypt to discuss ways of ending the Israeli-Palestinian violence.

Mr Mubarak did not say when the meeting will take place. But David Baker, spokesman for Mr Barak's office, said in Jerusalem the Israeli leader will leave for Egypt on Thursday to attend the summit.

Mr Mubarak said the gathering will be held at the Red Sea resort of Sharm El-Sheikh, where Mr Arafat and Mr Barak met last year and signed an interim peace deal.

"The aim of such a summit is to lay the foundations for a comprehensive settlement for all the outstanding questions," Mr Mubarak told reporters during a tour of a major agricultural project in southern Egypt.

The outbreak of violence has left at least 51 dead - mostly Palestinians - and Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, have agreed to meet the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, in Paris tomorrow.

The two leaders are to meet Mrs Albright separately, but the US clearly would like them to negotiate face to face to defuse a crisis that threatens to derail any hopes for a peace settlement. Meanwhile, reports of a new agreement to stop the fighting will buttress international diplomatic peace efforts.

But as the US tried to broker a peace deal, it blocked agreement early this morning on a UN Security Council response to the fighting by forestalling a public meeting that would have given Arab states an open forum to condemn Israel.

The council met in emergency consultations late Monday at the request of the Palestinians, who accused Israel of using lethal force against civilians, in violation of the Geneva Conventions, in five days of fighting. But after nearly six hours of closed-door negotiations, the council broke early today, unable to agree on the text of a statement to be adopted at the close of an open meeting which is now tentatively scheduled for this afternoon.

The US objected to references in the proposed statement that referred to violations of the Fourth Geneva Convention, which says an occupying power must guarantee the protection of civilians in areas it occupies.

Washington is reluctant to describe east Jerusalem as occupied, maintaining the status of Jerusalem must be worked out in negotiations between the Israelis and Palestinians. US officials said they did not want any council statement to prejudge the outcome of tomorrow's meeting between Mrs Albright, Mr Arafat and Mr Barak.

The UN Palestinian envoy Nasser Al-Kidwa had called for the council meeting, urging ambassadors to intervene to put an end to the fighting and salvage Mideast peace talks. As a first step, he said, the council should call for the immediate withdrawal of Israeli forces from Jerusalem's holiest site and from the vicinity of other Palestinian cities, as well as an investigation of the events of the last few days.

Israel's UN ambassador, Yehuda Lancry, however, said security council intervention now would not be welcome. "Therefore we do encourage our Palestinian partners to put an end to the violence, to disassociate themselves from unfruitful diplomatic steps and to get back to the final round of these negotiations," he said.

The Palestinians have said Israeli opposition leader Ariel Sharon's visit Thursday to the mosques at Jerusalem's holiest site provoked the wave of rioting. Israel says the unrest was orchestrated by the Palestinian Authority in hopes of extracting more concessions in peace negotiations.

fields.headline: Blockbuster trumps ballet
fields.standfirst: After much excitement and hype, Billy Elliot has failed to reach the number one box office spot on its opening weekend in the UK
fields.trailText: After much excitement and hype, Billy Elliot has failed to reach the number one box office spot on its opening weekend in the UK.
fields.body:
After much excitement and hype, Billy Elliot has failed to reach the number one box office spot on its opening weekend in the UK.

Hollow Man, which stars Kevin Bacon as a scientist who discovers a serum which makes him invisible, beat the low-budget BBC/Working Title film by a slim margin of £93,277. However, Billy Elliot still opened with an impressive £1.5m and is expected to overtake the Paul Verhoeven-directed vehicle over a seven-day average.

Billy Elliot tells the story of a young boy's love for ballet dancing and is set against a backdrop of the 1984 miner's strike. Directed by Stephen Daldry, it stars the unknown Jamie Bell as Billy and Julie Walters as his dancing teacher. It opened to much critical acclaim last Friday, with certain swooning critics hailing it the best British film ever.

Last week's number one, Me, Myself and Irene, dropped down to number three in the box office chart, with Scary Movie now in fourth place. Snatch, which has taken over £11m to date, is still on a nice little earner at number five.

webTitle: BBC to move news in thirteen days' time

fields.headline: BBC to move news in 13 days' time
fields.standfirst:
Bland defends news move
Reaction
Panorama moves to Sunday
Panorama reporters angry at new slot
fields.trailText: 12.45pm update: The BBC will move its 9pm bulletin to 10pm, six days a week including Sunday, in 13 days' time, Sir Christopher Bland will confirm this morning. By Janine Gibson.Panorama moves to Sunday
fields.body:
The BBC will move its 9pm bulletin to 10pm, six days a week including Sunday, in 13 days' time, Sir Christopher Bland has confirmed. Current affairs flagship Panorama is also to move to a Sunday night slot.

Speaking at a press conference this morning, Sir Christopher said: "10 o'clock gives us a better opportunity of reporting politics. It helps us to cover North American politics and breaking stories there, particularly at a time when the presidential elections are on. And it gives us better business coverage because the American markets are closed."

BBC governors met last night to examine whether ITV's decision to bring back News at Ten three nights a week should affect the BBC's plan to move to 10pm. Director general Greg Dyke announced in August that BBC1's main bulletin would air at 10pm from next year.

Staff were told this morning that "the ITC fudge", as BBC executives like to style the compromise reached between ITV and its regulator, was not sufficient to deter the BBC. Governors are said to have agreed unanimously to proceed.

However, ITV's move has forced the corporation to move faster than it anticipated. Monday 16 October is seen as a key week for BBC1's autumn schedule so, senior sources say, executives are keen to reinforce new viewing patterns as quickly as possible.

No material changes to the bulletin, other than the introduction of a regular Sunday night slot, have yet emerged. Michael Buerk and Peter Sissons will continue as anchormen on a rota basis and a senior source said that the 9pm's existing focus on international news would continue, adding that the move was ideal for coverage of the US presidential elections.

More to follow including industry reaction

fields.headline: Press review
fields.trailText:
Yugoslavia
Russian president Vladimir Putin's offer to hold talks in Moscow between the two sides of the Yugoslav standoff makes the front pages. The pro-Kremlin Nezavisimaya Gazeta (Independent Newspaper) says "Putin's announcement shows that the Kremlin agrees with the conclusions of the Yugoslav electoral commission - that although the opposition candiate Vojislav Kostunica won in the first round, the secound round should nevertheless go ahead, because no candidate won more than 50% of the votes. This position, obviously, goes against everything being said in the Western capitals". Izvestiya, another pro-government daily, concludes that it is "extremely unlikely" that Belgrade will respond positively to Moscow's proposal.

Yugoslavia
Russian president Vladimir Putin's offer to hold talks in Moscow between the two sides of the Yugoslav standoff makes the front pages. The pro-Kremlin Nezavisimaya Gazeta (Independent Newspaper) says "Putin's announcement shows that the Kremlin agrees with the conclusions of the Yugoslav electoral commission - that although the opposition candiate Vojislav Kostunica won in the first round, the secound round should nevertheless go ahead, because no candidate won more than 50% of the votes. This position, obviously, goes against everything being said in the Western capitals". Izvestiya, another pro-government daily, concludes that it is "extremely unlikely" that Belgrade will respond positively to Moscow's proposal.

Putin's visit to India
Marking the beginning of Putin's first state visit to India, liberal business paper Vedemosti predicts that over the course of the four day trip a series of large-scale arms deals will be announced - continuing Russia's lucrative supply of arms to India, which began in the 1960s and has since then brought Russia some $31 billion income. The Indian government is thought to be particularly interested in purchasing tanks from the Urals. Trud reports that in addition to signing treaties on scientific and technical cooperation and collaboration in the oil and gas industries, Mr Putin is looking forward to receiving an honorary law degree from the Nehru University in Delhi.

Most Bank sold
Vladimir Gusinsky's Most empire - which includes the beleaguered MediaMost television and newspaper holding - received another blow yesterday, according to Vedemosti, when Most Bank (the business which launched Gusinksy as a powerful oligarch) was sold for just $200,000, a mere one rouble per share. In paying such a knockdown price, the buyers - Vneshtorgbank - have agreed to take on some $500 million worth of debts, the paper reports. Although Gusinsky gave up control of the bank several years ago to focus on his media interests, most of the bank's assets are tied up with MediaMost.

Babitsky in court
The bizarre story of Andrei Babitsky - the Radio Free Europe journalist whose reporting of the war in Chechnya irritated the Kremlin - returns to the headlines, with the opening of a court case against him. Babitsky was imprisoned as a result of his work and then handed over to Chechen fighters by the Russians, in a still-unexplained prisoner swap, earlier this year. Reporting from the courtroom in Makhachkala in Dagestan, the region neighbouring Chechnya, a Sevodnya correspondent describes Babitsky's defence against the charge of using a false passport when he was picked up by the Russian police - that he was forced to use it and was in a situation where there was no alternative. The case is expected to conclude before the end of the week.

Olympics
Russia's successful performance in the Olympics is analysed in Kommersant, but the paper's sports commentator questions whether, having taken second place behind America, the country's former reputation for sporting excellence has really been restored. Not only did Russia's leading athletics stars fail to win banked-on medals, but the country also lost out in the most prestigious sports, it states. "To a great extent, the country's improved performance was the result of the expanded range of the Olympic programme." In an interview in Izvestiya, Vitaly Smirnov, head of Russia's Olympic committee, says that Russia could come first in the 2004 games if the Kremlin boosts its support financially and clears up an "unhealthy confusion" over which government department should be responsible for Olympic preparation.

webTitle: Fox Kids Europe signs video games deal

fields.headline: Fox Kids Europe takes gaming partner
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Fox Kids Europe is to expand into the gaming market after striking a five-year deal with Kalisto Entertainment, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Fox Kids Europe is to expand into the gaming market after striking a five-year deal with Kalisto Entertainment, a developer of interactive entertainment software for new platforms.

The first fruits of the deal are expected before the end of 2001 with the two companies collaborating on a series of games, some of which will be based on Fox Kids characters, to be be distributed across interactive platforms.

These will include games developed to work across narrowband, broadband and mobile platforms, digital cable and satellite, and consoles. The aim is to turn some of the more popular games into interactive TV programmes and license them to third parties.

Ynon Kreiz, chairman and CEO of Fox Kids Europe, said: "This agreement represents a great opportunity for our company to enter the $20bn video game market."

FKE currently broadcasts programmes including Power Rangers, Spiderman, X-Men, Inspector Gadget and Goosebumps via cable and satellite to 38 countries, reaching more than 21m households in 12 languages. Its main markets are the UK, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Italy, Poland, Russia, Romania and Turkey.

Separately, FKE has completed the roll-out of its pan-European channel platform in all major markets, with the launch this week of local channels in Germany and Austria.

webTitle: Upbeat Hague eases through party questions

fields.headline: Upbeat Hague eases through party questions
fields.standfirst: The Tory leader is in confident mood as he faces a welcoming audience, writes Julian Glover in Bournemouth
fields.trailText: The Tory leader is in confident mood as he faces a welcoming audience, writes Julian Glover in Bournemouth.
fields.body:
The already buoyant mood of delegates at this year's Conservative Party conference was further strengthened this morning at a question and answer session with the party leader, William Hague. Standing at the front of the stage and speaking without notes, Mr Hague answered a string of questions on largely predictable issues, such as pensions, crime, the Millennium Dome and farming.

Party officials stressed that the Conservative leader did not know the content of the questions in advance, although they did admit that he had an idea of the topics likely to come up.

Standing at the front of the conference platform like a showman taking on all comers, Mr Hague attempted to contrast his willingness to answer questions with the prime minister's reluctance to do so. Tony Blair did not take part in a question and answer session at this year's conference, as he had done in earlier years.

Not that Mr Hague faced a hostile audience. Many of his questioners had an interest in not rocking the boat: they included a string of parliamentary candidates.

"This is already the most successful, determined, upbeat and united Conservative conference that we have seen for years," he began, and continued in similar mood. Few questions were ever likely to cause him trouble and the session came to resemble a party rally, not parliamentary cross-questioning.

There is dissent and debate at this conference, but organisers have made sure that it has failed to infiltrate the hall.

Throughout, he espoused a jocular and robust Tory common sense. On marriage, he argued that "the state should signal its support"; and on pensions, that his party would offer more money. He called for the Dome to be "shut down" immediately and predicted that what had been "the story of the Dome" would be "the story of the government".

To repeated applause he turned on the European Union in several answers. Calling for the police "to be allowed to get on with the job" he stressed that "tackling crime across the country" was something "that the people yearned for us to do". He ended by calling for a live televised debate between "Hague and Blair".

"Let's make that challenge," he said.

fields.headline: Why TiVo empowers the viewer
fields.standfirst:
BSkyB's Brian Sullivan responds to Dawn Hayes' assertion in this week's Media Guardian that, with the launch of TiVo, a war is developing over who will win the right to filter our TV viewing experience for us.

Must-see TV, all day, every day
fields.trailText: The advent of the Personal Television Recorder in the UK following last week's launch of TiVo represents a step-change in the control British viewers have over their TV. By Brian Sullivan.
fields.body:
The advent of the Personal Television Recorder (PTR) in the UK following last week's launch of TiVo represents a step-change in the control British viewers have over their television entertainment. It is every bit as groundbreaking as the arrival 20 years ago of the VCR.

In a digital age of 200-plus channels, it also represents - as Dawn Hayes points out - a ratcheting up of the already overwhelming choice in digital home entertainment. So if PTR is to fulfil its promise and harness digital choice - not by limiting that choice before it reaches the home but by putting a new level of control in the hands of the viewer - it is important to cut through the competing claims to clarify matters.

Many myths persist about TiVo. Plenty of commentators still believe it cuts out ads, and a pseudo debate has been stoked up over the supposed implications for advertisers and, indeed, the whole commercial television sector. Except that the facts do not quite fit the arguments. In this regard, TiVo does nothing that early VCRs did not do 20 years ago. Sure, you can fast-forward through ads - up to 60 times normal speed - but that is nothing new. And Charles Allen's nostrum, about the oldest technology for skipping ads being the kettle, has already acquired the status of cliche.

Myth two: that BSkyB has snared both TiVo and the Pace/NDS technology in its forthcoming second-generation digibox to prevent other pay-TV networks from offering PTRs to their subscribers, and, or to corner (or "dominate", if you prefer) the PTR market in the UK.

Again, the facts get in the way. Sky's involvement with TiVo centres on handling sales, marketing and distribution. TiVo is platform-independent. It will work with virtually any TV delivery platform - pay or free-to-air. Indeed, our research shows that interest in TiVo is highest among consumers who do not have access to multi-channel television.

And with Sky being the UK pioneer in TV technology over the past 11 years, which company would be better suited to act as midwife to the UK PTR market?

From Sky's perspective, much of the commentary on TiVo and the PTR repeats the old mistake of missing what is happening in the real world. The Henley Centre predicts that 75 per cent - well over 15m - homes will have digital TV by 2008. And we have gone on record in projecting 7m Sky digital homes by 2003.

So, on any projection, a substantial proportion of UK homes - disproportionately skewed towards younger, more affluent households - will increasingly experience television as a 200-channel phenomenon. The PTR gives them the tool to manage that choice, while leaving the crucial elements of that choice where they belong - in the hands of the viewer.

Even on more limited digital platforms, with access to only a couple of dozen channels, the viewer will welcome the powerful sense of control offered by PTR.

In this context, TiVo is less a weird, high-priced, prematurely-obsolete gizmo that will send advertisers and broadcasters screaming than a crucial piece of the digital jigsaw.

Sky has given PTR a massive vote of confidence. The technology, in whatever form, is not what many are calling it. It is a consumer electronics breakthrough, a genuinely new market, and it will come to be seen as a key to unlock and manage the potential of digital entertainment.

Let's get over the hysteria, and move on.
