So if PTR is to fulfil its promise and harness digital choice - not by limiting that choice before it reaches the home but by putting a new level of control in the hands of the viewer - it is important to cut through the competing claims to clarify matters. Many myths persist about TiVo. Plenty of commentators still believe it cuts out ads, and a pseudo debate has been stoked up over the supposed implications for advertisers and, indeed, the whole commercial television sector. Except that the facts do not quite fit the arguments. In this regard, TiVo does nothing that early VCRs did not do 20 years ago. Sure, you can fast-forward through ads - up to 60 times normal speed - but that is nothing new. And Charles Allen's nostrum, about the oldest technology for skipping ads being the kettle, has already acquired the status of cliche. Myth two: that BSkyB has snared both TiVo and the Pace/NDS technology in its forthcoming second-generation digibox to prevent other pay-TV networks from offering PTRs to their subscribers, and, or to corner (or "dominate", if you prefer) the PTR market in the UK. Again, the facts get in the way. Sky's involvement with TiVo centres on handling sales, marketing and distribution. TiVo is platform-independent. It will work with virtually any TV delivery platform - pay or free-to-air. Indeed, our research shows that interest in TiVo is highest among consumers who do not have access to multi-channel television. And with Sky being the UK pioneer in TV technology over the past 11 years, which company would be better suited to act as midwife to the UK PTR market? From Sky's perspective, much of the commentary on TiVo and the PTR repeats the old mistake of missing what is happening in the real world. The Henley Centre predicts that 75 per cent - well over 15m - homes will have digital TV by 2008. And we have gone on record in projecting 7m Sky digital homes by 2003. So, on any projection, a substantial proportion of UK homes - disproportionately skewed towards younger, more affluent households - will increasingly experience television as a 200-channel phenomenon. The PTR gives them the tool to manage that choice, while leaving the crucial elements of that choice where they belong - in the hands of the viewer. Even on more limited digital platforms, with access to only a couple of dozen channels, the viewer will welcome the powerful sense of control offered by PTR. In this context, TiVo is less a weird, high-priced, prematurely-obsolete gizmo that will send advertisers and broadcasters screaming than a crucial piece of the digital jigsaw. Sky has given PTR a massive vote of confidence. The technology, in whatever form, is not what many are calling it. It is a consumer electronics breakthrough, a genuinely new market, and it will come to be seen as a key to unlock and manage the potential of digital entertainment. Let's get over the hysteria, and move on.

fields.headline: Come clean on Europe, Ken. It's all that matters
fields.standfirst:
It's time Clarke's wing exposed the fiction of unity
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: It's time Clarke's wing exposed the fiction of unity.
fields.body:
This is the week when the Conservatives have decided that they must suddenly prove themselves to be the party of one nation. We shall see. Words can be made to mean what a conference wants them to mean. But before speaking for one nation, the Tories need to be one party. That is the prior test.

Whether they pass it depends on the behaviour of a small number of people, who have hitherto conspired to create an impression of unity that works entirely to their own disadvantage. This is, I think, the week that will settle the fate for many years ahead of Kenneth Clarke and the brand of conservatism he stands for.

The public impression is solidifying that the Conservative party is not divided. This is quite a turnround. One of the many reasons John Major's party was driven from power was that the voters saw it as a fragmented rabble. The perception of splits is perhaps the most durably convincing of all explanations for the defeat of parties in elections everywhere in the democratic world.

Removing the outward signs of disagreement is the task William Hague has worked hardest to complete, at whatever cost in other ways. The Tories are now widely seen as rightist, nationalist, repressive, and opportunist. But they are united. Above all, they are united in being anti-European.

As this process has hardened, Mr Clarke has stood pretty tolerantly by. So have the two dozen or so MPs who remain of his persuasion. Coming from what may still be called the left of the party, they are uneasy about most of the epithets round which Hague has built his unity, and they continue, as Ian Taylor did at yesterday's Guardian meeting on the conference fringe, to try to explain the necessity for a more inclusive approach. Apprentice One Nationers need a bit of instruction from people with experience of that genre of politics.

But the greatest silence has been over Europe. Mr Clarke makes occasional sorties, reminding us where he stands. Along with the rest of his faction, however, he took a decision to raise no steam during the European elections. His strategy has been to lie low, in the hope that Hague's ascendancy will be destroyed by the evidence of its own electoral failure. Above all, Clarkeites have not wanted to distract from the enormity of the coming defeat by permitting any blame for it to be laid on their own splittist tendencies.

This strategy must now be reckoned a failure. Mr Hague has got stronger not weaker in the party, and appears to be making a slightly better fist of Tory positioning with the electorate. The Clarkeites, meanwhile, are trapped by their own decorous timidity into helping him. They assist in creating the illusion of party unity without which the election will never be won. There is, in truth, no such unity. Over Europe, the leadership position divides it ever further from the Clarkeites. Yet they collude in their own elimination from relevance by failing, even now, to drive home that difference with the destructive passion it requires.

In two respects, Hague's position, behind a screen of double-talk, is repugnant to them. Not mildly disappointing but fundamentally unacceptable. When Hague refuses to say he would "never" abandon the pound, he is dissembling, as they perfectly understand. He would indeed never join the euro.

It is unimaginable that any leader of the modern Tory party would ever do so. More than 60% of Tory MPs want "never", and it remains to be seen how many election candidates slip it into their manifestos. This position is absolute, unchangeable, and based on arguments that dispel the slightest doubt about it being a temporary rumination - as we will see when, after a decent interval, the party accepts the £20m on offer from the Europhobic plutocrat, Paul Sykes.

The reason why Hague and Michael Portillo refuse to be honest about this is in part their sense that the British public might not warm to their own timeless absolutism. Even obsessives have some political caution. But another reason is their desire to keep the Clarkeites alongside. They toy with the dinosaurs to keep them sweet, even as they despise them. And so far the Clarkeites have accepted the humiliation. Knowing that Hague means never, they reinforce his subterfuge by pretending that his avoidance of the N-word is all that matters. John Major, typically mealy-mouthed, is the newest exponent of this travesty.

I f there was any doubt about this being a bargain Clarke must now reject, it's settled by the other half of the Tory leadership's line, which is to propose a radical break with the European Union as hitherto constituted. The party is not in any way fooling. It demands a referendum on the coming Nice treaty, however trivial its provisions. It wants a renegotiation of certain existing treaty provisions, no matter how few other member states agree. Although some of these commitments, mainly made by Francis Maude, have been subject to anxious glossing, what lies behind them is an attitude of virulent hostility to the EU on the part of every member of the shadow cabinet.

Much can be said about the substance of these positions, their danger and their recklessness. They play with enlargement, which is the purpose of Nice, as frivolously as they dispose of any Tory who disagrees with Hague. Seen from Poland or Hungary, the putative sabotage of Nice looks like the unforgivable price Europe must be made to pay for the insu lar narcissism of British Conservatives. But in Bournemouth the focus has to be more particular.

The question is no longer avoidable. Can Clarke and co continue to perpetuate the farcical myth of unity? Will politicians who sign up to none of this - who abhor Europhobia, and despise a governing strategy of all-out war with Brussels - be prepared to split the party rather than enlist once more as dumb collaborators in a policy designed to wreck Britain's position in the EU?

Mr Clarke will take his stand today. He had a preliminary go last night, making a pitch for genuine one- nationism. But the Europe speech is what matters. If Hague were to win the election on his anti-EU platform, the major work of Clarke's wing of the party would go down the drain for ever. This is very big stuff. The secret hope of all Clarkeites can therefore only be that Blair will win.

This is what they want. The gesture they can make to assist it is to dispel, with the kind of unbending clarity they have so far been unwilling to show, the fiction that the Tories are one party. Otherwise they have no hope of sustaining either their own importance or the cause that most distinctively animates their politics. That cause is in multiple difficulties at the moment. Given the state of the Conservative party, it has also become the only thing left for Kenneth Clarke to fight for.

webTitle: Hamann tells Owen and Beckham to go abroad

fields.headline: Hamann tells Owen and Beckham to go abroad
fields.trailText: Germany midfielder Dietmar Hamann has urged Michael Owen and David Beckham to move abroad - for the good of their careers and their country.
fields.body:
Germany midfielder Dietmar Hamann has urged Michael Owen and David Beckham to move abroad - for the good of their careers and their country.

"These days international sides actually need their best players to broaden their horizons and their experience by playing abroad," he told the Mirror. "Michael is one of the best strikers around. He could easily play for one of the big clubs, and I think that would help him and England. David Beckham is the same.

"What I've seen this year of Michael makes me think there are not many better strikers in the game, and if he one day moved abroad, it would give him something extra."

Hamann also claimed that England and Germany's lack of success in recent years is partly down to having few players plying their trade abroad.

"Look at France. Most of their side play abroad in Italy, Spain or England, yet they won the World Cup and the European Championship," he said. "It was the same when Germany won the World Cup in 1990. Our best players were then playing in Italy, and I think it helped them develop their game to an even higher standard.

"England have only one player abroad - Steve McManaman. At international level a team needs to have vast experience these days and playing abroad - learning all about different styles - gives you that."

fields.headline: Gameplay counts cost of US acquisition
fields.standfirst: Mark Bernstein outlines Gameplay's future strategy
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Online games retailer Gameplay.com reported a large loss after spending £34m on a US acquisition, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Gameplay.com, the online games retailer, reported a large loss in its final results after spending £34m on a US acquisition.

The company said its pre-tax loss for the year to July was £33.5m, but did not provide figures for the same period last year. Nearly half the revenues of £23.2m came from the UK, though Gameplay has signed several deals this year to secure a presence in Spain, Germany and Scandinavia.

Gameplay has moved into video game publishing and broadband distribution with its all-share acquisition of Pixel Broadband Studios, a unit of the US game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software. The PixelBBS technology allows games to be played on high-speed internet or wireless devices, a format that Gameplay expects to dominate the market in the future.

Mark Bernstein, chief executive of Gameplay, said: "This technology will enable users of the future to access one set of unified games services offered by gameplay, whether from the PC at work, TV at home or mobile phone whilst waiting for a bus."

The company's chairman, Mark Strachan, said Gameplay will now concentrate on integrating its acquisitions and using its leading-edge technology to take advantage of broadband platforms.

fields.headline: Barbarella
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the tinfoil-clad sexpot and how she is, so to speak, coming again
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the tinfoil-clad sexpot and how she is, so to speak, coming again.
fields.body:
1. Never afraid to spurn a new idea when an old one will do, the wacky world of cinema has come up with a definitive chest-nut.

2. There is to be a remake of the 60's camp classic, Barbarella.

3. The eponymous heroine, first made glorious flesh by Jane Fonda, will be taken by the equally delectable Drew Barrymore.

4. There is, as yet, no news of the lucky dog who will get to play Barbarella's lover, originally camped up by David Hemmings.

5. The re-hash will be produced by Ms Barrymore, with the help of a lifetime of experience in the movies. She's 25, for God's sake.

6. La Barrymore has an army of fans, some of them quite seriously nuts. She's known to some as the Butterfly Goddess.

7. The first Barbarella, directed by Ms Fonda's lover and first husband, Roger Vadim, was created by voguish French sci-fi writer Jean-Claude Forest.

8. It was a huge hit. Some folk still love it to bits. Others hate it.

9. Barbarella will long be remembered for her sensationally kinky clothes.

10. And for her sensationally kinky way of bonking.

fields.headline: Mafiaville cheers its anti-mob hero
fields.trailText: A film about an anti-Mafia hero is scandously playing to enthusiastic audiences in the town synonymous with the Cosa Nostra and with Mario Puzo's fictional godfather who carries its name
fields.body:
Don Vito Corleone will be turning in his grave. A film about an anti-Mafia hero is playing to enthusiastic audiences in the town synonymous with the Cosa Nostra and with Mario Puzo's fictional godfather who carries its name.

"Only a few years ago this would have been unthinkable," said Giuseppe Cipriani, the Left Democrat mayor first elected by the town in 1994 on an anti-Mafia ticket.

The movie, Placido Rizzotto (pictured), which will be shown at the London Film Festival in November, celebrates the life of a local trade union figure who led a series of land occupations by the town's poorest peasants. The Mafia took a dim view and in 1948 he was bludgeoned and shot to death by Luciano Liggio (Lucky Luciano), later to emerge as the Cosa Nostra's "boss of bosses".

A local shepherd boy saw the murder and his resulting agitation was calmed with a lethal injection, administered by one of Corleone's Mafia-linked doctors.

Placido Rizzotto had its Sicilian premiere in Corleone last weekend. A packed cinema burst into applause at a scene showing a meeting between Pio La Torre, a leftwing politician who continued Rizzotto's struggle, and a young captain, Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa, who arrested the labour leader's killers but failed to get them convicted. In 1982 both men were killed by the Mafia, after playing a key role in Italy's battle against the mob.

The enthusiastic response to the picture, made by the Sicilian director Pasquale Scimeca, was a sure sign that the Cosa Nostra is losing its grip. Toto Riina, the Corleone godfather who led the Mafia into head-on confrontation with the state in the early 1990s, has been in prison for almost a decade. There have even been reports of petty crime in the town, another indication that control is slipping from the Mafia's grasp.

"If justice had been more just in those days, we would have made more progress by now," the trade unionist's nephew, Placido Rizzotto, told the audience. "Palermo justice acquitted these people and they came out of it stronger than ever."

Liggio's acquittal on grounds of insufficient evidence had allowed him and his gang to dominate the hills around Corleone for the following 30 years, Mr Rizzotto said.

The Mafia's stranglehold on the area is far from broken, however. Its armed element "has suffered severe setbacks, but the Mafia devoted to financial activities and the cultivation of politicians is still thriving", said Maria Maniscalco, another Left Democrat who is mayor of San Giuseppe Jato, a neighbouring agricultural town. In Caccamo, for instance, the wife of a fugitive Mafia boss was until recently the elected town councillor overseeing public works contracts.

Today's boss of all bosses is Bernardo Provenzano, also a Corleonese, who has eluded police for the last 37 years, even though the police believe he has stayed in the area.

Giuseppe Lumia of the Left Democrats - the first Sicilian to head the parliamentary anti-Mafia commission - said the Mafia still had enormous capacity to frighten people, yet public support would be crucial if the state was to win the battle.

"The novelty in Corleone is that now the anti-Mafia is in the majority," he said. He cited the confiscation there of a luxurious villa owned by Riina. It was recently turned into a school for agricultural studies.

webTitle: An interview with Gameplay chief Mark Bernstein

fields.headline: Mark Bernstein outlines Gameplay's future strategy
fields.standfirst:
Mark Bernstein, chief executive of Gameplay.com, is in charge of a company that is expanding at rate of knots. Here he talks to Dan Milmo.

Gameplay counts cost of US acquisition
fields.trailText: 'People want to see how well we can manage our business - they want to see our business models emerging. That is what next year is about.' Gameplay's Mark Bernstein talks to Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mark Bernstein, chief executive of Gameplay.com, is in charge of a company that is expanding at rate of knots. The online gaming firm was founded in March 1999, has over 500 employees and more than 1m customers throughout Europe.

Gameplay last month confirmed its European ambitions when it paid £7m for Spanish rival CentroMail, and today announced its annual results alongside the £34m acquisition of Israel-based Pixel Broadband Studios. Pixel BBS specialises in the distribution of games across multiple platforms, such as broadband and Wap.

Major Gameplay shareholders include BT and BSkyB, with high-street retailer Dixons having taken a 12.5% stake in August. In exchange, the Dixons group's @jakarta games stores will take the Gameplay name.

MediaGuardian's Dan Milmo asks: "You have announced an annual pre-tax loss of £33.4m, so what is the upside?"

Mr Bernstein: "For a start, the revenues were £23.8m, and a lot of the loss came from our acquisitions. If you add in the revenues from our recent acquisitions, our losses would have been a little bit less."

DM: "What are you getting from the Pixel BBS deal?"

MB: "We are now well positioned for the online distribution of games. Online rental of games will be a much higher margin service, and Pixel gives us the technologies to offer some of these services. For instance, its Jive platform means that multiple players can play the same game from all kinds of different devices, such as Wap phones and palm pilots.

DM: "Dixons has a 12.5% stake in Gameplay. Would it make sense to increase your offline presence and let it increase its stake in your company?"

MB: "Dixons may or may not increase its stake, as we enjoy a very good relationship. But I think it will want to wait and see, as we have to prove that we can run a business. People want to see how well we can manage our business - they want to see our business models emerging. That is what next year is about."

DM: "What is your plan for next year?"

MB: "Well, we started out with what we called 'four steps to heaven'. Last year was step one, which was to make a noise and acquisitions. webTitle: In brief: Norton leaves Bruce flapping

fields.headline: Norton leaves Bruce flapping
fields.trailText: Plus: Crudup signs for Faulks adaptation, Wes Craven does "serious" again, king of the world Cameron abandons Earth, Hawn dallies with rock chick flick
fields.body:
 Bruce Willis is looking around for a new co-star for his latest film, following the shock departure of Edward Norton from the project, due to that old favourite "creative differences". Willis has drawn up a list of young actors he wants to work with on Hart's War, a second world war drama about an American who becomes a prisoner-of-war in Europe. The film was due to have begun shooting in Prague in January but has been delayed because of recasting.

 Rising star Billy Crudup is set to appear alongside Oscar-nominated Cate Blanchett in a screen adaptation of the Sebastian Faulks novel Charlotte Gray. Crudup, who has received much critical acclaim for his role as a rock journalist in the forthcoming Almost Famous (released here at the end of the year), will play a second world war British air force pilot shot down over France. Blanchett will play his girlfriend Charlotte, who goes in search of him. Oscar and Lucinda director Gillian Armstrong will direct and shooting begins in February.

 The increasingly sombre Wes Craven has signed up to direct Drowning Ruth, a thriller based on the novel by Christina Schwartz. The story is based on a family living in rural America in 1919 and centres around two sisters and the mystery which surrounds one of their deaths. This will not be his next project though; The Nightmare on Elm Street creator will first work on an adaptation of his novel Fountain Society, which tells the story of a scientist who is given the opportunity to cure his cancer through a experimental cloning procedure.

 James Cameron is planning a trip into space, according to Ananova. The Titanic director has apparently undergone medical tests at the Russian Institute for Medical and Biological problems, so he can visit the Russian space station Mir. According to sources within the Institute, he was been passed fit and well and is hoping for a lengthy mission.

 Goldie Hawn looks set to follow in her daughter Kate Hudson's footsteps and star as a rock groupie in her next film. According to Mr Showbiz Hawn is close to signing up with Susan Sarandon to star as a pair of ageing rock groupies in a film called The Banger Sisters. Hawn would play a tough waitress still yearning for her wild past, while Sarandon would play a primmer character who would rather forget it all happened.

webTitle: Gap to appoint ad agency as marketing chief quits

fields.headline: Gap to appoint ad agency as marketing chief quits
fields.standfirst: Gap marketing chief quits
fields.trailText: 11.45am: The Gap plans to hire an advertising agency for the first time, following the resignation of marketing chief Jim Nevins, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Gap plans to hire an advertising agency for the first time, following the resignation of marketing chief Jim Nevins.

Mr Nevins' departure last week leaves the retailer in the lurch in the run-up to the crucial US holiday period. The decision to talk to agencies represents a major turnaround for Gap, which is famous for being one of the few major advertisers to create all of its ads in-house.

A Gap spokeswoman said: "We are looking for an ad agency to tide us over. The agency will be the hands and legs of the next campaign."

Mr Nevins resigned last week, saying he wanted to retain his focus on the creative side of the business, whereas the company had wanted him to take on a broader brand development role.

A replacement is being sought. In the meantime, Amy Schoening, head of marketing for Gap sister brand Banana Republic, will fill in.

Mr Nevins' departure is the latest in a series of setbacks for the company, which only two years ago was hailed as a marketing miracle when it overtook Levi's as the world's biggest clothing manufacturer.

In August, Gap issued its third profits warning in as many months. Analysts say the retailer has alienated older customers by focusing on trendy teenagers, although US retailers in general have suffered due to cooler weather and higher fuel prices.

Ironically, Mr Nevins was quoted only six months ago in the Media Guardian as saying the company would never use outsiders because "the strongest brands in the world have a much clearer idea of their own image than any ad agency".

webTitle: Scientists investigate outbreak of copper poisoning in cattle

fields.headline: Scientists investigate outbreak of copper poisoning in cattle
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Government scientists are investigating a potential new problem for Britain's cattle farmers, illness caused by an excess of copper ingested by cows, as ministers consider the verdict of an independent inquiry into how the BSE crisis was handled.
fields.body:
Government scientists are investigating a potential new problem for Britain's cattle farmers, illness caused by an excess of copper ingested by cows, as ministers consider the verdict of an independent inquiry into how the BSE crisis was handled.

Food safety watchdogs and vets are trying to establish why there is an apparent increase in copper poisoning of livestock, although they believe that the risk to consumers is "very small". Most cases so far have been concentrated in southern England and Wales and officials are trying to establish whether there has been any significant change in dietary supplements fed to cattle. Copper is a vital ingredient in improving animals' muscle, fertility and production value.

The alert over copper poisoning, a previously rare condition, was raised by government vets in a letter to the Veterinary Record, the profession's weekly journal. Fourteen outbreaks have been identified this year and the government is anxious to know about other suspected cases.

The vets said their investigations had not found "grossly excessive copper intakes" in rations on the affected farms and no single feed type seemed to be involved.

Animals struck by copper poisoning tend to suffer liver damage, which affects blood circulation. Symptoms include poor milking, abortion of calves and lack of coordination. The condition has so far affected only older cows, which are not used for food because of anti-BSE measures. In any case, infected offal should fail veterinary inspection in abattoirs, the food standards agency said.

"If you did eat liver with high copper content, you would not eat much more," said a spokesman. "It affects palatability." Danger from milk "is not something we consider a risk".

A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Agriculture said: "There are concerns because this is an animal health problem but I don't think anyone is concerned about human health implications."

The revelation coincided with publication of figures showing a further rise in the number of people dying from variant CJD, the condition linked to eating parts of cattle infected with BSE, itself once considered to pose no risk to consumers, and the official handing over of the 16-volume report by the BSE inquiry team, headed by Lord Phillips of Worth Matravers, to the agriculture minister, Nick Brown. It will be published later this month.

Seventy-seven Britons are now thought to have died from vCJD, including three last month of whom one worked in the Leicestershire village of Queniborough, where there has been an apparent cluster of four deaths. The disease may have claimed 22 lives this year, although postmortem confirmation is awaited in four cases.Seven people are thought to be suffering the incurable condition. Scientists have warned of a rising trend in vCJD, although they remain reluctant to predict the eventual number of casualties.

fields.headline: Books for babies
fields.trailText: The Bookstart programme, which provides free books for seven to nine-month-old babies, has shown that access to the right books from birth makes a substantial difference to a child's literacy and numeracy skills when they reach school.
fields.body:
The Bookstart programme, which provides free books for seven to nine-month-old babies, has shown that access to the right books from birth makes a substantial difference to a child's literacy and numeracy skills when they reach school.

However, choosing books for this age group is not easy. They must be simple enough to appeal directly to their audience through feel and colour, hence their laminated, board-book format with bright colours that babies will find instantly attractive.

They also need enough words to offer stimulation to both the listener and reader. Simple identification of objects can pall quickly for reader and listener alike, though babies do like to be able to point at what they know. Rhyming texts read well and sound good and also introduce babies to patterns of sound which it is easy for them to pick up and remember.

To highlight the importance of a baby's first books and to give guidance on the best books for the very young, the Sainsbury's Baby Book Award was set up last year by Sainsbury's and Book Trust. Judged by a range of professionals working with both books and babies, including a health visitor and a children's librarian, these books are selected for their appealing physical qualities - durability is especially important - as well as their actual content.

This year's winner is Boo Barney by Alex Ayliffe (Orchard, £3.50). An exuberant board book with bold illustrations in bright colours, it shows that Baby Barney can crawl, stamp and splash, share a book and busily cook. Strong on recognition for the very young child with a simple, near-rhyming text, it is easy to share with a baby and fun for both reader and listener.

Shortlisted for the prize were: Catherine Anholt for First Words (Walker, £2.99), a highly durable, chunky board-book introducing the first and most familiar words in a baby's vocabulary. There is much to point at for babies as they recognise things they know. Anholt's illustrations are immediately appealing with their soft focus and gentle colours while also including enough detail to pay more than one visit.

Dawn Apperley's Hello Little Ducklings (David & Charles, £3.50) shows four cheerful spreads of golden-yellow baby ducklings with a onomatopoeic text, including such expressions as "splishy-splashy" and "plip! plop!" to describe what they are doing. Its appeal is instant rather than long lasting.

Stephen Cartwright's Animal Noises (Usborne, £3.99) introduces the sounds different animals make. From Curly the pig to Rusty the dog, each spread offers a stylised, soft toy animal to look at and talk about as well as encouraging sound mimicry from baby and parent.

Cathy Gale's Tiny Teethers' Puppy (Campbell Books, £3.99) is half book, half teething-ring. Small-scale and hand-shaped, it shows baby and puppy through the day - playing, eating, washing and finally settling down to sleep.

John Prater's Number One, Tickle Your Tum (Bodley Head, £4.99) is an altogether more substantial book. It is another rhyming text with a counting theme as Big Bear and Little Bear play together. The bears' actions, 'Number four, touch the floor. Number five, do a dive.' lift off the page making them part of a pre-speech shared activity even without the book.

Prater's softly drawn bears are expressive and full of movement as well as being cuddly and charming. There is enough life here for the many re-readings that a baby will demand.

fields.headline: Ooh you are awful, but we like you
fields.standfirst: So Barbarella and Maximus have been voted sex icons? Oh dear, says Polly Vernon
fields.trailText: So Barbarella and Maximus have been voted sex icons? Oh dear, says Polly Vernon.
fields.body:
Maximus. Now, there's a man for you. Gladiator's lead is all scorching, testosterone-fuelled death wish, tinged with enduring passion for his lady. Butch incarnate, he's the Jude Law backlash, the long overdue response to Angst Boy and Moisturiser Man with all his tiresome, over-analytical ways.

Maximus isn't in touch with the intricacies of his sexuality. He doesn't need therapy. He couldn't interior design his way out of a Tuscan farmhouse. He doesn't cry. Or clean. And boy, can he make a leather skirt twirl! No surprise, then, that he has now hit the number one spot in Empire magazine's sexiest film character of all time poll.

Except, of course, it is surprising. Partly because Russell Crowe, Maximus' real-life alter ego, is distinctly unattractive in a squidgy, shapeless-faced kind of way (don't argue - he is) but also precisely because of the unreconstructed mindless man trip he indulges. The leaden, overly worked-out body shape. The brutal war instinct. The tendency to ditch his family for months at a time so he might rape and pillage elsewhere. The disregard for personal hygiene.

Read on down the poll and you will notice this regressive trend in movie sex icons evolving further. Princess Leia is number two, but only in her Return of the Jedi incarnation, because she wore a gold bikini top for most of the action. The poll is very clear on that point. Harrison Ford in macho, sweat-stained, wench-rescuing Indiana Jones guise makes it to number four. Jane Fonda's catsuit-clad Barbarella swings in at number six and apparently the appeal of that particular character is so enduring that a new version of the film, starring Drew Barrymore, goes into production as we speak. And so it goes on.

Who'd have thought it, eh? Behind all our pretty talk of gender issues and a second poll released yesterday which predicts that by 2015, all housework chores will be shared equally between the sexes, we are yearning for a revival of these two-dimensional cartoony versions of prototype manliness and girliness.

The closer the sexes get in real life, the more homogeneous we become in terms of role fulfilment, the more we lust after Maximus men and Barbarella totty in our multiplexes. One of the greatest taboos of the post-feminist era is that, for many of us, our fantasy realm is unreservedly un-PC. The buffer of fiction gives us scope to indulge a warped wonderland around which Maximus and his like can roam unchecked, but which bears no relation to the things to which women aspire in the cold, hard light of real life.

None of which gets us over the basic issue of Maximus' face. Nothing can excuse the gratuitous fancying of something so plain. And did nobody else who watched the film notice the damaged, corrupt beauty of evil Commodus Joaquin Phoenix, lurking behind pillars and skulking round battle tent corners? Really?

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: BIG RON AND TEDDY
fields.body:
BIG RON AND TEDDY

Teddy Sheringham for England? That's what Ron Atkinson argued for last week - and, judging by our postbag, many of you support him. "I totally agree with Big Ron," says Rob Smyth. "Without Sheringham on the bench, England have no get-out clause if they are one down with 10-15 minutes to play. He's done it so often for United in the last two seasons. What's Keegan going to do if things are going wrong? Bring in a half-fit Heskey? The man can't even hold himself up, let alone the ball."

The 'Big Ron good, Keegan bad' thesis is also supported by Matt Craven. "Keegan's devotion to old experienced heads is in no way consistent," he says. "Ince and Seaman are in, and yet Sheringham misses out despite scoring regularly and offering something else to the cause. Fowler has hardly played, Heskey is useless, so why is Sheringham excluded?"

However, not everyone thinks Atkinson is perfect. Graham Carnaffan remembers that "as a manager, he himself was quite the pathetic, poxy suit-wearing proto-typical 80's boyo who stood for glamour, huge transfer fees and flirtation with disaster every time he opened his mouth, very unlike Keegan."

But Andrew Liney enjoys Atkinson's column. However, he's a bit disappointed with the lack of Big-Ron-isms. "I would love to see him write about back-stick spin runs, or Beckham dinking one in and Yorkie giving the keeper the quick little eyebrows before slotting it in," he says. Maybe next week, eh?

THE GERMANS

So far you haven't exactly been flooding us with your England teams to face Germany. But to start the debate rolling, here's what Richard Clayton thinks:

"For the Germany game I think the main decision to be made is (again) whether Beckham starts on the right and tucks in or begins in the middle and ventures out to the wing occasionally to cross. I would choose the latter. The choice then is between Wise or Parlour in my book and, on form again, I'd opt for Parlour after his Lazio second half."

Richard's team (4-4-1-1) is: Seaman; Dyer, Keown, Adams, Le Saux; Parlour, Gerrard, Beckham, Barmby; Scholes; Owen. Anyone disagree?

THE FINNS

But why concentrate solely on the Germany game, when - according to Antti Lassila from Helsinki - we should be more worried about the Finns?

"The present Finnish team is by far the best we ever had," he says. "Hyypiä is a true leader at the back, and has developed an excellent partnership with Tihinen in the centre of defence. In midfield Litmanen, in peak form despite being frozen out at Barcelona, plays a Rui Costa-style free role, orchestrating fluid passing moves. And up front Forssel and Johansson are young, skilful, fast, hardworking and both natural finishers as proven in English leagues.

"With Kolkka from PSV and Nurmela from Heerenveen both natural wingers, and the rest of the squad being hard-working team players well capable of man-marking the England stars, the Finnish team is well balanced, and tactically clearly superior. I am looking forward to a major result and another step forward in the Finnish quest for football glory."

And another painful step back for Kevin Keegan's England, perhaps?

Graham Carnaffan remembers that "as a manager, he himself was quite the pathetic, poxy suit-wearing proto-typical 80's boyo who stood for glamour, huge transfer fees and flirtation with disaster every time he opened his mouth, very unlike Keegan." But Andrew Liney enjoys Atkinson's column. However, he's a bit disappointed with the lack of Big-Ron-isms. "I would love to see him write about back-stick spin runs, or Beckham dinking one in and Yorkie giving the keeper the quick little eyebrows before slotting it in," he says. Maybe next week, eh? THE GERMANS So far you haven't exactly been flooding us with your England teams to face Germany. But to start the debate rolling, here's what Richard Clayton thinks: "For the Germany game I think the main decision to be made is (again) whether Beckham starts on the right and tucks in or begins in the middle and ventures out to the wing occasionally to cross. I would choose the latter. The choice then is between Wise or Parlour in my book and, on form again, I'd opt for Parlour after his Lazio second half." Richard's team (4-4-1-1) is: Seaman; Dyer, Keown, Adams, Le Saux; Parlour, Gerrard, Beckham, Barmby; Scholes; Owen. Anyone disagree? THE FINNS But why concentrate solely on the Germany game, when - according to Antti Lassila from Helsinki - we should be more worried about the Finns? "The present Finnish team is by far the best we ever had," he says. "Hyypiä is a true leader at the back, and has developed an excellent partnership with Tihinen in the centre of defence. In midfield Litmanen, in peak form despite being frozen out at Barcelona, plays a Rui Costa-style free role, orchestrating fluid passing moves. And up front Forssel and Johansson are young, skilful, fast, hardworking and both natural finishers as proven in English leagues. "With Kolkka from PSV and Nurmela from Heerenveen both natural wingers, and the rest of the squad being hard-working team players well capable of man-marking the England stars, the Finnish team is well balanced, and tactically clearly superior. I am looking forward to a major result and another step forward in the Finnish quest for football glory." And another painful step back for Kevin Keegan's England, perhaps?

fields.headline: Myers up for catwalk project
fields.trailText: It seems Mike Myers has finally moved on from the Dieter debacle and got his teeth into a new project, based on a comic book written by fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi
fields.body:
It seems Mike Myers has finally moved on from the Dieter debacle and got his teeth into a new project according to The Hollywood Reporter.

The Austin Powers star's new vehicle is apparently based on a comic book written by fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi called The Adventures of Sandee the Supermodel. "Sandee" follows the adventures of a 5ft 9in blonde who is discovered by a designer named Yvesaac, a character based on Mizrahi. It is thought Myers will play Yvesaac.

It's not been an easy year for Myers. He was sued by Universal pictures for $30m for walking away from the "Dieter" project (because he felt the scripts weren't up to scratch) and then sued by co-producers Imagine Entertainment for breach of contract. Myers then turned round and counter-sued for $20m. The affair was eventually settled out of court with the help of Steven Spielberg, who stepped in to mediate.

It is not known when production will start on the project.

webTitle: Lucy Pearson: we can win the World Cup

fields.headline: Lucy Pearson: we can win the World Cup
fields.trailText: Lucy Pearson, 28, is a left-arm swing bowler for England and Staffordshire. She will go to the World Cup in New Zealand beginning on November 28 as one of England's most experienced bowlers and last month was named Vodafone's Female Player of the Year at the PCA Awards Dinner. Paul Farbrace, England's coach, helped to chose the winner. "There was only one choice. Lucy is the key member of her side. Lucy found time between teaching secondary-school pupils English and PE to talk to wisden.com
fields.body:
Lucy Pearson, 28, is a left-arm swing bowler for England and Staffordshire. She will go to the World Cup in New Zealand beginning on November 28 as one of England's most experienced bowlers and last month was named Vodafone's Female Player of the Year at the PCA Awards Dinner. Paul Farbrace, England's coach, helped to chose the winner. "There was only one choice. Lucy is the key member of her side. She takes early wickets for us in every game she plays, and enables us to keep it tight and to create pressure. She has gone from a bit part to a leading role." Lucy found time between teaching secondary-school pupils English and PE to talk to wisden.com

Do you feel pleased by your performances over the last year?
Yes. I'd always been on the periphery of the team until Farby [Paul Farbrace] took over. It was an act of faith from him really. We had a really hard time in Australia and New Zealand. The batting was a disaster but the bowlers did OK. I look at the way that I performed and the bowlers generally performed and I think we've built on that.

Why do you think you have improved?
There are lots of facets really. My mental approach has improved. I've become more self-confident. It is reassuring when the coach [Paul Farbrace] says to you everyone has bad days - it doesn't mean that you are going to be dropped straight away. It frees you from pressure. And a lot of things are coming together for the team - we have worked hard on our fitness and sports psychology. I think we're riding a wave at the moment.

How have things changed within the England set up since you first joined?
I joined the team towards the end of the New Zealand series of 1996. And things have changed beyond recognition since then. The ECB were on the point of amalgamating with the WCA. Then lots of things were funded by the players. Since then we've become sponsored by Vodafone and received a grant from Sports England, and we have become almost semi-professional. The expectations of what we can do have lifted. Eighteen-year-olds like Laura Harper have far more opportunities.

Is it easy to combine playing cricket for England and your profession?
Fortunately I am blessed. The headmaster, staff and students are 100% supportive. I will be away for three months and the other staff are going to take on the extra work. They don't get any compensation for my absence and if there was any bad feeling it would distract me from my cricket so it is great. I like a balanced life so being semi-professional is perfect. I wouldn't want to play cricket full time - I love my job and I love my cricket. I enjoy playing and training and when I look at the county scene they seem to lack the freshness and a eagerness for the game that we have.

You said that self-confidence had helped your cricket. Does this come from doing a job you love?
I think I'm very lucky to do a job that I feel comfortable in. It gives me a sound base and allows me to have a perspective on the game. If we lose an international it is terrible, yes, and it I feel defeat very keenly, but the world goes on. It isn't a third-world famine.

How has the dressing-room changed since Clare Connor became captain?
I came in when Karen [Smithies] was captain. I think things have changed - but then a change of captaincy often signals a change of leadership direction and emphasis. I suppose I know Clare better and from my point of view I suppose it is easier for me to see where she is coming from. I think the change has given us impetus. The results in New Zealand weren't any better than in Australia [Smithies resigned after the Australian leg of the tour] but I think we all felt that we had entered a new era.

How do you think England will fare in the World Cup?
People have said that we should be happy with a semi-final place but if you ask any of the team they will tell you that we can win. I think the semi-final is the bare minimum. I think we are on a par with India and New Zealand and that New Zealand are within our sights. I know that we lost 5-0 but our batting was at a very low ebb last winter. Had we put on another 30 or so runs things would have been different. And we can also save runs by not bowling wides and no-balls. Australia are the No. 1 nation but in World Cups bad days happen.

How do you find the pitches in New Zealand?
The tracks are different. They pitch the ball short of a length so they can get it to lift a little bit. But at the same time they aren't alien to us. We won't get the batting paradises we sometimes get over her but as a bowler that doesn't really worry me. We are going over a bit early to acclimatise for two warm-up matches. I don't see any reason to change the way I bowl - I was successful in the winter and if things are different I will adapt accordingly.

How is your batting coming along?
We have had one-to-one coaches and I think it is coming on well. I enjoy batting but I'm a No. 11. My career has been brief and relatively unglamorous - going in with 400 needed off the last over, that sort of thing.

Any injury worries?
I had a niggle in my quad over the summer but that goes with the job. Nothing serious.

Who will be the Lance Klusener of the Women's World Cup?
For Australia - Belinda Clark, Catherine Fitzpatrick and Charmaine Mason. And for us - Jane Cassar, who Farby acknowledges to be the best keeper in the world. And then Melissa Reynard of the bowlers and Barabara Daniels and Charlotte Edwards with the bat.

Do you teach cricket at school?
I've started up a girls' team this year which has proved to be very popular Ð I've been getting 20 people turning up to training. They enjoy the game and the team dynamic - there are not many team sports during the summer. At their age it is so important to make cricket fun, to mix the very talented and the less talented.

Does being an international help you with your teaching?
They take the rip out of me - newspaper cuttings appear on various boards round the school. But at the same time it gets me respect that I don't need to work for. There are not that many well-known female athletes and most of the ones the kids have heard of are fairly remote. I think it helps that they can look at me and think, I can do that. I've taught boys cricket as well and it has never been a problem except in Australia. Not only was I a Pom but I was a girl too. But when I ran in and bowled they soon accepted me - performance is the key.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read her previous column, on Sports Illustrated for Women, the mag that blew them away, click here

fields.headline: Témoin:  Cote d'Ivoire
fields.standfirst: Stéphane Orjollet describes the start of last year's military coup in Cote d'Ivoire
fields.trailText: Stéphane Orjollet describes the start of last year's military coup in Cote d'Ivoire
fields.body:
En fin de matinée, les soldats ont commencé à envahir la ville. Au début, ils se comportaient plus comme des bandes armées. Pas mal de gens croyaient que c'était toute une série de braquages parce qu'au début, ils ont attaqué les stations-service, les supermarchés et ont fait du "car-jacking".

Tout ça avait déclenché un véritable mouvement de panique dans la ville: les gens s'appelaient sur leurs portables pour se dire de rentrer chez eux le plus vite possible.

En deux ou trois heures, les mutins se sont mis à circuler dans Abidjan avec les voitures volées. C'était assez impressionnant parce qu'ils se penchaient aux portières des voitures en tirant en l'air avec leurs armes. On voyait que c'était des militaires parce qu'ils étaient en treillis mais on ne comprenait pas ce qu'ils faisaient parce qu'on ne pouvait pas aller leur parler pour leur demander. Ça ajoutait à ce sentiment d'incertitude et d'angoisse.

J'étais dans un des hôtels chics d'Abidjan avec mon fils de cinq ans qui prenait une leçon de natation. On a été pris dans l'attaque d'une station-service en rentrant en taxi. Tout d'un coup, les soldats se sont mis à tirer. Je suis vite rentré déposer mon fils à la maison.

Dans la nuit, un certain nombre de mutins ont fait le tour des radios et des agences de presse étrangères pour expliquer leur mouvement. À ce moment-là, les militaires parlaient de revendications de salaires mais les négociations avec le gouvernement ont mal tourné et c'est là qu'on s'est rendu compte que c'était peut-être un coup d'État.

Glossaire/Glossary

envahir to invade

une bande armée an armed gang

un braquage a hold-up

un mutin mutineer

une portière a car door

tirer en l'air to shoot in the air

les treillis (masc.) (mil) fatigues

la revendication demand

mal tourner to go sour, bad

 St*phane Orjollet was speaking to Zo* Eisenstein.

webTitle: United News & Media shares rise by 4%

fields.headline: United News & Media shares rise by 4%
fields.standfirst: Granada calls meeting to outline plans for United's ITV interests
fields.trailText: 11am: Positive analyst comment boosts United News & Media's share price by 4%. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
United News & Media this morning brought some much-needed good news to the media sector after positive analyst comment boosted its share price by 4%.

The stock rose 4.4%, from 744.5p to 776.5p, against last month's five-month low of 695p.

Credit Suisse First Boston analyst Mike Picken said the group's earnings growth was good, and that the £1.75bn gained from Granada Media's acquisition of United's ITV interests could create the opportunity for a share buy-back.

The CSFB comment is bad news for Granada Media, as it states United is likely to demand cash for the transaction, not shares. Granada's stock has taken a battering since brokers last week cut the company's earnings forecast, sending the share price below 450p.

"Assuming a purchase price of 850p a UNWS [United News & Media] share, the £1.25bn of cash to be returned could buy in around 30% of outstanding UNWS shares, providing significant support for the UNWS stock price," the report said.

The report put a target value of 1000p to 1200p on United's shares, without including the company's internet operations. A significant buy-back by the United board would be certain to boost the group's share price.

fields.headline: Life's a beach
fields.standfirst: Teenage chic emerges in Milan
fields.trailText: We should have known it could not last. For about two weeks this year, it was fashionable to look like a designer pastiche of what middle age entails, with chihuahua, mink stole and Campari and soda. But with teenage chic emerging as a theme of Milan fashion week, it looks as if designers have reverted to the worship of youth.
fields.body:
We should have known it could not last. For about two weeks this year, it was fashionable to look like a designer pastiche of what middle age entails, with chihuahua, mink stole and Campari and soda. But with teenage chic emerging as a theme of Milan fashion week, it looks as if designers have reverted to the worship of youth.

Blumarine is the cheaper diffusion line of Anna Molinari, the Italian label known for marabou-trimmed, sex-kitten style. Two years ago Molinari handed over design of the main collection to her daughter, Rossella Tarabini, who describes her style as more "calm, serene, sophisticated" than her mother's. Anna Molinari herself is now free to allow her love of animal prints, sequins and itsy-bitsy fur-trimmed cardigans to run wild at Blumarine.

Blumarine paid homage to the teenagers of the 1950s. In tong-curled high ponytails, gold hoop earrings and outsized beach bags, models bounced along the catwalk.

Shapes were retro: tightly belted sundresses with fitted, corset-laced bodices and demure, flouncy knee-length skirts; halter tops and capri pants; off-the-shoulder sweaters with pom-poms and hotpant-style bikini bottoms.

The patterns and colours, however, were pure Blumarine. The label's signature animal print was out in force, albeit in shades of pink or turquoise and often plastered with sequins. Even the inevitable high heels came in pastel tiger stripes.

Roses, another trademark of the label, were intricately appliqued in pink satin on to a pale blue dress, and in gold on a sheer overskirt worn over a full pink skirt. Tight, dark cropped jeans were decorated with diamante butterflies, while beachwear separates were adorned with hundreds of tiny pastel ballerinas.

The soundtrack to the show was confirmation of one of the surprise comebacks of the season, featuring two tracks by the 80s band Bananarama. No show this season is complete without the audience tapping their feet to Shy Boy.

The soundtrack to the show was confirmation of one of the surprise comebacks of the season, featuring two tracks by the 80s band Bananarama. No show this season is complete without the audience tapping their feet to Shy Boy.

fields.headline: Von s, ss und SOS
fields.standfirst: A year ago new spelling rules were introduced to German, but have they made life easier?  Nicole Prestle asks some young scribes
fields.trailText: A year ago new spelling rules were introduced to German, but have they made life easier? Nicole Prestle asks some young scribes
fields.body:
Deutschland ist "zweisprachig". Oder eher "zwei-schreibig" - wenn es dieses Wort gäbe. Denn seit die Kultusministerien vor etwa einem Jahr die neue Rechtschreibung eingeführt haben, geht es mit der Orthographie [Ortografie] oft drunter und drüber. Wer beruflich mit Schrift und Sprache zu tun hat - so auch wir Journalisten - ist ständig damit beschäftigt, die richtige, also neue, Schreibweise eines Wortes nachzuschlagen. Und je mehr Lexika er oder sie zu Rate zieht, desto mehr Antworten bekommen sie. Auch bei Spezialisten geht die Meinung über die Schreibweise des einen oder anderen Wortes nämlich auseinander.

So verwundert es kaum einen, wenn er auf dem Plakat eines Geschäftsmannes liest: "Kosmetikartikel im Obergeschos". Es ist ja eigentlich egal, ob es nun Obergeschos, Obergeschoss oder Obergeschoß heißen muß [muss] ... Hauptsache, die Kunden gehen überhaupt hinauf.

Auch bei Verlagen verhält man sich zwiespältig: Bücher für Kinder und Jugendliche halten sich penibel an die neuen Regeln. Schließlich pauken die Schüler seit über zwei Jahren, daß [dass] es nicht mehr daß" sondern "dass" heißt, daß [dass] ein Delphin jetzt als Delfin durch die Fluten schwimmt und daß [dass] die ehemalige Schiffahrt sich heutzutage nur noch mit drei "f" über Wasser hält. Sobald es aber an die Veröffentlichung von Erwachsenenliteratur geht, klammern die meisten Verlage an den alten Regeln.

Die Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung funkte SOS und hat die Reform jetzt für gescheitert erklärt. Ein Jahr lang veröffentlichte sie - wie auch alle anderen deutschen Zeitungen - im Sinne der neuen Regeln. Doch seit August ist damit Schluß [Schluss]. Die Reform habe, so die Begründung, ihre wesentlichen Ziele nicht erreicht. Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen umgehört, wie sie zur neuen Rechtschreibung stehen.

Seit gut zwei Jahren wird in den Schulen die neue Rechtschreibung gelehrt. Was haltet Ihr [ihr] davon?

Jutta (14): Man hat die Rechtschreibung ja geändert, weil die neuen Regeln das Schreiben einfacher machen sollten. Ich für meinen Teil bin inzwischen aber verwirrter, als ich es vorher jemals war. Ich muß [muss] inzwischen viel öfter im Duden nachsehen, wie man ein Wort schreibt.

Peter (18): Ich denke, daß [dass] es für Kinder, die jetzt erst in die Schule kommen, ziemlich egal ist, welche Schreibweise sie lernen. Ihnen werden die neuen Regeln in Fleisch und Blut übergehen, so wie es bei uns damals mit den alten war. Und was Erwachsene betrifft: Wenn sie nicht gerade beruflich mit Rechtschreibung zu tun haben, können sie ja schreiben, wie sie wollen. Am schlechtesten dran sind eigentlich wir älteren Schüler: Es ist nun Pflicht, die neuen Regeln zu lernen. Wir sind also gezwungen, umzudenken.

Als die Reform eingeführt wurde, hat man immer wieder betont, daß [dass] zunächst beobachtet wird, wie sich bestimmte Schreibweisen einbürgern. Einige Wörter kann man deshalb entweder in ihrer neuen, oder aber in ihrer alten Form schreiben. Was wird sich, glaubt Ihr [ihr], über kurz oder lang einbürgern?

Angelika (16): Also wenn ich Phantasie mit F, als Fantasie, schreiben soll, dann sträubt sich alles in mir. Rechtschreibung hat bei mir auch etwas mit Ästhetik zu tun. Ich schreibe ein Wort auf und es gefällt mir, wie es aussieht. Vielleicht nur, weil ich es so gewöhnt bin, aber es ist nun einmal so. Deshalb glaube ich auch, daß [dass] sich bei solchen Wörtern die alten Formen halten werden.

Sylvia (19): Man muß [muss] meiner Meinung nach auch mal offen sein für Neues. Die Rechtschreibung hat sich in Deutschland doch immer mal wieder geändert. Vielleicht nicht so umfangreich wie in der letzten Zeit, aber immerhin. Ich schreibe vieles jetzt bewußt [bewusst] in neuer Rechtschreibung. Neulich zum Beispiel auf meinem Einkaufszettel. Da habe ich bei den Spaghetti einfach das h ausgelassen - so, wie man es jetzt eben machen sollte.

Die Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) hat einen Schritt zurück gemacht und wieder die alten Regeln eingeführt. Eine gute Idee?

Angelika: Ja und nein. Für viele erwachsene Leser ist das bestimmt das Richtige. Sie konnten sich wahrscheinlich ohnehin nicht an die neuen Formen gewöhnen und schreiben privat nach den alten Regeln. Die FAZ hat sich aber auch selbst eines ausgewischt: Welcher Lehrer kann jetzt schon noch Artikel im Unterricht benutzen?

Peter: Ich mag das ewige Hin und Her nicht. Wenn das Kultusministerium neue Regeln erläßt [erlässt], dann muß [muss] man sich auch daran halten. Vor allem Zeitungen haben da Vorbildcharakter. Genau genommen sollte es sogar eine Strafe geben für Publizisten, die sich nicht an die neuen Regeln halten. Sonst bürgert sich eine halbherzige Haltung ein. Und dann wäre das ganze Hickhack um die Reform umsonst gewesen.

Glossar/Glossary

der Delphin [Delfin] dolphin

der Einkaufszettel shopping list

die Fluten the sea, floods of water

Hickhack (coll.) to and fro, fuss

inzwischen : meanwhile

klammern to hold on to sth.

die Kosmetikartikel cosmetics

das Obergeschoß the upper floor

pauken (coll.) to learn, to cram

penibel very accurate

sich sträuben to be against sth, refuse

verwirrt confused

zu Rate ziehen to ask for advice

zweisprachig bilingual

zwiespältig to be in conflict, ambivalent

sich über Wasser halten to keep one's head above water, survive

in Fleisch und Blut übergehen (reflexive) to become part of oneself, to learn by heart

* The words in brackets are the new spellings.

webTitle: The men who turn home into hell

fields.headline: The men who turn home into hell
fields.standfirst: Domestic violence accounted for half the murders of women in Britain last year. An international conference will be told enough is enough
fields.trailText: Domestic violence accounted for half the murders of women in Britain last year. An international conference will be told enough is enough
fields.body:
Jane is 27 years old. She has a three-year-old son, and she is afraid. "I bet they're looking up, laughing at me. He said he wanted me dead, and he's getting closer. I just don't get it."

Tonight she is looking at east London from the landing outside her sixth-floor council flat. It's a clear, crisp evening and in an absent moment she describes the wonderful view of the Millennium Dome and the London Eye from her window.

Then she turns to look at her front door, which is charred black and slightly ajar. She screws up her face at the smell of burnt plaster and carpet.

Her possessions and those of her son have been destroyed by a fire which started four hours earlier. They were out when the blaze began. They will never live here again. Below, a group of youths are milling in the street. In the dim light it is difficult to pick out faces, but Jane suspects her ex-boyfriend is among them. She pulls up her sleeve and shows a scar from a knife wound: "He did that."

And the reason she gives for this venomous campaign? "We had a row at a friend's house. I threw my mobile at him. He lost it. He's a nutter."

DC Euan McKeeve and PC Jackie Howe, from Newham's community safety unit - which investigates domestic violence - listen to the tale. They are not surprised when Jane says she is reluctant to give a statement. It's 7.30pm. They could be here for a while.

Reluctant

Detective Sergeant Sharon Stratton seems embarrassed. Plaistow police station is busy rather than frantic - only four of the nine officers are in this morning - and the overnight list is pretty thin. Nine reports of domestic violence and nobody in the cells.

"It's not usually this quiet," she says. "Just our bloody luck." Stratton does not usually wish for work. But today is significant - a "national snapshot" of domestic violence is being undertaken.

Details of every incident are being gathered ahead of a two- day international conference, Enough is Enough!, to be held at the end of the month, which is being organised by the Metropolitan police. The home secretary Jack Straw, the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens and Betsy Stanko, director of the Violence Research programme at the University of London, will be among speakers trying to reposition domestic violence at the top of a cluttered crime agenda.

Victims, police and policymakers have not always regarded domestic violence as "real" crime, but attitudes are changing. They must. The latest figures are horrifying. Every three days a woman is killed in a "domestic". Last year, more than 77,000 violent incidents were reported in London alone - one every six minutes.

A quarter of all reported violent crime is domestic. Half of the women murdered last year were killed in fights with their husbands, and on average a woman will be assaulted 35 times, and nearly always in front of her children, before she has the courage to ring the police.

The cost of helping the victims of domestic violence is estimated at £2bn a year. Stratton's team is in the frontline. Her CSU, which was set up 18 months ago in a reorganisation resulting from the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, investigated 519 incidents in July, more than any other borough in the capital.

There are West Indian, Asian, African and east European communities in the area, diversity that makes the job more challenging. Officers are loath to stereotype, but in their experience, Asian women are the most reluctant to come forward. One local victim suffered 40 years of abuse before dialling 999. Some Turkish men have been astonished the police regard wife-beating as a crime.

Although it is quietish this morning, it gives the officers a chance to talk. Cases they describe as "typical" are nothing less than shocking. PC Maria Neeves has called a 29-year-old victim to ask for the return of the panic alarm in her flat. There is a shortage and Neeves needs to give it to someone else.

The woman, Alison Smith, is having counselling and would prefer to keep the alarm. But she accepts she is no longer a priority because Peter, her ex-boyfriend, is now in jail.

"I broke off with Peter because I discovered he was seeing another woman," she says. "Even though he had another girlfriend, he couldn't take it. He wanted to get back with me, but there was no way. The trust had gone."

For the next six months Alison and her mother received anonymous and threatening phone calls. Alison thought she was being stalked. She wondered what lengths Peter might go to. On May 10, she found out.

Attack

The night before, he broke into the empty flat next door to Alison's in Forest Gate. Wearing a balaclava and combat gear, he waited. "The next morning I opened the door into the hallway to pick up my post. He grabbed me and pushed me back inside.

"First, he stabbed me above the right eye. He used a stun gun on me six times and coshed me over the head. He taped up my eyes and mouth, threw me on the sofa and punched me all over and beat my face.

"He told me if I kept quiet he would kill me quickly, otherwise he would torture me long and slow." Fortunately, a neighbour heard the commotion and called the police. Officers found a petrol can in the flat next door but could not link it to Peter.

"I think he was planning to kill me then torch the flat," Alison says. Peter pleaded guilty to false imprisonment and was jailed in August for three years. "With good behaviour, he will be out this time next year," says Alison. "I can't believe that's all he's got. I'm thinking of leaving the country."

Stratton's team regard the conviction as a success because prosecutions are hard to come by. Getting victims to make statements is difficult enough. Getting them to stick to their statements and give evidence in court can be tortuous.

It is common for victims to make "withdrawal statements" on the eve of trials. Neeves is still getting over the frustration of a case involving a mother who was being abused by an ex-boyfriend, the father of their nine-month-old girl.

The man tried to batter his way into her house with a piece of wood and said he would kill her if she dared leave. She did, but he followed her to work.

When she left at the end of the day, he ran down the road hammering on the side of her car, terrifying her baby and eight-year-old son. who were with her. That evening, he returned to her house and battered the door again. Then, he smashed every window of her car. She called the police at 9.40pm, saying "a man was going mad", and he fled.

As officers took down the details, he rang the house on his mobile phone and told one of them: "I'm going to get someone to blow her kneecaps off and throw acid in her face. I'm going to kill her family ... you know fuck all, fuck off." When he was arrested, his explanation was, "I get angry."

The case was dropped when the victim agreed to an out-of-court settlement from his family for the damage to her car. "It's easy to put pressure on a woman, especially if children are involved," says Neeves. "It takes a lot of courage to come forward, especially if your partner is apologising and saying it will never happen again. In most cases, it always does. We know some women who are bound to end up dead."

Abuse of men by women is extremely rare. Claims of such attacks are almost always made as discrediting counter-allegations. Stratton is dealing with one case involving a pensioner, but again, it seems unlikely it will come to court.

The 65-year-old victim owns a three-storey house in Forest Gate. When his son married, the newlyweds moved in. The son died 17 years ago, the daughter-in-law stayed and remarried. The victim alleges he was banished to the top of the house and treated like a slave.

"They sent him out to the shops and if he came back without the right things, they would beat him," says Stratton.

"The neighbours saw his injuries but he was too afraid to come forward and they said nothing. He suffered this for more than 10 years."

The man's relatives deny assaulting him. The victim is terrified and his resolve is weakening. Does he have the strength to go to court? "Probably not," says Stratton. "I'm not sure he can go through with it. He wants to withdraw."

Advice

Pek Choo is a social worker assigned to Newham's CSU. She's been working in the field for 17 years, advising women where to get help and whether to pursue their abusers through the civil or criminal court.

Newham is a poor area, but she says it is ignorant to assume domestic violence thrives in poverty. "Actresses, dancers, bankers, I've seen them all. With the middle and upper classes, it's just more hidden."

One of her clients was a woman whose husband worked in the City. She was also highly successful and independently wealthy. "One evening a week, he gave the servants the night off and ordered his wife to make a meal. Once it was prepared, he would take the plate and throw the food down the stairs, crushing it into the carpet.

"Then he would make her clear up the mess." On one occasion when she protested, he smashed her head against the wall. "Domestic violence is not always physical," says Choo. "It is almost always about control."

Arson

The 999 call for the council flat fire came at 4pm. It was classified as an 'I' incident - immediate response - but there were no uniformed officers available. Suspecting it might be their territory, DC McKeeve and PC Howe decide to check it out rather than wait for a report.

Within minutes of arriving at 6.45pm, their hunch proved right. Jane's ex-boyfriend was seen in the block carrying a brick shortly before the fire. A brick lies by a smashed pane of glass next to the front door.

The fire brigade believes it was arson, started by someone setting light to the sofa. The scenes of crime officer has arrived to take prints of a footmark and samples of smashed glass - it might be possible to match tiny fragments on the culprit's clothes.

At 9.07pm, the flat is boarded up with corrugated iron sheets. Jane is wondering where she will stay. She has decided to give a statement but does not doubt this will put her in more danger. "He told a mate of mine that I'd be dead the next time she saw me. There are times when I think I might as well kill myself."

Refuge 24-hour helpline 0870 599 5443. The names of the victims have been changed.

"It takes a lot of courage to come forward, especially if your partner is apologising and saying it will never happen again. In most cases, it always does. We know some women who are bound to end up dead." Abuse of men by women is extremely rare. Claims of such attacks are almost always made as discrediting counter-allegations. Stratton is dealing with one case involving a pensioner, but again, it seems unlikely it will come to court. The 65-year-old victim owns a three-storey house in Forest Gate. When his son married, the newlyweds moved in. The son died 17 years ago, the daughter-in-law stayed and remarried. The victim alleges he was banished to the top of the house and treated like a slave. "They sent him out to the shops and if he came back without the right things, they would beat him," says Stratton. "The neighbours saw his injuries but he was too afraid to come forward and they said nothing. He suffered this for more than 10 years." The man's relatives deny assaulting him. The victim is terrified and his resolve is weakening. Does he have the strength to go to court? "Probably not," says Stratton. "I'm not sure he can go through with it. He wants to withdraw." Advice Pek Choo is a social worker assigned to Newham's CSU. She's been working in the field for 17 years, advising women where to get help and whether to pursue their abusers through the civil or criminal court. Newham is a poor area, but she says it is ignorant to assume domestic violence thrives in poverty. "Actresses, dancers, bankers, I've seen them all. With the middle and upper classes, it's just more hidden." One of her clients was a woman whose husband worked in the City. She was also highly successful and independently wealthy. "One evening a week, he gave the servants the night off and ordered his wife to make a meal. Once it was prepared, he would take the plate and throw the food down the stairs, crushing it into the carpet. "Then he would make her clear up the mess." On one occasion when she protested, he smashed her head against the wall. "Domestic violence is not always physical," says Choo. "It is almost always about control." Arson The 999 call for the council flat fire came at 4pm. It was classified as an 'I' incident - immediate response - but there were no uniformed officers available. Suspecting it might be their territory, DC McKeeve and PC Howe decide to check it out rather than wait for a report. Within minutes of arriving at 6.45pm, their hunch proved right. Jane's ex-boyfriend was seen in the block carrying a brick shortly before the fire. A brick lies by a smashed pane of glass next to the front door. The fire brigade believes it was arson, started by someone setting light to the sofa. The scenes of crime officer has arrived to take prints of a footmark and samples of smashed glass - it might be possible to match tiny fragments on the culprit's clothes. At 9.07pm, the flat is boarded up with corrugated iron sheets. Jane is wondering where she will stay. She has decided to give a statement but does not doubt this will put her in more danger. "He told a mate of mine that I'd be dead the next time she saw me. There are times when I think I might as well kill myself." Refuge 24-hour helpline 0870 599 5443. The names of the victims have been changed.

webTitle: Itel strikes output deal with RAI

fields.headline: Itel strikes output deal with RAI
fields.trailText: 11am: UK distributor Itel has signed an output deal with Italian broadcaster RAI, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
UK distributor Itel has signed an output deal with Italian broadcaster RAI.

The deal commits RAI to a minimum of 25 hours per week of wildlife and factual programming over the next two years, with a commitment to produce a further three projects every year.

First fruits of the deal, inked at this week's Mipcom programme market in Cannes, will be three films about the Barracuda with Partridge Films; Bear Essentials, a study of the grizzly bear by Richard Kemp; and Golden Lemurs, Crocodile Caves from Survival, about a family of Lemurs in Madagascar.

RAI has also acquired Wall to Wall's Neanderthal, a 3D animation film about early man.

webTitle: French to endure British film season

fields.headline: French to endure British film season
fields.trailText: A season celebrating British film is set to open in Paris this week in the hope it will raise interest in British cinema among French movie-goers
fields.body:
A season celebrating British film is set to open in Paris this week in the hope it will raise interest in British cinema amongst French movie-goers.

The five-month long festival, called Typiquement British will feature a broad range of over 200 British films, from Monty Python to the Hammer horror films. It begins with a month-long tribute to the Redgrave-Richardson acting dynasty, according to ananova.

Opening the festival will be the 1946 drama The Captive Heart, starring Michael Redgrave and his wife Rachel Kempson. Kempson will attend the opening ceremony alongside Vanessa, Corin and Jemma Redgrave and actress sisters Joely and Natasha Richardson.

France has a thriving film industry with over 100 films made each year and with 10% more cinema admissions than the United Kingdom. But less than 5% of the cinema-going public opt to see a British film. It is hoped this festival will spark an interest in UK cinema.

British Film Institute director Jon Teckman said: "The festival aims to familiarise audiences with the history and heritage of British cinema we hope this wonderful celebration will appeal widely to French people interested in cinema, but also to the growing number of British citizens resident in Paris."

fields.headline: McCann names regional creative chief
fields.trailText: 10.15: McCann-Erickson has promoted Jonathan Cranin to the post of chief creative officer for the Europe, Middle East & Africa region, Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
McCann-Erickson has promoted Jonathan Cranin, a senior creative, to the post of chief creative officer for the Europe, Middle East & Africa region. He also joins the McCann-Erickson WorldGroup board.

Mr Cranin, 45, will oversee creative output for the agency's largest operating region including full-service operations in more than 100 markets as well as the 14 full-service North American agencies outside New York. He will operate from a dual base in London and New York. London's four creative directors will report to him.

Don Dillon, regional director, McCann-Erickson Europe, Middle East & Africa, said: "Jonathan's newly expanded role will enable him to oversee as well as sharpen our creative product throughout the European region, with a special focus on bringing creative solutions to our key global and pan-regional accounts."

Mr Cranin's credits include "There are some things that money can't buy. For everything else, there's MasterCard." In addition, he has had direct creative responsibility for McCann's Salomon Smith Barney, DuPont, Motorola and Chase Bank accounts.

He joined McCann-Erickson New York in 1994 as executive VP, deputy creative director. In 1998 he added creative responsibility for the agency's Buick account as executive creative director of McCann Detroit, and in 1999 he was promoted to the North American executive creative director post with creative responsibility for all agencies outside New York.
