fields.headline: Thatcher denounces government over pensions
fields.standfirst:
• Pensions policy 'an outright fraud'
• Former PM Heath attacks Hague
fields.trailText: Tory former Prime Minister Baroness Thatcher today denounced the Government's pensions policy as "an outright fraud".
fields.body:
Tory former Prime Minister Baroness Thatcher today denounced the Government's pensions policy as "an outright fraud".

Arriving at the Conservative Party Conference in Bournemouth, she said it was wrong for pensioners to be means-tested for a benefit towards which they had contributed all their working lives.

Lady Thatcher was greeted by William Hague who, she said, was doing "very well" as leader.

Meanwhile, Tory former prime minister Sir Edward Heath today unleashed a stinging attack on William Hague's leadership.

He accused the Conservative leader of producing policies "out of the blue" to cut fuel tax and raise pensions and questioned whether they could really be afforded. Sir Edward said the party was wrong to emphasise tax cuts at the expense of increased spending on the National Health Service and cast doubt on Mr Hague's claims that Tories were now a "One Nation" party.

"What people are saying is that he suddenly produces these policies out of the blue - this was certainly true of petrol - and of course then people aren't impressed," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "They say you are just making it up on the spur of the moment ... That is a very dangerous technique to follow."

Sir Edward said Mr Hague still had to show that he would, as he claimed, govern in the interests of all of the British people. "It is not enough to say we're the One Nation party. You have got to show you're the One Nation party by the action that you take," he said.

However shadow chancellor Michael Portillo insisted that continuing growth in the economy meant that the party's spending plans were affordable. "As long as we don't have the Government taking all of the increase in national wealth as it occurs year-by-year we can have much more money on public services and we can leave some room for tax reductions," he told the programme.

Mr Portillo, who is set to unveil proposals for a major expansion of private sector healthcare, rejected Sir Edward's argument that better-off voters were prepared to pay higher taxes in order to fund NHS improvements. He said that the recent fuel tax protests showed that there was strong public resistance to any increase in taxation levels. "I think governments are now going to find it extremely difficult to get new tax money," he said.

webTitle: Muzik appoints Ministry deputy Chris Elwell-Sutton as editor

fields.headline: Muzik appoints Ministry deputy Elwell-Sutton as editor
fields.trailText: 9am: Chris Elwell-Sutton has replaced Dave Fowler as editor at IPC Media's dance music title, Muzik, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Chris Elwell-Sutton has replaced Dave Fowler as editor at IPC Media's dance music title, Muzik.

Mr Elwell-Sutton joins from the Ministry of Sound's Ministry magazine, where he was deputy editor. Mr Fowler has gone to work for the Ministry's new media development team.

Mr Elwell-Sutton will be the third editor of Muzik in a year. He has been at Ministry for a year, and has freelanced for the dance music and national press.

Mr Fowler replaced Ben Turner, who earlier this year left to join internet music agency Worldpop.

Muzik, which launched in 1994, has carved out a niche in the dance music magazines market under co-launch editor Mr Turner. However, the magazine has recently been overtaken by newcomers such as Ministry.

IPC's Music & Sport division has consolidated recently following the appointments of Mike Soutar as managing director and Eric Fuller as publishing director. The division has witnessed falling ratings figures across the board and rumours earlier in the year of a possible sell-off.

webTitle: IPC lures ITV marketing chief Sam Carter

fields.headline: IPC lures ITV marketing chief Carter
fields.trailText: 9.15am: IPC Connect has poached ITV head of marketing Sam Carter to be its marketing director. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC Connect has poached ITV's head of marketing, Sam Carter, to be its marketing director.

Ms Carter is the final senior marketing appointment instigated by group marketing director Philippa Brown, who earlier this year was appointed from planning and buying agency Starcom Motive.

Capital Radio's Vijay Solanki was recently hired as marketing director of IPC Music & Sport, while former Procter & Gamble brand director Helen Farquhar was appointed strategic marketing director at IPC Southbank. Her appointment follows a period of repositioning at IPC, which has followed the lead set last year by Emap in grouping its magazines around brand sectors, such as music and sport and Connect (women's weeklies).

Ms Carter is expected to lay the ground for IPC Connect to extend more magazine brands into masthead TV content.

IPC has created a number of masthead TV programmes from its magazine brands. The publisher this month announced plans to launch NME TV on Bravo, after dipping a toe in the water with Practical Parenting and Chat's Moral Dilemmas on the Living Channel.

Ms Carter joined ITV in 1996, aged 26, from advertising agency TBWA, with a brief to focus and extend the ITV brand. The departure will be a setback for ITV, which is still searching for a chief executive.

fields.headline: QXL hires Webvan's Zaleski
fields.trailText: 9.45am: QXL has appointed its first chief operating officer, Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
Auction site QXL has appointed its first chief operating officer and plans to expand into new areas and markets.

Mark Zaleski joins from US company Webvan Group, where he was senior vice-president of area operations.

Mr Zaleski, 37, is to be responsible for all operational aspects of the business, manage the auction site's individual country operations and ensure the integration of recently acquired companies. Before joining Webvan, he worked at ACNielsen and Federal Express.

"I have spent a large part of my career working in the pan-European operations of global companies and I look forward to using this knowledge at QXL to help continue building a world-class operation," he said.

At the same time, QXL has promoted Stan Laurent, currently senior vice-president of sales and marketing, to the new role of president, strategic development. Laurent will focus on strategic investments, key partnerships and further geographic expansion.

Jim Rose, chief executive officer at QXL, said: "Mark's wide international business experience, including significant pan-European roles and the start-up of Webvan in the US, brings further depth to the strong management team of QXL."

fields.body:
Monster.com, the global career and recruitment portal, has handed its $40m (£26m) pan-European launch business to Zenith Media.

Creative work is handled by Zenith's sister agency, Saatchi & Saatchi, which produced the current campaign running in Monster.com's key markets of Belgium, France, Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands, Spain, the UK and Italy.

webTitle: Granada to hold meeting to outline plans for United's ITV interests

fields.headline: Granada calls meeting to outline plans for United's ITV interests
fields.standfirst: United News & Media shares rise by 4%
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Senior United News & Media executives have been called to a meeting tomorrow to hear Granada Media's plans for taking over United's ITV businesses, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Senior United News & Media production and broadcasting executives have been called to a meeting in London tomorrow to hear Granada Media's plans for taking over United's ITV businesses.

Granada Media chairman Charles Allen and chief executive Steve Morrison are expected to address the gathering, which will take place in the morning at the LWT offices on the South Bank.

The meeting will take place on the same day that Granada takes over official management control of United's ITV interests, which encompass the Anglia, HTV and Meridian franchises, United Productions, sales house TSMS and distribution arm Itel.

The £1.75bn deal was last Wednesday given the go-ahead by the two companies' shareholders at respective EGMs.

webTitle: Two Way TV hires games channel head

fields.headline: Two Way TV hires Small to launch games channel
fields.standfirst: Two Way TV signs sponsorship deal with Sportal.co.uk
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Two Way TV has poached Simon Small to launch its interactive games channel, Jessica Hodgson writes.
fields.body:
Two Way TV has poached former Sky Sports interactive TV producer Simon Small to head the launch of its interactive games channel.

Mr Small, who left Sky Sports earlier in the year to join digital agency Digital Octopus, worked on Sky's interactive Five Nations Rugby coverage last year.

Two Way TV is understood to be on the verge of striking a carriage deal with ONdigital and intends to take over responsibility for ONdigital's games offering, On Games.

But the deal has been delayed by uncertainty surrounding ONdigital's future following reports that telecommunications companies are considering taking a stake in the channel.

webTitle: Kraft looks to consolidate Euro media

fields.headline: Kraft looks to consolidate Euro media
fields.trailText: 9am: Kraft Foods International has begun talks with media networks with a view to consolidating its European media business, Jade Garrett writes.
fields.body:
Kraft Foods International has begun talks with media networks with a view to consolidating its European media business. Agencies approached so far are thought to include MindShare, Media Edge, OMD Worldwide, Carat, Zenith and CIA.

Kraft Foods International European Union region, based in London, now works with 14 different agencies for planning and six for buying. A decision is expected by the end of the year.

Nick Shepherd, vice-president, strategy and business development of Kraft's EU business, who is spearheading the review, has said his aim is to optimise media operations throughout the region while taking into account the individual requirements of different European markets.

Kraft's European review will include Germany, France, Italy, the UK, Spain, Portugal, Benelux, Austria, Switzerland, Greece and Ireland.

webTitle: Oftel to act on BT local loop row

fields.headline: Oftel to act on BT local loop row
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Oftel has confirmed that it has received a complaint from an "industry group" about BT's unbundling of local loops. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
Telecoms regulator Oftel has confirmed that it has received a complaint from an "industry group" which is believed to be protesting over BT's unbundling of local loops.

Colt Telecom, Kingston Communications and Energis have lodged a protest with the watchdog over BT's slow roll-out of broadband access, fearing it is allowing the company to build up a monopoly of ADSL lines.

An Oftel spokesperson said processing the complaint was still in the preliminary stages, and could not give a likely time for settling what has become a major row between BT and its rivals.

A source close to the telecoms companies said the group is concerned that BT is racing ahead in rolling out ADSL access, while competitors must wait until July 2001 before they can compete with BT's service.

"People don't just want to be the carriers. They also want to manage the network, and select the areas they are going to use. It is a question of network management, and I'm sure the debate will run and run," said the source.

Under the current strategy agreed between Oftel, BT and other telecoms companies, the first telephone exchanges to be made available for broadband use will be in rural areas, barring immediate access to the more lucrative urban exchanges.

BT's shares were up 2.2% at 726.5p at the close of trading.

webTitle: Vivendi woos US investors with shake-up

fields.headline: Vivendi woos US investors with shake-up
fields.standfirst: Vivendi awaits Seagram verdict
fields.trailText: Vivendi yesterday posted sharply higher earnings and plans to revamp its corporate governance structures, writes Mark Milner.
fields.body:
French media and utilities group Vivendi's efforts to woo the international investment community were boosted yesterday by sharply higher earnings and plans to revamp its corporate governance structures.

Jean-Marie Messier, the chairman, said the group was looking to scrap a series of measures which limit shareholders' voting rights.

"I believe all the measures, taken together, make for an ambitious corporate governance package," Mr Messier said yesterday.

The company has held a series of investor road shows, ahead of its planned $34bn acquisition of Seagram of Canada, at which American shareholders are understood to have voiced concerns about Vivendi's existing corporate governance practices.

"It [the package] shows we are listening to investors," Mr Messier said.

The proposals include scrapping double voting which gave some shareholders more rights than others, linked to the length of time they had held their shares.

They also end the board's right to issue large amounts of new shares - without consulting shareholders - in the event of a takeover bid. Mr Messier said the company planned to post voting forms on its website as soon as French law allowed for the change.

Restrictions which link the numbers of shares of investors who hold stakes of more than 2% to the overall number of shares being voted look likely to stay for at least the time being, with Mr Messier arguing that the curb will become decreasingly important as Vivendi increases the number of shareholders taking part in annual meetings from the current 30% or so.

Vivendi's strategy is expected to put pressure on other French companies to bring their corporate governance more closely into line with international best practice.

Corporate France has already taken a number of steps, including unwinding cross shareholdings and, under pressure from the government, publishing the pay of top executives.

As well as its reform of shareholder voting rights Vivendi revealed that net attributable profits rose to €1.4bn (£840m) in the first half of the year - up from €847m in the same period last time.

The figures, which included a €380m after-tax profit on the sale of assets, were quoted on a pro-forma basis because of accounting changes at Cegetel, its telecoms business, and the effect of converting the results to an average foreign exchange rate for the period.

The group - which in Britain takes in the rail companies Connex South East and Connex South Central and water companies including Three Valleys - said that it expected second-half performance either to match or beat that of the first half.

First-half sales rose to €19.4bn with the main surge coming from the communications and environment business. The internet business was €72m in the red at the operating level but Vivendi said the loss was within budget.

Debt at the end of the first half amounted to €21.7bn but that figure would have been €14.5bn if the proceeds from the recent flotation of Vivendi Environment and other asset sales since the end of the period were taken into account.

Vivendi shares ended the day up €1.70 at €85.90 on the Paris Bourse.

fields.headline: Was Skinner really worth the price?
fields.trailText: 3.30pm overnights: The ITV debut of the Frank Skinner Show, which transferred from BBC1 earlier this year, produced solid but not spectacular ratings last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The ITV debut of the Frank Skinner Show, which transferred from BBC1 earlier this year after the corporation allegedly walked away from a £20m contract renewal demand, produced solid but not spectacular ratings last night.

The Frank Skinner Show opened at 10pm with 5.5m/30% share, against BBC1's Panorama (4.1m/22%). The Skinner programme enjoyed a wealthy inheritance from Without Motive (9m/40%, from 9pm), the first instalment of a hard-hitting six-part drama in which Ross Kemp plays a detective on the trail of a Welsh serial killer. At 10.35pm ITV successfully ran a third debutant, with After they were Famous, which attracted 5.3m (38%).

Channel 4, as part of its Doctors on Trial season, opened four-part documentary Why Doctors Make Mistakes (1.8m/8%) at 9pm. This aired against Channel 5's film re-run, Hot Shots! Part Deux (2.2m/11%).

Earlier yesterday, normal daytime service was resumed following the hiatus provided by the BBC's Olympics coverage, with ITV ruling the roost. In the morning Trisha (1.3m/34%) and This Morning (1.4m/35%) outgunned the BBC1 line-up of Kilroy (1.1m/30%), City Hospital (0.8m/23%), Bargain Hunt (0.9m/23%), Real Rooms (1m/25%) and Wipeout (1.2m/24%).

Even the return of that nice Christopher Timothy in Doctors (1.3m/22%) at 12.30pm could not stop the rot for BBC1, with the daytime medical soap losing out to ITV's Lunchtime News (2.4m/40%).

webTitle: Business: £16.5m for BSkyB boss despite £263m losses

fields.headline: £16.5m for BSkyB boss despite £263m losses
fields.trailText: Tony Ball, chief executive of the loss-making satellite TV business BSkyB, has become one of Britain's highest-paid directors after it emerged last night that he has been awarded a pay deal worth £16.5m.
fields.body:
Tony Ball, chief executive of the loss-making satellite TV business BSkyB, has become one of Britain's highest-paid directors after it emerged last night that he has been awarded a pay deal worth £16.5m.

The bulk of that package comprises shares in the company worth more than £15m, most of which he received under a long-term incentive plan soon after he joined in June last year. A third of the 1.8m shares can be cashed in as early as next month, with another tranche in November 2001. The shares were on top of a pay packet of more than £1.5m last year, including a bonus of £700,000.

BSkyB, in which Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is the largest shareholder, made pre-tax losses of £263m last year largely because of the cost of introducing digital services and the rising cost of programming. BSkyB's decision to give away digital set-top boxes cost the company £381m.

Mr Ball, 44, has, however, won praise for the successful introduction of digital services which has allowed the company to pull away from its cable rivals.

After a faltering start 10 years ago, BSkyB had reached 4.5m subscribers in June and has forecast that it will hit 7m by 2003.

He also resisted stiff competition in the auction for the continued rights to screen the FA Premier League.

A spokesman for BSkyB defended the award. He noted the incentive programme was linked to performance but declined to detail the targets that had been set out.

"This is the market rate for such posts in the media and new media sectors and is what you have to pay to retain people of Tony's calibre," he said.

The BSkyB share price has fallen from a peak of £21.58 in March, when enthusiasm among investors for media and internet companies reached its peak, to £10.34.

webTitle: British manufacturing shrugs off hauliers' blockades

fields.headline: British manufacturing shrugs off hauliers' blockades
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: British manufacturers weathered last month's fuel crisis largely unscathed, figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
British manufacturers weathered last month's fuel crisis largely unscathed, figures showed yesterday.

Factories increased their output in September, although at a slower rate than in the previous month, according to the Chartered Institute for Purchasing and Supply.

The purchasing managers index stood at 51.6 in September, largely unchanged from the 51.7 recorded in August. Readings above 50 indicate that the sector is expanding.

"The effects on the index of the petrol crisis were less marked than in euroland, suggesting the net impact on the economy will be slight," said Neil Parker, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Analysts said the underlying health of the manufacturing sector had obviously improved, allowing firms to shrug off the impact of the fuel blockades. Buoyant domestic and foreign demand kept order books expanding, despite the strength of the pound.

However, some analysts warned that it was too soon to pronounce manufacturing back on its feet as sterling's strength is still pricing British goods out of some foreign markets.

"Manufacturers continue to seek ways to cut costs," said Adam Cole, UK economist at HSBC markets. "The survey reported the eleventh consecutive monthly contraction in employment and orders are being met largely by running down existing stocks."

While fuel shortages did not impact on overall output last month, purchasing managers reported that the hauliers' protests had caused delays and disrupted deliveries and the institute warned that effects were still being felt.

"The fuel crisis placed UK purchasing managers under immense pressure during September," said Roy Ayliffe, director of professional practice at CIPS. "The sharp lengthening of delivery times seen during the month hints that the full impact of the fuel crisis may be still to appear."

fields.headline: Big oil's £75bn bonanza
fields.standfirst:
Crisis prices for motorists mean bigger dividends and share buybacks for investors

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The world's top 10 oil companies, including BP and Shell, will generate nearly $111bn (£75bn) cash this year on the back of booming crude prices, according to financial experts.
fields.body:
The world's top 10 oil companies, including BP and Shell, will generate nearly $111bn (£75bn) cash this year on the back of booming crude prices, according to financial experts.

This embarrassing accumulation of wealth against the backdrop of a fuel crisis could lead to calls from motoring organisations for windfall taxes to be levied on the oil groups. The lobby would seek sympathy from the government, which also feels the oil companies let it down during the crisis. The industry is expected to reduce the size of its money mountain through increased capital expenditure, higher dividends and share buybacks.

Investors could get $82.5bn (£56bn) through share buybacks from the 10 largest companies over five years to 2004, according to research by UBS Warburg. The biggest lump of this, £27.8bn, would be offloaded by the world's largest oil group, ExxonMobil, with £10bn by Royal Dutch Shell, and £11.2bn by BP.

These estimates, confirmed privately to the Guardian as "realistic" by oil company executives, are based on a conservative outlook of world oil prices. The share buybacks could be much larger if crude prices remain strong.

UBS Warburg has based its predictions on the assumption that the key Brent blend price will drop from an average of $29 per barrel this year to $17 per barrel between 2003 and 2004. However, it is not just the price of crude that has created the "spare" cash. Income growth from cost savings, half of which were generated through an unprecedented level of mergers and acquisitions, have also contributed.

The top 10 oil companies, which also include TotalFina of France and Conoco of the US, were 17 separate groups before they amalgamated under pricing pressure in 1998.

Yesterday there were signs that corporate restructuring is continuing in this sector with Gulf Canada unveiling an £800m takeover of rival Crestar Energy.

The top 10 oil companies are also benefiting from higher gas prices, better refining margins and improved conditions in the chemical sector where trading has been tough in recent years.

UBS Warburg believes this year will prove to be "as good as it gets" for the big oil firms, who will spend more of their surplus cash in future on expanding chosen areas such as gas and power projects.

Global crude prices could peak over the coming months when they reach $40 or even $50, but experts believe that growing production output will gradually hammer down long term prices.

The price of Brent rose again to over $30 yesterday, amid news of renewed tensions between Iraq and Kuwait, and signs that the EU countries were putting aside plans to tap into strategic reserves.

Kuwait has accused Iraq of stealing oil from a pipeline laid during Baghdad's occupation of the country ten years ago. Deputy prime minister Mohammed Sharar said yesterday that Kuwait had satellite pictures and field evidence to back up its claims.

Brent crude for November delivery moved up $1 to $30.84, while US light crude futures were up 96 cents at $31.71. EU governments failed to agree to sell off strategic reserves last Friday, after Germany expressed doubts about the plan.

A final agreement is not expected until the EU leaders' summit in Biarritz, in two weeks time. In the meantime hopes that Europe will follow the US lead and tap its reserves are fading. fading.

webTitle: Comment: Voters tire of French sleaze

fields.headline: Voters tire of French sleaze
fields.standfirst: The French electorate are weary of the contemptuous ways of their politicians, writes Jon Henley in Paris
fields.trailText: The French electorate are weary of the contemptuous ways of their politicians, writes Jon Henley in Paris.
fields.body:
The real question behind France's latest monumental sleaze scandal is not which of the country's two leaders will be worst hit by the fallout, but how much longer French voters are prepared to put up with a political class that seems to think that they were born yesterday.

There is no question that last month's publication of a videotaped confession by a now-dead property developer and leading conservative, which alleged that President Jacques Chirac was involved in a vast covert financing operation for his RPR party while he was mayor of Paris in the 1980s and early 1990s, has seriously damaged the president.

The tape came on top of a string of other rumours and allegations of dodgy goings-on at Paris town hall under Mr Chirac's rule. Perhaps not surprisingly, a poll last week showed 75% of respondents felt the president, who is immune from prosecution as long as he remains in the Elysée palace, owed them an explanation. Another 23% thought he should resign from office.

The cassette provided the most direct evidence yet of Mr Chirac's involvement in the slush fund. The deceased whistleblower, Jean-Claude Méry, claimed building companies eager for town hall contracts paid some £3m a year in bribes that went straight into the RPR coffers. Once, Méry said, Mr Chirac was present when he handed over £500,000 to a party official.

Nor does the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, come out of this sordid affair smelling of roses. His former finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, has admitted to holding onto the cassette for two years without passing it on to judicial authorities investigating the RPR's financing, rather undermining Mr Jospin's promise of a new form of clean, open and ethical Socialist government after the multitudinous scams and scandals of the Mitterrand era.

Part of all this, of course, is a by-product of the way France has, in the past, regulated the financing of political parties. Until a succession of laws in the early 1990s, this was pretty much of a free-for-all -- even the Communists were, it seems, illegally financed, as the appearance in court today of their leader, Robert Hue, attests.

That makes the "amnesty" proposed by leading RPR members last week understandable, if not exactly honourable. webTitle: Comment: New US battlefield for the rights of the unborn child

fields.headline: New US battlefield for the rights of the unborn child
fields.standfirst: The civil rights of women and those of the unborn child seem to be in conflict again, writes Julian Borger in Washington
fields.trailText: The civil rights of women and those of the unborn child seem to be in conflict again, writes Julian Borger in Washington.
fields.body:
Some 11 years ago, a woman called Lori Griffin checked herself into a hospital in Charleston, South Carolina, complaining of premature labour pains. Instead of receiving treatment she was handcuffed and shackled, put in a wheelchair and whisked off to jail. Her urine had tested positive for cocaine and she was charged with passing drugs to a minor - her unborn child.

On Wednesday the case will arrive at the US Supreme Court, which will consider whether the hospital had the right to test Griffin, and nine other plaintiffs, without their consent. On the face of it, it is a matter of privacy and the authorities' right to conduct searches on suspicion of a crime.

But it is about much more than that. It is a case that straddles the fault lines in US society because it pits the rights of women against the rights of their unborn children. There are other issues in this election year which will decide more votes, but none that will arouse deeper emotions. If the Supreme Court rules on the side of the unborn child, the road may be paved towards a reversal of Roe v. Wade, the landmark case guaranteeing women the right to an abortion.

In the late 1980's, the hospital administrators in South Carolina were facing a tide of crack addiction. Robert Hood, a South Carolina lawyer involved in the hospital cases said there were: "Pathetic situations, where the babies were born dead, mothers had abrupted placentas and almost died. And there weren't one or two of them, there were hundreds of them. It was going on all over the United States. And, in fact, in '89, it was an epidemic."

So the doctors and nurses began to carry out surreptitious urine tests on high-risk maternity patients. At first, women who tested positive were simply arrested. Later on, in 1990, they were offered the choice of treatment or arrest, but women's rights campaigners say forcing women into treatment is no way of curing them of addiction. Furthermore, basic constitutional rights to privacy, which prevent the government from carrying out illegal searches, are at stake.

Susan Dunn, the women's lawyer argued: "It's un-American. It is an abuse of power. It is coercion and control. It is turning a health-care practitioner who is there to build a healthy alliance with their patient for health, and turning that person essentially into a tool of the state, who's in a position to say, 'You do what I want you to do or I'm going to have you arrested.'"

The lawyers on the other side of the case argue that the woman's right to privacy cannot entirely outweigh the basic rights of the child, and as these cases where the pregnancy had entered its last three months, the foetus was a fully fledged child before the law.

"It can't be an unreasonable search and seizure when the government interest is so profound to protect maternal health, to protect the health of the unborn child, when the magnitude of the invasion is so small, because you're already in a medical setting," said Doug Kmiec, a constitutional lawyer from the conservative Pepperdine University.

The case is not only a proxi for the ongoing conflict over abortion. It is also tinged with race. The decision to test for crack cocaine inevitably targeted black women, because crack is the cheap, highly addictive drug of the urban ghettoes. Civil rights advocates argue it would make more sense to test for alcohol or tobacco, which are more widespread and can be as damaging to the foetus.

The simple reason, say South Carolina's supporters, is that alcohol and tobacco are not illegal, so it would be impossible to gain court backing to search for traces of them.

Whoever wins the case, it will be a sharp reminder that Supreme Court has become the arena for some of the most visceral debates in US society, and it's make-up is therefore highly-politicised. At the moment there is a 5-4 conservative majority on the bench, but with retirements looming, the next president will probably be able to choose up to three Supreme Court judges. It is one of the great prizes of this election.

webTitle: UK agrees restricted EU rights charter

fields.headline: UK agrees restricted EU rights charter
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The British government was last night claiming victory in helping to frame a European Union charter of rights that does not grant any new rights or extend the authority of the union.
fields.body:
The British government was last night claiming victory in helping to frame a European Union charter of rights that does not grant any new rights or extend the authority of the union.

Lord Goldsmith, Tony Blair's representative on the committee drafting the document, said he would recommend it be adopted as a non-binding declaration at the Nice summit in December. It was welcomed by the Confederation of British Industry but attacked by the Conservatives.

The charter of fundamental rights of the European Union, published coincidentally and confusingly just as Britain's Human Rights Act came into force, is designed to define what the EU - not individual governments - can or cannot do.

The idea was to make existing rights more visible to EU citizens and to give a moral dimension to a body which has never given prominence to human rights. Britain resisted attempts to add any new ones, or to undermine the European convention on human rights.

"We welcome the final text of the charter," Downing Street said. "It reflects the range of rights enjoyed by European citizens and is fully compatible with the European convention. On social and economic issues the charter sets out principles from national and European legislation but does not assert new legal rights."

Lord Goldsmith, a barrister, succeeded in qualifying references to the right to take strike action by referring back to national laws and practices. The same qualification was applied to article 30, guaranteeing protection against unjustified dismissal. In British law that exists only after a year's employment.

British intervention also managed to alter a draft reference to the need for workers' consultation. The original phrase "at all levels" finally became "appropriate levels", reflecting concerns from business that trade unions might be given a management role.

Article 16 of the charter recognises the freedom to conduct a business. The 53-point document itself states explicitly: "This charter does not establish any new power or task for the community or the union, or modify powers and tasks defined by the treaties."

It will now be sent to the EU's 15 heads of government, including Mr Blair, who meet at the Biarritz summit in a fortnight before they formally adopt the charter at Nice.

British officials say they will resist any attempts to unpick the text or to shift the charter to anything more binding. France and Germany have been pressing for the charter to be incorporated into the Nice treaty.

The draft won immediate endorsement from the CBI, which had opposed earlier versions on the grounds it would impose new costs on business and undermine Britain's competitive advantages.

"Nobody should pretend that this draft is perfect, but the government has fought hard for business and come up with a result we can live with," said Susan Anderson, director of human resources. "There will be no shift in the balance of power between the EU and member states."

Giampiero Alhadeff, secretary general of Solidar, an umbrella group of unions, said: "This is just the kind of Europe people want, a Europe of rights and responsibilities. We did not get all we wanted, but this is a great beginning."

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, accused the prime minister of having sold out British interests. "This job- destroying charter should have been vetoed at the outset, as Conservatives demanded. Everyone throughout the EU - except Labour - now admits that the charter is very likely to grow into a legally binding treaty. The charter's rights to strike threaten to roll back 20 years of Tory reforms."

Rights charter

Right to life

Respect for private and family life

Protection of personal data

Right to education

Freedom to conduct a business

Equality between men and women

Fair and just working conditions

Right of collective bargaining and action

Access to EU documents

Rights of elderly to life of dignity

fields.headline: America brokers peace talks
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, announced late last night that the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, have agreed to meet her in Paris tomorrow.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, announced late last night that the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, have agreed to meet her in Paris tomorrow.

"The purpose of our meetings is to find a way to end the violence, restore calm and ensure that there is no repeat of such an escalation," she said in a statement released during a visit to the French capital.

A senior state department official told reporters Ms Albright would talk to Mr Barak and Mr Arafat separately at first. "We'll start with bilaterals between the United States and each of them and take it from there," the official said.

Ms Albright had joined world leaders earlier yesterday in condemning Ariel Sharon, the Israeli hardliner whose visit to a holy site in Jerusalem triggered the violence. Ms Albright described his visit to the Temple Mount, or Haram al-Sharif, as "definitely counter-productive".

Mr Sharon, an experienced politician, can scarcely have been unaware of the response his visit would provoke among Palestinians, who hold him responsible for the 1982 massacres of refugees at Sabra and Shatila in Lebanon.

But some of the criticism was aimed at the Israeli government. In a comment seemingly directed at Mr Barak, French president Jacques Chirac said: "One does not fight against popular emotions with tanks."

webTitle: International: East not sold on values of the west

fields.headline: East not sold on values of the west
fields.standfirst: Germans learn two into one won't go
fields.trailText: The new ad for Lichtenauer mineral water shows, well, a bottle of Lichtenauer mineral water. "Tastes good not only after golf but also after doing the vacuum cleaning," declares the text.
fields.body:
The new ad for Lichtenauer mineral water shows, well, a bottle of Lichtenauer mineral water. "Tastes good not only after golf but also after doing the vacuum cleaning," declares the text.

That alone would be enough to bring on derisive laughter in most advertising agencies. But then comes the slogan: "Lichtenauer mineral water - so beautifully normal."

Despite reunification the Germans remain to a striking extent two distinct peoples. And nowhere is that clearer than in the overlapping worlds of retailing and advertising.

Lichtenauer mineral water is sold exclusively in eastern Germany. The agency behind its latest campaign, Fritzsch & Makat, has built up a sizeable business, with a turnover last year of DM5m (£1.7m) by producing advertisements that appeal to the still-differing sensibilities of eastern Germans.

Ten years after the merging of the two Germanies, Fritzsch & Makat's co-founder, 30-year-old Alexander Makat, sees no reason to abandon his firm's guiding premise, that Der Ossie tickt anders, which roughly translates as "the easterner marches to another beat".

"Everybody is trying to be politically correct and skate over the differences," he argues. "But when you do that you undermine people, because you play down the things that give them their personality and confidence."

Statistics show that consumption patterns are converging rapidly. But that, says Mr Makat, is only part of the story. "You see that easterners and westerners both spend, say, 10% of their disposable income on beer. But then you find that the easterner buys only eastern beer and the westerner only western beer."

From Radeberger beer to Florena cosmetics by way of Super-Illu magazine, there is a long list of products bought overwhelmingly by easterners.

Sometimes brand preferences belie deep seated differences in outlook. In the west, for example, people with enough money to buy an expensive car tend to plump for a Mercedes Benz.

"In the east, the ranking is Audi, then BMW and then - at a considerable remove - Mercedes Benz. This is because the image of Mercedes Benz is imbued with the old notion that it is a car for big capitalists," Mr Makat says.

In formerly communist east Germany, wealth and success are not seen as the unmitigated blessings they are taken to be by most in the old federal republic.

Mr Makat describes the dominant eastern ethos as "Prussian-puritan". Its values include order, discipline and modesty. This could explain a phenomenon for which there is no universally accepted explanation.

"If you come to the east and say 'My product is the best' or 'I am number one', you will get nowhere. Here you must never, absolutely never, use superlatives."

Thus the emphasis on normality in the mineral water slogan. The rest of the copy, by the way, is subtler than it appears: since easterners rarely play golf, the copywriter is conspiratorially intimating that they are most likely to need a drink after doing good, honest work.

Advertising for western products devised by western agencies can provoke suspicion - or worse - in the east. Among the companies which have turned to Fritzsch & Makat is the distributor in Germany of Persil.

At the time, it was running a television commercial that showed a woman executive who had gone back to work in late middle age. Her husband and children were failing miserably to cope at home. That was until she decided it was "time for Persil megaperls".

Fritzsch & Makat identified at least three ways in which the advertisement upset easterners. It seemed to be telling liberated eastern women that there was something wrong about going back to work. At the same time, it seemed to be saying to a part of the country in which work is scarce that you can drop into employment whenever you like.

Lastly, though, it tried to sell the product by reference to a lifestyle rather than on its intrinsic merits, and the inhabitants of formerly communist states are notoriously resistant to that kind of subliminal message.

Fritzsch & Makat came up with a campaign that concentrated instead on the fact that Persil does not wash out colour. The poster showed red underwear on a clothes line. The slogan was: "Red is love and should stay that way."

No prizes for guessing what else red stands for. Or rather, what it stood for until reunification 10 years ago.

webTitle: Olympics: Cuba punches above its weight to claim gold

fields.headline: Cuba punches above its weight to claim gold
fields.standfirst:
The unofficial best

Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: The United States, predictably, won the most medals at the 2000 Olympics, but everyone knows that is mainly because it is a hugely rich country with plenty of people. It drops dramatically to 62nd position in the Guardian's alternative medals table, which adjusts results to take into account the size and prosperity of individual countries.
fields.body:
The United States, predictably, won the most medals at the 2000 Olympics, but everyone knows that is mainly because it is a hugely rich country with plenty of people. It drops dramatically to 62nd position in the Guardian's alternative medals table, which adjusts results to take into account the size and prosperity of individual countries.

Its long-time enemy, Cuba, a small and relatively poor nation, comes No1 in our rankings.

We have given three points for a gold, two for a silver and one for a bronze and then divided the total number of points to see how many each country got per $10bn of national income.

This produces a totally different outcome, with all except Cuba dropping out of the official top 10 medals table. Cuba moves from ninth position to the top of the alternative table.

As in the last Olympics, post-communist countries did particularly well. Eleven years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, communist or post-communist countries captured 12 out of the top 20 places. But Russia fell from second in the official table to 25th in ours.

Nevertheless, the combined might of Russia and its former satellites is impressive despite the economic chaos that still prevails throughout the region.

There would not have been a single "developed" nation in the top 20 had the host nation, Australia not slipped in at 19.

Britain did well in the official table even after allowing for the fact that there were a lot more gold medals on offer this year.

With 1% of the world's population, Britain managed to get 3.6% of the gold medals, compared with only 0.5% in 1996. But on our adjusted table, Britain slumps from 10th to 54th position.

This year we decided to adjust the results by reference to points per $10bn of national income instead of adjusting the ranking by per capita national income as we did in 1996.

We made the change because the size of the economy is linked to the size of the population and our new system allows us to adjust for the fact that big countries have a larger talent pool from which to select their athletes.

China won't thank us for this. Third in the official table, the world's most populous country plummets to 56th on the Guardian scoreboard. (It would have been No1 on our old system which only adjusted for relative poverty and not population.)

However, its neighbour India, the world's second-most populous country, had the lamentable tally of just one bronze medal to share among its near 1bn population. But at least it did better than Pakistan and Bangladesh, whose teams returned home without a single medal. Maybe it is time to include cricket as an Olympic sport.

Japan, the third-biggest economy in the world, came fourth from bottom despite being 15th in the official table with five gold medals. There's a thesis waiting to be written about the state of sport in (non-communist) Asia.

If there were a regional prize, it would have to go to the Caribbean. Cuba, Jamaica and the Bahamas took first, second and third places (with Barbados and Trinidad and Tobago also in the top 20). For the peace of mind of the rest of the world, let's hope they don't enter a single Caribbean team next time.

If there were a prize for the top performing country of the European Union, it would go to Greece in 27th position. The richest countries in the EU - Germany, France, Italy and Britain - all ended up between the 50th and 54th positions on our table.

But these league tables can have very different outcomes depending on the criteria used.

Maybe next time around the statisticians should have their own event: there should be an Olympic event for drawing up Olympic tables.

webTitle: International: Germans learn two into one won't go

fields.headline: Germans learn two into one won't go
fields.standfirst:
Ten years ago today, amid fanfare, universal rejoicing and boundless optimism, the two Germanies became one. But almost from day one the reunification dream was clouded by misjudgment, hardship and political scandal.
East not sold on values of the west
fields.trailText: Today Germany celebrates the 10th anniversary of reunification. For some, however, "celebrate" might not be the right word. The dream has soured.
fields.body:
Today Germany celebrates the 10th anniversary of reunification. For some, however, "celebrate" might not be the right word. The dream has soured.

Reunification has placed a huge burden on the west Germany taxpayer. Officially the figure is just shy of DM500bn (£153bn) - other, unofficial estimates put it at double that amount. Even today the costs are blamed for hobbling the scope of tax reform.

But for all the flow of cash from west to east, unemployment in the new länder remains much higher than in west Germany and wages lower - an economic underachievement which has certainly not hindered, and probably helped, the rise of the extreme right.

Yet amid the prevailing euphoria of 1990, unification was meant to have been a breeze. East Germany's economy was the showcase of the old Soviet bloc. Its integration into the west German powerhouse could scarcely present an insurmountable challenge - could it? Germany's financial markets, in party mood over reunification, barely gave the issue a thought. Investors scrambled to climb aboard what promised to be a gravy train.

A decade on and conventional wisdom has been stood on its head. Far from merging seemlessly with the west, eastern Germany has struggled as plants have closed or cut back and workers have been thrown out of jobs once thought secure.

Unemployment in the new länder is just under 17% - significantly more than double the level in what was west Germany. Real per capita gross domestic product - a measure of relative economic performance - has been stuck at less than 60% of that of west Germany for the last five years.

Stock market analysts struggle to name an established east German enterprise which has made it to the Dax index - the equivalent of Britain's blue chip FTSE 100.

But why did the showcase turn out to be a basket case? Two decisions taken amid the euphoria of unification have had a big impact on the east German economy. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's insistence -against the advice of the Bundesbank, the country's central bank - on a one-for-one exchange rate of the east German mark for the west German mark was a vote winner in the east, but made much of the industrial base of the new länder uncompetitive overnight.

West German trade union determination that wage rates in the east should rise to within hailing distance of those in the west meant that efforts to address the competitiveness issue were stymied from the start.

Though wage deals have moderated in the past five years, unit labour costs in the new länder are still 25% above those in west Germany.

But as a Commerzbank economist, Ralph Solveen, points out, though the high level of wage settlements in the early years undermined east German competitiveness, a more commercial approach to wage levels would have had awkward consequences, too.

"Everyone who could have come from the east to the west would have done so. We would have had lots of highly skilled people in west Germany and no one in the east," he says.

East German industrial firms also lagged far behind their western counterparts. Take for example the state-owned chemical plant at Schwarzheide, bought by BASF, one of west Germany's big three chemical companies, within a week of reunification. At the time of the purchase the plant employed almost 5,000 people. Since then BASF has invested some DM2bn (£613m) at the site, boosted productivity, and yet the workforce is down to around 2,000.

True enough, not all of the reduction stems from improved efficiency. As well as manufacturing chemicals, the Schwarzheide plant provided a range of social services - from the local fire brigade to kindergartens, and even today BASF is the town's biggest landlord. But Schwarzheide is still a handy yardstick of the extent of overmanning and under-investment in the old east German economy.

Some Germans argue that east Germany has been held back by the attitudes which prevailed under central economic planning, that the region lacks the culture needed to produce an entrepreneurial class. Others argue that, in the past at least, east Germans have found it harder to raise capital than their west German counterparts.

The future is scarcely rosy. Though the performance figures are distorted by the downturn in the construction sector and manufacturing is doing better than the data shows, Mr Solveen reckons that without a serious reform programmeto boost economic growth, east Germany will remain dependent on the west for years.

webTitle: The best supermarket scene: Me, Myself & Irene

fields.headline: The best supermarket scene: Me, Myself & Irene
fields.trailText: Mild-mannered small-town motorcycle cop Charlie (Jim Carrey) is shopping in his local supermarket. As he gets in line at the checkout queue, a woman approaches him.
fields.body:
Mild-mannered small-town motorcycle cop Charlie (Jim Carrey) is shopping in his local supermarket. As he gets in line at the checkout queue, a woman approaches him.

"Charlie, hey, do you mind if I get ahead of you? I'm in a wicked rush. Is that OK?"

Charlie glances over. She's only holding a chocolate bar. He smiles.

"Oh, yeah, sure, go ahead."

"You're a doll."

Charlie blushes.

" Aww... "

Suddenly, the woman breaks out in a shriek.

"Hey kids! Over here! Now!"

Her two children rush over, both wheeling trolleys piled high with goods. Charlie looks stunned. His face reddens and starts to twitch; although Charlie is trying to restrain himself, his evil alter-ego Hank is taking over. After a moment, Charlie has evidently transformed into Hank. He looks around, peers into the woman's trolley, and pulls out a tube of ointment. His eyebrows raised, he turns to the woman.

"Vagiclean, huh?"

She look shocked.

"What's the matter honey? Little extra cheese on the taco?"

The woman is aghast.

"Excuse me?"

"No, excuse me. There's no tag on this."

Hank/Charlie strides towards the checkout and grabs the microphone.

"Price check on Vagiclean, aisle five. I repeat, price check on Vagiclean, aisle five."

He waits until he has every customer's attention.

"That's Vagiclean."

See also: Repo Man, Blue Steel, Go, Gummo, Palookaville

Don't see also: UFOria

Pointless trivia: Jim Carrey was paid $350,000 for his breakthrough role in 1994's Ace Ventura: Pet Detective and $540,000 for starring in The Mask later the same year. He is now paid between $20-$25 million a movie.

fields.headline: Little women writ large
fields.standfirst: For years, women's fiction has meant sex, cigarettes and calories. But now Helen Simpson is stepping back into the home to explore deeper truths about our domestic lives.  Melissa Benn reports
fields.trailText: For years, women's fiction has meant sex, cigarettes and calories. But now Helen Simpson is stepping back into the home to explore deeper truths about our domestic lives.  Melissa Benn reports...
fields.body:
One of the truths we take to be self-evident is that it is great polemics that change women's lives. But whatever happened to that great, and in many ways far trickier, tradition: fiction for, by and about women? Ask most of us for the title of a life-changing book and we are likely to pick a much-loved novel or even a collection of poems. It is not hard to see why. Great fiction always welcomes our return, there to find new meanings, explore old ambiguities.

For Linda Grant, journalist, non-fiction writer and Orange Prize-winning novelist: "It is the novels I go back to, particularly Fay Weldon's Down Among The Women and Doris Lessing's The Golden Notebook. I can think of non-fiction that was important to me but I wouldn't re-read it because one has absorbed the arguments and time has moved on."

That was then, but what about now? Where is the literary writing, as opposed to the fiction-lite of a Helen Fielding or Amy Jenkins, that explores the deeper truths about domestic life, friendship, motherhood, political involvement? Maybe we don't write like that because we don't live like that?

According to Anna Davis, one of the few women to feature in the recent much-vaunted New Puritan collection: "The New Puritans have been criticised for being influenced by cinema and popular culture, but when I listen to people talking on the street, they are talking about EastEnders. In many ways, these are selfish times. This is an era of trivia."

But we are undoubtedly the poorer for it. What was so important about some of the earlier women writers was that they granted their heroines a complex consciousness, a consciousness we take for granted in grown-up contemporary fiction by the likes of Philip Roth or Saul Bellow.

Simone de Beauvoir's The Mandarins, published in 1954, is probably one of the most monumental novels to describe masochistic, dependent love, political commitment and deep sexual love in one tale. Doris Lessing's The Golden Notebook, published in 1962, both charted the illusions and despair of a political generation and showed, literally, how women break down.

At the same time, writers such as Lessing, Margaret Drabble and Fay Weldon brought a ruthless honesty to their descriptions of motherhood. The feminist movement threw up its own explicit, polemical fiction. "This book changes lives" proclaims my copy of Marilyn French's The Women's Room. While there was undoubtedly mediocre work produced under the feminist flag, the best of it was serious women writing about serious stuff. It allowed a kind of multi-layered subjectivity that seems to have been ironed away by the relentless cigs, calories and condoms mentality.

Of course there are good women writers, young and old. Zadie Smith, Linda Grant, Maggie Gee, Hilary Mantel, Pat Barker. Lessing, Drabble and Weldon are all still publishing. But as the critic James Wood recently wrote, the fiction that dominates our consciousness and the market is penned largely by men and refuses "to take much note of place, history or society". Some of British fiction's most eminent women, such as Jeanette Winterson, avoid engagement with what we might call ordinary, rooted experience. AL Kennedy's last book was about bullfighting.

Enter Helen Simpson, the brilliant short story writer chosen as one of Granta's Best of Young British novelists and former Sunday Times Young Writer of the Year. Simpson's first two collections were wondrous wisps of satire, surreal snippets of modern sexual manners. But in her new collection, Hey Yeah Right Get A Life, she offers us something both subtly and significantly altered: a searing portrayal of modern womanhood that feels like some kind of restoral. In her slim, satirical, angry tales, we meet Jade the teenager repulsed by the "ragged cuticles ... heels stuck out from the backs of her sandals like hunks of Parmesan" of a mother she meets on the street struggling to get a lentil out of her child's nose. Then there is Dorrie, the stay-at-home mother who patiently endures the "seamless cycle of nourishment and devoural" that is family life, allowing herself snatched moments of solitude and a dream of a different future.

In some ways, it seems odd to argue that Simpson is the modern inheritor of an earlier tradition of truth-telling about women's lives. There is nothing polemical in her stories. They have a comic lightness born of rigorous craft. To an undiscerning reader, her heroines, most more or less desperate mothers, could be Bridget Jones postpartum. But in the current bland climate, her stories seem almost revolutionary. I doubt a less admired writer would have been published on such an unpromising subject as women at home, women in despair.

Simpson recognises that she has written something oddly new yet old. "The way people have been talking about it, before it's even published, I can see there will be some ... hostility." She hesitates. "Someone came up to me yesterday and said: 'You've written a political book.' I feel I've breached some kind of taboo." Which is odd, again, given the near saturation of our culture with ersatz tales of contemporary motherhood.

But if she is updating domestic fiction, in the best truthful tradition, Simpson's heroines never make it past the front door. In that sense, her work reflects the personal and political quiescence of our time. We still lack a literature that describes women in a wider context, women as citizens in the wider community, nation or globe, the kind of complex fiction that characterises the work of the Nobel Laureate Nadine Gordimer.

According to Maggie Gee, author of The Burning Book, one of the most brilliant personal/political novels of the 80s: "There are people, men and women, writing about wider society. But so many things, such as the market, the critical consensus or the slant towards historical fiction, stop us seeing it. A good writer like Pat Barker, who had written novels about contemporary Britain, began to get more serious attention when she wrote about reputable literary men in the first world war." Gee believes: "If you are interested in language and structure, write about contemporary society and are political, it somehow doesn't fit into the critical grid."

We can but hope. Anna Davis sees positive changes in both public life and publishing. "The protests against the World Bank suggest that something is changing. There's a new politics, a new generation out there. People in publishing are getting fed up of the Bridget Jones thing and talking about wanting to publish writing that has a wider sweep. Things could now be on the turn."

Hey Yeah Right Get A Life by Helen Simpson is published this week by Jonathan Cape, £14.99.

webTitle: Needed: academic high-flyer with a taste for airline food

fields.headline: Needed: academic high-flyer with a taste for airline food
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: For thousands of years our universities have puzzled over the most difficult scientific, moral and philosophical questions. To which the University of Surrey is adding a new one: chicken or beef?
fields.body:
For thousands of years our universities have puzzled over the most difficult scientific, moral and philosophical questions. To which the University of Surrey is adding a new one: chicken or beef?

The world's first professor of airline food is to be appointed at the Guildford-based university, paid for by a grant from the International Flight Catering Association worth about £500,000 over five years.

Professor David Airey, head of the school of management studies for the service sector at the university, said an eventual MSc in airline catering was likely, though he ruled out a BSc. He said: "There is certainly enough potential in it to do a doctorate of philosophy."

Willie Seeman, president of the IFCA, which represents all the major airline food producers, said yesterday: "More than 100,000 people are employed in the airline catering industry around the globe and around £10bn is spent on in-flight catering annually and it is growing all the time."

Up to 42,000 catering items might these days be carried on a single long-haul flight, Mr Seeman said.

"We have come a long way since the early days of flying when only tea, coffee and sandwiches were available when low-altitude turbulence prevented anything more sophisticated being offered.

fields.headline: Know your rights
fields.standfirst: First Edition/C4 - the Human Rights Act
fields.trailText: First Edition/C4 - the Human Rights Act
fields.body:
Do you feel safer today? Yesterday, laws were passed in the UK that will force any organisation making decisions about our lives to take our rights into account before they act.

For the very first time, the basic freedoms every citizen is entitled to expect have been written in legislation called the Human Rights Act.

What are these human rights and where do they come from?

There are 12 main parts or "Articles" to the act plus some additional rules in something called a Protocol. Some Articles promise us freedom from torture or slavery while others underline our right to such things as a fair trial, family life, and our beliefs. Protocol 1 describes our rights to possessions and education.

The Articles are based on those found in the European Convention on Human Rights. These were passed in 1949 in the hope that they would prevent a repeat of the crimes against humanity committed during the Second World War. So far, 41 countries have signed the convention as part of their membership of the Council of Europe. Many of those are well ahead of Britain by having already added the convention's rules to their own laws.

So, is this the first time rights have been laid down in British law?

No. There was the Magna Carta in 1215 and the Bill of Rights in 1689. These were forced on the kings of the day by the most powerful men in the country who hoped to limit their royal powers. What makes the Human Rights Act different is that it applies to everyone.

To complicate the situation, British citizens have been able to challenge laws which they feel ignore their basic freedoms. After failing to get justice in UK courts, people have been able to take their problems to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France. But this has always been a very expensive and long process. The new Act will make going to Strasbourg unnecessary - although the possibility still exists.

In what way is the Human Rights Act different from other laws?

The British people have always been protected by laws, but these have usually covered specific matter and have not laid down any general principles. One way of understanding the difference is to think of a game. So far our legal system has been like the rules of the game telling us exactly what to do. The Act opens things out. Now it's as if the game rules include bigger promises such as the guarantee that we will get time to play and have fun when we do so.

Is everyone in favour of the Human Rights Act?

Critics are worried that it will create more problems than it solves because some rights it guarantees are so general. Certain Articles also seem to be in conflict. Where does a newspaper's right of expression stop and the right of someone's privacy begin?

Some fear it gives too much power to judges who, although not elected, will be able to challenge the laws passed by elected governments. Others fear that lawyers will bring all sorts of "inappropriate" cases on behalf of troublemakers or lawbreakers hoping to escape justice.

Its supporters say that adopting the European Convention on Human Rights has not brought chaos to other European countries.

How will the Act affect young people?

It could touch on everything. For example, Article 2 (the Right to Life) may allow your parents to challenge your health authority if it refuses you treatment for some reason.

Headteachers and governors may also face challenges. They will have to be careful that punishments do not break Article 3 which protects people from degrading treatment. The right of freedom of expression (Article 10) could be used, as in a recent case, to defend someone excluded for setting up a controversial website critical of their school. The right to a fair hearing (Article 6) could also affect pupils facing exclusion. And just last week there was the case of Rachel Warden. Her father plans to use the Act to find out why an admissions panel would not support his claim that Rachel failed her 11-plus exam because of a health problem.

Is it enough to have rights?

Rights are one thing but they need to be balanced by a sense of one's responsibilities, and an understanding of how one person's freedoms can undermine those of others.

More information: The Children's Legal Centre's advice line is: 01206 873820

The Citizenship Foundation publishes a free booklet Human Rights Impact (tel: 020 7929 3344) and offers teaching resources on-line at: www.citfou.org.uk

The charity Legal Action Group has devoted the September edition of Legal Action to the Human Rights Act (tel: 020 7837 6094)

Curriculum links: citizenship, key stages 3 & 4.

fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.standfirst: Safety on the net
fields.trailText: Safety on the net
fields.body:
A mid the clamour of last week's campaign to persuade parents to "try out" the internet at their child's school - complete with laborious point-and-click demonstrations - one initiative lies buried. You are not lilely to find them on the official Parents Online Week site (www.parentsonline.gov.uk), but the Safety Tips for Children (www.iwf.org.uk/safe/children.htm) do represent a real step forward.

Internet Watch Foundation's chairman Mike Kerr, compares the five guidelines to the Green Cross Code. He worries that safety issues were overlooked in the rush to publicise Parents Online. Certainly the grotesque figure of a buxom Web Auntie, who purports to answer parents' questions but lacks an email address herself, is a very poor substitute for intelligent advice which could be given about children's use of the web.

Parents, a recent Readers' Digest survey revealed, are at the same time trusting (75%) in their children's ability to use the web "sensibly" and suspicious (49%) that they will find violent or sexually explicit sites. Chief among their fears - thanks, no doubt, to the News of the World's recent campaign - is the presence of paedophiles on the web. Kerr drew my attention to a recent case in which a Milton Keynes mother accompanied her daughter to meet a friend she had met on the web. He turned out to be a 47-year-old man. Sarah's Law, Kerr points out, will be no protection against such incidents.

Knowing your enemy and daubing a slogan on his door is, of course, a lot easier than finding the words to explain the possible dangers of the web to a small child, and the News of the World has not published his advice. The IWF has done well to transpose the "stranger-danger" messages with which children are likely to be familiar into an online setting. "Don't talk to strangers," for example, becomes "Remember that other people may not be what they seem, so don't take them at face value ... never agree to go off into a private chat room with anyone. It's much safer to stay in public areas with other people around."

Central to the safety tips is the advice never to give out your name or address online. Around a third of children are prepared to do this in exchange for gifts or information.

Parents Online, meanwhile, should help absolute novices. The Journeys section at: www.parentsonline.gov.uk/journeys is worth a look if you have a small child, and there are a number of alluring competitions to enter.

fields.headline: Loads of US
fields.standfirst: As New York University invests in a big London research centre,  Rebecca Smithers reports on the American Laura Spences
fields.trailText: As New York University invests in a big London research centre, Rebecca Smithers reports on the American Laura Spences
fields.body:
In the next couple of weeks record numbers of bright-eyed, bushy-tailed American students will arrive in Britain to study at our universities and colleges as the long-standing "special relationship" between the two countries shows no sign of cooling.

American universities understandably have a newfound appeal because of concerns here about the prospect of spiralling tuition fees and the case of comprehensive schoolgirl Laura Spence, who was accepted by Harvard after being rejected by Oxford. But at the same time the UK continues to hold its appeal for American students as the most popular country for study abroad.

The most recent figures, published by the Institute of International Education in New York in its OpenDoors Report on international educational exchange, show that the UK attracted 25,900 students in 1997/98. This is a 14.6% increase on the previous year and puts it 15,000 ahead of its closest rival, Spain.

Bill Clinton's daughter Chelsea recently revealed her wish to follow in the footsteps of her famous father - himself a Rhodes scholar - and take up a place at Oxford.

Although these figures are for the number of US students receiving formal academic credit for study abroad, time spent in the UK can be a matter of weeks, as a visiting student, through to three years for undergraduate study, with further study beyond that. Many students opt to take their "freshman" year at a British university, before returning home to continue their study at an American university. Increasingly, compatibility of courses means that students can now get credited for most - if not all - of their coursework in the UK.

If Americans enjoy the social life in Britain it is not surprising. Over here, US students can drink alcohol legally, whereas at home they have to wait until 21. But jokes about booze apart, there are worries on both sides of the Atlantic about whether the thousands of US students descending on British libraries and common rooms are engaged in legitimate study, or simply taking a glorified vacation.

The president of New York University raised these very concerns at the official opening of NYU's latest venture, its "NYU in London center". Dr L Jay Oliva, who studied in Europe as a Fribourg Fellow, warned: "The problem with the structure of the 'standard version' of the study abroad programme for US undergraduates is that it has been more like a vacation than a year spent working towards a degree. It has the elements of the Grand Tour: a little study, a little language acquisition, a few museum visits, and a lot of hours at local cafes. It is more 'international education' in theory than in practice."

On a more positive note, he said he foresees a future "in which no university education is seen as complete unless it involves a real and substantial international component".

NYU has decided to build on its links with two colleges at London University - the London School of Economics and University College London - by investing hundreds of thousands of pounds in a permanent base at the heart of the university in Bloomsbury. The new foreign study centre will be the first in the world to offer ongoing science work for American undergraduates doing a pre-medical curriculum. The London coursework will give US credits, while NYU is expected to offer courses to British undergraduates.

NYU already has similar centres in Paris, Florence, Madrid, Prague and - next on the list - Tel Aviv, as well as collaborations and exchange programmes with universities and higher education colleges in nearly 30 cities around the world. David-Hillel Ruben, director of the programme in London, explained: "We wanted to produce the most credible academic programme that will be highly regarded in both countries. In particular, we want to avoid students being ghettoised by being taught together, by American staff. We believe we will have a truly reciprocal arrangement which will benefit everyone."

London and Oxford and Cambridge remain the most popular cities because of the combination of their academic reputations and cultural attractions. But famous cities such as York, Bristol and Bath also have big pulling power, and easier air travel has made Scotland more viable. At St Andrew's the joke is that there are more Americans than Scots. That is flatly denied by the university, which says only 8.84% of its students are from the US. Overseas students make up only 12% of its student population.

At the top of the academic league, the long-established Rhodes programme for Oxford and the Fulbright Commission have offered American students the chance to study in Britain. Also recently confirmed is Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates' scholarship scheme for Cambridge University, which will open more places.

This year's 25 Fulbright scholars flew into Britain from the US for induction before dispersing to their respective corners of the country. Refreshingly, only four are bound for Oxbridge, although a large number are heading for London.

Rachel Stanley, a 21-year-old chemistry graduate from MIT, went straight to Southampton Oceanography centre, where her nine-month research programme will centre around measuring ocean currents. Fellow Fulbrighter 24-year-old Daniel Margolis, who is taking an MSc in local economic development at LSE, added: "I grew up in LA and went to university there. I wanted a different perspective on life from a different country. London is a cultural mecca - I intend to make the most of it."

James Moore, director of the Fulbright Commission, welcomed the NYU initiative - particularly if it puts an end to ghettoisation. "Anything that will bring more young Americans over here is to be welcomed. We want to show them that there is more to this country than men in tweeds and women in Laura Ashley. As Senator Fulbright said: 'It is when you leave your country that you really learn about it'."
