fields.headline: Lady Plowden
fields.standfirst:
Consensus-seeking committee chairman whose controversial report changed the course of primary education
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lady Plowden, who has died aged 90, enjoyed her highest public profile during the years in which she chaired the Independent Broadcasting Authority, between 1975 and 1980.
fields.body:
Lady Plowden, who has died aged 90, enjoyed her highest public profile during the years in which she chaired the Independent Broadcasting Authority, between 1975 and 1980. But her most seminal influence on British life was in the 1960s, as chairman of a national committee on primary education, which endorsed and symbolised a progressive educational philosophy.

At the time, the Guardian described her committee's report as "thorough, humane and liberal", and it was praised - even by harsh critics - as a real advance on what had gone before. Yet a generation later, so-called "Plowdenism" in education was widely vilified by people who had never read a word of the report - and who certainly ignored what should have been its most potent message: that Britain continues, at its peril, to accept high rates of school failure.

Plowden's public life also coincided with a crucial phase in the history of that peculiarly British institution, the "great and the good", the caste which, for more than a century, had chaired national bodies and peopled, in a relatively non-partisan way, the commissions dedicated to social reform. She shared her caste's tribulations too, scarred by Thatcher hostility to consensual politics.

It was not until she was in her 50s that Bridget Plowden became a national figure. But public service was in her bones. She would talk about "getting things done", with the implication that it was the obvious course of action if you were in the right place at the right time. And she was.

She was the daughter of an admiral, naval historian and master of Downing College, Cambridge (who gave her Horatia as a middle name). Her husband was the life peer, Edwin Plowden, one of the most eminent civil servants of his day, and himself the chairman of a number of important public policy committees. Her son William, UK director of the Atlantic fellowships, set out early on much the same path.

Because of her father's profession, Plowden was educated at a variety of schools and by governesses in England and Ceylon. She did not take up a profession while her four children were growing up. "I wanted to cherish them," she would say.

It was voluntary committee work that revealed her talents. In 1962, a family friend, Geoffrey Crowther, got her on the board of the hotel and caterering group, Trust House Forte. She was then 52. In 1963, so the story goes, she was seated at an official dinner next to Sir Edward Boyle, the most liberal and intelligent Conservative education minister since RA Butler. Impressed by Plowden's judgment and charm, Boyle insisted she drop her duties as a London juvenile magistrate, and her charities, to chair the Central Advisory Council on Education.

It was a major test for any chairman. The council's wide-ranging function was "to consider primary education in all its aspects". The members included stars of the profession and several intellectual big shots, among them AJ Ayer, Michael Young, author of The Rise Of The Meritocracy, and the Conservative MP Timothy Raison, then editor of New Society. It was Plowden's achievement to obtain a report from them, which broke so much new ground.

The report, published in 1967 and entitled Children And Their Primary Schools, has gone down in history as justifying a swing against rote learning in primary education, in favour of "learning readiness". But its real message was, of course, far more nuanced. Indeed, its curricular recommendations look like today's national curriculum.

It was also the first of the major education reports to give a place to parents, another theme of our times. It favoured systematic nursery education and denounced the cane. In addition, the committee argued strongly for favouring schools in socially deprived areas with extra staff and funds. This was a perfect example of old-style governance.

The idea had been fed to the committee by those who knew about American models. But it was Plowright's reaction which swung her colleagues. Her associates remember her coming to committee enthusiastic and purposeful. But then, one always imagined her being both popular and effective in a school team. She wanted to say she had been inspired by informal primary schools in the mining villages of the West Riding. Despite all the odds, children really wanted to learn. Shouldn't the committee look at this?

Plowden had known the Department of Education and Science would try to block her committee's ambitions. But "Biddy", as the DES called her, went on fighting for children in areas "buffeted" by failure and "forces outside their control" - like unemployment and poor housing - who had a right to the best kind of schooling. As she put it in 1972: "Much of the misunderstanding and violence in society . . . comes from a deep feeling of isolation and injustice ingrained in our city failures and within our education system."

She also argued that national interest was at stake. Not to act would be to accept "that we will follow the American pattern, and the problems will have outstripped our capacity to deal with them".

But however enthused by effective professionals, and believing in a consensual interest in reform, the liberal elite had forgotten one basic rule - that public bodies forget public opinion at their peril. Reasoned critiques of the Plowden report, like a famous book from the London University Institute of Education, were brushed aside by a new right, in the form of the education black papers, edited by Professor Brian Cox, of Manchester University. A hardening left offered no support; it simply saw Plowden as the mother of two Etonians.

The problems were not obvious immediately. Indeed, initially, the Plowden report was widely cheered. Christopher Chataway, Conservative leader of the Inner London Education Authority, co-opted her to help London primary schools "go Plowden". In 1970, she became vice-chairman of the BBC governors, where her "plain speak-inc" caused some surprise but added to her committee reputation. At the end of her BBC term, she was made chairman of the Independent Broadcasting Authority.

This was not a job in which people of goodwill worked together with more or less common goals. Here, the only unity of view was that they did not want an interventionist chairman, let alone an "educator" and an "amateur".

But while Plowden eventually won respect for what turned out to be a reasoned and minimally interventionist approach, she did perhaps sign the death knell for the "great and the good" being allowed to award franchises on a kind of Oxford viva system. It was the disaster of TV-am going to the establishment scion, Peter Jay, that was to lead to the introduction of the bids system by competing television companies.

Some monstrously partisan attacks were made on Bridget Plowden in her old age, amplified by the popular press. Yet she continued to encourage teachers and others dedicated to fighting educational failure, and she never abandoned the values of public service.

In her 80s, she was still president of an under-5s charity she had invented, called VOLCUF, of the Council for Gypsy and Travellers' Children, of the College of Preceptors, and of the volunteer reading help programme in schools, in which volunteers helped schoolchildren by reading with them. Plowden also told off John Major's government for decimating the HM inspectorate of schools, "the independent conscience for education". We must hope that she will now be properly honoured.

Plowden is survived by her husband, a daughter and two sons. A second daughter pre-deceased her.

fields.bodyText: Lady Plowden, who has died aged 90, enjoyed her highest public profile during the years in which she chaired the Independent Broadcasting Authority, between 1975 and 1980. But her most seminal influence on British life was in the 1960s, as chairman of a national committee on primary education, which endorsed and symbolised a progressive educational philosophy. At the time, the Guardian described her committee's report as "thorough, humane and liberal", and it was praised - even by harsh critics - as a real advance on what had gone before. Yet a generation later, so-called "Plowdenism" in education was widely vilified by people who had never read a word of the report - and who certainly ignored what should have been its most potent message: that Britain continues, at its peril, to accept high rates of school failure. Plowden's public life also coincided with a crucial phase in the history of that peculiarly British institution, the "great and the good", the caste which, for more than a century, had chaired national bodies and peopled, in a relatively non-partisan way, the commissions dedicated to social reform. She shared her caste's tribulations too, scarred by Thatcher hostility to consensual politics. It was not until she was in her 50s that Bridget Plowden became a national figure. But public service was in her bones. She would talk about "getting things done", with the implication that it was the obvious course of action if you were in the right place at the right time. And she was. She was the daughter of an admiral, naval historian and master of Downing College, Cambridge (who gave her Horatia as a middle name). Her husband was the life peer, Edwin Plowden, one of the most eminent civil servants of his day, and himself the chairman of a number of important public policy committees. Her son William, UK director of the Atlantic fellowships, set out early on much the same path. Because of her father's profession, Plowden was educated at a variety of schools and by governesses in England and Ceylon. She did not take up a profession while her four children were growing up. "I wanted to cherish them," she would say. It was voluntary committee work that revealed her talents. In 1962, a family friend, Geoffrey Crowther, got her on the board of the hotel and caterering group, Trust House Forte. She was then 52. In 1963, so the story goes, she was seated at an official dinner next to Sir Edward Boyle, the most liberal and intelligent Conservative education minister since RA Butler. Impressed by Plowden's judgment and charm, Boyle insisted she drop her duties as a London juvenile magistrate, and her charities, to chair the Central Advisory Council on Education. It was a major test for any chairman. The council's wide-ranging function was "to consider primary education in all its aspects". The members included stars of the profession and several intellectual big shots, among them AJ Ayer, Michael Young, author of The Rise Of The Meritocracy, and the Conservative MP Timothy Raison, then editor of New Society. It was Plowden's achievement to obtain a report from them, which broke so much new ground. The report, published in 1967 and entitled Children And Their Primary Schools, has gone down in history as justifying a swing against rote learning in primary education, in favour of "learning readiness". But its real message was, of course, far more nuanced. Indeed, its curricular recommendations look like today's national curriculum. It was also the first of the major education reports to give a place to parents, another theme of our times. It favoured systematic nursery education and denounced the cane. In addition, the committee argued strongly for favouring schools in socially deprived areas with extra staff and funds. This was a perfect example of old-style governance. The idea had been fed to the committee by those who knew about American models. But it was Plowright's reaction which swung her colleagues. Her associates remember her coming to committee enthusiastic and purposeful. But then, one always imagined her being both popular and effective in a school team. She wanted to say she had been inspired by informal primary schools in the mining villages of the West Riding. Despite all the odds, children really wanted to learn. Shouldn't the committee look at this? Plowden had known the Department of Education and Science would try to block her committee's ambitions. But "Biddy", as the DES called her, went on fighting for children in areas "buffeted" by failure and "forces outside their control" - like unemployment and poor housing - who had a right to the best kind of schooling. As she put it in 1972: "Much of the misunderstanding and violence in society . . . comes from a deep feeling of isolation and injustice ingrained in our city failures and within our education system." She also argued that national interest was at stake. Not to act would be to accept "that we will follow the American pattern, and the problems will have outstripped our capacity to deal with them". A hardening left offered no support; it simply saw Plowden as the mother of two Etonians. The problems were not obvious immediately. Indeed, initially, the Plowden report was widely cheered. At the end of her BBC term, she was made chairman of the Independent Broadcasting Authority. This was not a job in which people of goodwill worked together with more or less common goals. webTitle: Football chief to run school body

fields.headline: Football chief to run school body
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The head of Leeds United football club was picked yesterday to run the city's new emergency educational service, in a populist move which took opponents of the private-sector partnership experiment by surprise.
fields.body:
The head of Leeds United football club was picked yesterday to run the city's new emergency educational service, in a populist move which took opponents of the private-sector partnership experiment by surprise.

Peter Ridsdale, who won national attention for his reconciliation efforts after two British fans were killed in Istanbul last year when his club played there, will chair the joint venture company which is to run Leeds education authority after a devastating Ofsted report this year.

Mr Ridsdale will combine the job with his chairmanship of United. He called last night for an end to local controversy over the venture board, which will have two city councillors and two members from a private education company.

"I'm not an educationist, but I know a thing or two about service delivery and getting people to work as a team," he said after addressing Leeds headteachers at United's Elland Road stadium.

Leeds was criticised for inefficiency and political interference by Ofsted, whose chief inspector, Chris Woodhead, last week repeated a demand for innovation and improvement during a visit to the city.

The new board was, in effect, forced on the Labour council by David Blunkett, education secretary, after an audit concluded in June that the council alone could not ensure the changes needed.

The Department for Education and Employment is monitoring the bill for the Leeds experiment, which has already cost the council £50,000 in legal advice. Consultancy fees before the board starts work next year are estimated to top £600,000.

webTitle: So you want to learn... museum curating

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Museum curating
fields.trailText: Museum curating
fields.body:
W hat lovely porcelain. Oi!

It's Limoges, isn't it? Put that down at once! (crash)

It just sort of slipped. You clumsy idiot!

Please tell me it's insured! It isn't.

What? Why on earth not? That's my tea-break mug you've smashed.

Thank God for that. It's my favourite mug.

I'm sure you curators are well paid. You're joking.

Actually, I'm thinking about becoming a curator myself. Oh well, there are over 3,000 museums in the UK employing 13,000 curators.

Meaning? You won't have to apply here.

I get the message. Look, here's 50p for the mug - Thank you - if you tell me a bit about the job. Very well. Curators manage collections of objects of archaeological, scientific, historical and general interest. In large museums they are likely to specialise, but in small general collections that's generally not the case.

Any other differences? In large national museums curators either manage collections or administrate, ie boss other staff, go to meetings, fundraise and so on. In a smaller museum these duties are combined.

What larks! Tell me more. Curators identify objects.

Oops. Like your mug. Precisely. They record details, and organise restoration, care and cleaning. They plan exhibitions and displays, which involves labelling and displaying exhibits, writing catalogues and organising publicity. They may be called upon to give talks to visitors, including school parties. They're also asked to identify and examine items brought into the museum.

What skills are you looking for? Curators need to be versatile. Obviously they need expertise in the subjects that they deal with. Imagination and creative flair are important for attracting the public. Good writing and communication skills are also desirable for this and for accurately recording information and giving lectures.

What about qualifications? Over 85% of curators have degrees and higher degrees. Some local authorities require a postgraduate qualification in museum studies whereas large or specialist museums may employ someone on the basis of a good school record.

What degrees are preferred? Some first-degree courses include museum and heritage management, for example, heritage conservation or museum and heritage studies. Otherwise, relevant subjects might be history, biology, botany, fine art, anthropology, engineering, chemistry, ceramics, textiles - anything related to a specific collection.

Any age limit? You're lucky. There's no upper age limit as long as you have the relevant qualifications.

Cheeky! Any other tips? It's a good idea to have done some voluntary work in a museum.

What about training and promotion? Training is usually on the job. Most entrants start as assistant curators. In national museums, the career path is from assistant curator to curator, then department head and director. Promotion often depends on the size of the museum. Many are too small for a promotion structure. Related occupations include conservator, restorer, archivist and archaeologist.

 The Museums Association Telephone 020-7608 2933

 Scottish Society for Conservation and Restoration Telephone 01506 811 777

fields.headline: Well connected
fields.standfirst: Martin Yarnit finds some real examples of joined-up government
fields.trailText: Martin Yarnit finds some real examples of joined-up government
fields.body:
The government has still to discover what the practitioners have known for years: there are actually two departments for education. The Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) is the other. Supported by the Single Regeneration Budget matched with European Funding and the Lottery, a dense thicket of DETR-sponsored education initiatives and projects has sprouted all over the land. The result is two parallel systems, the old, or mainstream, and the new.

The inflexibility - of funding, management and curriculum - that dogs the mainstream system has helped to spark the growth of the new. If further education colleges cannot afford to run neighbourhood centres, then the Single Regeneration Budget can. If schools cannot afford to open up their facilities for evening and holiday use, then there is Lottery funding to help. The result, as a new survey by the Learning City Network shows, is a complex set of local partnerships set up to manage facilities which cut across traditional boundaries.

Hull is one city which has been grappling with these problems for years. In the mid-90s, it pioneered the use of the regeneration budget to fund schools and neighbourhood renewal. As a new unitary authority, it recognised the need for a partnership which could weld the old and the new systems together. The city created an urban development company, CityVision, to promote its revival, with a board representing the great and the good to run it. Sub-partnerships were given the task of managing economic development, lifelong learning, community development and the environment. A key benefit of this approach is that the main agencies have collaborated to bring about major projects, which would have been beyond their resources acting alone. Last year brought £5.9m for lifelong learning in Hull, including an innovative science and technology project for schools, whilst this year there will be a further £6m to promote learning in the city's most disadvantaged communities.

Joining up initiatives, promoting collaboration, developing an overview of local needs: this is the job that Learning Cities are doing throughout the UK and Europe. The rapid growth of the Learning City Network - from five in 1995 to 45 today, including Birmingham, Liverpool, Edinburgh - reflects the need for local partnerships to make sense of the plethora of government policies and initiatives. The survey demonstrates the range of the response, from small towns like Torfaen in South Wales, to Kent Thames-side, a region in its own right.

The real power of the idea comes from connectivity, from joining up centres so that they can share expertise and information. Glasgow's REAL Learning Network is the most ambitious project in the UK. A partnership of the City Council, Scottish Enterprise, further education further education, higher education, schools, business and community organisations are working together to create a single standard for an e-learning system designed to stimulate 300,000 new enrolments and to help small firms to adopt innovative approaches.

 Martin Yarnit, a consultant on learning and urban regeneration, acts as policy adviser to Learning City Network.

fields.headline: On the web
fields.standfirst: Media
fields.trailText: Media
fields.body:
Media History Project

*****

Aimed at: everyone

If you want to see the study of media in its historical context - from its printing origins through to sound recording and the beginnings of the internet - this is by far the most useful place. Its exhaustive timeline starts thousands of years before Caxton and Gutenberg with the earliest known clay tablets depicting Sumerian accounts in 3500BC. MHP also has an eclectic set of explanations of key concepts in media studies, including muckraking, symbolic interactionism and technological utopias.

Hobbes' Timeline

***

Aimed at: everyone

The early history of the internet, which is peppered with acronyms and the construction of data networks, is of interest chiefly to technical staff. Developments from around 1992 onwards are more compelling. Scroll down for useful cross-references to relevant essays and studies.

Editor and Publisher

***

Aimed at: everyone

The Editor and Publisher resembles Britain's trade publication, the UK Press Gazette, but some of it is of interest to students elsewhere. Steve Outing's Stop the Presses column is particularly well-informed. The Media Links service, meanwhile, takes you to newspaper, magazine, TV and radio sites all over the world.

Media Guardian

(No star rating - it's a Guardian site)

Aimed at: everyone

The Guardian's latest site chronicles and analyses developments on the web, in newspapers and on TV, making it useful for research. It will also send a daily update via email.

Journalism Review

**

Aimed at: everyone

What makes online journalism different from the traditional press? It's a popular topic. Online Journalism Review only merits two stars because its downtimes are so frequent, but articles are useful.

National Museum

****

Aimed at: teachers

The National Museum of Photography, Film and Television's education section has online activities and articles for pupils at all key stages. It also holds regular workshops for children, some of which relate to media studies, and encourages schools to develop a website in association with the Stem (Students' and Teachers' Educational Materials) project.

About the BBC

****

Aimed at: everyone

An engaging history of the BBC, with video clips and audio, alongside details of its obligations and aims.

MCS

*****

Aimed at: everyone

An eerie voice greets visitors to the Media And Communications Site - "Just one moment, please" - before the full menu loads. (It may actually refer to a cult TV series. Certainly some in-joking is going on here). It's run by Dr Daniel Chandler, a media theory lecturer at the University of Aberystwyth, and is undoubtedly the most useful resource for media students on the web. It's really just a collection of links, but an excellent one.

Media Education

***

Aimed at: everyone

Does the media have responsibilities towards the people it informs, in particular children? Instances such as the News of the World's campaign for "Sarah's Law" would suggest so, although editors do make very similar decisions every day. The Center for Media Education, based in the US, tackles the subject admirably.

You can find more media studies sites at: Netclass or contact Ros Taylor at: ros.taylor@theguardian.com

webTitle: Success story: Lord Mayor Treloar National Specialist College

fields.headline: Success story
fields.standfirst: John Crace visits a college where art helps students deal with life and death
fields.trailText: John Crace visits a college where art helps students deal with life and death
fields.body:
Looking at much of the art work produced by the students at the Lord Mayor Treloar National Specialist College, near Alton in Hampshire, you would be hard pushed to distinguish it from that of other art students. A discerning eye might note that much of the work was small scale, but you might just put that down to fashion. You would be wrong. Many of the students are wheelchair users and only have limited reach and others have no use of their arms whatsoever and paint with their mouth or feet.

Treloar College was created in 1995 as an independent further education college for young people with physical disabilities and learning difficulties. It attracts students from all over the country. It offers a broad range of courses, but it is the art department that has won most accolades. The department, which offers art and design courses at all levels, along with photography, performing arts and computer graphics to 63 students, has been marked out as "outstanding" in its last two Further Education Funding Council inspection reports and some of its students go on to art school.

Linda Gartshore is the programme manager for creative studies at Treloar; a graduate of Winchester School of Art, she ran her own textile company before taking up her post five years ago. Understandably she is immensely proud of both her own and her students' achievements.

"All students are assessed when they enter the college and then placed on the appropriate courses," she says. "This can be anything from A-level to pre-vocational NVQ level 3. The main difference between our students and other art students is that ours can take longer to complete their work. For instance, students with conditions such as Friedreich's ataxia, can get very tired very quickly and can only work for half an hour or so. Therefore we have to allow everyone to work at their own pace and to give them the time to do so. The studio is open throughout the day. Some students have to be almost dragged away from the place. The improvements can be phenomenal. One girl student, who painted with a mouth stick, could only draw matchstick figures when she first arrived. She left the college with a grade C in A-level art."

The students also benefit from the expertise of artists in residence. Last year, Chris Plowman, a visiting lecturer at the Royal College of Art, collaborated with the students on two murals and this year Linda Chiew, a ceramicist, will take up the mantle. However, for all the academic and artistic expertise on offer, the college plays an equally important role in helping students in their efforts to achieve independence. Sam Snoxell, 18, has cerebral palsy and has problems with her balance; she came to the college from Dunstable College near Luton.

"I found it very hard to keep up with the speed of the course at my old college," she says. "I feel much more comfortable here, not least because there are so many people who understand how I feel and who I can talk to when things get difficult."

And things do get difficult. Adolescents with severe disabilities often have much shorter lifespans, and death is not an infrequent occurrence at Treloar; in the last year three students in the art department died within a short space of one another.

"It is tough emotionally," says Edward Pruen who has been full-time chaplain at the college for the past seven and a half years. "Oddly though, the students sometimes cope with bereavement much better than the staff. Many have suffered huge losses already and have a much more mature attitude to grief. Perhaps also the art students get to express their more complex feelings, those feelings that cannot be put into words, through their work. Everyone reacts in their own way; after the third death this year, we all just stopped work, walked to the shop and bought loads of chocolate."

A discerning eye might note that much of the work was small scale, but you might just put that down to fashion. You would be wrong. Many of the students are wheelchair users and only have limited reach and others have no use of their arms whatsoever and paint with their mouth or feet. Treloar College was created in 1995 as an independent further education college for young people with physical disabilities and learning difficulties. It attracts students from all over the country. It offers a broad range of courses, but it is the art department that has won most accolades. The department, which offers art and design courses at all levels, along with photography, performing arts and computer graphics to 63 students, has been marked out as "outstanding" in its last two Further Education Funding Council inspection reports and some of its students go on to art school. Linda Gartshore is the programme manager for creative studies at Treloar; a graduate of Winchester School of Art, she ran her own textile company before taking up her post five years ago. Understandably she is immensely proud of both her own and her students' achievements. "All students are assessed when they enter the college and then placed on the appropriate courses," she says. webTitle: Furthermore: When students keep you from food

fields.headline: When students keep you from food
fields.standfirst: Let's not be personal,  Donald Hiscock  urges his students
fields.trailText: Let's not be personal, Donald Hiscock urges his students
fields.body:
Being a personal tutor brings many pleasures and rewards. It can also have its downside. Right at this moment I can't think of any pleasures or rewards so I'll dwell on the downside. Like when a student comes between me and my lunch.

I've learned to walk the corridors with my head down just in case a nod of recognition gets mistaken for friendly concern or an invitation to open up a conversation.

And there's a financial incentive in adopting this posture, as students don't bother picking up loose change dropped onto the floor. On a good day, between my office and the cafeteria I've got enough for a cup of coffee and a flapjack. Mind you, pickings are thinner now that Colin from maths has started doing the same.

Anyway, it was while stooping to pick up a 5p piece on the way to lunch that I bumped in to Roxanne. I caught a glimpse of her distinctive tattoo.

"You're my tutor aren't you?" she accused.

"I think you've mixed me up with someone else," I tried.

"No, it is you. You're the one with the jar full of pennies on his desk."

She said that she needed to see me urgently, that she had been looking for me for days and I had not responded to her voice mail messages. She demanded to see me now. I was trapped.

The noise of clanking chains followed me up the corridor. When we arrived at my office I turned round to see Troy standing next to Roxanne. I was introduced quickly.

"Great piercings, Troy," I offered. "Mind your chains on the desk lamp."

"It's Troy who needs your help," said Roxanne

"What about your own tutor Troy?" He stared gloomily at Roxanne. "Erm, it's not me is it?"

"No, Troy wants to change his tutor. Tell him Troy," urged Roxanne.

There was silence. I tried not to look at the clock. Troy's bottom lip quivered and his eyes welled up. His make-up was running. There was an awkward moment when I thought I might have to get him to blow his nose and give him a manly hug. And all this while the choice of filled rolls in the cafeteria dwindled ever smaller.

Roxanne gently tugged on one of Troy's chains and he let forth. From what I could make out Troy had been the victim of psychological bullying by his PE teacher at school, or so Roxanne interpreted. I could barely make out what he was saying in between enormous sniffs.

"He was made to wear a school wig," said Roxanne. "When he shaved his head the PE teacher opened a box of wigs and forced him to choose one."

"So it all goes back to being made to go around wearing an early Ringo Starr hairdo," I suggested. Silence. Then a sniff.

"And all the other things, like the pantomime horse, the fear of whistles and the cycling proficiency fiasco," summed up Roxanne. "And when he escapes here they give him a PE teacher as his college tutor."

I promised to sort it out, to get Troy into my tutor group, to lend Roxanne her bus fare. Anything to get some food before it vanished. I met Colin coming out of the canteen. With a grin he patted his stomach and then rattled the loose change in his pocket.

"£2.58," he said smugly.

"55p," I mumbled in reply.

webTitle: It's parents who need help when the young fly the nest

fields.headline: Delivery room
fields.standfirst: As freshers arrive at the start of term, it's their bereft parents who need attention, discovers  Angelique Chrisafis
fields.trailText: As freshers arrive at the start of term, it's their bereft parents who need attention, discovers Angelique Chrisafis
fields.body:
Jackie Utting had just dropped her eldest son at Leicester University for the start of his first term. Hailstones battered 18-year-old Robert's duvet as they ran from the car. His face fell when he realised he'd forgotten to pack his radio. Not to worry, his mother would drive it one and half hours from Lowestoft, Suffolk, next weekend. She felt terrible leaving him there in the pouring rain.

"I feel dreadful, but not as bad as I thought I would. And not as bad as his dog, who has been very depressed all week. The full force of it will hit me at work tomorrow."

Jackie Utting clutched a custard cream. She had left Robert to unpack his kettle and gone straight to a meeting of Leicester University's "family programme" - the first scheme in the country designed to support parents through their children's student life.

Did Robert know where his mother was? "I don't think he cares what meeting I'm at as long as I'm out of his room and out of the way," she says. "But I'll pop back to the halls after this to say goodbye. I know I shouldn't but I can't help myself."

Leicester University launched its family programme in 1996. What started in the form of open days for students' parents has recently mushroomed to include a newsletter, web page, special receptions for parents, discount offers on food and books, university credit cards and a system for ordering cakes and flowers for children sitting exams.

It also includes invitations to socialise at exclusive alumni events - this month's is a party on the Cutty Sark - and the hope of persuading parents to sign up for postgraduate courses. The university has a large distance-learning department to spare parents the embarrassment of bumping into their child at lectures.

This year, for the first time, Leicester University staged a presentation for parents on the day they dropped off freshers. Not the standard tea and biscuits in the student bar, it was designed to ease the dilemma of parents who want to be there for their fresher children and students who consider themselves adults and do not want their parents around - unless it's to carry hi-fi systems.

At the presentation, the university's vice-chancellor, Robert Burgess, and the head welfare officer planned to address parents on finance, sick bays and their chance to use university facilities whenever they wished. Paradoxically, in the age of the gap year where mothers and fathers are encouraged to put their children on a plane to Borneo at 18 and never look back, 2,000 parents signed up.

Nigel Siesage, head of the family programme, said 60% of students' parents sign up each year to the lifelong scheme, which is free. "We aim to provide a point of contact and a form of cultural exchange where parents know exactly what is going on. For most of them, they feel this is the first time they have been excluded from their children's lives," he said.

The programme is the first sign of a culture where, as grants shrink, parents who fund their children are taking control of student life to be sure of value for money. There is an implication that one day, parents could receive academic reports on their student children, turning university life into an extension of school.

"No, no, no!" laughs Leicester's vice chancellor, Robert Burgess. "That could never happen because records of achievements are the property of students. We must not forget that students are legally adults and are here to work autonomously."

Even so, this year the University has produced postcards with pictures of the halls of residence and details of wardens' numbers which students can send their parents so they know where to reach them. The piles of postcards are depleted at the start of the afternoon.

At the family presentation, the university's vice-chancellor stood on a box in the middle of a sea of tea-drinkers in driving shoes. "I would like to welcome you to the largest convention of removal drivers in Leicester today," he told parents. There was nervous laughter. Students' relatives shuffled as they listened to talk about "a big community" and "large learning family" and fell silent with concentration when details of hardship schemes, paid-work rules and top-up loans were given. Di and Ian Johnson, anoraks still wet from ferrying their son Nick's hi-fi equipment, had come to the meeting for financial tips. Their son had just returned from inter-railing around Europe.

"I'm not nervous, I'm excited," said Mrs Johnson. "I thought the presentation was brilliant. Not every parent is here because they are upset about their birds flying the nest. We just want information."

First-year genetics student Sukhvans Sandhu, 20, from Nottingham, had followed his parents, brother and sister to the meeting, despite the fact that he was not in the slightest bit nervous.

"I don't mind as long as they're happy," he said. "My eldest daughter went to Cambridge and we had nothing like this there," his father Babinder Sandhu said.

"A form of pride in new universities is emerging at Leicester to match the old universities' alumni tradition," comments Robert Burgess. "Over 14% of our students had parents at the university, and we find lots of students come here if their mothers did. The family programme highlights to students and parents that they are joining a community for life."

Back at the drop-off point at Leicester's Beaumont hall of residence, crowds of 18-year-olds stood arms folded to the sound of "get in the queue to register, darling".

First-year law student Richard Paul sat embarrassed in a corner of the bar watching motor racing on a large screen only a foot from his face. Every other person in the room was a parent or sibling. "My mum drove me up from Watford this morning because my dad's just had an operation. But they are divorced anyway, so we wouldn't have done these formal family things," Paul said.

But his mother did mention a meeting and he suspects she sneaked off to the family presentation after dropping him off.

"I think she may have been a bit sad I've left home," he said. "It's good the university is welcoming parents because it's a bit annoying to have so many sitting in the bar right now. I'd like to go up and say hi to freshers. But it feels awkward when their mums have their arms round their necks."

As for the university's plan to encourage parents to sign up for distance learning, the first pile of fliers to vanish from the family stands was the postgraduate prospectus.

webTitle: If you ask me...about when the best local school is a church school

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: All the best local schools are church schools and they are also closest to home. My partner and I are not religious, although our youngest son seems very interested in God. The thing is, I neither want to go to church nor be a hypocrite. So do I sacrifice my child's education for my principles?
fields.trailText: All the best local schools are church schools and they are also closest to home. My partner and I are not religious, although our youngest son seems very interested in God. The thing is, I neither want to go to church nor be a hypocrite. So do I sacrifice my child's education for my principles?
fields.body:
Keith Porteous Wood, general secretary, national secular society, says:

Your dilemma is increasingly common as more people "come out" as atheists: 30% of the population say they do not believe in God. Although only 7% attend church on an average Sunday, 33% of schools are church schools. It is surely scandalous that religious schools - despite being funded by all taxpayers - can reject pupils because their parents are not deemed sufficiently pious, or of the appropriate denomination. Although they can turn our children away, we can't opt out of paying for them.

Parents want the best education for their children, and if this needs some gross hypocrisy by going to church regularly to gain a church school place, then that's what you will have to do, like thousands of other non-believers.

Not all denominational schools are felt to be good, of course, but many are. Their success is generally due to better funding and an ability to cream off the best pupils. The more they do this, the more other schools suffer.

Nor are denominational schools helpful in working towards an integrated multicultural society, free from sectarianism. You might think the awful lessons from Northern Ireland would encourage the government to reduce the number of denominational schools. On the contrary, it is actively encouraging more church schools.

The National Secular Society wants high-quality, non-religious schools to be available to all, regardless of belief. You may wish to join our campaign at: www.secularism.org.uk

If you send your son to a church school, encourage him to be tolerant of others' beliefs but, above all, to question what he is taught and to value truth and integrity above all else.

Monsignor Richard Moth Communications Officer, Archdiocese of Southwark, says:

Many Catholic schools are over-subscribed to by practising Catholics, so few places are left for non-practising pupils. All schools have their own admissions policy drawn up by the governors, but they normally offer places first to children who have been baptised as Catholics and regularly attend mass. The next group are those who have been baptised but who do not necessarily attend church every week. Other places are offered first to children who are baptised and practising in another denomination, and only then to other applicants.

In some areas Catholic schools cannot even take all the Catholic pupils. Where there are fewer Catholic families, the number of non-practising pupils is greater. It really depends on the admissions policy and location of a school.

There would be no question of going to church a few times and hoping to get a place at a Catholic school. References are sought from parish priests, and baptism certificates have to be produced. With children from other denominations we would expect to see, for example, a baptism certificate from the Church of England.

John Hall, general secretary of the Church of England's Board of Education and National Society, Church House, says:

C of E schools were never meant to be exclusive but for all 17,000 schools were founded by the National Society (the Church's educational arm) in the first half of the 19th century. Currently, there are high proportions of C of E primary schools in rural and inner-city areas - up to 75% in some areas) but fewer in the suburbs (often 1:8) and far too few secondary schools (nationally 1:20).

The Church wants to increase the number of schools in response to demand. Lord Dearing is chairing a review of Church schools and has called for 100 more C of E secondaries within the next five years. Popular schools doing well are not allowed to expand at the expense of others. So where there is high demand, C of E schools have to turn pupils away. The governing body frames an admissions policy in consultation with the diocesan and local education authorities.

Many C of E schools admit pupils from a wide area, giving preference to practising Anglicans. Others admit local children as a priority. They want to be places of encounter between Christians and those of other faiths and none, places that are generous and open but of clear conviction.

They explore the tremendous and fascinating mystery at the heart of all things, who is called God. That gives them their integrity.

Next week's problem: My teenage son only reads the odd football magazine. He used to be such a voracious reader, but now has no interest in reading. I'm concerned that this will hold him back in the future. Are my fears justified? What can I do to persuade him to read more?

webTitle: College heads should be in touch with their feelings

fields.headline: Get emotional!
fields.standfirst: The new breed of college heads can't wear bossy boots but must be in be in touch with their feelings, says  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: The new breed of college heads can't wear bossy boots but must be in be in touch with their feelings, says Peter Kingston
fields.body:
A word of advice to anyone thinking they might like to run a further education college. Two words, actually: emotional intelligence. Before many more moons have passed, this buzz phrase will be inked on the blotters of every governors' interview board in the sector.

And if you, the applicant, can't demonstrate that you've got it in buckets, let alone know what it means, you might as well claim your rail fare straightaway and mooch back home.

So, what is it?

"The capacity for recognising our own feelings and those of others, for motivating ourselves and for managing emotions well in ourselves and others," explains Lynne Sedgmore, principal of Guildford college.

What it definitely isn't is the authoritarian, autocratic, bossy mode which, fairly or unfairly, was attributed to Margaret Thatcher and caricatured as the "handbagging" style. Nor is it a management style which the lecturers' union, Natfhe, complains has obtained in a number of colleges in recent years.

Sedgmore is very familiar and comfortable with the emotional intelligence concept. It has been tripping off the lips and pens of academics in the leadership field since the 1960s, she says.

She is clearly fascinated by the subject. The bookcase in her office in college is dominated by tomes on creative organisation theory and corporate strategy. Her masters degree was on "transformational" leadership, her dissertation entitled Change Agent Skills and Strategies.

"My research has been on looking at how leaders develop themselves professionally and personally and become great leaders."

And so it was of no surprise to those who knew her that she was among the first batch of 100 college principals who volunteered for the further education leadership programme, funded by the DfEE, which began in January.

And no surprise that she was the principal invited to address her peers on this subject at a principals' conference in Liverpool last week entitled Leadership 2000.

Her address focused on emotional intelligence as a crucial attribute for future college leaders, and it was at the core of the leadership programme from which the first wave of principals have just emerged.

Not all of these people by any means were so familiar with the concept as she was.

"For the majority of people it was very, very new," she says.

The programme guaranteed its participants absolute discretion. There would be no leaking back to colleges details of how their principals performed.

Lynne Sedgmore is equally anxious to preserve confidentiality, adding that considerable trust and camaraderie developed among the groups of 15 or so, into which they divided.

But she does admit that the programme delivered a few whammies to some, starting with the introductory module entitled Taking Stock.

Its key feature was "360 degree appraisal". Each principal had to complete a questionnaire appraising him - or herself on 20 emotional "competencies" which together add up to this notion of emotional intelligence. They start with emotional self-awareness, and range through self management, social awareness and social skills.

If this wasn't sobering enough, the real rub was to come. For every principal, five colleagues from their college completed the same questionnaire, giving their assessments of their boss.

The only consolation was that principals could choose the five to appraise them. This turned out to be no consolation at all in some cases.

"There were stark discrepancies between some principals' views of themselves and their staff's views of them."

Sedgmore won't break the omertà of the group, but drops some hints.

"It is easier for women to relate to this model and to exhibit some of these competencies.

"But there were some men who came up high too."

The next module - Leadership - proved an even bigger blow for some. This considered six leadership styles used in combination by good leaders: coercive, authoritative, democratic, pace-setting, coaching and affiliative ie "very focused on people and encouraging them".

"According to the analysis, the ways that some principals led their colleges were very different to the profiles we were being shown of effective leadership."

Participants agreed that this was the most challenging part of the programme. Was anybody's confidence shattered?

"No. By the time you reach chief executive level you're strong enough, so that even if this doesn't give you a strong leadership profile, you decide to change and accept the mode, or whatever."

Sedgmore has little doubt that the emotional intelligence model will now become de rigueur for anyone applying for a principal's job.

The second batch of 100 principals is soon to start the programme. And a similar programme is just about to begin for senior college managers and aspiring principals.

Further education has certainly caught the zeitgeist. Concern about the quality of British leadership is sweeping through government, and the public and private sectors.

In best Whitehall tradition, a committee has been formed for the task. The Council for Excellence in Management and Leadership was launched jointly by the Department for Education and Employment and the Department for Trade and Industry in April. Top of its list of aims is making sure that the UK "is able to develop the managers and leaders of the future to match the best in the world".

Obviously the project needs time. "What do we mean by excellence in management and leadership? We're at a very early stage in that work," she says.

No single model has emerged as favourite, which begs a question. Has further education jumped the gun?

The leadership programme was put out to tender by the Further Education Funding Council. This was won by the Further Education Development Agency (Feda), in partnership with Hay McBer, an international firm of human resource consultants which was already working on leadership programmes with school heads.

Was the decision to run with the "emotional intelligence" model chiefly driven by a desire for an obvious change from the autocratic, authoritarian style which has been perceived in the sector over the past decade?

"No," says a senior Feda figure involved in this crucial decision.

"It was driven by the idea of leadership as opposed to management.

"And it's not the opposite of taking tough decisions."

How do you measure up?

Emotional intelligence: the 20 components

 Emotional self-awareness

 Accurate self assessment

 Self-confidence

 Self-control

 Trustworthiness

 Conscientiousness

 Adaptability

 Achievement orientation

 Initiative

 Empathy

 Organisational awareness

 Service orientation

 Developing others

 Leadership

 Influence

 Communication

 Change catalyst

 Conflict management

 Building bonds

 Teamwork and collaboration

webTitle: Radical proposal to cure Britain's illiteracy

fields.headline: Back to basics
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston  reports on a radical proposal to cure Britain's illiteracy
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reports on a radical proposal to cure Britain's illiteracy
fields.body:
Government should drop its "fixation" for getting 700,000 more people into colleges because it will do little to cure the UK's massive adult literacy and numeracy problems, a leading basic skills campaigner warns.

Instead it should make a certificate of numeracy and literacy a job requirement, says Alan Wells, director of the Basic Skills Agency.

He welcomes the extra £150m for basic skills announced by the education secretary, David Blunkett, last week at the Labour conference but says it must not be frittered away on the government's widening participation programme.

Most of the estimated seven million adults with poor literacy and numeracy don't need college courses, and they don't want them, he says.

A much more diverse and varied approach is needed which will enable many of those with less severe problems to get help at home, according to Wells. Nearly nine out of 10 adults with poor literacy or numeracy told researchers in the north-west of England recently that they had no interest in signing on for a course to improve their basic skills.

And of the 25,000 people who rang a helpline during a major publicity campaign on television, radio and in the cinema last year, less than half actually joined a course, he says. Only one in four was still on a course six months later.

"At the agency we have a sweepstake on how many were still there by last July and the clever money is on 5%. We'll know the answer soon," declares Wells, who believes there's a "real fixation" with participation in adult and further education.

"It's usually participation in formal courses and programmes, more suited to the needs of bureaucrats and administrators than learners."

The Basic Skills Agency is shortly publishing research showing progress in basic skills courses is pretty modest for most learners.

"We need to be a bit more radical. Success needs to be measured by how much we have reduced the seven million problem, not by how many people have joined college courses."

Many of the seven million could quite easily brush up their reading, writing or basic maths through self-help material if it was available widely, he says.

"This would allow them - as with most things people learn - to learn or improve at a time and in a place that suits them, not at a time and in a place that suits administrators."

A minority of the seven million - possibly four in 10 - will need specialist and skilled teaching, he reckons. "So we need to focus high quality courses, in colleges and elsewhere, on these people who really need them."

People need an incentive to improve, or even a disincentive to remain under-educated, Wells says.

"This is because they don't see much incentive at present except a vague 'feel good' factor.

"It means making the new national literacy and numeracy tests widely known, highly valued and a requirement for many jobs, in much the same way as a clean driving licence or a degree.

"It also means providing some financial reward for getting out of the seven million."

A DfEE spokeswoman said a national basic skills strategy would soon be announced.

"We've got a number of programmes for improving quality and relevance of learning opportunities which includes improving access to non-traditional provision."

fields.headline: Now or never
fields.standfirst: Being a mature student can turn your life upside down. Former barmaid  Caron Freeborn reflects on life at Cambridge and  Helene Mulholland looks at money matters
fields.trailText: Being a mature student can turn your life upside down. Former barmaid Caron Freeborn reflects on life at Cambridge and Helene Mulholland looks at money matters
fields.body:
When I was a little girl, my mum took me to the library each week. It did not occur to me then that I wasn't supposed to love reading. The librarian, regularly and in a terrifying manner, used to say: "You're going to grow up to be a right little bookworm, if you're not careful!"

I did, too. But I grew up in an exclusively working-class area, where it wasn't acceptable to be bookish. Only one person I knew - a boy - went on to university. Teenagers know that every song of angst and yearning is about them; I was also convinced that Thomas Hardy's Jude the Obscure, about a working-class character with a thwarted passion for learning, was my story.

Frustrated, I dropped out - although what exactly I was dropping out from is a good question. What I dropped into is easier to answer: sex and drugs and rock'n'roll, a failed marriage, dodgy associates, violence, a mental breakdown. But something positive did come out of that time - by chance, I stumbled into the Open University. Of course, I was a weirdo for writing essays when I didn't have to, but I was in my twenties by then, and reputation no longer concerned me. When I had my breakdown I couldn't do ordinary things, but I kept on studying. In a senseless world, filled with the dangers of preparing a bowl of cornflakes, books were the only things that made sense. Then my OU tutor suggested I should be in education full-time. I could see that was something worth getting better for, and began to research it.

Lucy Cavendish is a university college unique in Europe for taking only female mature students. That sounded great. Yet it is part of the University of Cambridge - I mean, me, an ex-barmaid, go to Cambridge? Do me a favour. But if you forget the hype it becomes clear that Cambridge can accommodate many kinds of student, with its collegiate system, one-to-one supervisions and student-led reading choices. Even the criteria for getting in suited me: mature students there still take an entrance exam, and must show evidence of recent study to a high standard, but not necessarily three A levels.

So I put my health back together. I had to. I wanted this. And in 1992, when I was nearly 27, I went up to Cambridge to read English.

It changed my life. Radically. I can't pretend that there aren't some attendant costs: educating yourself out of your own class, but doing so at an age where assimilating into the educated class is not realistic, not even entirely desirable, means that you become, for ever, neither flesh nor fowl nor good red herring. But that disadvantage can be made to work for you. My first novel, Three Blind Mice, comes out in April (Little,Brown/Abacus), and relies on my privileged access to a wide variety of class accents, attitudes, ways of life. Novelists should fit in everywhere and nowhere.

Lucy Cavendish College should perhaps, then, produce more novelists than it does, for it is full of women from every social class who find themselves in a position far different from their original expectations.

And it is the one place where not fitting in becomes the touchstone for belonging. The friends I made at Lucy Cavendish will be in my life always. My contemporaries include a journalist (ex-housewife), a medical negligence solicitor (ex-nurse), a doctor (ex-rock musician), an academic researcher (ex-care assistant). I'm not saying it's been easy for any of us, that there aren't less encouraging stories of marriages breaking down under the pressure, of debts building up - but of my own crowd, only one person is not more fulfilled than before.

I stayed on to do graduate work, and now teach for Lucy Cavendish and for several other Cambridge colleges, including the more famous ones. But I always give preference to Lucy, turning down other work if I think it will interfere with my commitment there. I generally prefer teaching mature students - they often bring a real passion to their work, rarely taking the opportunity for granted. And after all, I owe my own college my loyalty, as it gave me my chance. For me it wasn't a second chance. It was my chance, for which I'm inexpressibly grateful.

Not all mature students will have their lives so transformed, but no life can be quite the same after an education. At the least, it will contain a far higher level of choice.

Parity of secondary education and a change in social attitudes would mean that fewer people who would benefit from higher education would have to do without one.

The biggest barrier is that too many people don't realise that the possibility is open to them. We who have discovered that it is have a responsibility to shout about it.

An ex-public schoolboy said to me: "When I came up to Cambridge, I never expected to be taught by someone who wears five-inch heels, has tattoos, and speaks like an Essex girl." She never expected to be teaching him, either. For some mature students, other universities, perhaps those in their home towns or those offering distance or part-time courses, would be more suitable, but this is my story and I went to Cambridge. It is just one option, but it is a real one. Jude wasn't about me after all; I've constructed my own narrative. We must ensure that other stories will be written by repeating our own.

 Caron Freeborn, Senior Member of Lucy Cavendish College, Cambridge, will speak at a major policy conference, organised by the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals in UK Universities, called Mature Students: encouraging participation and achievement. It is on Tuesday October 10 at the New Connaught Rooms in Covent Garden, London and is supported by the Guardian. Booking details are on 020-7453 5499 or visit www.cvcp.ac.uk/policyconferences. Experts on mature student recruitment, retention and support will speak. Keynote speakers are Baroness Blackstone, minister of state at the Department of Education and Employment; Dr Michael Goldstein, chair of the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service and Baroness Warwick, chief executive of CVCP.

Money matters

At the very time the government is setting its sights on 50% of under-30s taking up university study within the next decade, the figure for mature student applications is on the wane. Last year, the introduction of tuition fees saw applications fall by nearly 5% on the previous year.

So is university life still a viable option for the adult returner? The truth about tuition fees, when all the media hype has been stripped away, is that 44% of all students pay nothing at all (soon to rise to 50%), with mature students least likely to do so. As thresholds currently stand, anyone earning less than £17,805 prior to studying is exempt. Only those making more than £28,504 pay the full amount, currently £1,050 per year.

The downside is that both the prospective student and their cohabiting partner or spouse will have their income, and any interest, means-tested, though capital savings are not included. Students who previously studied full-time on a HE course for longer than one academic year with state support will be expected to pay the full fee.

On the maintenance side, the biggest source of finance is the student loan, of which 25% is means-tested. A few student groups automatically get full loans, including those on part-time teacher training and NHS bursary holders.

Students over 54 are ineligible on the grounds that their future careers will be short, reducing the prospect of repayment. Applicants aged 50-54 will only qualify if they can prove that they intend to work after graduation.

Part-time students on low incomes and on the right side of 54 will be eligible for an annual £500 loan for study costs. But any student solely in receipt of a student loan will find it just isn't enough. Unless you stashed away a nest egg before starting your studies, paid work fitted in between essays, reading and preparing presentations is a must.

Craig McKenzie works 25 hours a week in a pizza chain, on top of his 15-18 hours studying Biomedical Sciences at Brighton University. He is torn by a passion for his subject, and the awareness that he is going to have to work five years as a registered medical scientist to get up to £17,000. Undergraduate Emma Blackmore, 25, is in the same boat, working 12 hours each weekend in a cash and carry to make ends meet. Her recipe for coping financially is simple: "A nice credit card and no social life. It's down the pub for one drink, literally."

Some student unions are setting up employment agencies. But not all students can work. Parents, particularly lone parents, will struggle to be student, carer and part-time worker.

Statutory funds in the shape of supplementary grants are available for needy full-time students, namely carers and students with disabilities - approach your local authority as early as possible. Universities may also be able to help through a small menu of funds, some repayable, others not. Hardship funds are not repayable. Hardship loans are.

Individual institutions also hold a limited number of access bursary funds, worth up to £1,000 to students from disadvantaged backgrounds.

Career Development Loans and Professional Studies Loans are also available from banks, allowing deferred payments and fixed rates of interest. On the benefit front, only student couples with children may be eligible for the Job Seekers Allowance, and only lone parents or students with a disability can claim Income Support. But even then, look out for the quirks of the system. Someone entitled to housing benefit cannot get their rent paid if they are living on campus. To work out whether you can realistically do a full-time degree, do your homework, and do it early. Find out how many hours a week your course entails, and see how much paid work you could do.

Talk to mature students at the university by contacting the mature students' society. If you can't do full-time study, join the swelling ranks of mostly mature students doing part-time degrees. It may take longer to achieve your aim, but it might be less stressful in the long run.

Useful contacts: To see what courses are available and where, see www.ucas.ac.uk/getting/prospect. For Career Development Loans, see www.lifelonglearning.co.uk and www.dfee.gov.studentsupport for supplementary grants.

For details about student loans and hardship loans, see Student Loans Company website on www.slc.co.uk, or freephone 0800 405010. Charities Direct at www.caritasdata.co.uk lists 5,000 charities, of which several will be educational ones.

Alternatively, your library should stock one of these directories: The Grants Register (Macmillans), Directory of Grant Making Trusts (Charities Aid Foundation) or the Charities Digest (Family Welfare Association).

Or access funding databases such as Fundfinder, Inspire and Moneysearch, which match funding sources with specific needs. Available in student unions, careers services and citizens advice bureaux.

It is on Tuesday October 10 at the New Connaught Rooms in Covent Garden, London and is supported by the Guardian. Booking details are on 020-7453 5499 or visit www.cvcp.ac.uk/policyconferences. Experts on mature student recruitment, retention and support will speak. Keynote speakers are Baroness Blackstone, minister of state at the Department of Education and Employment; Dr Michael Goldstein, chair of the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service and Baroness Warwick, chief executive of CVCP. Money matters At the very time the government is setting its sights on 50% of under-30s taking up university study within the next decade, the figure for mature student applications is on the wane. Last year, the introduction of tuition fees saw applications fall by nearly 5% on the previous year. So is university life still a viable option for the adult returner? The truth about tuition fees, when all the media hype has been stripped away, is that 44% of all students pay nothing at all (soon to rise to 50%), with mature students least likely to do so. As thresholds currently stand, anyone earning less than £17,805 prior to studying is exempt. Only those making more than £28,504 pay the full amount, currently £1,050 per year. The downside is that both the prospective student and their cohabiting partner or spouse will have their income, and any interest, means-tested, though capital savings are not included. Students who previously studied full-time on a HE course for longer than one academic year with state support will be expected to pay the full fee. On the maintenance side, the biggest source of finance is the student loan, of which 25% is means-tested. A few student groups automatically get full loans, including those on part-time teacher training and NHS bursary holders. Students over 54 are ineligible on the grounds that their future careers will be short, reducing the prospect of repayment. Applicants aged 50-54 will only qualify if they can prove that they intend to work after graduation. Part-time students on low incomes and on the right side of 54 will be eligible for an annual £500 loan for study costs. But any student solely in receipt of a student loan will find it just isn't enough. Unless you stashed away a nest egg before starting your studies, paid work fitted in between essays, reading and preparing presentations is a must. Craig McKenzie works 25 hours a week in a pizza chain, on top of his 15-18 hours studying Biomedical Sciences at Brighton University. He is torn by a passion for his subject, and the awareness that he is going to have to work five years as a registered medical scientist to get up to £17,000. Undergraduate Emma Blackmore, 25, is in the same boat, working 12 hours each weekend in a cash and carry to make ends meet. Her recipe for coping financially is simple: "A nice credit card and no social life. It's down the pub for one drink, literally." Some student unions are setting up employment agencies. But not all students can work. Parents, particularly lone parents, will struggle to be student, carer and part-time worker. Statutory funds in the shape of supplementary grants are available for needy full-time students, namely carers and students with disabilities - approach your local authority as early as possible. Universities may also be able to help through a small menu of funds, some repayable, others not. Hardship funds are not repayable. Hardship loans are. Individual institutions also hold a limited number of access bursary funds, worth up to £1,000 to students from disadvantaged backgrounds. Career Development Loans and Professional Studies Loans are also available from banks, allowing deferred payments and fixed rates of interest. On the benefit front, only student couples with children may be eligible for the Job Seekers Allowance, and only lone parents or students with a disability can claim Income Support. But even then, look out for the quirks of the system. Someone entitled to housing benefit cannot get their rent paid if they are living on campus. To work out whether you can realistically do a full-time degree, do your homework, and do it early. Find out how many hours a week your course entails, and see how much paid work you could do. Talk to mature students at the university by contacting the mature students' society. If you can't do full-time study, join the swelling ranks of mostly mature students doing part-time degrees. It may take longer to achieve your aim, but it might be less stressful in the long run. Useful contacts: To see what courses are available and where, see www.ucas.ac.uk/getting/prospect. For Career Development Loans, see www.lifelonglearning.co.uk and www.dfee.gov.studentsupport for supplementary grants. For details about student loans and hardship loans, see Student Loans Company website on www.slc.co.uk, or freephone 0800 405010. Charities Direct at www.caritasdata.co.uk lists 5,000 charities, of which several will be educational ones. Alternatively, your library should stock one of these directories: The Grants Register (Macmillans), Directory of Grant Making Trusts (Charities Aid Foundation) or the Charities Digest (Family Welfare Association). Or access funding databases such as Fundfinder, Inspire and Moneysearch, which match funding sources with specific needs. Available in student unions, careers services and citizens advice bureaux.

webTitle: Staff face the axe as students fall short

fields.headline: Wrong number
fields.standfirst: Staff face the axe as students fall short, say Donald MacLeod and  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Staff face the axe as students fall short, say Donald MacLeod and Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Hundreds of lecturers are facing the sack as universities and colleges of higher education fail to attract enough students to meet the government's ambitious targets.

With at least 13,000 places going begging as term starts, the disappointing recruitment figures cast doubt on whether Tony Blair's goal of bringing 50% of young people into higher education can be realised. For many academics in departments hit by falling student numbers the result is a premature end to their careers.

The higher education funding councils have funded an extra 19,000 full-time places for UK students starting in the 2000-01 academic year. But figures released last week by the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service show the number of accepted student applicants up by only 6,000 on last year, to just over 333,000 in total.

Up to 1,000 academic jobs were threatened, claimed Tom Wilson, higher education officer for the lecturers' union Natfhe. Institutions had been banking on the money: "Because the student applications have not materialised they are having to make redundancies. There is a lot of anger out there, and justifiably so."

While applications in areas like media studies and IT are buoyant, subjects like engineering and physics have continued a long-term decline, with the result that universities are restructuring departments to stay afloat financially. Worst hit are the new universities, but at pre-1992 universities academic staff on fixed-term contracts are not having them renewed.

Northumbria University, Newcastle, is making deep cuts in its total staff of nearly 2,000, including more than 50 academic jobs. The announcement has provoked a ballot for industrial action by members of Natfhe. A spokesman for the university said it had managed to avoid going into deficit despite underfunding, but was now facing a deficit in two years' time.

"We are looking to achieve an overall saving of 7% across the board. Much of this saving is expected to come from a reduction in staffing costs. We hope to achieve the required saving through natural wastage, internal transfer and voluntary redundancy."

Hertfordshire University is axing 100 jobs, including about 55 academic posts, as it closes four declining subject areas - chemical sciences, social sciences, civil engineering, and performing arts. Lecturers have voted three to one to take action in protest at the redundancies, but Professor Neil Buxton, the vice-chancellor, said he made no apology for clearing the decks to concentrate on what the university did best: "There is a need to direct resources from other areas, and the regrettable fact is that there have been marked problems with certain traditional parts of the university, often due to a national decline in interest amongst the young."

The Ucas figures do not cover part-time students, for which the funding councils provided an extra 35,500 funded places this year. There are no official figures for postgraduates, but it seems clear that colleges and universities have failed to hit the government's target for teacher training recruitment - an estimated 7% increase in postgraduate enrolments in contrast to the 20% target, despite the introduction of £6,000 salaries and £4,000 golden hellos in maths, science and modern languages.

 More than 1000 scientists employed by the Medical Research Council have been awarded a 9% pay rise over three years on top of the normal cost of living rise which this year is 3.8%, making a rise of almost 7% this year alone. The council's chief executive, Professor Sir George Radda, said: "We are on the threshold of a revolution in science, as the challenges of unravelling the human genome present us with an unlimited number of new ways to tackle health problems. With this settlement, MRC is giving a lead in supporting and nurturing the best scientists, who can help ensure that the UK remains at the forefront of medical research."
