fields.headline: Tories shun 'mini-manifesto'
fields.standfirst:
Only 16% bother to vote as Hague faces pressure from left and right

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: William Hague's belated efforts to reposition the Tories inside the "mainstream majority" of British politics in time for the general election took a Bournemouth conference beating yesterday from the left and right of the party and its grassroots activists.
fields.body:
William Hague's belated efforts to reposition the Tories inside the "mainstream majority" of British politics in time for the general election took a Bournemouth conference beating yesterday from the left and right of the party and its grassroots activists.

Although the former prime minister John Major used a rare public speech to chivvy his successor as Tory leader towards consensus, understanding and multiracial "inclusivity", the unkindest cut on the opening day of the party conference was grassroots apathy towards Mr Hague's "mini-manifesto" ballot.

Just 50,508 - 16.67% - of eligible members bothered to vote to endorse the mini-manifesto, "Believing in Britain", the Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, was forced to admit after an opening speech to the conference which claimed that the tide has turned decisively against Tony Blair.

"We know and, more importantly, our opponents know, that we can win," insisted Mr Ancram, savaging Mr Blair as a cynical liar who had fatally disappointed voters.

In a speech to beleaguered Tory moderates last night Mr Major also itemised alleged Labour deceptions - from Kosovo and the economy to "fibs about pensions" - to argue that Blairism is a mixture of self-delusion and "one of the most unscrupulous spin machines Britain has ever seen".

But he also warned that, to win an election, middle England's votes were not enough. "We must reach out to all, the people in the slums, the people in need, the people outside the circle of rising prosperity, the black and brown and yellow Britons who are as much a part of our society as I am," Mr Major said.

In the scramble towards the centre ground he will not be alone this week in asserting: "We are the party that stands for one nation...a Tory who believes that consensus and understanding the point of view of others is a strength and not a weakness." Such talk contrasted sharply with cheers for "quit Europe" sentiments on the conference fringe.

With the party's right wing now dominant in policy-making, the pro-Europe ex-minister Ian Taylor also warned against "picking policies off the shelf". More surprisingly, he was joined by another exile from the Hague shadow team, the rightwing MP David Davis. At a Guardian fringe meeting he spoke against over-reliance on focus groups and "corrosive" populism.

After Labour's brief collapse in the post-fuel-crisis polls the Conservative leadership has persuaded itself it can win the expected May election after all. Like George W Bush, the Republican candidate for US president - whose tactics the Tories closely monitor - Mr Hague is keen to sound more compassionate as polling day looms.

But the concentration on reconsolidating the core Tory vote - scattered in the 1997 landslide - with rightwing populist tactics for most of the past year has left Mr Hague too far from the centre ground where most elections are won.

Claiming that Conservatives have answers, where Labour has only empty gestures, Mr Ancram used his keynote speech to address the problem head-on. "This is our chance to show that, far from the shores of extremism upon which our opponents seek to place us, we are the party of the mainstream, sharing the values of the mainstream majority of this country," he said.

Popping up all over the conference complex yesterday, Mr Hague himself joined in with an attack on the arrogant "metropolitan elite" which he said dominated New Labour thinking at the expense of rural Britain. He had already launched the new party policy for revitalising inner cities, building a more privatised structure on what have become Labour policies.

webTitle: Suzanne Goldenberg on the Palestinian boy martyr

fields.headline: Making of a martyr
fields.standfirst:
On Saturday a 12-year-old Palestinian boy went out to look at used cars and within hours had become a potent symbol of one of the world's most bitter and enduring conflicts. But was he the victim of stray gunfire? Or was he targeted by Israeli soldiers? Suzanne Goldenberg searches for the truth behind the pictures that rocked the world

Listen to Suzanne Goldenberg reporting on attitudes to the death of Rami al-Dirreh:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: On Saturday a 12-year-old Palestinian boy went out to look at used cars and within hours had become a potent symbol of one of the world's most bitter and enduring conflicts. But was he the victim of stray gunfire? Or was he targeted by Israeli soldiers?  Suzanne Goldenberg  searches for the truth behind the pictures that rocked the world.
fields.body:
A circle of 15 bullet holes on a cinder block wall, and a smear of darkening blood. That is what marks the spot where a terrified 12-year-old boy spent his final moments, cowering in his father's arms, before he was hit by a final shot to the stomach, and slumped over, dead.

Those last minutes in the life of Mohammed al-Durrah, captured in sickening detail by a Palestinian cameraman working for French TV, have taken on a power of their own. His death, aired around the world on Saturday night, has become the single searing image of these days of bloody rioting.

The pictures of Mohammed's death seemed not just to encapsulate the horror of these last five days but also to have become its motor. Outside the al-Durrah home in a sandy lane of the Bourij refugee camp, children his age and even younger are fighting over photocopied strips of the final eight frames in the boy's life. Here, the version of his death includes images too disturbing for most broadcasters: the loosening of a dying boy's grip on his father, Jamal, and his father's convulsive twitch when he was struck by more rounds.

Though more Palestinians have been killed since Mohammed's death - including a two-year-old yesterday - it is his image that haunts Israel. For all of the claims of the prime minister, Ehud Barak, and other officials that their soldiers only fire to protect Israeli lives, Mohammed's death seems an irrefutable reply.

The images of al-Dirreh and his son cowering, vainly, behind a barrel would have been emotive enough if, as first reports suggested, they were caught in the crossfire between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian police or protesters. But by the end of the weekend the evidence was pointing to a still more chilling conclusion: that the 12-year-old boy and his father were deliberately targeted by Israeli soldiers.

For Israelis, the camera footage of Mohammed's death makes exceedingly uncomfortable viewing. Which might explain why - for all the furore his death has caused worldwide - it has caused barely a ripple here. The English-language edition of the Ha'aretz newspaper, the most liberal of Israel's press, confined its reporting to 21 lines on the front page, focused on an Israeli army investigation into the killing. For those who have been tracking the pattern of violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, the location of Mohammed's death could almost have been predicted.

Over the years, Netzarim junction, where Mohammed was killed, has been a regular point of confrontation between Israeli troops, and Palestinian youths. The source of the friction on an otherwise unremarkable junction on Gaza's main coastal road is an Israeli army post, a hunkering fortress of armoured steel and concrete with watchtowers on each of its four corners. The post, on the north-west corner of the junction, is the frontline defence for the Jewish settlement of Netzarim to the west. So contentious is the Jewish settlement that its occupants - a mere 60 families - are under strict orders to travel only by military convoys.

For Palestinians, the heavily guarded Netzarim settlement is a symbol of their continued occupation, seven years after the start of the peace process. So, by extension, is the post at Netzarim junction, which any Palestinians from Bourij or the other refugee camps to the south have to negotiate, if they want to visit Gaza City.

"When the people of Palestine are crying out against Israel, they find this place to throw stones. It is a target for all the anger against the people sitting in their belly and in their bedroom," says Brigadier General Osama al-Ali.

He was speaking from the other installation that played a crucial part in Mohammed's death. As well as the Israeli position, the junction also houses a small command post of Palestinian security forces who, under interim peace arrangements, are mandated to jointly patrol the area with Israeli troops.

The post, a small hut really, lies diagonally across the junction from the Israeli position, at a distance of perhaps 100 yards.

This was the stage on which the al-Durrahs blundered, father and son, on Saturday morning. Although Mohammed's uncles feel obliged to describe him as a studious boy, his mother and his six surviving siblings recall a playful child who wanted always to be where the action was. His mother, Amal, says he had wanderlust and would often run off to the beach or, when there were protests, to watch the older boys throw rocks.

On Friday night, in his home in the Bourij refugee camp, Mohammed was watching the rioting on television. "When he saw what happened in Jerusalem on TV, he asked me: 'Can I go to join the protests in Netzarim?' I did not dare to answer him. I did not want him to go," she says.

Which is why on that fateful morning, Jamal al-Dirreh says he took steps to steer his son away from trouble. The two set off for the used car auction in Gaza City. Mohammed was excited at the outing. They started for home by taxi, but, with the trouble already starting, the driver refused to cross Netzarim. Jamal and Mohammed tried to cross the junction on foot; it was a fatal mistake.

Caught in a burst of firing, the pair sought shelter behind a concrete water butt, about 15 yards to the east of the Palestinian post, diagonally opposite the Israeli position. The father gestured frantically towards the Israelis, as if pleading with them to stop firing. They did not.

"They were cleaning the area. Of course they saw the father," says Talal Abu-Rama, the camera man who watched the horror unfold. "They were aiming at the boy, and that is what surprised me, yes, because they were shooting at him, not only one time, but many times."

The result of that salvo is visible on the cinderblock wall. Aside from the circle of bullet holes - most of them below waist level - the expanse of wall is largely unscarred. This appeared to suggest that the Israeli fire was targeted at the father and son.

The impression is reinforced by other Palestinians at the scene, including a volunteer in the ambulance which tried to get the pair out. "There was still some breath left in him when we reached the ambulance, but when we opened the doors, they started shooting again," says Bassam al-Bilbays, who was riding with the ambulance. The driver was shot dead.

Inevitably, the Israeli army version of Mohammed's death is rather different. Although the army expressed regret about the boy's death, it said the soldiers in their armoured post had been under fire. "I am sorry for this kid. But we are sure that this kid and his father were not there by accident. They were there like the others throwing stones, and throwing Molotovs [petrol bombs]," Major-General Yom Tov Samia told Israeli radio.

But in an interview with Israeli television, General Samia suggested the boy had not been killed by Israelis at all, but by Palestinian police, or rioters: "I have no doubt that the gunfire, as it appears in the television close-up, was not from Israeli soldiers."

That explanation is also difficult to sustain. During the fury of these clashes, Palestinian forces have turned their guns on Israeli troops - rather than try to contain their own people. The Palestinian General al-Ali admits his men did open fire at the Israelis. However, he claims that his men did not try to exact revenge until much later on that bloody afternoon.

"We saw our kids dying and we could not help them," he said. "Of course, some people went mad later in the afternoon, when they saw what happened."

Palestinians at the scene - including the cameraman - also cast doubt on the Israeli claim that father and son were caught in the crossfire between the two security forces. "At the beginning of the clash, there was some shooting from the same area, but after five minutes they [the Palestinians] ran away from there. Nobody was shooting from the base," says Abu Rameh. He says he heard fire from only one direction - the Israeli camp.

Abu Rameh also believes it unlikely that the Israeli fire could have been directed further down the road from the water butt where the al-Durrahs sought shelter. "In that whole area, there was nobody except me, the boy and his father," the camera man says.

Whatever the truth about the circumstances surrounding his death, Mohammed's terrified face has now entered the grim gallery of images that have come to symbolise - and often to powerfully influence - a conflict. That is of little comfort to his mother, Amal al-Durrah. She keeps imagining he will walk in the door to check on the love birds in their pink cage.

"Nothing good will come of this. We will have many more martyrs, and nothing will change."

webTitle: Putin tries to broker deal for Yugoslavia

fields.headline: Putin tries to broker deal for Yugoslavia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: President Slobodan Milosevic issued a defiant challenge to his political enemies yesterday, dubbing the Serb opposition attempting to topple him from power as western lackeys who would lead the country into war and poverty.
fields.body:
President Slobodan Milosevic issued a defiant challenge to his political enemies yesterday, dubbing the Serb opposition attempting to topple him from power as western lackeys who would lead the country into war and poverty.

In his first televised address to the nation since the disputed presidential election on September 24, Mr Milosevic insisted that he had no intention of admitting defeat. Yugoslav officials have called a run-off vote for Sunday, which the opposition says it will boycott because his challenger Vojislav Kostunica won outright in the first round.

In his 15-minute address, Mr Milosevic warned that if the opposition took office Yugoslavia "would inevitably break up". All opposition plans, he declared, were initiated by Nato and western countries.

"Our policy guarantees peace," he said, while the opposition promoted "clashes and hostility". Without him Yugoslavia would be "occupied by foreign forces".

The robust statement came on the day the opposition tried to bring the country to a halt by launching a general strike designed to force him from office. Mr Milosevic will have gained renewed confidence by the fact that the strike failed to take hold, with opposition leaders conceding that the turnout was disappointing.

The Yugoslav president accused his opponents of resorting to "bribing, blackmailing with money from the west" to bring the country to a standstill. But he said that Yugoslavia's laws would be applied to prevent a "western invasion".

The defiance from Belgrade ran counter to attempts by the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, to solve the crisis by calling on Mr Milosevic and Vojislav Kostunica, his main rival, to travel to Moscow this week for talks.

Mr Putin's attempt at a negotiated settlement followed a meeting of key Kremlin officials on Yugoslavia yesterday after which the Russian president said the mounting tension in Serbia was turning into a threat to European stability.

It was not clear whether Mr Milosevic, in particular, would agree to the Russian offer of mediation. His brother Borislav, the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow, dismissed all talk of mediation in Belgrade which also reacted negatively at the weekend to a Kremlin offer to send the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, to Yugoslavia.

But with Moscow shifting from being Mr Milosevic's traditional backer to a more even-handed role in the current stand-off while seeking to be the peace broker, Mr Putin is gambling that he can mediate a peaceful handover of power in Belgrade in what would be a triumphant first big foray into international diplomacy and crisis management.

While Mr Putin has recognised that Mr Kostunica won last week's election, according to the German government following a telephone conversation between Mr Putin and Gerhard Schröder, yesterday's Putin statement, issued while he was en route to India for a four-day visit, also made a nod to the Milosevic camp by talking of a second round.

But in the latest of several signals that the Kremlin is distancing itself from Milosevic and discreetly backing Mr Kostunica, one of Mr Putin's closest aides, Sergei Ivanov, the head of the Kremlin's security council, said Yugoslavia needed a legitimate president recognised by "the world community".

Greece, an Orthodox country like Russia and Serbia, said it was discussing the possibility of helping to organise a recount of the first-round vote with Russia and France, currently in the European Union chair. The renewed Balkan crisis also featured at talks in Paris yesterday between the French government, Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, and top EU foreign policy officials.

His brother Borislav, the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow, dismissed all talk of mediation in Belgrade which also reacted negatively at the weekend to a Kremlin offer to send the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, to Yugoslavia. But with Moscow shifting from being Mr Milosevic's traditional backer to a more even-handed role in the current stand-off while seeking to be the peace broker, Mr Putin is gambling that he can mediate a peaceful handover of power in Belgrade in what would be a triumphant first big foray into international diplomacy and crisis management. While Mr Putin has recognised that Mr Kostunica won last week's election, according to the German government following a telephone conversation between Mr Putin and Gerhard Schröder, yesterday's Putin statement, issued while he was en route to India for a four-day visit, also made a nod to the Milosevic camp by talking of a second round. But in the latest of several signals that the Kremlin is distancing itself from Milosevic and discreetly backing Mr Kostunica, one of Mr Putin's closest aides, Sergei Ivanov, the head of the Kremlin's security council, said Yugoslavia needed a legitimate president recognised by "the world community". Greece, an Orthodox country like Russia and Serbia, said it was discussing the possibility of helping to organise a recount of the first-round vote with Russia and France, currently in the European Union chair. The renewed Balkan crisis also featured at talks in Paris yesterday between the French government, Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, and top EU foreign policy officials.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Strumpshaw, Norfolk
fields.trailText: Strumpshaw, Norfolk
fields.body:
Through the wood came the report of a shotgun, then a party of pheasants sailed overhead and vanished from sight. Immediately afterwards another male bird swerved through the trees, plumped down on the woodland edge, made a nervous run through the stubble and crouched down. The season on pheasants has just opened and this one had a lucky escape.

Originally an Asian bird, the pheasant was probably brought to Britain by the Normans. Yet it was not until the late 18th century that pheasants started to become the standard sportsman's quarry.

Some of the environmental consequences of its popularity have been deeply negative. Gamekeepers worked on the principle that other animals preying on pheasants must be ruthlessly eliminated, and many of our birds of prey are only now recovering from this long history of persecution. On the plus side, the pheasant's requirement for tree cover has tended to protect woodland.

My bird, meanwhile, oblivious of his environmental impact and forgetful of his recent ordeal, began the elaborate physical ritual which precedes his night-time roost. He puffed out his chest and threw back his head in a gesture of defiance. A loud hoarse "Gok-kok", accompanied by the simultaneous drum-beat of his wings, rang out through the woods and across the fields.

Back in seconds came the same defiant note from half-a-dozen other pheasants, until the calls echoed back and forth across the entire landscape. It is a triumphant note, a sound that seems the very essence of Norfolk at dusk, and the pheasant's irreducible gift to the British countryside.

webTitle: Leader: Whitehall has a new website inspector

fields.headline: Webmaster-general
fields.standfirst:
Whitehall has a new site inspector
Net news
fields.trailText: Just as in the age of paper you would not patronise Her Majesty's Stationery Office for sharp prose and cutting-edge graphic design, so these days government websites are too often unimaginative and (a damning word in the internet lexicon) slow.
fields.body:
Just as in the age of paper you would not patronise Her Majesty's Stationery Office for sharp prose and cutting-edge graphic design, so these days government websites are too often unimaginative and (a damning word in the internet lexicon) slow. Some departments just dumped their files into the new format. Others are not intuitive - they expect visitors to have a diploma in public admin. For all the talk about "joining up", government online is still wedged into bureaucratic boxes. Yesterday's announcement of the appointment of a new official "webmaster" referred, narrowly, to the 1,000 sites operated by Whitehall. In addition the state online encompasses many council and quango sites; there are too few portals and signposts to them. Trying to follow a single strand of policy through them - say, what government does to and for children - is well-nigh impossible.

The job of rejuvenating government websites is a big one. E-czar Alex Allan is departing for personal reasons after only a short stint and has not yet been replaced. Ministers somewhat more charismatic than Ian McCartney and more hands-on than Mo Mowlam might help, too. The Cabinet Office is excellent at big thoughts and inspiring reports. It is less adept at translating them into action by far-flung public servants, who tend to be a lot more attentive to what the purse-controllers at the Treasury are up to.

Still, new man Lucian Hudson deserves a welcome. He used to work at the BBC, which has an impressive online presence. (Blame the pre-emptive purchase of online rights by the Americans for gaps in its internet coverage of the Olympics.) Some bits of government have established themselves as electronic providers - NHS Direct and the Court Service. Tony Blair recently set quantitative targets for putting public services online. They will only be met if government's qualitative presence in the new medium is improved.

fields.headline: Cahoot 'giveaway' gauntlet to IF
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Abbey National's internet bank Cahoot will today increase the interest rate on its current account to a market-beating 7.1% and introduce cash giveaways of hundreds of pounds to credit card customers in a bid to derail the launch of rival IF from Halifax.
fields.body:
Abbey National's internet bank Cahoot will today increase the interest rate on its current account to a market-beating 7.1% and introduce cash giveaways of hundreds of pounds to credit card customers in a bid to derail the launch of rival IF from Halifax.

The rate increase leapfrogs other internet banks, such as Smile and First-E - which both pay less than 5% on current accounts - and Egg, which pays 6.3% in its savings account. Today's rate increase will give all Cahoot customers a minimum of 6.5%, while accounts with more than £5,000 will earn 7.1%.

In October Cahoot aims to prise open the credit card market with a product that will give anybody transferring a balance from another card a cash gift of 5% - for example, someone transferrring £3,000 from another card operator will be given £150.

The cash giveaway is believed to be the first from a major credit card company.

Cahoot, whose systems embarassingly collapsed on its first day, is also planning a string of product releases over the next few months.

These include personal loans, at around 8% interest, compared to the present best of 9.2% offered by Northern Rock. Like other internet banks it is also aiming to give away free net-enabled Wap phones, but with the added inducement of an immediate £100 cash given back.

The new Cahoot products - emailed to existing customers today - come just days after the long delayed launch of Intelligent Finance from Halifax, which went live last Friday.

An IF spokeswoman said: "We are not doing cash giveaways in this form. We have always said we would not do loss leaders. It is important for both us and our customers that IF is profitable."

She added that at the weekend IF opened 4,500 accounts and plans to pick up balances of £3.5bn over the next year.

webTitle: TV: Getting personal with Paul Tonkinson

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with Paul Tonkinson
fields.trailText: Getting personal with Paul Tonkinson
fields.body:
Full Name: Paul Robert Tonkinson

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

I sometimes travel under the alias of Paul Tompkinson, because I can.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?

Never, but then I'm 26 so there's no need.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Sensitive Northern romantic (gsoh) seeks fit lass to tinker with.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

I ran a red light.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

I helped a lady laden down with shopping off the bus.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Miles Ross - enthusiastic, sharp and funny.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

My co-worker is my friend.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

My tears can't save their lost and deluded souls.

What would you advertise without a fee?

The local Turkish fish restaurant called Sariyer Balik on Green Lane.

What would you never advertise?

If I tell you, I'd be advertising it.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

My daughter, she's five months and very vocal.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

The taxi home.

Paul Tonkinson presents Dicing With Debt tomorrow on Channel 4.

fields.headline: Accidents in Emergency
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Why Doctors Make Mistakes/Without Motive
fields.body:
As part of the Doctors On Trial season, Why Doctors Make Mistakes (Channel 4) inevitably had to detail exactly what those quite horrific errors are. The doctor who was supposed to be administering life-saving drugs to a lymphatic cancer sufferer, actually killed him by injecting the wrong drug into his spine. Another doctor pierced the lining of a patient's lung while trying to find a vein. A nurse only just prevented a woman, who was in hospital because she feared she was infertile, from having her tubes tied.

Such stories are the stuff of nightmares and headlines. Now that we have traded dinner tables for campfires, they are our ghost stories, our urban myths. These days, everybody knows somebody who knows somebody who went into hospital to get their tonsils out and was discharged with a vasectomy.

While medical errors may not be that epidemic, they might as well be, since every story of misdiagnosis, drug mix-ups or surgeries gone wrong chips away at the faith we have in the medical profession. Although no official figures exist - this being a dirty little secret - there are an estimated 320,000 accidents per year in the UK resulting in 40,000 deaths. In every hospital in the country, patients are dying needlessly.

But as terrible and tragic as the stories of malpractice are, there is perhaps a lesson to be learned from them.

We want doctors to be infallible, for medicine to be an exact science, for everything to be fine. We want to believe that while we're not immortal, we are, at least, pretty resilient and, in case of emergencies, there are people who can put us back together again. We don't want to know that medicine isn't an exact science, that a lot of it is intelligent guesswork and, as such, has a margin for error.

We don't want to admit doctors' fallibility because it means facing our own mortality, the distinct lack of happy endings. Of course doctors make mistakes - and some, like the misadministration of Richie Williams' drugs, are unforgivable - but they do so because they are human. We forget it sometimes, as do they (sometimes to an alarming extent), but the fact remains.

It is for that reason programmes like Peak Practice and Casualty are so successful: they are anaesthetics against reality. In Cardale and Holby, doctors are heroic. In the real world, flawless heroes are harder to come by, yet still we have great expectations. As always, there is a pressing need for a re-evaluation of how we appreciate doctors and nurses. If fatigue or lack of time for examining patients are factors in mistakes being made, then those factors need to be tackled. Which is to say, there needs to be more money better spent within the NHS. And who ever voted for higher taxes? You don't get something for nothing. Set your stakes too high, you're bound to lose.

When Grunt Mitchell departed Walford, expectations were high for Ross Kemp, and with Without Motive (ITV), the ghost of Grunt is closer than ever to being laid to rest. Alas, after In Defence and Hero Of The Hour - and this drama with Kemp as a CID officer investigating a serial killer in Wales and Bristol - what has replaced it is a succession of bland, identikit members of the law-and-order fraternity all of whom are still essentially Kemp in a too-tight suit.

Without Motive was a humourless, moribund police procedural drama you could have been forgiven for thinking was the second part of Tough Love, which was on the night before. In that marginally better effort, Ray Winstone's Lenny was a good egg among bad apples, while Kemp's Jack Mowbray was another exemplary egg in the larder of life. Both men even had the same wife.

Taking longer to get started than a 1981 Ford Fiesta, Without Motive was allegedly about the hunt for a serial killer. With its sub-Seven titles, it might have been a worthy successor to Touching Evil, but it was not to be. The first dead body turned up soon enough, but then, inexplicably, there was a let's-meet-the-policemen interlude which was as dull as it sounds, even if one of them was Welsh and went to Andrew Neil's hairdresser. And the worst thing of all about Without Motive? Not one of Jack Mowbray's colleague's was witty enough to give him a nickname. Had he popped into The Cops or even The Bill, he would have been The Pie to all and sundry.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Cry-Baby/The Perez Family/American History X/Jagged Edge
fields.body:
Cry-Baby

(John Waters, 1990)

1.10am, Sky Cinema

Johnny Depp plays Wade (Cry-Baby) Walker, Elvis-like leader of rock'n'roll crew the Drapes in 50s Baltimore; Amy Locane is the girl who revs his bike. The straighter-looking Squares are their sworn enemies in this brash and sexy ode to the teen movie, which sports a pop icons hall of fame - Iggy Pop, Troy Donahue, Patty Hearst; plus Joe Dallesandro and Willem Dafoe. Great soundtrack too.

The Perez Family

(Mira Nair, 1995)

8.20pm, FilmFour

This vivid romantic comedy from the director of Salaam Bombay! and Mississippi Masala is propelled along by an excellent ensemble cast. Alfred Molina is Juan Perez, released after 20 years in a Cuban jail and heading to his wife Carmela (Anjelica Huston) in Miami. On the way he meets Marisa Tomei's ex-hooker Dottie Perez, and the pair pose as a married couple to get past immigration. Meanwhile Carmela is romantically inclined towards Chazz Palminteri's Officer Pirelli. Meandering and soft-centred, it's a heartwarming account of people striving for a better life.

American History X

(Tony Kaye, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

An awesome performance from Edward Norton centres this compelling study of American neo-Nazism. His charismatic Derek, a hate-filled skinhead, kills two black car thieves and after rehabilitation emerges from prison a changed man, struggling to free his brother Danny (Edward Furlong) from the grip of fascist gang leader Cameron (Stacy Keach). Norton reportedly re-edited, and Kaye disowned the final cut, but it's a highly charged, thought-provoking movie.

Jagged Edge

(Richard Marquand, 1985)

10.20pm, FilmFour

Taut, twisty thriller sharply scripted by Joe Eszterhas and full of surprises, to the last gasp. Top -class performances, too, with Glenn Close as a lawyer defending suspected wife-murderer Jeff Bridges. Her judgment starts to cloud when they become lovers. It projects a constant sense of menace.

webTitle: Leader: Tory activists are in no mood to change

fields.headline: Bournemouth's faultline
fields.standfirst:
Tory activists are in no mood to change
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Conservatives seemed destined to gather in Bournemouth under clear, sunny skies. The clouds melted away over the weekend and the political weather looked just as benign: last week's polls had William Hague out in front, the Danes had obligingly said no to the euro and, on Sunday night, Channel 4 aired what looked like a 55-minute election broadcast for the Conservatives.
fields.body:
The Conservatives seemed destined to gather in Bournemouth under clear, sunny skies. The clouds melted away over the weekend and the political weather looked just as benign: last week's polls had William Hague out in front, the Danes had obligingly said no to the euro and, on Sunday night, Channel 4 aired what looked like a 55-minute election broadcast for the Conservatives. Things were going the Tories' way.

The Danish result has certainly put a spring in the step of the Eurosceptic delegates who dominate today's Conservative party. At a fringe meeting even John Redwood had a job to keep up with the militant Europhobes gathered before him. Perhaps cheered by the sight of leafleteers outside, kitted out in Viking helmets, the Tories believe the Danes are the trailblazers of a new anti-wave sweeping Europe. Meanwhile, Channel 4's documentary had Tories blinking in disbelief: although anti-Hague viewers might have barfed at the leader's giggling and staged folksiness, plenty of undecideds will have seen Hague in a new way - as a human being. In this age of empathy politics, being seen with wife, family and friends has become a political essential. For all that, by the afternoon the sky was looking a little less blue. The polls had reverted to their pre-fuel crisis position, with Labour again holding the advantage. Emboldened by that news, several senior Conservatives dared attack the current strategy - revealing the faultline which now, perhaps as much as Europe, divides their party.

At yesterday's Guardian debate the former minister Ian Taylor accused Mr Hague of kneejerk populism, acting in at least one instance on "gut instinct" rather than making an "intelligent contribution". Later, John Major made a plea from the fringe for a Conservative party that speaks not only to middle England but also to "the people outside the circle of rising prosperity, the black and brown and yellow Britons". That kind of inclusive talk is code for a gentler Conservatism - at odds with the hard-edged populism Mr Hague has adopted on, say, asylum seekers.

The riddle is this. Mr Major is right: British elections are won in the centre. But his voice, and Mr Taylor's, are the minority in Bournemouth. The Tories like the hard stuff they've been getting from Mr Hague, and they think it has lifted them from the doldrums of 1997. They are in no mood to turn left just yet.

The Tories like the hard stuff they've been getting from Mr Hague, and they think it has lifted them from the doldrums of 1997. They are in no mood to turn left just yet.

fields.headline: The price of failure
fields.standfirst:
Enemies of peace fill the Middle East void
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The appalling explosion of Israeli-Palestinian violence over the past few days is the predictable consequence of the failure of men of peace to agree
fields.body:
The appalling explosion of Israeli-Palestinian violence over the past few days is the predictable consequence of the failure of men of peace to agree. The immediate spark was provided by last week's deliberately provocative incursion by Ariel Sharon, the hardline Likud leader, into the precincts of the Arab-administered Muslim holy site of Haram al-Sharif, also revered by Jews as Temple Mount. Mr Sharon's intention was ostentatiously to assert his belief in a united Jerusalem in the teeth of faltering, last-gasp attempts by Ehud Barak's government to reach some kind of compromise with Yasser Arafat. But he was also widely believed to be asserting his credentials as standard-bearer of the Israeli right at a moment when Mr Barak's equally unaccommodating predecessor as prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, looks poised to make a comeback.

Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, was right to condemn Mr Sharon's clumsy confrontationalism yesterday during a visit to Paris. But perhaps it was only to be expected from a man reviled in the Arab world and beyond for his role in Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon and the subsequent Palestinian refugee camp massacres, from a man who has championed Israeli settlements in the occupied territories, from a man who has clearly learned nothing over the years about the ultimate futility of racial and religious hatred. Mr Sharon and Mr Netanyahu are to the peace process what a fox is to a chicken coop. In the guise of defending Israel's security, they weaken it. They play cynical politics with peace while consistently expecting others, particularly the US, to mop up the blood they shed. They are men without vision. And yet they, and ever more violence and tears, may be what awaits the Middle East should Mr Barak's minority gov ernment be overwhelmed when a hostile Knesset reconvenes later this month.

Preoccupied by Serbia, Ms Albright said she had no plans to fly to the region. And this, too, has a gloomy significance. Bill Clinton's extraordinary, all-out drive for peace hit the buffers at Camp David last July and has not fully recovered since. With the November 7 elections looming, US engagement and energy is diminishing, leaving a vacuum where, only a few short months ago, existed the real hope of a grand, final settlement with the Palestinians and with Syria, too.

The enemies of peace are not only to be found on the Israeli side of the divide. Mr Arafat, like Mr Barak, is now much weakened. His personal inability to make a leap of faith at Camp David over Jerusalem was justified retrospectively by his claim to be representing the interests of the entire Muslim world. But that same Muslim world displayed precious little solidarity when he subsequently sought its support for a declaration of an independent state last month. That postponement, the latest of many, convinced many Palestinians that armed conflict, like Hizbullah's in Lebanon, was the only way. It partly accounts for the pent-up fury released on the streets in past days. And both events have further encouraged and incited Arab rejectionists like Hamas. Now the wind-blown Mr Arafat is driven to speak fatuously of "war" with Israel - as if a long, sorrowful history had not shown that this is a struggle that nobody can win.

Mohammed Jemal al-Duri, the 12-year-old gunned down by Israeli soldiers on Saturday, was not a "martyr" to the cause of Palestine. But he is a symbol. He is the innocent victim, among countless others from both sides, of all those who thwart, exploit, or fail the cause of peace. Just how many more must there be?

webTitle: LSE? The thinking now is to stop thinking

fields.headline: LSE? The thinking now is to stop thinking
fields.standfirst: The battle seems already lost
fields.trailText: It has become fashionable to say that exchanges no longer count for much in the modern financial world. They are little more than the IT departments of the markets - markets which will always sort themselves, as efficient markets do.
fields.body:
It has become fashionable to say that exchanges no longer count for much in the modern financial world. They are little more than the IT departments of the markets - markets which will always sort themselves, as efficient markets do.

Even this newspaper's leader column has stated, quite bluntly, that it no longer matters who owns the London Stock Exchange, for all its 200 years of existence.

But now there are disturbing whispers that the LSE's current management, chairman Don Cruickshank and marketing director Martin Wheatley, are taking such opinions literally.

They are said to have abandoned any pretence of having a vision for the future. No battle plan is under construction, no energetic display of why this institution should remain independent - or why, in fact, any of the management might deserve to keep their jobs.

They assume that, whatever the LSE says or does now, shareholders will just automatically vote down the hostile takeover from Sweden's OM Gruppen. The thinking now is to stop thinking. It is too risky: the LSE cannot whip out a new strategy or alternative merger from the hat since it has not time, under the bid timetable, to get it right. Such a move would lack credibility.

Oh, and it might get things wrong again.

In any case, it is said, why rush around for a fix when the London equity market is not broken? The technology is fine and we have the biggest pool of captive liquidity in Europe.

This is complacent in the extreme. In fact, those who have been briefed on the new non-strategy reckon Mr Cruickshank and his colleagues need some help, and sharpish. So here goes:

First the LSE should identify its crucial weaknesses before their competitors point them out. The trading technology is substandard. Teething problems with the Sets order book have been going on for a short five years. In particular, there have been persistent problems setting credible end-of-day prices for companies of all shapes and sizes. This is fundamental, since the price-setting mechanism is perhaps the single, most important reason for an exchange to exist.

Clearing and settlement systems are cumbersome, costly and lack international reach. The LSE might protest that it is no longer responsible for such matters, having been stripped of its role by the Bank of England. But for anyone trading British equities it does matter.

The LSE's customers - and, awkwardly, its shareholders - are split into two, broad, opposing camps. Neither feels its needs are being met. The split has been there for 14 years so the LSE should probably stop hoping that if the matter is ignored it will disappear.

Next, the LSE needs to identify its key strengths.

Its history, time zone and language has enabled the exchange to retail a substantial majority of all European equity trading.

Its procedures and rules are well established and well tested, while regulation in London has reached a level of professionalism that is second only to New York. On the whole, market participants here feel they operate in a fair environment.

Levels of probity and corporate governance in London are far higher than in any other European centre.

Moving forward from here, the LSE needs that vision thing - a view of where the business is headed. There are alternatives to the usual mergers or alliance options, but it first requires the re-telling of the cautionary tale of a newspaper - the Financial Times.

Two years ago the paper set out to use the internet to create a global online product with a global brand, FT.com. Stephen Hill, the chief executive, toured Sillicon Valley for advice. The big technology firms all told him one thing: great idea, do not do it yourself. In fact, one firm, Hewlett Packard, offered to fund, build and run the entire infrastruture simply in return for a small cut of future e-commerce revenues.

So the FT decided to manage the project itself, contracting out work to specialist firms rather than going for one big partner. The result was a badly designed website, full of technical glitches, which has failed to destroy the competition to boot.

FT.com has failed to reflect and distribute the exceptional qualities of the newspaper. A great idea was bungled.

So, back to the LSE. It already has a sizeable portion of pan-European business and also has a brand with global potential. It also has a rulebook that is respected, and international - that is, American - standards of disclosure.

What the LSE needs is a big, blue-chip technology partner that has a commercial interest - through a stake or a trading toll - in making the business hum.

It needs to build an international infrastructure that is efficient and cheap and does everything - for everyone. It needs to promote London's standards as the international benchmark - and it needs to market the hell out of the whole package.

Oh, and it also needs a chief executive.

webTitle: Mother who murdered baby sons loses appeal

fields.headline: Mother who murdered baby sons loses appeal
fields.trailText: The husband of Sally Clark, the solicitor convicted of the murder of her two baby sons, vowed yesterday to continue to fight for his wife's freedom after an appeal against her two life sentences was thrown out at the high court in London.
fields.body:
The husband of Sally Clark, the solicitor convicted of the murder of her two baby sons, vowed yesterday to continue to fight for his wife's freedom after an appeal against her two life sentences was thrown out at the high court in London.

Three high court judges rejected fresh evidence in support of Clark's claim that her children had died of sudden infant death syndrome (Sids), or "unascertained death", stating that there was overwhelming evidence of her guilt at her trial last November.

The judges also ruled that despite errors in the way statistics concerning the chances of a family losing two babies to Sids, also known as cot death, were presented at the trial, that did not prejudice the jury in considering its verdict. "If there had been no error in relation to statistics at the trial, we are satisfied that the jury would still have convicted on each count," they said.

But Steven Clark, a senior partner in a Manchester law firm, maintained his wife's innocence. "For 72 days and as many dark nights Sally and I have been waiting. Now three judges, eminent, respected, with intellect beyond ours, decree that Sally did murder her two sons. She did not. They are wrong.

"We are not the first who have had to come to this place [the high court] twice, three, four times or more before achieving justice. I take heart, for though the years may drip slowly by, sense has a way of seeping even through these walls. We will be back, Sally will be released," he said.

On hearing the verdict, his wife, 35, remained composed, dabbed at her left eye with a handkerchief and mouthed the words "I love you" to her husband. Mike Mackie, her solicitor, said: "She is in a state of shock and disbelief at what has happened to her."

The couple's children, Christopher, 11 weeks, and Harry, eight weeks, died within 13 months of each other between December 1996 and January 1998. Their mother was alone with both children at the time of their deaths at home in Wilmslow, Cheshire.

When Christopher died Dr Alan Williams, the pathologist who examined the child at Macclesfield general hospital, gave the cause of death as an infection of the respiratory tract, a form of Sids, and dismissed evidence of bruising to the child's legs and a cut to his mouth, features that were presented by the crown as evidence of abuse at Clark's murder trial.

Within three months of Christopher's death she was pregnant again - "part of the healing process," said her husband - and Harry was born. Eight weeks later he too was dead.

Dr Williams also examined Harry and detected rib damage, swelling of the spinal cord, small tears to the brain and bleeding within the eyes. It appeared to him a classic case of death by shaking.

His suspicions led him to look again at his notes relating to Christopher, who had been cremated, and he decided the bruising and cut mouth, in addition to samples taken from the boy's lungs which showed evidence of bleeding, suggested that Christopher may have been smothered. A murder inquiry was launched and Clark, who had a third baby boy following Harry's death, was arrested and charged.

At the trial at Chester crown court the jury was told that the chances of two babies from a single family dying of Sids were 73 million to one, or once every 100 years, a figure erroneously reached by squaring the ratio for one cot death in a family (around 1:8,500) and ignoring environmental and social factors.

Yesterday, the judges accepted that the figure endorsed by the judge was incorrect, but ruled that that had not rendered the conviction unsafe.

fields.headline: Dress code
fields.standfirst: Moss Bross axes staid suit brands
fields.trailText: Struggling retailer Moss Bros is renaming its Blazer and The Suit Company chains after deciding they are "a little bit staid" to cope with contemporary dress down policies.
fields.body:
Struggling retailer Moss Bros is renaming its Blazer and The Suit Company chains after deciding they are "a little bit staid" to cope with contemporary dress down policies.

The group intends to rebrand the chains as Code, a more "colourful, contemporary and engaging" concept on trial in Southampton and Clapham.

Code will also replace most of shops branded Savoy Tailors' Guild - as pictured above at Covent Garden in London - and Moss Bros. These brands will only survive at flagship stores.

Moss Bros announced the changes with half-year losses of £16.2m, depressed by a restructuring charge of £12m. The group disappointed investors by paying no interim dividend, sending the shares down 5p to a new low of 26p.

Finance director Tom Singer said the company wanted to move away from "the look of a gentlemen's outfitter with rows of grey and blue suits".

Only 35-40% of Code's clothes will be formal, compared to about 60% at the group's existing stores.

Mr Singer said Code would have brighter lighting and graphics and a more modern layout. By the end of next year the group expects to have 78 Codes, which will also be selling womenswear.

Moss Bross's more upmarket chains, Hugo Boss and Cecil Gee, continued to trade well, with same-store sales up by 4-5%. However, its middle market brands have fallen victim to changing workwear habits.

Mr Singer said: "The dress down phenomenon has sowed some confusion in some peoples' minds - they don't want to buy suits in the volume they once did."

Underlying losses were £4.2m, against profits of £1.39m a year ago.

The group said that its total like-for-like sales fell 2% during the half-year and had slipped by 1% in the first eight weeks of the second half.

webTitle: £4,000 each for 500,000 as Scottish Life is sold

fields.headline: £4,000 each for 500,000 as Scottish Life is sold
fields.trailText: The more than half a million policyholders of Scottish Life are in line for average windfalls of £4,000 after the Edinburgh-based mutual insurer sold itself to Royal London for £1.1bn yesterday.
fields.body:
The more than half a million policyholders of Scottish Life are in line for average windfalls of £4,000 after the Edinburgh-based mutual insurer sold itself to Royal London for £1.1bn yesterday.

The announcement of the sale ends months of speculation about the fate of Scottish Life, which had received final bids from four prospective buyers, thought to include General Electric's financial services arm and Liverpool Victoria.

Colchester-based Royal London tried to calm concerns about the impact on jobs in Edinburgh, where Scottish Life is based. It admitted the company's 25 fund managers would need to relocate to the south-east of England.

Mike Yardley, the chief executive of Royal London, insisted more jobs would be created in Edinburgh as result of the acquisition.

"Some fund managers may move but the bulk of Scottish Life is offering great service to IFAs [independent financial advisers] who will continue to based in Edinburgh," Mr Yardley said. The head office will be based in Colchester, Essex.

Mr Yardley said the acquisition was not a sign that Royal London was boosting its size in preparation for a stock market listing. "Mutuality has worked tremendously well for us and will continue to do so," he said.

The acquisition continues the consolidation in the mutual life sector, following the £1.8bn acquisition of Scottish Provident by Abbey National and the "for sale" sign put on Equitable Life.

The deal gives Royal London - which until now has been regarded as player in the door to door sales market - as a way to sell products through the independent financial adviser area.

Analysts also believe it will give the combined company a stronger chance of competing in the pensions fund industry, where profit margins are expected to be depressed after the introduction of stakeholder pensions next year.

Under the terms of the sale to Royal London, the precise payments to each Scottish Life policyholder will depend on the status of their policy.

The average payment to with-profits policyholders who also have member rights is £4,000.

fields.headline: At this price?  NTL/Telewest
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The prospect of a merger between Britain's two largest cable operators would have been unthinkable five years ago. Now it is being seriously discussed. The proposed deal would bring together the cable operations of NTL and Telewest Communications to form a group that would dominate the British industry.
fields.body:
The prospect of a merger between Britain's two largest cable operators would have been unthinkable five years ago. Now it is being seriously discussed. The proposed deal would bring together the cable operations of NTL and Telewest Communications to form a group that would dominate the British industry.

The driving force behind the proposal is UPC, the Dutch cable TV group that has seen its 25% stake in Telewest slump in value. It is suggesting that NTL swaps its promising European operations for the 25% stakes in Telewest held by both UPC and Microsoft. NTL would then have to make a bid for the rest of Telewest.

The logic behind the deal is that NTL would emerge in a much better position to negotiate with content providers and compete with the digital TV companies BSkyB and ONdigital.

But it is a complex deal that could easily collapse. UPC will not be interested in a deal that values Telewest shares at anywhere near their current level.

The sharp slide in Telewest's price has been caused partly by investors' preference for dot.com companies. The big cable companies have been seen by many investors as "old" technology, even though they are able to bundle their basic TV product with telephony and high-speed internet services.

NTL will have to weigh up the advantages of being bigger in Britain against the loss of its strategic cable assets in Europe.

There is a strong argument for saying that it should not enlarge its British cable business until the fruits of its acquisition of Cable & Wireless Communications are already evident. It has already been able to use its present scale to negotiate a new contents deal with BSkyB, giving it better margins.

Buying Telewest shares now in the hope of profiting from an NTL bid, however, would be a risky strategy. The shares, up 2.25p to 134.25p yesterday on bid rumours, could easily resume their downward trend.

The proposed deal would bring together the cable operations of NTL and Telewest Communications to form a group that would dominate the British industry. The driving force behind the proposal is UPC, the Dutch cable TV group that has seen its 25% stake in Telewest slump in value. It is suggesting that NTL swaps its promising European operations for the 25% stakes in Telewest held by both UPC and Microsoft. NTL would then have to make a bid for the rest of Telewest. The logic behind the deal is that NTL would emerge in a much better position to negotiate with content providers and compete with the digital TV companies BSkyB and ONdigital. But it is a complex deal that could easily collapse. UPC will not be interested in a deal that values Telewest shares at anywhere near their current level. The sharp slide in Telewest's price has been caused partly by investors' preference for dot.com companies. The big cable companies have been seen by many investors as "old" technology, even though they are able to bundle their basic TV product with telephony and high-speed internet services. NTL will have to weigh up the advantages of being bigger in Britain against the loss of its strategic cable assets in Europe. There is a strong argument for saying that it should not enlarge its British cable business until the fruits of its acquisition of Cable & Wireless Communications are already evident. It has already been able to use its present scale to negotiate a new contents deal with BSkyB, giving it better margins. Buying Telewest shares now in the hope of profiting from an NTL bid, however, would be a risky strategy. The shares, up 2.25p to 134.25p yesterday on bid rumours, could easily resume their downward trend.

webTitle: Bob the Builder bolsters HIT profit

fields.headline: Bob the Builder bolsters HIT profit
fields.trailText: Children's television specialist HIT Entertainment said yesterday that pre-school favourite Bob the Builder has laid some solid foundations for the group's new consumer products and video division.
fields.body:
Children's television specialist HIT Entertainment said yesterday that pre-school favourite Bob the Builder has laid some solid foundations for the group's new consumer products and video division.

Demand for Bob videos and associated merchandising quadrupled consumer product income in the year to July 31 and now accounts for 43% of group income compared with 11% a year ago, chief executive Peter Orton said.

About 76% of that income came from Britain but with Bob episodes now showing in 100 countries around the world Mr Orton is forecasting further sharp growth on a global scale.

"We have only just scratched the surface of potential licensing and merchandising income," he said. "These figures do not include sales in Japan where Bob is incredibly popular and he starts to go on air in the US five times a week from January. If the response there is anything like it has been here we could be in for some very interesting times."

Turnover for the period climbed 32% to £20.3m, while profit before tax leapt 59% to £5m. Analysts said that by signing toy licensing deals with Hasbro, Mattel and Lego and several international broadcasting deals HIT had cemented its position as one of the leading independent creators and distributors of animated children's television.

HIT shares climbed 17.5p yesterday to 452.2p.

webTitle: Nader's green machine strives to get up steam

fields.headline: Nader's green machine strives to get up steam
fields.standfirst:
Third party politicians - right and left - try to make their mark on the White House race
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As the US presidential election enters its final five weeks, the race is again proving that the winner will not necessarily be the man who gives the people what they want.
fields.body:
As the US presidential election enters its final five weeks, the race is again proving that the winner will not necessarily be the man who gives the people what they want.

The candidate who is drawing the largest and most enthusiastic crowds is lagging far behind in the polls; the only man with a black running mate is the least popular with black voters; and the one promising what most Americans want is barely registering. All are third-party candidates.

Ralph Nader, the Green party contender and veteran consumer-rights campaigner, drew a crowd of 10,000 on Sunday to hear him speak in Boston, following hard on the heels of gatherings of 10,000 in Seattle, 12,000 in Minnesota and 10,500 in Portland, Oregon.

Not only are these higher figures mustered by either Al Gore of the Democrats or George W Bush of the Republicans, but they are paying customers, shelling out up to $10 (£6.75) a time to hear the Nader message.

Despite the enthusiasm with which he is greeted, despite high-profile support from actors Paul Newman and Susan Sarandon, filmmaker Michael Moore, chatshow host Phil Donahue and some union leaders, Mr Nader is still stalled at around 5% in surveys of public opinion.

The Gore team's efforts to persuade liberal America that "a vote for Nader is a vote for Bush", the decision by groups such as Friends of the Earth to back Mr Gore for the same reasons, and the lack of a chance to debate with the two main candidates on television are seen as some of the reasons for Mr Nader's low profile.

But his team says that the big rallies are bringing in thousands of extra activists, most of them from the 51% of the electorate who usually do not vote.

Their fund-raising efforts, often through house parties, have yielded $4m (£2.7m), just enough to run some provocative commercials, but a fraction of what the Gore and Bush camps are spending.

"We get lots of people who say, 'thank God Ralph's running'," said Peter Stair of Nader 2000. "You could say that to get 5% of the vote would be one of our benchmarks, but this is part of a continuing movement which will go on far beyond the election."

Paradoxically, the better Mr Gore does, the bigger chance Mr Nader has of winning votes: if the race between the frontrunners is not seen as not close, Mr Nader's natural supporters may feel more free to back him.

Explaining why there were no jokes about Mr Nader, the chatshow host and comedian Jay Leno said: "Here's a guy, he comes out and tells it like it is. My job's over!"

Mr Nader has reacted to criticism of his lack of past involvement in equality issues by delivering speeches that refer to "slavery and the genocide of the Native Americans ... the two worst crimes committed in North America". His running mate, Winona LaDuke, is a Native American academic.

His relatively strong standing in key marginal states such as Oregon, Washington and New Mexico have kept him firmly in the Gore camp's sights.

The president of Friends of the Earth, Brent Blackwelder, is touring these states on the Democrats' behalf to persuade environmentalists to back Mr Gore, something that has pained the Nader camp deeply. Mr Blackwelder has justified the move by saying: "We're looking at the reality here. Third-party candidates do not get elected to the presidency."

Michael Moore, the maverick documentary filmmaker who has been a chief Nader cheerleader, rebutted this argument at the Minnesota rally by asking what would have happened if Martin Luther King and Rosa Parks had also decided to accept the status quo in case things got worse.

"A vote for Nader is a political Molotov - throw it into the voting booth," said Moore.

But if Mr Nader is having problems capturing the magical double-digit support level, his nearest third-party rivals are floundering in his wake.

Pat Buchanan, the renegade rightwing Republican who won the Reform party nomination in a messy battle at its Long Beach convention in August, is barely registering 1% in the polls.

The adoption of a black vice-presidential running-mate, Ezola Foster - a supporter, bizarrely, of the far-right John Birch Society, has done little to win Mr Buchanan credibility. His platform is essentially anti-UN, anti-immigration, anti-world trade, anti-abortion and anti-"Republicrats", as he now calls the two main parties.

Overtaking Mr Buchanan now in states such as Georgia, Illinois and Colorado, is the Libertarian party's Harry Browne, a 67-year-old Tennessee-based investment analyst who also ran in 1996. His message is straightforward and, superficially, extremely appealing to most voters: no more income tax.

He also reaches other constituencies with a promise of an end to the "war on drugs", believing in a person's right to do what they like in their own home. Mr Browne backs the repeal of all gun-control legislation and the removal of all American troops from foreign countries.

But, Mr Nader, Mr Buchanan, Mr Browne and the two other better-known alternative candidates - John Hagelin of the Natural Law party - and Howard Phillips of the Constitutional party - all know their chances of having their voices heard above the sound of the multi-million dollar Gore-Bush battle are slim.

fields.headline: Marchioness inquiry opens after 11 years
fields.standfirst:
Judge promises full and fearless investigation of Thames tragedy

More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: It was the early hours of Sunday morning and the 26th birthday party of financier Antonio Vasconcellos was in full swing as the pleasureboat Marchioness cruised down the Thames towards Cannon Street bridge.
fields.body:
It was the early hours of Sunday morning and the 26th birthday party of financier Antonio Vasconcellos was in full swing as the pleasureboat Marchioness cruised down the Thames towards Cannon Street bridge.

A few minutes behind, heading for the same bridge, was a juggernaut of the river, the dredger Bowbelle, heading out to sea to suck sand for use in the construction industry.

Just after 1.45am on Sunday, August 20 1989, the front of the Bowbelle collided with the rear of the much smaller ship, swinging her to port, then collided again, sending the Marchioness over to starboard.

As the Bowbelle continued to bear down on her, all the lights on the Marchioness went out. In seconds, she flooded through open doors and windows and in less than a minute she sank.

Some of the 132 people on board were pitched into the Thames, their screams audible to Captain Douglas Henderson in the wheelhouse of the Bowbelle. But he did not release the dredger's lifebuoys, which he could have done, instead apparently concentrated on his own vessel.

The Marchioness captain, Stephen Faldo, was among the 51 who died. Some 24 were trapped on the wrecked ship.

The anguish of survivors and relatives after the horror of that night has been deepened by a feeling that the full truth has not been revealed.

The families have channelled their anger into a vigorous 11-year campaign for a public inquiry. Yesterday, on the first day of a formal public investigation ordered this year by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, the chairman Lord Justice Sir Anthony Clarke, pledged "a full, fair and fearless investigation".

Among the questions examined will be whether alcohol affected the duties of the Bowbelle's captain, who admitted drinking six pints of beer on Saturday afternoon, and his lookout Terence Blayney, who has admitted drinking four cans of bitter and four pints of lager on Saturday evening.

Experts reckon, however, that at the time of the collision the captain would have had no alcohol in his blood and the lookout would have had just under half the legal limit for driving on the road.

Opening the inquiry, the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, told how six years previously, in 1983, the Bowbelle had collided with a passenger launch, the Pride of Greenwich, prompting an investigation in which a Department of Transport official wrote: "This incident can only be put down to grossly inadequate visibility from the respective steering positions."

Both the Marchioness and the Bowbelle had lights which should have been visible from miles away, said Lord Williams, although a witness would give evidence that on the previous night he saw the Marchioness proceeding on the river with no stern light. Lord Williams said: "Some Marchioness passengers have described how they saw the dark hull of Bowbelle looming over Marchioness and did not see any lights."

Lord Williams went on: "It is difficult to imagine that the collision would have occurred had both vessels kept a good lookout." The Marchioness skipper "should have been all the more careful because he was navigating his vessel along the middle of the river when Bowbelle would also be passing along the middle of the river".

On the Bowbelle the forward lookout was being kept by Mr Blayney, who had received no instructions as to what he was to look out for, or to report.

The system relied upon him shouting and although there were three VHS radio sets on Bowbelle at the time of the collision, they were not used.

A practice of posting an officer equipped with a VHS set to keep a lookout seemed to have been deliberately discontinued on the Bowbelle from 1987, Lord Williams said.

On the Marchioness, the lookout system being kept by the skipper "could not possibly be regarded as safe". The pleasure ship had undergone conversion work in the early 1980s which prevented helmsmen from having an all-round view.

On whether Captain Henderson could or should have helped Marchioness passengers in the water, Lord Williams asked: "Why did he not release them [the lifebuoys] straight away? Was it because in the agony of the moment, he overlooked that simple step? Or because his attention was directed at getting his ship safely through Cannon Street bridge?"

The inquiry continues.

fields.headline: 'The families now have a voice'
fields.standfirst: More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: Eileen Dallaglio's daughter Francesca, 19, was the youngest to die on the Marchioness. Mrs Dallaglio, mother of former England rugby captain Lawrence, said the inquiry had finally given relatives the prospect of hearing the truth,  writes Jeevan Vasagar.
fields.body:
Eileen Dallaglio's daughter Francesca, 19, was the youngest to die on the Marchioness. Mrs Dallaglio, mother of former England rugby captain Lawrence, said the inquiry had finally given relatives the prospect of hearing the truth, writes Jeevan Vasagar.

"We didn't have a voice. The law worked against the very people it should have been there to protect.

"This inquiry must reflect what a famous judge once said, that justice must not only be done, it must be seen to be done. It has never been seen to be done in the case of the Marchioness disaster. This is an opportunity to have the whole of the evidence heard in an open court.

"I am hopeful that we are going to get to the truth of how 51 of our children died and 86 of them were severely traumatised.

"Francesca had just left Elmhurst [ballet school] on July 15. She died three weeks later. I had 19 wonderful years with her which I will never forget. She didn't give me 100%, she gave me 500%.

"That's why I have given every ounce of my commitment to bring these people to justice today. I did my best for her in life, and now I feel I have done my best for her in death."

Tony Perks, 31, who lost his brother Stephen, 23, in the disaster, drove to the riverside from his family's Watford home that night.

"My brother's friend had phoned me at home. I was in a horrible state of shock. The police told me to bring a picture of my brother.

"It was like being in a film, the whole place was in confusion. People were trying to find Cannon Street police station, which is where they had been told to go.

"There were people coming out upset, and other people waiting to go in. I didn't know whether they had found my brother."

He added: "Contrary to popular belief, it's not true that everyone had a lot of money. They were just a group of ordinary young people."

webTitle: Letter: Islington's streets are not paved with gold

fields.headline: Tarnished dream of gold in the streets
fields.trailText: Richard Heseltine (Letters, September 30) is perverse to think it is "self-serving, wishful thinking and a gross distortion of reality" for me to note that Islington ranks eighth on the National Index of Deprivation 2000 as published by the DETR - a deterioration from the 1998 ranking of 10th (so much for Islington's "regeneration   success story"). I am sorry if these official government figures undermine Cllr Heseltine's dreams of an Islington of streets paved with gold, and I hate to upset him with the news that Hull, Sunderland, Barnsley and Doncaster rank 14th, 15th, 16th and 38th respectively.

I have to say I find it personally insulting that Cllr Hesletine should believe that I would actually wish for Islington to be more deprived than it is - in fact I only wish that his golden vision of the borough were true and accurate.

Director, Islington Voluntary Action Council
