webTitle: Town in uproar after votes for opposition are sent for pulping

fields.headline: Town in uproar after votes for opposition are sent for pulping
fields.standfirst:
Driver finds ballots in load for recycling

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Further claims of illegal practices in Yugoslavia's elections emerged yesterday after a lorry driver alleged that he found ballots for opposition   politicians among a load of paper he was transporting for recycling.
fields.body:
Further claims of illegal practices in Yugoslavia's elections emerged yesterday after a lorry driver alleged that he found ballots for opposition politicians among a load of paper he was transporting for recycling.

The driver, who asked not to be named, took a sample of the voting papers to Velimir Ilic, the mayor of Cacak - the town where the pulping factory is based. Last night several of those completed polling slips were shown to the Guardian. They were all genuine.

The papers included a white presidential ballot with a vote marked for Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition challenger for the presidency which Slobodan Milosevic is clinging to, despite faring badly in last week's vote.

There were also two ballot papers, blue for the House of Citizens and yellow for the House of Republics in the federal parliament; both of these were marked for Mr Kostunica's coalition, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia.

The batch included several local election ballot slips, too. One of these contained a vote for the rightwing Radical party. None of the ballots was marked with a vote for Mr Milosevic or his federal coalition.

There was also a formal document authorising the bearer to carry ballot papers from a prison to the president of the election committee. This bore two blue original stamps.

The material for destruction contained several empty envelopes that would have contained votes from the Yugoslav army. There were large pink envelopes and smaller blue ones. The pink bore the address of the federal or local election committee, depending on what kind of vote was inside. The blue one had three stamps on the back to prove that the envelope had been sealed securely.

The date on one envelope was September 23; members of the military often vote before polling day, as the ballots go to the constituencies where the soldier's family is based.

For this material to be in the public domain at all at this stage in the election process is illegal: it should still be under lock and key and transported only under escort. Even the used envelopes should be kept and when disposed of later, should be destroyed according to strict rules and procedures.

Mr Ilic handed the ballot papers to the television station in Cacak. Its editor-in-chief, Svetlana Kojanovic, then contacted the managers at the Diva recycling plant.

"I spoke to the general manager, Milovan Jovanovic, and two workers and one other manager," Ms Kojanovic said. "The lorry involved was a big truck and they destroyed the contents. But all of them admitted that they had seen ballot papers."

Mr Ilic, who received the ballot papers from the haulier said yesterday: "It's stealing votes. It is proven that there has been a lot of stealing."

Cacak has a reputation as a strongly anti-Milosevic town. The discovery of ballots supporting opposition candidates on their way for recycling quickly added fuel to the anger of people there. Many took to the streets yesterday.

"People do not want to accept cheating and deceit. We have chaos here. We have 30,000 to 40,000 people on the street and an emotional revolt because of the stealing," Mr Ilic said.

He said some people had gathered outside the tax office and were threatening to destroy it.
fields.bodyText: Further claims of illegal practices in Yugoslavia's elections emerged yesterday after a lorry driver alleged that he found ballots for opposition politicians among a load of paper he was transporting for recycling. The driver, who asked not to be named, took a sample of the voting papers to Velimir Ilic, the mayor of Cacak - the town where the pulping factory is based. Last night several of those completed polling slips were shown to the Guardian. They were all genuine. The papers included a white presidential ballot with a vote marked for Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition challenger for the presidency which Slobodan Milosevic is clinging to, despite faring badly in last week's vote. There were also two ballot papers, blue for the House of Citizens and yellow for the House of Republics in the federal parliament; both of these were marked for Mr Kostunica's coalition, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia. The batch included several local election ballot slips, too. One of these contained a vote for the rightwing Radical party. None of the ballots was marked with a vote for Mr Milosevic or his federal coalition. There was also a formal document authorising the bearer to carry ballot papers from a prison to the president of the election committee. This bore two blue original stamps. The material for destruction contained several empty envelopes that would have contained votes from the Yugoslav army. There were large pink envelopes and smaller blue ones. The pink bore the address of the federal or local election committee, depending on what kind of vote was inside. The blue one had three stamps on the back to prove that the envelope had been sealed securely. The date on one envelope was September 23; members of the military often vote before polling day, as the ballots go to the constituencies where the soldier's family is based. For this material to be in the public domain at all at this stage in the election process is illegal: it should still be under lock and key and transported only under escort. Even the used envelopes should be kept and when disposed of later, should be destroyed according to strict rules and procedures. Mr Ilic handed the ballot papers to the television station in Cacak. Its editor-in-chief, Svetlana Kojanovic, then contacted the managers at the Diva recycling plant. "I spoke to the general manager, Milovan Jovanovic, and two workers and one other manager," Ms Kojanovic said. "The lorry involved was a big truck and they destroyed the contents. But all of them admitted that they had seen ballot papers." Mr Ilic, who received the ballot papers from the haulier said yesterday: "It's stealing votes. It is proven that there has been a lot of stealing." Cacak has a reputation as a strongly anti-Milosevic town. The discovery of ballots supporting opposition candidates on their way for recycling quickly added fuel to the anger of people there. Many took to the streets yesterday. "People do not want to accept cheating and deceit. We have chaos here. We have 30,000 to 40,000 people on the street and an emotional revolt because of the stealing," Mr Ilic said. He said some people had gathered outside the tax office and were threatening to destroy it.

fields.headline: Civil rights and wrongs
fields.trailText: Two cheers only for the Human Rights Act (Court test for new right to life law, October 2). We should be able to claim these rights without taking enormous financial risks.
fields.body:
Two cheers only for the Human Rights Act (Court test for new right to life law, October 2). We should be able to claim these rights without taking enormous financial risks. The right to go before a court to argue, for example, that constant aircraft noise infringes the right to private and family life, is fatally compromised while powerful corporations can pass the huge cost of deploying the best brains to defend their interests on to any complainant who loses an unequal contest.

Meaningful human rights must involve protection against any claim for legal costs by large corporations or the state itself for any individual who can make out a prima facie case to a court that his human rights have been denied.
Michael McCarthy
London
michaelmccar75@hotmail.com

 Your leader on the Human Rights Act (October 2) questions its long-term survival because some Tories "have lately sought to reinvent themselves ... arguing that only MPs should adjudicate civil rights and wrongs".

I am not a Tory, just a democrat. I am therefore concerned that the terms of the act are so broad that it will leave the judiciary with such powers of interpretation as to be quasi-legislative. I therefore ask myself why this task is being conferred on judges, whom we have not elected, and not on MPs, whom we have elected. Please do not assume that all opponents of the HRA are self-serving and bandwagon-seeking Tories.
Walter Cairns
Manchester
W.Cairns@mmu.ac.uk

 I suffer from an incurable, progressive neurological disease. As I enter the advanced phase the illness increasingly subjects me to "cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment" (Article 5). I passionately hope the courts will safeguard my human dignity (Article 1) by allowing me to die when my life finally becomes unbearable.
Waltraud Coles
Durham

 Does the Human Rights Act really use the masculine pronoun throughout?
Judith Taylor
London
judith.taylor@ucl.ac.uk

 The very week when "No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment" is incorporated into British law, millions of television viewers will be subjected to the repellent spectacle of hundreds of blue-rinsed, flag-waving ladies drooling over a handful of rabble-rousing party leaders in Bournemouth.
John Sheeran
Cheltenham

fields.headline: Labour's learning swerve
fields.trailText: Has Estelle Morris (Minister says New Labour has learned to like private schools, September 30) given us a true glimpse of New Labour? My abhorrence of the private system has nothing to do with the fact that pupils achieve good results, but rather that these are achieved at the expense of a significant section of society.
fields.body:
Has Estelle Morris (Minister says New Labour has learned to like private schools, September 30) given us a true glimpse of New Labour? My abhorrence of the private system has nothing to do with the fact that pupils achieve good results, but rather that these are achieved at the expense of a significant section of society. In comprehensive schools throughout the country, teachers take on the role of counsellor, social worker and mediator, as well as teaching of classes of 30-plus.

Middle-class parents flock to private schools because they want their children to mix with the "right" children - in other words, children like theirs. New Labour has succumbed to their voting power. Have we lost the ideal that the more able contribute to the wellbeing of those less privileged? How many desperately needed new recruits to the health service, teaching and social services come from private schools?
Marion Saunders
Greenford, Middlesex
m.l.saunders@which.net

 Estelle Morris declares that New Labour admires private schools. So what does she think about socialists who believe that private schools reinforce inequality? She must find it difficult to understand those of us whose old Labour principles led us to support state schools by sending our children to the nearest comprehensive.
Bob Holman
Glasgow
BOB@holman24.fsnet.co.uk

 Glad to hear that Estelle Morris and New Labour are "open and honest about what they can learn from" the independent school sector. What would that be then? High expenditure per pupil? Well-maintained and developed school buildings? Fifteen pupils per class? No, thought not.
Jeff Wells
London

 This is clearly an attempt to ensure that the middle-class voters stay onside without any real understanding of the damage that it is doing to the educational attainments of the majority. The undemocratic and impossible hurdles set for parents who wish to stop the selective system, such as here in Kent, is another clue to the blinkered approach to education that Labour have taken. Tony Blair's mantra of education, education, education has a most hollow ring about it when compared with the reality on the ground.
Sid Hollands
Maidstone, Kent
sid_hollands@onetel.net.uk

 How sad it is to see Estelle Morris, a one time passionate advocate of ending the divided secondary system, now turning a New Labour somersault. She says that "there has been a huge cultural change in the Labour party".

But Labour has opposed the independent sector since the 1950s and I challenge Miss Morris to produce a single statement of party policy to back up any change from that position.
Max and Margaret Morris
London
MMMorris@msn.com

 Estelle Morris says Labour will never try to restrict parents' right to choose a private school education for their children. Without massive redistribution of wealth through a progressive tax regime, however, the Labour government is doing exactly that. How many parents whose children might benefit from the advantages of better-funded private education can afford to provide such an expensive luxury? Defending the right of the wealthy to choose while economic inequality stifles such choice for the majority is simply undemocratic and unjust.
Peter Burgess
Cardiff
burgesski@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Marching with Mandela
fields.trailText: As a member of the Anti-Apartheid Movement executive committee for over 20 years, I do not recognise Val Mainwood's description (Letters, September 30) of the hard left's "contribution" to our campaigns.
fields.body:
As a member of the Anti-Apartheid Movement executive committee for over 20 years, I do not recognise Val Mainwood's description (Letters, September 30) of the hard left's "contribution" to our campaigns. They did come along to our events to sell their newspapers, and to argue that Nelson Mandela was mistaken to build a national liberation struggle rather than a socialist revolution. Meanwhile it was left to those of us on the traditional left, together with liberals, church members, trade unionists and others, to get on with the practical solidarity requested by the ANC.
Paul Blomfield
Sheffield

 As Nelson Mandela thanked the Labour party for the support he received dur ing his years of captivity, I listened with the usual tears in my eyes and lump in my throat. However, I felt doubly sad as I realised that there must be so many longstanding Labour party members like myself (36 years) who are no longer members, simply because New Labour has reneged on so many of the basic socialist principles to which Nelson Mandela referred.

I would doubt whether many of those sycophantic CLP delegates sitting in the conference hall were even members of the party at the time, never mind marching the streets and giving accommodation to our comrades from South Africa.
Shirley Haines
Leeds
shirley@rochester16. freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: More healthcare secrets
fields.trailText: I read with interest Sarah Boseley's article (Cubans tell the NHS the secret of £7 a head healthcare, October 2). A friend and I both suffered severe gastroenteritis on holiday this summer. I was seen immediately by a doctor at the resort where I was staying. Rehydration was deemed necessary. An ambulance took me to the local infirmary where a doctor met me immediately. I was fed salts, put on a drip for four hours and prescribed four different medicines. Seven hours later I was taken by ambulance back to my hotel. Within 18 hours of suffering the attack I was able to go out for a meal.
fields.body:
I read with interest Sarah Boseley's article (Cubans tell the NHS the secret of £7 a head healthcare, October 2). A friend and I both suffered severe gastroenteritis on holiday this summer. I was seen immediately by a doctor at the resort where I was staying. Rehydration was deemed necessary. An ambulance took me to the local infirmary where a doctor met me immediately. I was fed salts, put on a drip for four hours and prescribed four different medicines. Seven hours later I was taken by ambulance back to my hotel. Within 18 hours of suffering the attack I was able to go out for a meal.

My friend was taken by car to the accident and emergency department of the nearest local hospital. While her partner tried to find somewhere to park his car, she staggered in and gave her details to the admissions officer as she slid down the counter. After a wait, she got an injection. An ambulance? You wouldn't bother asking.

I was in Cuba. She was in Manchester.
Mick Gosling
London

 It's not only in health care that Cuba excels. In the Olympic medals league Cuba came 9th (one place ahead of the UK) beaten only by countries with either far larger populations or mightier economies. Imagine where they would have been on a table calculated on size of population or GNP - not to mention one showing countries suffering from illegal US economic blockades.
Lucy Craig
London
lucycraig@talk21.com

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Coal miners pull plug on Serbian power, page 13, yesterday, we said the Kolubera colliery provided the coal for the Obrenovac thermonuclear electricity station. Thermonuclear was an invention of our own. The station does use coal.
fields.body:
In a report headed Coal miners pull plug on Serbian power, page 13, yesterday, we said the Kolubera colliery provided the coal for the Obrenovac thermonuclear electricity station. Thermonuclear was an invention of our own. The station does use coal.

In recommending Laurence Olivier's Henry V, among the week's best films on television, page 53, the Guide, September 30, we drew particular attention to his "St Swithin's Day" speech before the battle of Agincourt. We called it "a heroic rabble-rouser". It was, of course, St Crispin's Day. This is how the speech, from Act IV, scene iii, concludes: And gentlemen in England, now a-bed /Shall think themselves accurs'd they were not here,/And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speak/That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day.

Also among the Guide's recommended films on television, page 54, we described James Booth, one of the stars of the 1961 film In The Doghouse as "Cherie's dad". Cherie Blair's father is Tony Booth, not James.

In reporting Courtney Pine's tribute to the musician Mac Tontoh, Profile, Saturday Review, pages 6 and 7, September 30, we referred to the latter as "the late musician". There is nothing late about him. He is alive and well and touring the UK with his new 11-piece band from Ghana, the Mac Tontoh Project. Apologies for that. Information about the tour by telephone from 07968 158469; website www.mactontoh.com

We played several wrong notes in a piece about organs, headed Pipe dreams, pages 8 and 9, Friday Review, September 29. In a list of famous organist/composers we meant to mention Jehan Alain, rather than his sister Marie-Claire Alain; we inadvertently knighted the builder of the Royal Festival Hall's organ, Ralph Downes (the installation was completed in 1954); and Bridgewater Hall in Manchester is not about to have a fine modern instrument - it already has one.

In an appreciation of Basil Bernstein, Obituaries, page 24, September 29, we said he could not be pigeonholed as "a Hogarthian scholarship boy". Certainly not, nor as a (Richard) Hoggartian scholarship boy, the description transformed by a mishearing on the telephone.

The Collioure of the Matisse painting to which we referred in our review of Méditerranée, page 16, yesterday, is not on the Riviera, but on the Golfe du Lion, very close to the border with Spain.

The hurricane warning, page 15 yesterday, covered the Yucatan peninsula, not peninsular (a word very rarely needed but often used).

webTitle: Business: Hewitt backs Oftel on local loop

fields.headline: Hewitt backs Oftel on local loop
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Patricia Hewitt, the minister for e-commerce, yesterday gave her backing to the beleaguered Oftel chief, David Edmonds, and his handling of the break-up of British Telecom's monopoly of the local phone network.
fields.body:
Patricia Hewitt, the minister for e-commerce, yesterday gave her backing to the beleaguered Oftel chief, David Edmonds, and his handling of the break-up of British Telecom's monopoly of the local phone network.

Her comments came as controversy surrounding the unbundling of the local loop intensified.

It emerged that twelve of BT's competitors - including Energis, Colt Telecom and Kingston Communications - have lodged an official complaint with the telecoms regulator against BT as a prelude to possible legal action.

Ms Hewitt defended the timetable set out by Oftel which she said will see "widespread" alternatives to BT in the local network by next July.

She blamed the previous government and the former Oftel director-general, Don Cruickshank, for not setting the process in motion earlier and for allowing the US and some European countries to gain a head start.

"It is worth remembering that the last government and regulator weren't interested in local loop unbundling," Ms Hewitt said. "They were pursuing a policy of competition against the local loop by laying cable. It was only when David Edmonds arrived that he put unbundling on the agenda.

"Oftel are making very tough decisions to deliver unbundling and to deliver an increasingly competitive telecoms market. They have the government's full support."

BT has been accused of dragging its feet and of denying suppliers access to its most lucrative local exchanges.

Rival operators have vented their anger on Oftel for allegedly being "soft" on BT. They are concerned that the erstwhile monopoly will gain a lead in the deployment of digital technology which upgrades copper wires for broad band use to carry high speed internet or even television transmissions.

A spokeswoman for Energis said: "We are currently not able to play on a level playing field to BT and we don't feel that is right."

Ms Hewitt is today in Luxembourg for a meeting to approve draft EU regulations on the opening of the local loop to competition - the last mile from local exchanges to the home or business.

The draft says BT and its opposite numbers throughout Europe must meet any "reasonable requests" from rivals to store equipment in their ex changes from December 31. Caveats are made regarding "technical feasibility" and BT's ability to "maintain network integrity".

Ms Hewitt said Britain would fall in line with the regulations by starting the process at the beginning of next year but that nobody expected the entire network to be open "from day one".

She would not be drawn into criticism of BT. "Incumbents have their own commercial positions to protect. It's very easy for people to complain - sometimes they are justified, sometimes not."

The process of breaking up the local loop has broad political implications. In the US, where unbundling took place some time ago, the advent of competition has driven prices down and increased the use of high speed internet services.

Oftel is expected to issue a consultation document within the next two weeks setting out the options for how space in BT local exchanges will be divided between the various rivals. At present demand far outstrips the space available in more popular exchanges.

A spokesman for the regulator said there would be no comment on the case against BT until further meetings had been held with the complainants.

A spokeswoman for Energis said: "We are currently not able to play on a level playing field to BT and we don't feel that is right." Ms Hewitt is today in Luxembourg for a meeting to approve draft EU regulations on the opening of the local loop to competition - the last mile from local exchanges to the home or business. The draft says BT and its opposite numbers throughout Europe must meet any "reasonable requests" from rivals to store equipment in their ex changes from December 31. Caveats are made regarding "technical feasibility" and BT's ability to "maintain network integrity". Ms Hewitt said Britain would fall in line with the regulations by starting the process at the beginning of next year but that nobody expected the entire network to be open "from day one". She would not be drawn into criticism of BT. "Incumbents have their own commercial positions to protect. It's very easy for people to complain - sometimes they are justified, sometimes not." The process of breaking up the local loop has broad political implications. In the US, where unbundling took place some time ago, the advent of competition has driven prices down and increased the use of high speed internet services. Oftel is expected to issue a consultation document within the next two weeks setting out the options for how space in BT local exchanges will be divided between the various rivals. At present demand far outstrips the space available in more popular exchanges. A spokesman for the regulator said there would be no comment on the case against BT until further meetings had been held with the complainants.

webTitle: US struggles to keep talks together

fields.headline: US struggles to keep talks together
fields.standfirst:
President Clinton's hopes of a 'peace coup' look forlorn
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration was scrambling yesterday to salvage something from its eight-year attempt to forge a comprehensive Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement, as prospects for a deal appeared to evaporate in the smoke rising from the occupied territories.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration was scrambling yesterday to salvage something from its eight-year attempt to forge a comprehensive Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement, as prospects for a deal appeared to evaporate in the smoke rising from the occupied territories.

The White House announced it would chair a meeting of Israeli and Palestinian security officials to discuss the roots of the violence in an attempt to prevent further clashes. The national security council spokesman, PJ Crowley, said the meeting would take place somewhere in the region "as soon as conditions permit".

He added that US security experts would take part to "see how both parties can ensure that the Palestinian and Israeli people do not relive the terrible events of the last few days".

The meeting was proposed in the course of a hectic weekend of damage limitation by US leaders. Mr Clinton telephoned the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, on Saturday, and Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader, the next day.

According to Mr Crowley, the president expressed his concern over the course of events, conveyed his condolences to the families of the dead, and called for calm.

The secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and the national security adviser, Sandy Berger, also called officials on both sides of the conflict in an attempt to prevent any further escalation.

In Washington, however, there was a growing sense of helplessness and resignation over prospects for a permanent Middle East settlement, a diplomatic coup which the White House had hoped would be Mr Clinton's crowning foreign policy achievement. Although he will remain in office until January 20, he will have little authority to pursue a Middle East peace agreement after the November 7 presidential elections.

The administration, normally anxious not to apportion blame, could not hide its anger with Ariel Sharon, the Israeli opposition leader whose visit last Thursday to the Muslim holy site in Jerusalem, Haram al-Sharif, sparked the current wave of rioting.

Ms Albright called the visit counter-productive while the White House spokesman Jake Siewert said of the Sharon visit "We've said that was not helpful, and we've urged everyone to exercise good judgment, avoid provocative acts and respect, particularly, that site."

Before the violence erupted, US officials believed they had a fighting chance of reaching an elusive compromise over Jerusalem's future. Trilateral talks in July at Camp David ground to a halt over the fate of Jerusalem, and particularly over who would control the Haram al-Sharif (known to Jews as the Temple Mount), which is sacred to both religions. But both sides had promised to continue to explore the limits of compromise over the highly emotive issue.

Last month, US diplomats had floated a number of "bridging proposals" including one plan under which the holy sites would be under UN control. But such a compromise would have involved political risks for Mr Barak and Mr Arafat. Their scope for taking such risks has now narrowed considerably, Middle East analysts agreed yesterday.

"This is not just another outburst of violence," Itamar Rabinovich, a former Israeli ambassador to Washington, told the New York Times. "This will have the most profound effect on the Israeli public ... This opens some very old books."

According to the New York Times, the Clinton administration compiled a summary of the conflicting positions 10 days ago, together with the bridging proposals. However, rather than present the document as a fait accompli , the White House invited the top Israeli and Palestinian negotiators to Washington, in an attempt to make some headway. The emissaries made little progress and left the US on Thursday, the day Mr Sharon made his controversial visit to the Haram al-Sharif.

webTitle: What the Arab and Israeli papers say

fields.headline: What the Arab and Israeli papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Jerusalem Post
fields.body:
Jerusalem Post

Yasser Arafat is once again attempting to negotiate with violence. The supposed reason for the Palestinian riots - Likud leader Ariel Sharon's visit to the Temple Mount on Thursday - should be dismissed outright ... Violence of the scope recently seen - the worst rioting since 1996 - is effectively an act of will by the Palestinian leadership, for which Sharon's visit at most provided a convenient rallying cry

Ha'aretz (Israel)

Whoever expected Palestinian restraint in the wake of the visit to the Temple Mount is probably the same person who hoped to see rational restraint throughout the days of the vacillating diplomatic negotiations between the two sides ... The struggle between the Islamic strands and the Palestinian Authority ... has been ongoing, and every time a conflagration occurs, questions arise anew about the level of control exercised by Yasser Arafat.

Bahrain Tribune

The world may be hearing new talk on "Israeli commitment to peace" but, alas, the world is seeing old, familiar scenes of a distorted, often brutal, violence-laden policy of subjugation that Israel continues to wield in occupied Jerusalem ... It seems the matter has been thrown wide open once more as doubts are raised anew on Israel's genuine commitment to peace. While everyone is wondering if authentic concessions would be made over occupied Jerusalem, Israeli bullets are already giving a hint that probably there would be none.

Syria Times

The entire American approach towards the peace process no longer seems promising. If there is no other US approach, the peace process will soon come to a complete standstill - but with grave and destructive consequences.

al-Quds al-Arabi (Palestinian)

The intifada [uprising] is carrying a message to the Americans and Israelis that the peace process in its old form has to be re-evaluated and has to respect the feelings of the Palestinian people. If there is to be a ceasefire it should be with the Palestinian people, not with Mr Arafat, because they are the ones who are really facing the Israelis ...

fields.headline: Patchy start to Serbian strike
fields.standfirst:
The capital fails to match anger in the provinces

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: A general strike to force Yugoslavia's president, Slododan Milosevic, to concede electoral defeat failed to bring the Serbian republic to a complete standstill yesterday.
fields.body:
A general strike to force Yugoslavia's president, Slododan Milosevic, to concede electoral defeat failed to bring the Serbian republic to a complete standstill yesterday.

Opposition strongholds in the provinces lived up to their record of radicalism, but in Belgrade and other major cities workers failed to heed opposition pleas for a boycott.

The opposition had urged a countrywide general strike to force Mr Milosevic to concede that his challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, had won an outright victory in the first round of the presidential election on September 24.

The state electoral committee ruled last week that Mr Kostunica's share of the vote fell just short of 50% and ordered a runoff next Sunday.

In activist towns such as Cacak, Kraljevo, and Kragujevac, roads were blocked, shops shut and businesses closed. But an opposition spokesman conceded that the day's showing was a disappointment.

"Today we particularly failed with this general strike...People in Serbia are not ready yet to boycott everything," the spokesman said.

Major roads leading to the centre of the capital were blocked during the first few hours after the strike's 5am start. But later they grew busy with buses and trams taking workers to offices and businesses. Staff arrived late, but many went to work.

In the afternoon, students disrupted major streets in the heart of the capital. Tens of thousands rallied outside the federal parliament. A crucial intersection was blocked at various times by the students, who blew whistles and horns and waved flags. One group handed in a letter at the army general staff building, calling on the army to stay neutral.

Olivera Obradovic, 23, said that she and her fellow students planned to occupy a university building overnight."We are trying to inject some enthusiasm and to encourage people to hold on and get this finished - to end this destruction of the country," she said.

The patchy support in Belgrade was in contrast to the commitment shown by several towns in Serbia's hinterland. The strikers at the Kolubera coal mine complex said they were under enormous pressure, but that they had rebuffed police on Sunday night.

"Everyone is 100% ready to continue the strike," a union member, Milovan Jankovic, said.

Around 4,500 miners also downed tools at the Kostolac mine in eastern Serbia. They blocked off the mine and power plant but agreed to maintain minimum output.

In the opposition-held town of Kraljevo, a journalist, Ljudmila Svetkovic, said that key roads were blocked. Restaurants, shops, buses, state companies - even the local Socialist party television station - were on strike, she said.

In nearby Kragulevac, more than 30,000 people took to the streets, including car workers and labourers from the armaments factory. And in Cacak an angry crowd threatened to demolish the tax office.

In Mr Milosevic's hometown of Pozarevac, until recently firmly controlled by his allies, farmers blocked roads and the schools were closed.

fields.headline: Political casualties
fields.standfirst: How the mighty fell
fields.trailText: Remarkably, all the politicians most closely associated with the reunification have had their careers and reputations tarnished by scandal:
fields.body:
Remarkably, all the politicians most closely associated with the reunification have had their careers and reputations tarnished by scandal:

Helmut Kohl

Germany's then chancellor and the driving force behind reunification has been the most outstanding victim.

Last year he admitted running a string of accounts while in power to disguise the origin of donations to his party, the Christian Democrat Union (CDU). He has excluded himself from today's commemorative events.

Wolfgang Schäuble

Mr Kohl's longtime lieutenant and the man who negotiated the treaty of union on behalf of West Germany.

He succeeded Mr Kohl as leader of the CDU but was forced to resign earlier this year after admitting that he had received a contribution to the party that was not subsequently disclosed.

Lothar de Maiziere

East Germany's first and only democratically elected prime minister and chief representative of the formerly communist state in the unity negotiations. Two months after unification he was accused of being an informer for the Stasi, the East German intelligence service. He quit active politics soon after.

fields.headline: Mystery surrounds rules of engagement
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The rules of engagement used by the Israeli Defence Force and the border police in the occupied territories have always been something of a mystery. It has never been clear if a systematic set of rules existed, let alone whether they were followed in the heat of civil unrest.
fields.body:
The rules of engagement used by the Israeli Defence Force and the border police in the occupied territories have always been something of a mystery. It has never been clear if a systematic set of rules existed, let alone whether they were followed in the heat of civil unrest.

During the 1987-93 intifada (uprising) evidence emerged that undercover Israeli units were operating under a shoot-to-kill policy and were carrying out summary executions on suspected instigators of the riots. A 1993 report by Human Rights Watch alleged that 120 Palestinians had been killed by these squads operating in disguise among the protesters.

A report by the US state department during the intifada noted that although the IDF was supposed to have rules of engagement which limited the use of force, these guidelines "often were not followed, resulting in avoidable deaths and injuries."

Since the intifada, the Israeli security forces have frequently used live ammunition against Palestinian demonstrators in the West Bank and Gaza despite the absence of firearms on the Palestinian side, producing a steady stream of deaths among the shabab - the young men at the forefront of the protests.

The IDF does not disclose its rules of engagement as a matter of policy, presumably so that Palestinian rioters could not be sure of the threshold of violence which would draw a lethal response. However, the army and the border police frequently defend the use of live fire by arguing that their troops had been under threat.

For observers, it has been hard to distinguish which circumstances would trigger live fire from Israeli lines, and which would evoke the Israeli version of rubber bullets - normally a metal ball bearing covered in a layer of black rubber quite capable of causing lethal injuries.

There have been few cases over the years in which Israeli soldiers have been prosecuted for shooting Palestinian protesters, and there has been scant pressure from the Israeli media for public investigations. A soldier is much more likely to face a court-martial for allowing his weapon to be taken from him than for opening fire in a tense situation.

Soldiers are forbidden under any circumstances from opening fire on Jewish settlers. The fact emerged in the course of an enquiry into the 1994 massacre of Muslim worshippers at a Hebron mosque. A border police superintendent told the commission of enquiry that soldiers would have been unable to prevent the killings because of the rules of engagement.

fields.headline: On the slant
fields.standfirst: Do the media create public opinion through the way they report the news, or do they simply give their audience what they want to hear?
fields.trailText: Denmark's verdict on the euro was surprising in one respect only - the Copenhagen media were broadly to be found in the yes camp.
fields.body:
Denmark's verdict on the euro was surprising in one respect only - the Copenhagen media were broadly to be found in the yes camp. In the United Kingdom the opposite holds. The foreigners and Channel Islanders who own such a large chunk of daily newspaper circulation in this country are vehement nay-sayers; the BBC, too, is more likely to run stories critical of European institutions.

In this, as in other political debates, media biases matter. Across Europe, Europe gets a bad press. In Denmark, too, the euro has tended to be reported negatively. Unsurprisingly, then, public attitudes towards the European Union are downbeat if not hostile. A new study* by Pippa Norris, a British polling expert who now teaches at Harvard, argues that there is a strong link between negative news coverage and public support.

Barring elections to the European parliament, people lack direct experience of pan-European politics. For knowledge and evaluation of EU institutions they rely on other sources of information. Europe, political scientists say, is a test bed for the thesis that people take their political cues from the news media. It looks as if they do.

Most EU matters get minimal media coverage, except in the context of summits of prime ministers when interest ticks up. Of course some media reportage is neutral in tone. Most is slanted. The graphs show that extensive and sustained negative coverage of the euro is associated with lowered levels of public support for Europe. Media editors might argue that they were merely following opinion, not creating it. It is true that the empirical findings do not establish which way cause runs. Yet surely we have enough experience in this country of pro-active media and influential proprietors never to doubt that the media do create attitudes.

"European citizens cannot be expected to care much about European elections or know much about their rights within the EU if there is minimal coverage of parliamentary debates in Strasbourg," Professor Norris says in her new book. History shows that consistently negative coverage erodes support for particular leaders (Neil Kinnock's fate), governments and policies. Likewise a persistently Eurosceptic press damaged early public confidence in the euro - not just in the UK but across the EU.

In the media mix, newspapers still count. They have not been supplanted by television and electronic media. Long-run trends in sales are fairly stable across the western world. In countries belonging to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), average newspaper circulation was 271 copies per 1,000 population in 1950, rising modestly to a 1980 peak before falling slightly to 263 per 1,000 in 1996 - despite the growth of television. The UK's relatively high newspaper circulation is exceeded only in Japan and Scandinavia. It is about the same as in Germany and the Netherlands.

The chart shows just how much newspaper news is still consumed. Across the 15 member states of the EU, 71% say they watch television news on a daily basis, compared with 45% who read news in papers and 47% who listen to radio news daily. Even if all internet users get their news online, they form only a fifth of the EU's population. The conclusion has to be that new media tend to supplement the old rather than replace them; there is every indication this pattern will hold for the internet.

Professor Norris's book takes issue with the conventional wisdom that the media (and Millbank-style campaigning) have fuelled people's disenchantment with politics - which is not the same as saying media campaign and biases do not turn people off in particular instances. The evidence, on the contrary, says that the media may turn people on to politics in the sense that those most knowledgeable about politics (and most likely to vote) are also the heaviest users of the media. Thanks to the media, people can take part. Those motivated to find out tend to be better educated and better off (and younger and male). The relatively small numbers who get their news online tend also to be politically savvy and "trusting".

But there is an implication in Professor Norris's work to alarm pro-Europeans. Even if Rupert Murdoch were to wake up one morning with the gold stars of the EU flag before his eyes, his papers' change of allegiance might make no difference in a campaign for UK membership of the euro. Those people who are most disenchanted with politics tend to screen out coverage of things they do not like. Anti-Europeans wouldn't watch, listen or read positive stories. Only those already in sympathy with further integration are going to attend to neutral or good news about the EU.

In the early years, the makers of Europe relied on a "permissive consensus" among people at large. But during the 1990s indicators of dissent started climbing, and who knows if last week's Danish vote represents a peak?

At the same time, however, newspapers have been losing their partisan stamp. Across Europe traditional allegiances have fallen away and personal proprietors given way to corporations. This "press-party dealignment" has made it more difficult for parties to manage the media. Such a process has not happened in the UK. Even if it had, editors might still be tempted to move coverage of Europe and the euro in the anti direction they think public opinion is taking.

*Pippa Norris, A Virtuous Circle: political communications in postindustrial societies, Cambridge University Press


Links: www.cambridge.org

The evidence, on the contrary, says that the media may turn people on to politics in the sense that those most knowledgeable about politics (and most likely to vote) are also the heaviest users of the media. Thanks to the media, people can take part. Those motivated to find out tend to be better educated and better off (and younger and male). The relatively small numbers who get their news online tend also to be politically savvy and "trusting". But there is an implication in Professor Norris's work to alarm pro-Europeans. Even if Rupert Murdoch were to wake up one morning with the gold stars of the EU flag before his eyes, his papers' change of allegiance might make no difference in a campaign for UK membership of the euro. Those people who are most disenchanted with politics tend to screen out coverage of things they do not like. Anti-Europeans wouldn't watch, listen or read positive stories. Only those already in sympathy with further integration are going to attend to neutral or good news about the EU. In the early years, the makers of Europe relied on a "permissive consensus" among people at large. But during the 1990s indicators of dissent started climbing, and who knows if last week's Danish vote represents a peak? At the same time, however, newspapers have been losing their partisan stamp. Across Europe traditional allegiances have fallen away and personal proprietors given way to corporations. This "press-party dealignment" has made it more difficult for parties to manage the media. Such a process has not happened in the UK. Even if it had, editors might still be tempted to move coverage of Europe and the euro in the anti direction they think public opinion is taking. *Pippa Norris, A Virtuous Circle: political communications in postindustrial societies, Cambridge University Press Links: www.cambridge.org david.walker@theguardian.com

webTitle: Ford joins the cut-price club as drivers gear up for cheaper cars

fields.headline: Ford joins the cut-price club as drivers gear up for cheaper cars
fields.standfirst:
Industry divided as to whether steep reductions will benefit buyers

Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford, the UK's biggest car seller, yesterday heralded a long-awaited shake-up in the British car market by cutting its list prices by between 5% and 13% in a move designed to bring wary motorists back to showrooms and to challenge its rivals to follow suit.
fields.body:
Ford, the UK's biggest car seller, yesterday heralded a long-awaited shake-up in the British car market by cutting its list prices by between 5% and 13% in a move designed to bring wary motorists back to showrooms and to challenge its rivals to follow suit.

The world's second largest auto manufacturer became the first volume car-maker to slash its recommended retail prices (RRPs) after a year of a government-inspired "rip-off Britain" campaign that prompted consumers to look to Europe and the internet to buy new cars which cost up to 12% more in the UK. Or to keep their old cars and wait and see.

Ford said it would cut the listed price for its best-selling car, the Focus 1.6 Zetec, by 11.1% or £1,505 to an on-the-road price of £11,995 and offer a three-year, 60,000-mile warranty for all its new cars, backdated to September 1.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, who last month implemented measures to close the £1bn-a-year gap between UK and European car prices, hailed Ford's announcement as "a victory for the consumer" and forecast that other big manufacturers would follow suit.

But Vauxhall, the second biggest car-seller, merely said it would examine Ford's move and insisted its cars remained "excellent value for money'.'

Industry analysts warned that consumers should not expect to see showroom prices come tumbling down immediately.

"It's all smoke and mirrors and I don't expect to see a significant cut in transaction prices [the price a motorist actually pays to a dealer]," a rival industry insider said. "Before, dealers used to say, here's the listed price but let's have a chat. Now they'll say, here's the price and that's that."

Peter Wells, senior research fellow at the motor industry unit at Cardiff business school, agreed. "Consumers - and dealers - may find they have far less room to manoeuvre. Over the piece consumers may benefit but not necessarily so."

Paul Everitt, chief economist at the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), said Ford had been the first major player to adjust its RRPs to transaction prices and these, including trade-in and discount, would not change substantially in the coming months.

But Alan Pulham, director of the National Franchised Dealers Association, said he expected the gap between British prices and those in continental Europe to narrow significantly. "Consumers can expect just about all the manufacturers which have not moved to drop their prices and hopefully this will be the once-and-for-all move to bring confidence back to the market-place," he said.

The reason for the confusion is simple. The government's campaign against high car prices forced manufacturers such as Ford to offer a series of incentives such as cash-back deals, free AA membership and insurance and low rates of interest to win back customers.

Average new car prices fell 5.9% in the year to August, according to the Alliance & Leicester index published last week, with prices for nearly new and used cars down 18.2% and 21.7% respectively. But sales to individual consumers, according to Mr Pulham, have fallen around 10%. Ford's market share has dropped from 17.7% in August 1999 to 16.7% in August this year.

Ford insiders insisted yesterday that its incentives packages had boosted its market share last month - in SMMT figures due out later this week - to above 18%. But they admitted, too, that yesterday's cut in RRPs might make little difference to the actual price a motorist pays: the basic Ka, with £500 cash back, cost £6,995 before and now, without cash back, will cost the same on the road.

Ian McAllister, Ford's UK chairman, said the key point, however, was that his company's measures brought "clarity and stability" for the new car buyer.

Consumers welcomed them as creating the greater transparency they had long campaigned for, but industry experts were not so sure.

Mr Everitt said the measures, coupled with an optimistic economic outlook as a whole, should boost car sales from this year's expected 2.2m - the same as in 1999, but held up by company sales - by 50,000 to 100,000 next year.

But Dr Wells said the prospects were for greater rather than less turbulence in the coming months.

One reason is that the government is pressing the European commission to end the so-called block exemption - allowing car manufacturers to sell exclusively to their own franchised dealers - when it runs out in September 2002. Other EU countries, where car prices scarcely rate as a political issue, are not so keen and experts say this will increase uncertainty about future prices.

Another source of instability is the fluctuating exchange rate between the pound and the euro. Manufacturers had assumed that the single currency's decline would be a short-term blip but, after 21 months of falling value, they are hesitant and confused. "Ford's decision to cut its listed price is quite a gamble that the euro will recover," one expert said.

A final fly in the ointment is that the price cuts, together with expensive new model programmes, will bring a further drop in the profit margins of the big car manufacturers, which are barely able to get 2% on sales. They could squeeze dealers who, in turn, squeeze customers with less attractive packages - and consumers will continue to buy from the web at prices up to £1,500 cheaper, say, for a Ford Focus.

Price cuts will also spell further trouble for British components makers as manufacturers try to offset sterling's strength by buying abroad. "There are big investment decisions pending, at Nissan's Sunderland plant and Peugeot's Ryton factory," Mr Everitt said. "The government may get rock-bottom prices but how many jobs is that worth?"

webTitle: Party fails to pick women for safe seats

fields.headline: Party fails to pick women for safe seats
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: A Tory woman MP yesterday appealed for more women to be selected to stand for parliament as the party came under sustained attack for its failure to do so.
fields.body:
A Tory woman MP yesterday appealed for more women to be selected to stand for parliament as the party came under sustained attack for its failure to do so.

Caroline Spelman, MP for Meriden, admitted there were too few Tory women MPs - just 14 compared to Labour's 101 - and that the party had failed to do enough to tackle this enduring problem.

But she failed to suggest how this could be changed or to answer criticism from one hopeful woman MP that candidates were being blocked by other women involved in the selection process.

"We haven't made enough progress in selecting women candidates," she confessed to the party's conference in Bournemouth.

"We have some really excellent women candidates and I appeal to you to select them, to encourage them, to mentor them, because we need more of them."

Mrs Spelman's rallying cry, in the party's first debate on Women's Choices, came after Fiona Guest, one unselected candidate accused women within the party of hindering other women's progress.

Lamenting the "far too few Conservative MPs who are women", she said: "There are still women who don't want women to be MPs and turn down able women ...I know. I have sat on selection committees."

After the debate, Mrs Guest, a 32-year-old pharmicist, elaborated: "It's the old ladies on the selection committees to put it bluntly. I have seen it in action.

"It isn't at the borough or local level, but at the parliamentary level."

She believed there were several reasons such elderly women opposed the selection of other women: "It's possibly because while they were growing up there were few women MPs and they are not used to it, possibly because they don't see it as a woman's place and possibly because of jealousy - because they didn't have the opportunity to do it themselves."

And she called on the abolition of women's committees - part of many constituencies, and therefore an influence on the selection process - describing them as a "magnet and power base" for such women.

Mrs Guest's attack followed criticism earlier in the day of the party's selection process when two would-be women candidates - one of whom had been trying to be selected for a decade - told BBC Radio 4's Today programme it was stacked against them.

Elizabeth Gibson, who is searching for a winnable seat, told the programme: "The current selection process does work against women.

" Very often at selection it appears that men are parachuted in from nowhere having had little previous political experience whereas women who have got longer years of service seem to be shoved aside."

Calling for an overhaul of the system, she attacked a process which demands a "barn-storming speech" at each of the last three stages of the selection, and suggested more emphasis should be placed on the question and answer sessions - "a much more satisfactory way of looking at how women perform."

For Melinda Libby, who has spent 10 fruitless years searching for a winnable constituency after contesting the safe Labour seat of St Helens North at the 1987 election, womens-only shortlists - a method favoured by Labour, who will introduce new laws governing this after the next election - may be the answer. "I understand that there are 19 winnable seats that have so far selected candidates and not one of them has been a woman," she said.

"Something must be done and that something - the bullet that has got to be bitten - has probably got to be some form of positive discrimination."

But, throughout the debate, women insisted they did not want to be treated differently from their male colleagues. Opening the debate, the shadow spokesman for women's issues, Theresa May, insisted: "We have never believed in ghettoising any group unlike Labour who have patronised women for far too long."

Nicola Page, the Tories' next candidate for Bury South added: "In Britain any ambitious, talented woman can be successful in any career even politics.

"The New Labour government considered me a special case because I'm a woman but I am not a special case. I don't want to be considered a special case."

Labour - which introduced women's-only shortlists before it was ruled illegal before the last election - responded by criticising Mr Hague's "utter failure to deal with the massive under representation of women in their ranks."

Tessa Jowell, the minister for women, added: "We want a parliament that looks like Britain with equal representation of men and women."

fields.headline: Yesterday: Good day, Bad day
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Yesterday
fields.body:
Yesterday

Good day

Kenneth Clarke. He may not feature in William Hague's plans but the former chancellor is still popular as a survey of 325 London businesses showed. Mr Clarke was picked as the best man to lead the party by 43% of the firms. In contrast Mr Hague was chosen by just 25%, the same number who picked shadow chancellor Michael Portillo in the survey conducted by polling firm IDA for the London Chamber of Commerce.

Bad day

Boris Johnson. The editor of The Spectator and Tory hopeful for Michael Heseltine's old seat, Henley, appeared to fall asleep at the Guardian debate, and was certainly confused when asked by Hugo Young what William Hague could do to make himself more unpopular. The Jackal, who had waffled amusingly throughout his earlier contribution, repeated the question several times and finally appeared stumped, admitting: "My imagination's totally run dry." He finally came up with two possible solutions, however: bring back the death penalty - or start wearing a dress.

Jokes of the day

Shadow cabinet office minister Andrew Lansley had a go at Labour 'products' He said: "Then there is the John Prescott thesaurus - when only the wrong word will do. Or what about a Jack Straw burglar alarm - it warns the burglar when the police are coming. Or why not take out a loan for a Peter Mandelson washing machine - goes straight to the spin cycle but never washes whiter. Or could you spare 75p for a Gordon Brown kiss me quick hat." Jim Davidson need have no worries.

Delegate of day

Linda Baldry, 50, a secretary from Buxton, in Derbyshire. "It feels very positive. We've spent two years listening to people and now we've got some policies to offer them. For a while they were disillusioned with us - and quite rightly so.

I particularly enjoyed seeing all the candidates rushing on to the stage today because I thought: 'This is a team.' It didn't strike me that there were too few women. I'm not in favour of positive discrimination: I think if women are good enough they get selected - they shouldn't get chosen just becuase they're women.

Today

11.30am William Hague makes his first of two conference outings when he takes questions from the floor. 2.30pm Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo addresses the conference

3pm Shadow health secretary Liam Fox on NHS policy

4pm Shadow transport secretary Bernard Jenkin. Fringe Kenneth Clarke speaks at Conservative Group for Europe; Ffion Hague due at British Council-sponsored meeting.

fields.standfirst:
Where to find the best price

Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford
fields.body:
Ford

Ford Focus 5-door 1.6 Zetec: from £13,500 to £11,995, saving £1,505. First cut in manufacturer's recommended retail prices. Officially designed to bring "clarity and stability to the marketplace" but, equally, to maintain Ford as UK market leader after a fall in sales to private customers pushed market share down from 17.7% to 16.7% in a year.

Rover

Rover R45 5-door 1.8 IXS: from £15,495 to £13,795, saving £1,700.

Price cuts of initial 10% in June brought in ostensibly to offer value for money. But triggered by dramatic decline in sales after a heady month in April, the first few weeks after BMW said it would sell the loss-making group. Market share had slumped to below 4%.

Jaguar

Jaguar S-Type 3.0l V6: from £28,300 to £26,700, saving £1,600.

Average price-cuts of 8.5% introduced to maintain the Ford-owned company's position in the luxury car sector against growing competition.

BMW

BMW 5-series M5: from £59,995 to £52,000, saving £7,995.

Cuts of up to 16.9% triggered by growing public expectation that prices were bound to come down and consumers hesitating to go into showrooms.

Mercedes

Mercedes A-Class 140 Classic: from £14,490 to £12,790, saving £1,700.

Price cuts of up to 20%, including the first Mercedes to sell for less than £13,000. Triggered by inexorable rise in pound's value to a peak of DM3.44 in May.

webTitle: Ariel Sharon: the bloodstained past that inflames Palestinians

fields.headline: Ariel Sharon: the bloodstained past that inflames Palestinians
fields.standfirst:
'Super hawk' blamed for sparking battles after visit to holy shrine
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: When Ariel Sharon, the bulldozer of Israeli politics, marched up to the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem last Thursday accompanied by hundreds of riot police, he was - as he put it - merely exercising the right of every Jew to visit the holiest site in Judaism.
fields.body:
When Ariel Sharon, the bulldozer of Israeli politics, marched up to the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem last Thursday accompanied by hundreds of riot police, he was - as he put it - merely exercising the right of every Jew to visit the holiest site in Judaism.

But was it a pilgrimage or a provocation? Yesterday, governments around the world appeared to have little doubt as they heaped condemnation on Israel's hardline opposition leader.

The 45 minutes that the former army general - described in an Israeli newspaper as a "connoisseur of non-kosher foods" - spent exercising his religious rights sparked five days of bloody violence in which scores of people, mostly Palestinians, have died.

Mr Sharon's dramatic gesture appears to have been calculated to embarrass Mr Barak and to reinforce his own position as leader of the Likud party in the face of a likely challenge from the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu.

Mr Netanyahu's path to a political comeback was cleared last Wednesday when the Israeli attorney general decided not to prosecute him for alleged corruption.

Mr Sharon claimed on television that his visit was meant to demonstrate that no Israeli needs ask for permission to visit sovereign Israeli territory. But Israeli governments - including those in which Mr Sharon served - have always been conscious of the sensitivity of the site and have tried to keep Jewish extremists away.

One theory advanced by a western diplomatic source yesterday was that Mr Sharon may have expected Israeli security forces to turn him away from the site - which would have allowed him to accuse Mr Barak of surrendering sovereignty over the area.

Besides infuriating Palestinians, Mr Sharon's visit appears to have caused offence to pious Jews. An article in Ha'aretz newspaper yesterday accused him of desecrating the holy site by visiting it without taking a ritual bath beforehand or changing into non-leather shoes.

Mr Sharon yesterday insisted: "It was not my visit to the Temple Mount that ignited the disturbances." He said the riots were "part of an overall campaign planned in advance", which had begun about 10 days ago near Gaza, and had spread to Jerusalem.

Several Israeli officials have lent their support to this claim, suggesting that some of the Palestinians - with or without the connivance of their leaders - were looking for an opportunity to cause trouble, and that Mr Sharon provided it.

"Sharon was (in the best case) not the cause of the disturbances but rather a pretext for them," an article in Ha'aretz newspaper said yesterday. "Instead of lighting the fire, he gave the Palestinians the match. The question remains: Why did he do it?"

As far as the international community was concerned, Mr Sharon deserved and received widespread condemnation. In addition to the criticism levelled by individual countries, France, the current holder of the European presidency, issued a statement on behalf of the EU. "The European Union is very concerned by the continuation of bloody confrontations in Jerusalem and in the territories and dismayed by the number of victims," it said. The European Union urges all those responsible on both sides to take all necessary measures to stop the violence and avoid new provocations."

Meanwhile, the Palestinian observer at the UN protested to the organisation about Mr Sharon's visit and called for the withdrawal of Israeli troops from east Jerusalem and the vicinity of all Palestinian cities.

Mr Sharon is regarded by some Israelis as a hero and by others as a super hawk. Almost anything he says or does is liable to inflame Palestinian feelings because of his bloodstained past.

In 1953 he founded and led the notorious "Unit 101" commando unit which carried out retaliatory raids against Arab "infiltrators". In one infamous instance, 69 civilians (most of them women and children) were killed by accident in Qibya, a Jordanian village.

webTitle: 'Bold' city agenda not costed, Hague admits

fields.headline: 'Bold' city agenda not costed, Hague admits
fields.standfirst:
Tories plan new private sector led regeneration companies to tear down tower blocks, build schools and reclaim derelict sites
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Conservative plans to turn the tide in favour of England's cities by creating new private sector led regeneration companies to tear down tower blocks, build new schools, and reclaim derelict sites, have yet to be costed, William Hague admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Conservative plans to turn the tide in favour of England's cities by creating new private sector led regeneration companies to tear down tower blocks, build new schools, and reclaim derelict sites, have yet to be costed, William Hague admitted yesterday.

Unveiled at the start of the 2000 Tory conference yesterday as a sign of a "bold new social agenda", they appeared to urban analysts to be a mix of current government initiatives and old programmes which have been widely criticised as often wasteful and ineffective.

Among Mr Hague's plans are fresh curbs on greenfield sites in the crowded south-east and fast-track planning permission for "brownfield" urban sites in the midlands and north, plus a host of incentives to make decayed inner cities more attractive to ambitious people now heading south.

Communities will be able to bring in extra police - paid for from their regeneration budget - and neighbours will be able to trigger the anti-social behaviour orders which Labour introduced against so-called families from hell. The deterrent will result in fewer evictions, not more, Mr Hague predicted.

Flanked by senior members of his team the opposition leader promised that a future Tory government would appoint a special regeneration minister, possibly of cabinet rank, to cut through red tape and ensure speedy action across areas from planning, to crime and education.

Challenged at his press conference to say where his overall vision of urban renewal differs from the public/private partnership approach of John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, Mr Hague insisted that Labour had "waffled" about partnership and cross-departmental "joined-up government" in Whitehall, but had not achieved much.

His environment spokesman, Archie Norman, said that in three years poverty and crime were up, as were homeless and other indices of urban decay. Even spending on inner city regeneration was down, said the former Asda chief whose revival of the supermarket chain took him into inner city politics.

Also drawing heavily on some urban initiatives in the US - but not offering US-style tax breaks - Mr Hague and Ann Widdecombe, the shadowe home secretary, took the populist line of floating "cops in shops", with officers operating from shops in communities to lead the fight against crime and be visible as both a deterrent and an reassurance.

The police will also be urged to use empty property as bases to stop them being used by gangs. "I believe we are ready to be a government because we are ready to govern for all the people and that means tackling the problems of our inner cities," the Tory leader said. He told his news confer ence in Bournemouth: "Millions of people live and bring up children in our inner cities. The cultural life of the nation beats to a distinctly urban rhythm ... while it is certainly true that many city centres have enjoyed a renaissance in recent years, the residential areas that surround them have too often remained places of great deprivation and poverty."

The last 30 years had seen a huge exodus from inner cities as middle-income families moved out to the suburbs, putting enormous pressure on "precious" green belts.

High levels of unemployment, crime, poor schools, drug problems had also taken over too many areas. "These social problems are most evident in the vast concrete tower block estates that scar our urban landscape."

Part of the Tory solution is to create regeneration companies, with a relatively short life-span, which will have powers to buy and sell land, pay grants to developers, and even draw up contracts with local schools, and police, to improve conditions in run-down areas.

Their concept appears similar to 12 English urban devel opment corporations - albeit with wider powers - the last of which was abolished after Labour came to power. While devouring hundreds of millions of pounds from the Department of the Environment, they were criticised for often side-steeping social problems and concentrating purely on bricks and mortar. A few were beset by scandals, with the National Audit Office criticising the performance of some.

Labour has created three regeneration companies in Liverpool, East Manchester, and Sheffield with more likely to be outlined in an white paper.

fields.headline: Major's appeal to Tories
fields.standfirst:
Former PM makes case for 'one nation' policies with call to remember those in slums

Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: John Major last night rebuked William Hague for lurching to the right when he warned that the Tories are failing to appeal to voters "outside the circle of rising prosperity".
fields.body:
John Major last night rebuked William Hague for lurching to the right when he warned that the Tories are failing to appeal to voters "outside the circle of rising prosperity".

In his first conference speech since leaving Downing Street, the former prime minister flew the flag for the Tories' beleaguered "one nation" wing with a powerful appeal to the leadership to recapture the centre ground.

At a fringe meeting organised by Conservative Mainstream, a group set up by Michael Heseltine to oppose the drift to the right, Mr Major went out of his way to praise his successor for reaching out to middle Britain more effectively than any other party.

But the former prime minister pointedly added: "That isn't enough. We must reach out to all. The people in slums, the people in need, the people outside the circle of rising prosperity, the black and brown and yellow Britons who are as much a part of our society as I am. Our policies and our party are as much for them as for anyone else."

His remarks underlined Mr Major's growing frustration with Mr Hague's flirtation with the right over asylum seekers and law and order. Mr Major has told friends that he believes that some of Mr Hague's more provocative pronouncements mark a worrying departure from the "one nation" Toryism he tried to promote in Downing Street.

The former prime minister angrily denied reports over the weekend that he was planning to use his last conference appearance as an MP to criticise Mr Hague.

However, his remarks about "people in slums" was a clear sign of his unease. Mr Major qualified his criticisms by applauding the Tory leadership for its eleventh hour conversion to "one nation" Toryism.

The words "mainstream majority" are the buzzwords of this week's conference in Bournemouth as Mr Hague attempts to appeal to middle of the road voters who were put off by his provocative interventions on asylum seekers and on law and order.

Mr Major made clear that he would examine the new raft of policies carefully to ensure they measure up to his one nation beliefs.

"This week there are a range of inclusive policies to be announced," Mr Major said. "I hope they will prove effective to people in every part of the country and from every background.

"We must not allow ourselves to be falsely labelled by our opponents. We are the party that stands for one nation." Mr Major received a rapturous reception in Bournemouth yesterday as he entered the main conference hall for the opening ceremony, accompanied by his wife Dame Norma.

The Majors were embraced enthusiastically by Mr Hague and his wife Ffion, a year after the Tory leadership attempted to airbrush the former prime minister out of history.

In his speech the notoriously sensitive former prime minister showed that he still bore scars from his premiership.

"Certainly some MPs in our party did us great harm," Mr Major said in a reference to the likes of Neil Hamilton who associated the party with allegations of sleaze.

But he said that it was unfair to "hang individual misdemeanours around the neck of a political party" led by the likes of Douglas Hurd, Michael Heseltine and Ken Clarke. His praise of Mr Clarke, who wastes no time in lambasting Mr Hague's leadership, was seen as a none too subtle hint that the former chancellor should be given a frontline role. Mr Clarke's friends have called for him to be given a shadow cabinet post.

Mr Major also made no mention of the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, who will forever be seen by Mr Major as one of his "bastard" ministers.

Mr Major's criticism of the leadership was echoed by the former transport minister Steve Norris, who said the Tories must do more to appeal to members of ethnic minorities. "None of us would wish to belong to a party which was not there to appeal to everyone equally in our society, whether ther are male or female, rich or poor, black or white, gay or straight," he told a fringe meeting.

fields.headline: Bournemouth diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Believing in Britain, the Tories' rallying cry for the week, marks a determined effort by William Hague to reclaim the union flag from Tony Blair.
fields.body:
 Believing in Britain, the Tories' rallying cry for the week, marks a determined effort by William Hague to reclaim the union flag from Tony Blair. Party apparatchiks only agreed on the slogan to launch Hague's tilt at No 10 after a Central Office row over two alternatives. The first, Ambitious for Britain, was judged too "young man" for Hague by advisers who feared the Tory leader would sound vacuous. The second, Ready to Govern, invited unfavourable com parisons with David Steel's ill-judged advice to Alliance activists in the eighties to return to their constituencies and prepare for government. So the Tories plumped for Believing in Britain and, in an historic bit of dithering, Hague yesterday used the others during interviews.

 How far big business has deserted the Tories is evident from a stroll through Willieville. With 75 stands, the Conservative exhibition area is smaller than that of the Liberal Democrats a fortnight ago, and less than half the size of Labour last week ,with Virgin, Transco and Railtrack among those not bothering to make the Bournemouth pilgrimage. The total would be even more pathetic if it had not been inflated by 13 party sites.

 Euro MP Bill Newton-Dunn has become the man with no name, airbrushed out in true Stalinist style. The Tory whip in Brussels was mysteriously withdrawn last week after he challenged Hague's bid to make 3p on or off a litre of petrol the fundamental dividing line in British politics. Alas a stand for Willieville, listing 36 Conservative Euro MPs, was already built and paid for. Yesterday it contained 35 names and one strip of white paper.

 More on that funky 3D set intended to give a disco edge to a party more at home with tea dances. The backdrop was designed by Michael Lockett who last sprung to public prominence over his role organising the millennium dome's very successful (not) opening night. Sir Humphrey told Jim Hacker in Yes, Minister that if he had a good speech to make it against a plain background and a bad one in front of many shapes to distract the audience.

 This week's diary U-turn competition has opened and closed after the Sun, which two conferences ago portrayed Hague as a dead parrot, yesterday urged readers not to underestimate him.
