fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Privatisation has brought such a cornucopia of benefits to this nation - just think of Virgin Trains, British Nuclear Fuels and Yorkshire Water. Another triumph now follows in their footsteps.
fields.body:
 Privatisation has brought such a cornucopia of benefits to this nation - just think of Virgin Trains, British Nuclear Fuels and Yorkshire Water.

Another triumph now follows in their footsteps. Working Links - a job-search business aimed at the unemployed, owned by accountants Ernst & Young, Manpower and the government's Employment Agency - has told claimants they can't sign off the dole.

Meg Burton was a client of Working Links' "employment zone" in Brighton, when she found herself a part-time job. Bizarrely, her Working Links "adviser" told her she had to stay signed on for the job seekers allowance.

It would be nice to think this is a new, liberal regime, but other forces are involved. Working Links only gets paid its fee by the government when its clients are found a permanent full-time job.

Ian Smith, the manager of Brighton's Working Links, says this is "the standard line of advice" for national insurance reasons.

But Tony Greenstein, secretary of the Brighton Unemployed Centre, says he's never heard anything like it in 20 years. "Usually you have to fight just to convince them you're eligible to sign on," says Tony, "It's an absurdity."

 Prince William will spend his gap year (according to the Daily Telegraph) "working and living with former drug addicts, the long-term unemployed and young people with histories of crime". But how different will that be from his daily life as a member of the British upper class?

 A fascinating conference on neighbourhood renewal is planned for November. Live from London, boasts the leaflet, will be Lord Falconer, and let's hope he's still a cabinet office minister by next month.

As minister responsible for the dome, Lord F is highly qualified to speak on the subjects he's chosen: "Learning from past failures," for example, along with "Getting it right - power in the hands of the many, not the few".

And the conference's title - "People before structures" - is so reminiscent of the dome, with the people in that case being ministers like Charles, putting their careers first.

 Our old friend Peter Hitchens was in highly consistent form in yesterday's Express, eulogising Nelson Mandela (in rebuking Labour for attempting to bask in his glory) as a great man for rebuilding South Africa from "one of the most unpleasant regimes of the 20th century."

One might argue that apartheid was slightly worse than "unpleasant", but still, fine words indeed.

And it really is excellent Peter has been able to change his views so completely from the old nonsense he was happy to spout in the same paper two years ago, when he called Mandela "personally well short of sainthood".

 Yet another candidate for most exciting press release of the year comes fizzing out of the fax, this time from Hampshire county council.

Astonishingly, it reveals a new survey that may rock the foundations of Hampshire to its irreducible core. The survey shows that 80% of visitors to Hampshire's libraries go there to borrow books. Extraordinary.

 This Diary is always happy to plug anything, but in the case of my colleague Alan Travis's excellent book Bound and Gagged - The Secret History of Obscenity there is no need, since the title alone will sell it.

One tale not included is of Jack Straw's secret porn collection in the bowels of the Home Office. Until recently it contained a number of valuable first editions seized as filth, including an early uncut copy of Lady Chatterley's Lover.

The edition had a print run of 1,000, but the other 999 were burned by Scotland Yard. The Home Office says the more valuable books have now been given to the British Library, but I wonder if Jack Straw keeps a close eye on those that remain in the Home Office basement.

fields.headline: Swiss ready to legalise cannabis
fields.trailText: Switzerland is preparing to introduce legislation that effectively would allow the consumption of cannabis, adding to the country's pioneering but controversial record on drugs policy.
fields.body:
Switzerland is preparing to introduce legislation that effectively would allow the consumption of cannabis, adding to the country's pioneering but controversial record on drugs policy.

The Swiss government said it would draw up legislation next year after consultation among local authorities and community associations revealed that there was widespread support for decriminalising cannabis.

"Two-thirds of the organisations consulted said they were in favour of this move," the interior minister, Ruth Dreifuss said yesterday.

But the same groups opposed any such move on hard drugs, and officials ruled out softer laws on possessing or using such substances.

Switzerland has the most liberal approach in Europe towards the treatment of heroin addicts. Since 1998 it has been providing clean needles and allowing the distribution of heroin to addicts under strict medical supervision.

The policy, approved by Swiss voters in 1998 but criticised by international drug enforcement bodies, also involves tougher prevention measures, comprehensive social support for addicts and a police clampdown on heroin users as well as dealers.

As many as 937 addicts were on record as following this heroin regime last December. The federal health authorities said this system had improved the social conditions and overall health of about two-thirds of those treated for two years, and brought their drug habit under control.

Deaths from heroin overdoses have also been declining in recent years, according to official figures, but there has been a surge in the consumption of cocaine and synthetic drugs such as ecstasy.

Swiss police and justice officials have said they fear "drugs tourism" if soft drugs are legalised, especially if the country is out of step with its neighbours.

The new legislation on cannabis is likely to include a minimum age of 16 or 18 years, and reinforced penalties for dealers and anyone who "incites consumption".

But cannabis would, in effect, be put on an equivalent footing to alcohol and cigarettes.

"We also need prevention measures because, quite frankly, we don't want young people to take up cannabis," Suzanne Auer, a spokeswoman for the Swiss interior ministry said.

The Swiss cabinet has not yet decided whether production and sale of cannabis would also be tolerated, but Ms Dreifuss said that if producers respected some restrictions, their activities "could be tolerated even though still punishable by law".

webTitle: Hitman links apartheid regime to massacre

fields.headline: Hitman links apartheid regime to massacre
fields.trailText: One of the apartheid state's most notorious assassins has for the first time linked the former white regime's security forces to a massacre that almost wrecked negotiations to end minority rule
fields.body:
One of the apartheid state's most notorious assassins has for the first time linked the former white regime's security forces to a massacre that almost wrecked negotiations to end minority rule

Ferdi Barnard, a member of two security-force death squads who is serving a life sentence for murder, yesterday told South Africa's truth and reconciliation commission, which is investigating apartheid crimes, that hitmen gave guns to Zulu hostel-dwellers to carry out a series of massacres.

The killings, in townships near Johannesburg, aimed to destabilise the African National Congress during the talks in the early 1990s.

The most notorious massacre was eight years ago, when 39 people were slaughtered in their homes in the middle of the night at Boipatong, south of Johannesburg. Barnard said that a few days before these killings he was told that guns were to be given to Zulus in the local hostel for an attack on the ANC.

When FW de Klerk, then president, visited the massacre scene, he was chased away by thousands of angry residents.

The ANC, which had already put negotiations on hold to protest at the government's complicity in the mounting violence, considered calling off the talks altogether. But that would play into the hands of the killers, it decided, and Boipatong eventually made the ANC more determined to make the negotiations succeed.

Government members from the early 1990s have consistently denied that the security forces had any hand in the massacre, but Barnard's testimony will reinforce the widely held belief in South Africa that a "third force" played a big role in such killings.

He is seeking amnesty for a number of crimes, including the 1989 murder of a prominent academic and human rights activist, David Webster, whom he confesses to killing, and for hanging the foetus of a baboon outside the home of Archbishop Desmond Tutu.

Barnard worked for at least two hit squads, the infamous "civil cooperation bureau" and the army's "directorate of covert collections".

Yesterday he also told the commission that the apartheid army had recruited criminals to disrupt ANC rallies in the run-up to the first free election in 1994.

"These things I personally arranged. These were paid out of state funds," he said.

During a break in yesterday's testimony, the transport minister, Dullah Omar, shook hands with Barnard, who came close to murdering him in 1989. The hitman said he hid in Mr Omar's garage with a gun, but the anti-apartheid activist came home with his wife and Barnard fled.

"I knew I was going to be responsible for Omar's death. I had no doubt," he told the commission.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Carnage at Sri Lanka rally
fields.body:
Carnage at Sri Lanka rally

A suspected Tamil suicide bomber killed at least 19 people at an election rally yesterday for the ruling People's Alliance in eastern Sri Lanka.

Among those reported killed at Muttur, 150 miles (240km) east of Colombo, was the party's candidate for the October 10 parliamentary elections, Mohommed Bayatullah, a retired police intelligence officer who narrowly escaped assassination by the Tamil Tiger rebels four years ago.

Reuters, Colombo

Russia to revive Iraq flights

Scheduled air services between Iraq and Russia are to begin in two weeks and Baghdad wants them to use Iranian airspace, Iraq's transport minister, Ahmed Khalil, was reported as saying yesterday by the Iranian news agency Irna.

Tehran said the request would be studied. Earlier in the day Aeroflot said it and Iraqi Airways had agreed to resume a service despite UN sanctions imposed on Iraq for invading Kuwait in 1990, but it gave no date.

Reuters, Tehran

Dario Fo to fight executions

Nobel Prize-winning Italian satirist Dario Fo, author of Accidental Death of An Anarchist, yesterday pledged the proceeds of his new comedy play based on the life of St Francis to anti-death penalty causes "wherever this practice exists, be it in America, China or Japan".

Fo dedicated his fund to Derek Barnabei, an Italian- American executed in Virginia last month for raping and killing a 17-year-old girl he had dated.

AP, Rome

webTitle: French communist chief on trial for slush fund

fields.headline: French communist chief on trial for slush fund
fields.trailText: The French Communist party leader, Robert Hue, and 19 other defendants, including a former senior executive from the water, waste and entertainment giant Vivendi, appeared before a Paris court yesterday charged with running an illegal party slush fund in the early 1990s.
fields.body:
The French Communist party leader, Robert Hue, and 19 other defendants, including a former senior executive from the water, waste and entertainment giant Vivendi, appeared before a Paris court yesterday charged with running an illegal party slush fund in the early 1990s.

The case marks another blow to France's political establishment, shaken last month by allegations that President Jacques Chirac was involved in a kickback operation for his conservative RPR party.

Mr Hue, whose party has 38 MPs in the national assembly and is a member of the ruling coalition, has denied all charges of influence-peddling and insists that the communists have only ever been funded by membership fees, MPs' salaries and sales of lily-of-the-valley on May Day.

"Some people would like to mix up the scandals now under way with the charges against us today," he said. "We will show that the charges against the French Communist party are without foundation."

The prosecution alleges that between 1990 and 1994, after the introduction of legislation that was supposed to end slush funds and kickbacks, a consultancy firm that advised mainly communist-run councils accepted £2m from Compagnie Generale des Eaux (CGE) - as Vivendi was then known - in return for recommending that the company be awarded water supply and waste management contracts.

Magistrates believe the cash then landed in the Communist party's coffers via an internal laundering system involving fake bills for advertisements in the party's daily newspaper l'Humanité.

"It was common practice - every party was up to this kind of thing," said Claude Poperin, a former communist militant. "Hue has to tell the truth about this."

Another former party official, Claude Llabres, said he could "bear witness that it was always a lot easier to cream a few per cent off the top of a contract over a lunch of foie gras and Sauternes with a businessman than it was to stand outside the factory gates with recruiting pamphlets".

CGE, renamed Vivendi two years ago, is one of France's most successful conglomerates. Best known for its recent mega-merger with the French pay-TV channel Canal Plus and the US entertainment giant Universal, it also runs 20% of Britain's rail network through Connex.

In the dock alongside Mr Hue were Pierre Sotura, the party's treasurer, and Jérome Deschamps, CGE's former deputy managing director.

webTitle: Pret a Manger takes a bite at the Big Apple

fields.headline: Pret a Manger takes a bite at the Big Apple
fields.standfirst: Cheese and pickle offensive aims for a taste of victory where other British chains have failed
fields.trailText: Lurking in the shadow of the New York Stock Exchange, Pret a Manger's first American store attracts curious glances. The locals are unused to pre-wrapped sandwiches; and a store that sells cheese and pickle rather than pastrami and rye is a distinct oddity.
fields.body:
Lurking in the shadow of the New York Stock Exchange, Pret a Manger's first American store attracts curious glances. The locals are unused to pre-wrapped sandwiches; and a store that sells cheese and pickle rather than pastrami and rye is a distinct oddity.

Pret a Manger is playing a dangerous game. The successful 14-year-old chain has won over the British palate and is planning to tackle the richest market of all - the United States.

If it is successful, Pret will be almost unique. America is a graveyard for British food outlets - Belgo and Pizza Express are the latest to scale back their ambitions after a lukewarm reception from the locals. So why is it so tough to serve food across the Atlantic? They like our beer, our films and our music - why not our food?

Rob Clewley, director of planning for Whitbread's restaurants, says it is all to do with perceptions of brands: "In the UK, branded restaurants are only 25 years old. In the US, they push back 50 years."

Many of America's chains are so established in the country's consciousness that the chances of an upstart foreign company nudging its way in are slim. Clewley says: "They've got brands in everything from fast food up to fine dining. America, of course, is the home of the international branded pizza."

Britain's modest chains are like lambs to the slaughter when pitted against mighty marketing supremos such as Starbucks, Dunkin Donuts and McDonald's.

Whitbread invested in a chain of steak and seafood restaurants in the north-western states of the US in 1985. The company sold up 10 years later, deciding that there were easier ways of making money.

The company is in no hurry to export chains such as Café Rouge and Beefeater. Clewley says: "If we ever went back to the US, it would probably be by buying a US branded operation."

Andy Bassadone, chief executive of Belgo, says: "Going overseas is fine but if you have a problem, it's much further afield." After a successful roll-out in Britain, Belgo tried its mussels and beer format in New York two years ago. Things did not go to plan - the outlet lost £400,000 in its first year.

Pizza Express had little more luck. It has opened restaurants this year in Washington and Philadelphia, under the name San Marzano. The company's promotional material raved that Georgetown, Washington, was an ideal location for the "sophisticated Pizza Express experience" with a customer base of "students, businessmen, politicians and other colourful characters in this political hotspot".

Aggressive market

The reality has not been as great as the potential. Chief executive David Page admitted earlier this month that the company had found the US market "terribly aggressive" and that it planned to concentrate its international expansion elsewhere. Ironically, the company has had more luck selling its pizzas in Japan than in America.

So is Pret a Manger on a hiding to nothing? Co-founder Sinclair Beecham, who has moved to New York to oversee the chain's new offshoot, says: "When I looked at this market, I started from the premise that as far as I can work out, everyone's failed here."

He insists, however, that Pret will be different. His presence in New York emphasises the fact that the privately owned company is keen to keep a close eye on the nitty gritty of operations. The company has brought staff over from British outlets, rather than using locals who are unfamiliar with the format.

Beecham says: "We started very, very cautiously. A lot of people who try to move from one market to another employ local managers and people with medium skills. We've sent one of the founders of the business over - me."

After two and a half months, the store is serving between 5,000 and 6,000 customers a week and is clocking up takings of "close to the average branch in the UK".

Beecham has begun looking for new sites. He says: "We've got 75 branches in central London. If the market's the same, we could undoubtedly build 75 or more in New York. But I don't want to prejudge the opportunity."


Spreading the word on a paper bag

"I think it's great", says Doug, 53, who describes himself as the president of a software company. "You can tell it's fresh, well prepared and good quality, and not at a price."

Doug is clutching a sandwich outside Pret a Manger's cafe in Broad Street, New York. He reckons the chain will be a hit: "It'll take off in major cities. The good thing about it is the waiting time is so low - everything's pre-prepared."

Pret a Manger's opening in July was greeted with scepticism from British newspapers. Some said New Yorkers would never buy a pre-prepared sandwich - they wanted to see them made up.

Pret has made no concessions to transatlantic cultural variations. The outlet is identical to a British Pret a Manger, heavy on the chrome and with uncomfortable stools.

The most popular sandwiches are the same - super club and egg mayonnaise. At 2pm on a weekday afternoon, Pret is quiet but the few customers around are enthusiastic.

A 28-year old female lawyer, who declines to give her name, says: "It's easy and the service is quick. I've seen lots of people in my office with their bags."

Whitbread invested in a chain of steak and seafood restaurants in the north-western states of the US in 1985. The company sold up 10 years later, deciding that there were easier ways of making money. The company is in no hurry to export chains such as Café Rouge and Beefeater. Clewley says: "If we ever went back to the US, it would probably be by buying a US branded operation." Andy Bassadone, chief executive of Belgo, says: "Going overseas is fine but if you have a problem, it's much further afield." After a successful roll-out in Britain, Belgo tried its mussels and beer format in New York two years ago. Things did not go to plan - the outlet lost £400,000 in its first year. Pizza Express had little more luck. It has opened restaurants this year in Washington and Philadelphia, under the name San Marzano. The company's promotional material raved that Georgetown, Washington, was an ideal location for the "sophisticated Pizza Express experience" with a customer base of "students, businessmen, politicians and other colourful characters in this political hotspot". Aggressive market The reality has not been as great as the potential. Chief executive David Page admitted earlier this month that the company had found the US market "terribly aggressive" and that it planned to concentrate its international expansion elsewhere. Ironically, the company has had more luck selling its pizzas in Japan than in America. So is Pret a Manger on a hiding to nothing? Co-founder Sinclair Beecham, who has moved to New York to oversee the chain's new offshoot, says: "When I looked at this market, I started from the premise that as far as I can work out, everyone's failed here." He insists, however, that Pret will be different. His presence in New York emphasises the fact that the privately owned company is keen to keep a close eye on the nitty gritty of operations. The company has brought staff over from British outlets, rather than using locals who are unfamiliar with the format. Beecham says: "We started very, very cautiously. A lot of people who try to move from one market to another employ local managers and people with medium skills. We've sent one of the founders of the business over - me." After two and a half months, the store is serving between 5,000 and 6,000 customers a week and is clocking up takings of "close to the average branch in the UK". Beecham has begun looking for new sites. He says: "We've got 75 branches in central London. If the market's the same, we could undoubtedly build 75 or more in New York. But I don't want to prejudge the opportunity." Spreading the word on a paper bag "I think it's great", says Doug, 53, who describes himself as the president of a software company. "You can tell it's fresh, well prepared and good quality, and not at a price." Doug is clutching a sandwich outside Pret a Manger's cafe in Broad Street, New York. He reckons the chain will be a hit: "It'll take off in major cities. The good thing about it is the waiting time is so low - everything's pre-prepared." Pret a Manger's opening in July was greeted with scepticism from British newspapers. Some said New Yorkers would never buy a pre-prepared sandwich - they wanted to see them made up. Pret has made no concessions to transatlantic cultural variations. The outlet is identical to a British Pret a Manger, heavy on the chrome and with uncomfortable stools. The most popular sandwiches are the same - super club and egg mayonnaise. At 2pm on a weekday afternoon, Pret is quiet but the few customers around are enthusiastic. A 28-year old female lawyer, who declines to give her name, says: "It's easy and the service is quick. I've seen lots of people in my office with their bags."

fields.headline: Drugs firms drag down FTSE
fields.trailText: Last-minute sales of drugs and telecoms stocks robbed the FTSE 100 of a positive start to fourth-quarter trading yesterday. The benchmark index had been slightly ahead for most of the day but any gains were wiped out by the closing price auctions.
fields.body:
Last-minute sales of drugs and telecoms stocks robbed the FTSE 100 of a positive start to fourth-quarter trading yesterday. The benchmark index had been slightly ahead for most of the day but any gains were wiped out by the closing price auctions.

AstraZeneca and Glaxo Wellcome were to blame for a combined 13 point loss as the session ended 9.7 points down at 6,384.5.

It was a disappointing end to a day which had shown signs that the market was prepared to look past the recent raft of profit warnings and high oil prices.

The initial hours of trading had seen computer-related stocks flying high, along with those in the oil, telecoms and banking sectors. Volume was at a fairly brisk 1.3bn as the session drew to a close.

Software company CMG, one of the day's early chargers, maintained momentum to storm up 106p to £14.15 at last night's close. Rival Logica also enjoyed a 5% rise to take it up 110p at £23.35.

Shares in Israeli technology firm, GEO Interactive, climbed 87.5p to £13.10 after signing a deal with Lucent Technologies, the world's largest telecoms maker, to sell enhanced video services.

BP Amoco and Shell were both lifted on the back of fresh tensions between Iraq and Kuwait. The oil companies rose 3p to 605p and 6p to 557p respectively.

Trading in the shares of the leading supermarket chains was also mixed ahead of a competition commission report on the industry.

Tesco, which announced a raft of price cuts totalling £55m, fell 4.5p to 244p, while rival J Sainsbury saw 0.25p shaved off its stock price to end the day at 372.75p.

Banks also had an unstable time. Barclays, which hit highs of £19.11 during the day, fell victim to profit taking and slipped 24p to £18.48. Lloyds TSB, however, proved it was still in favour with a 6p rise to 637p.

After being beaten by Premier League rivals Arsenal in Sunday's match, Manchester United revealed it had been having a rough ride in the boardroom.

The club announced a 25% profits slide because of soaring player costs, the controversial decision not to compete in last year's FA Cup competition and an early exit from the European Cup.

Adding to the disappointment, the widely-expected £300m kit deal with Nike was not confirmed, although an announcement is expected soon. As a result, the stock sank 8.75p to 267.25p.

Menswear retailer Moss Bros added to the gloom after announcing it had suffered from the fashion for dressing down at work. It reported a £4.2m first half loss - excluding the £12m restructuring costs - and suspended its dividend payout. Shares were down 5.5p at 25.5p, a drop of 17.7%, as a result.

Also reporting was HIT Entertainment, a children's character rights owner, which had a 17.5p rise to 452.5p after reporting strong growth.

On the downside, Marconi was a stock having a poor day, shedding 20p to 905p despite announcing a two year contract with Telecom Italia, worth £140m.

And construction group Boustead saw its shares suspended at 7.5p because of a delay in its annual report.

BT enjoyed a 15.5p rise after a day spent continuing to quash rumours that its chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, will step down a year early.

The stock price sunk to 703p at one stage, its lowest for two years, before it recovered to close at 726.5p.

Ongoing speculation over the future of Perpetual lifted the fund management group 212.5p to £41.00. Weekend reports had suggested that CGNU, Britain's biggest insurance group, was in advanced talks over a £1.3bn bid. CGNU was said to have made an informal approach in the past month.

Elsewhere, the techMARK 100 added 1.3% to end at 3,782 points, while the FTSE 250 gained 21 points to 6,698. Wall Street's Dow Jones industrial index was 58 points higher as London closed.

webTitle: Business: Smart cars drive the Paris catwalk

fields.headline: Smart cars drive the Paris catwalk
fields.standfirst: Onboard systems, from navigation to mechanical diagnostics, are this year's motoring haute couture
fields.trailText: This week the world's motor industry is strutting its stuff in Paris. For car buffs there is the usual mixture of the quirky and the workaday. Designers' dreams are parked alongside production directors' realities. Mondeo man can imagine climbing behind the wheel of the latest customised Ferrari.
fields.body:
This week the world's motor industry is strutting its stuff in Paris. For car buffs there is the usual mixture of the quirky and the workaday. Designers' dreams are parked alongside production directors' realities. Mondeo man can imagine climbing behind the wheel of the latest customised Ferrari.

The show, Mondial de l'Automobile 2000, is not just about prices and performance, style and safety, however. Despite the launch of the new Mini, the hot news has more to do with developments in mobile phones than brakehorse power or fuel consumption.

For one of the eight halls at the exhibition centre at Porte Versailles is entirely dedicated to the interaction of the car with the new information and communication technologies.

According to the organiser, Cyberh@all, this is the first time a motor show has set aside an entire hall to the new information and communication technologies.

True enough, some of the exhibition stands offer little more than sophisticated computer games or online services with automotive industry related content.

Others, however, portray a vision - rapidly becoming a reality in some cases - of how the capability to transmit information to and from cars through the internet can be exploited as the automotive industry catches on to the fast expanding potential of the mobile telephone.

Peugeot, Citroen and Vivendi, for example, chose the show to unwrap their Wappi! portal. Although many systems concentrate on im porting information into the car via the internet, Wappi! goes the other way.

Drivers speeding down the motorway wondering what the funny clunking noise in their car is will be able to find out via the Wappi! portal. It will offer the option of onboard diagnosis or allow an approved to check out remotely what is happening.

Handily, the same system can be used to immobilise stolen vehicles- which could cause a few surprises for future generations of joyriders. The Peugeot 607 will be the first car to carry the security system but the manufacturer is hoping to offer it on most other models by 2002.

In-car services on show include on-board navigation systems with both visual display and audio systems as well as video systems installed in the back of the front seat headrests which, like some airline systems, can be used to show films. Online games and internet surfing options are on the way. But perhaps the most intriguing exhibit is Siemens' Automotive "concept cockpit". As the driver approaches, the vehicle's onboard system recognises a special card and automatically unlocks the doors. Activiating a small finger-print recognition panel allows both the driver's seat and the steering wheel to be switched to pre-programmed preferred positions.

Forget instrument dials: be hind the steering wheel is a panel on which the information found on the conventional dashboard can be flashed up.

Drivers can use the mobile phone system by tracing the numbers they want on a pad in the centre of the steering column. Another screen, positioned where most cars at present have the radio, flashes up incoming emails. The passenger glove compartment opens to reveal a computer keyboard while the dashboard houses a tiny camera which allows video conferencing.

At this point one can be forgiven for recalling a short but pointed poem which runs something like: "Beneath this slab John Brown is stowed. He watched the ads and not the road." But not to worry, apparently. According to Siemens, most of the automated services likely to be on offer are linked to the car's central braking system as well as the internet and so will not function unless the car is stationary.

Given the propensity of some drivers for hands-free motoring - free of the steering wheel, that is - such precautions are hardly over the top.

webTitle: BBC's Casualty to screen gay wedding

fields.headline: BBC's Casualty to screen gay wedding
fields.trailText: 8am: The BBC is to screen the first gay wedding on UK television this month, in a special double bill of Casualty, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The BBC is to screen the first gay wedding on UK television this month, in a special double bill of Casualty.

The move reflects the new, racier image of the long-running hospital drama. Inspired by the success of ER on Channel 4, the BBC has in recent years introduced elements of the US show into Casualty, including dramatic scenes in the operating theatre and an increased focus on inter-staff relationships.

The gay wedding episode is scheduled for broadcast on a Sunday, a move that is likely to attract criticism from religious groups. The depiction of homosexuality on TV continues to prove controversial - last year Britain's first gay drama, Queer as Folk, received more complaints than any other television programme.

The double episode will be shown on October 14 and 15. The first programme will show a local newspaper revealing that Adam, a gay male nurse at Holby City Hospital, is HIV positive. On the advice of his dancer boyfriend Reuben, Adam agrees to talk to the press, but this only makes matters worse. In distress, he tells Reuben he wants to cool off their relationship and cancels their planned wedding.

But in the second episode Adam realises he has made a mistake and the wedding goes ahead. The two characters will leave the show after the wedding.

While Casualty continues to enjoy ratings success, BBC1's drama output as a whole has suffered in the face of competition from ITV. The new controller of BBC1, Lorraine Heggessey, has pledged to improve the channel's drama output, beefing up the drama department and investing in the development of new drama series.

fields.headline: Blackadder special proves top draw for Sky
fields.trailText: 8amSky One's cunning plan to broadcast the TV premier of the first new instalment of comedy classic Blackadder for 11 years paid ratings dividends on Sunday night. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sky One's cunning plan to broadcast the TV premier of the first new instalment of comedy classic Blackadder for 11 years paid ratings dividends on Sunday night.

Blackadder Back and Forth, a 45-minute one-off special made by Tiger Aspect Productions that has been showing in the Millennium Dome, drew an average audience of 1.4m and a 14% share in multi-channel homes on Sky One on Sunday from 9pm.

fields.headline: Royal Liver reviews ad arrangements
fields.trailText: 8am: Royal Liver Assurance is reviewing its advertising and media accounts, Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
Royal Liver Assurance is reviewing its advertising and media accounts as it prepares to increase its marketing spend.

The company is understood to have approached a number of London agencies about the account, which will be worth around £6m. Publicis, the incumbent on the creative account, will repitch for the business. Media is with Optimedia.

A source at one of the pitching agencies said: "Royal Liver stands out from the competition in its approach to marketing and advertising. Everyone else has been going for shareholder value but it wants to make a benefit out of being a friendly, mutual society."

Publicis has held the account for four years, taking Royal Liver on to TV for the first time in the late 1990's. A series of ads currently on TV feature people going about their everyday jobs with the tagline: "Lean on the Liver".

A decision is expected by the end of the month.
